title: Mexico City
description: To the Editor: Having lived in Mexico City for three and a half years, I strongly disagree with a comment by Tim Weiner: ''It is difficult to get a bad meal in a city with some of the world's best and cheapest street food and too many restaurants to count.''

title: Verniero, by His Testimony, Soiled Himself and the Court
description: Peter Verniero could have gone back to Morristown to golf and spend clients' money, a moderately big deal still addressed as ''general'' by the occasional lawyer or waiter.

title: I'm Born (Phew!)
description: Isuppose if we're going to start at the beginning, we should start right at the beginning with the stuff I can't remember. Like my birth. To be honest, the story of my birth is a bit traumatic and definitely not much fun, so I'm going to pass you over to my mum, whose name, by the way, is Maria. She can give you all the gory details.

title: Business Diary: Keyless in Seattle: Alarm Mystery Unsolved
description: Car alarms have been known to go off en masse in an earthquake, and Seattle has certainly had its share of earthquakes recently. But there was no apparent reason for the spate of Seattle car alarms that sounded a few weeks ago. The only clue to the mystery was that all the cars in question had keyless entry systems.

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column on March 18, about the Edgar Allan Poe cottage in the Bronx, referred erroneously to the setting of a Poe short story, ''The Cask of Amontillado.'' The story does not disclose where the victim was bricked behind a wall; it was not Paris.

title: Coming to Life
description: IN her lifetime, BeA Haverbusch created more than 300 paintings, moving from hobbyist and casual amusement to become a serious practitioner of art. A new exhibit, ''Artistic Salvation: Lifework of BeA Haverbusch,'' displayed at two local galleries, chronicles how her work and her life were changed by her struggle with breast cancer.

title: Sampling Seasonal Delicacies, At Reasonable Prices, in Osaka
description: JUST as many Americans shuttle along the northeastern corridor of the United States, many Japanese commute between Tokyo and Osaka. Business traffic in and out of Osaka, domestic and foreign, has risen sharply in the past decade -- contributing, perhaps, to the increase in fine dining spots there.

title: Ruland Deal With Iona Is Not Done
description: Jeff Ruland, who recently vowed to remain the coach at Iona, his alma mater, instead of pursuing a position at a bigger school, may soon be in contention for the Seton Hall job.

title: A Choreographer Who Can Make Dreams Dance
description: I WAS 6 or 7 years old in Ottawa,'' Julia Adam recalled, ''and for an end-of-the-year school program I recited a poem about a black cat. I told the teacher I thought it would be a great idea if everyone stood in a circle and I was the cat.'' Watching the performance, her mother, a former ballet dancer, wept happy tears as she recognized her daughter's creative spirit.

title: When Hispanics Think of Race, A Nuanced Palette Comes Into Play
description: ''I don't know,'' said Tony Felix, who owns a shoe store in Washington Heights. ''I'm not black, but I'm not white either. People in the Dominican Republic say they are dark.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If God does keep books, I hope he keeps books on what I'm doing now.''

title: In a Crisis, Vegetables, Not Beef, For British
description: The love of red meat was once so much a part of the national makeup of the English that the French called them ''les rosbifs.'' The 18th-century painter William Hogarth titled a famous canvas portraying the quintessential robustness of his countrymen ''O the Roast Beef of Old England.''

title: Model Students, Business Models
description: To the Editor:

title: Juiced
description: Lick Creek

title: Corrections
description: The Correspondent's Report column on March 18, about travel restrictions in Britain caused by foot-and-mouth disease, gave an incomplete Web address for the Ramblers Association, an organization with a Web site that lists restrictions on hiking. It is www.ramblers.org.uk, not www.ramblers .org.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LISKIN, ELLIOT
description: LISKIN-Elliot. April 5. On his birthday and everyday...the loving memories linger on. Children, Grandchildren & Joyce

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about effects of the economic downturn on San Francisco misspelled the surname of a real estate broker who commented on changes in the market. She was B. J. Droubi, not Droubie.

title: Reality and Its Discontents in a Photographic Age
description: PHILOSOPHERS worry about the nature of reality. Plato posited a cave and shadows. Bishop Berkeley contended that no object existed apart from the mind, to which Dr. Johnson responded by ''striking his foot with mighty force against a large stone,'' and saying of Berkeley's proposition, ''I refute it thus.'' Most people who do not ponder the conundrums of existence for a living have been in Dr. Johnson's corner, rather blithely assuming that reality simply is, that stones are hard and water wet and that it isn't just our imaginations that tell us so.

title: Karen Palmer and Stephen McCain
description: HOMES for boys have a dark reputation going back to ''Oliver Twist'': images of children processed through years of loneliness, neglect and bitter pain. So when men like Stephen Alexander McCain, an associate producer for ''48 Hours'' on CBS, emerge out of the foster-care system whole and even thriving, it bends the clich into new shapes.

title: Article 2001040191931695731 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: The Evolving Presidency; A Bow to Political Realities
description: For the first nine weeks of George W. Bush's presidency, millions of Americans seemed to be experiencing agenda shock -- the political equivalent of sticker shock. They simply did not believe he was that conservative. Nor had they perceived him as so hostile to the government's role in conservation and workplace regulation or so determined to turn key agencies over to administrators hostile to their basic missions. Mr. Bush's response to questions and complaints had one theme. He was a leader who did not take his signal from the polls, but simply did what he thought was right for America.

title: Testing Your Metal: Guide to the Meltdown
description: WASHING up on the gritty shores of Asbury Park this week are Flotsam and Jetsam, Opeth, Primal Fear, Raven, Fleshgrind, Pig Destroyer, Napalm Death, Drill 187 and more than 100 other bands in the third annual Metal Meltdown festival. As in previous years, the groups come from all around the nation as well as Canada, England and Sweden. They thrive in fairly obscure subgenres of the metal underground. Some bands have intensely violent lyrics and would be more controversial if they were to receive mainstream attention.

title: Article 2001040190836336964 -- No Title
description: By MARGARET GOLDSBOROUGH

title: The Sound Of New Music Is Often Chinese; A New Contingent Of American Composers
description: OF the 10 Academy Award nominations received by Ang Lee's ''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon,'' two went to the composer Tan Dun, for original song (in a collaborative effort) and original score; his score took the Oscar. Mr. Tan is now busy with prestigious commissions from, among others, the New York Philharmonic and the Metropolitan Opera.

title: POSTINGS: A New 180-Bed Residence Hall at Purchase College; 57 Modular Units = 1 Dormitory
description: A new 180-bed dormitory made up of 57 modular units is nearing completion on Purchase College's 500-acre campus in Westchester County. The college said the four-story dormitory is the first steel and concrete modular building to be constructed on any of the 64 campuses of the State University of New York. The last of the modules was put in place two weeks ago and occupancy is scheduled for fall.

title: Paying Off A Loan For a Co-op
description: Q. I am in the process of paying off my mortgage on a co-op in Jamaica, Queens. In addition to paying off the loan and making sure I receive all the papers being held by the bank, what other procedures and responsibilities should be made final at this time? . . . Constance Gardner, Bayside, Queens.

title: Le Shack
description: When you hear the name Le Corbusier, you think of the sleek, white Villa Savoye or the chapel at Ronchamp, France, where the soaring roof seems to hover above massive walls. What you don't think of is a log cabin. A 12-foot-by-12-foot one-room log cabin, no less. But in 1952, on a rocky hillside overlooking the Mediterranean in Roquebrune-Cap-Martin, France, the architect who was one of the godfathers of Modernism built just that -- a tiny retreat, called the Cabanon, to which he escaped as often as he could until his death 13 years later.

title: The Trees That Don't Grow in Brooklyn
description: SECLUDED among loam hills in central Queens, before the advent of urban zoning and brick row houses, sprawled a storied peat bog known locally as Juniper Swamp. The bog, used in the 1920's by the gangster Arnold Rothstein as the site of a phantom village built to dupe potential property buyers, earned a niche in the archives of quirky city history.

title: The Season In a Bottle
description: Georges Duboeuf's 2000 Beaujolais-Villages is bottled springtime.

title: March 25-31; Fears for Kyoto Accord
description: Even as a presidential candidate, George W. Bush made no secret of his disregard for the 1997 Kyoto treaty on climate change. But when Mr. Bush made it clear that his administration would abandon the accord, the response from much of the rest of the world -- whose environment ministers met in Montreal -- was stunned disappointment. The Europeans, Japan and Canada fear that if the treaty is cast aside, it may take years to come up with another approach to what they see as an urgent problem. Douglas Jehl

title: Creatures of the Wild
description: These days, Eliza Thornberry, Nickelodeon's resident Dr. Dolittle, is talking to a few new animals: the endangered kind. As part of Keep the Wild Alive Week, ''The Wild Thornberrys'' will focus on species struggling for survival. The special episodes (tomorrow through Thursday at 8 p.m.), followed by brief segments on animal facts, are part of Nickelodeon's new partnership with the National Wildlife Federation, to which a portion of proceeds from the show's retail products will be donated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSH, BURT
description: MARSH-Burt. Dear Burt-we have been friends for more years than we can remember. We will miss you terribly but are consoled by the memory of all the good times we spent together. Our hearts and thoughts are with Elaine and all the Family. Mickey and Allan

title: A Hill of Riches, Worldly and Spiritual
description: PRESSED to name the world's most visited holy cities, one might think of Mecca or Jerusalem. Rome maybe. But the name Tirupati would hardly roll off the tongue of many people, at least not many outside India.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-1-01: Process; Blow by Blow
description: I directed a film called ''Blow.'' Blow is a code word for cocaine. (As if you didn't know that.) And it's a word I couldn't say in the film's trailer. But let's start from the beginning.

title: Detained in China
description: To the Editor:

title: A Family Restaurant in Bedford Hills
description: OVER the last few years, this restaurant, set back on busy North Bedford Road, has undergone a quick succession of ownerships, at one time or another Bacco, Chuck's Steak House, Bedford Grille, Rockwell's, Spiga and Mitty's. Mystic Grill, the new occupant, may very well be a keeper.

title: Faith-Based Furor
description: The first time Alicia Pedreira heard from co-workers that they had spotted her picture in a photo exhibit at the state fair in Louisville, Ky., she was baffled. ''I thought: Photograph? What photograph?'' Pedreira said recently of the strange sequence of events that began in August 1998 and would soon upend her life. ''I had no idea what they were talking about.''

title: Letters
description: Gregg Easterbrook's essay on why we gripe when times are good prompted some readers to do a double take: Times are good? What about the issues raised in our articles on Claritin (the high cost of drugs) and Harold O. Levy, schools chancellor (problems in public education)?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOEN, MURRAY
description: SCHOEN-Murray, 97. Of New York City, NY, passed away on March 28, 2001. Beloved husband of Ruth for 59 beautiful years. Loving father of Ronni Fitzgerald and Robert, grandfather of Doreen, Sean and Jeremy, great-grandfather of Royden, father-in-law of Brian and Carol. Devoted brotherin-law to Joan Siegel and uncle to Kenneth. He was in the motion picture theatre and real estate business; an officer/director of The Indep. Theatre Owner's Assn, and member of Motion Picture Pioneers of America. His memory will long live on in those who knew him. Memorial services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York City on Sunday, April 1, at 2:30 P.M. Contributions in lieu of flowers can be made to the charity of one's choice.

title: Daunting Question
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLESINGER, SAUL O.
description: SCHLESINGER-Saul O. Age 86. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and friend. Althought we will miss you beyond words, our memories of your love and strength will sustain us.

title: Disc Jockey, 55, Back In His College Booth
description: AS New York radio evolves, one longtime disc jockey, Pete Fornatale, has come full circle. Known primarily for his tenure at WNEW-FM from 1969 through 1989, when it was a groundbreaking progressive rock station, Mr. Fornatale has left big-time commercial radio to return to WFUV, the college station at Fordham University where he held his first job.

title: 2001 BASEBALL PREVIEW
description: This preview was written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in predicted order of finish.

description: To the Editor:

title: Demonstrators Demand Changes In Plan to Expand Con Ed Plant
description: More than 150 community leaders and residents of Manhattan's East Side, some pounding pots and pans and wearing gas masks, protested outside Consolidated Edison's power plant on East 14th Street yesterday and demanded that the utility make the plant environmentally safer before expanding it.

title: James J. McManus, 81, Owner of Celebrated Bar
description: James J. McManus Sr., the proprietor of the Peter McManus Caf, a venerable family-owned bar in the Chelsea section of Manhattan that often doubled as a set for movies and television episodes, died on Monday in Philadelphia. He was 81 and had moved from Manhattan to Brigantine, N.J., not long ago.

title: Ideas & Trends; Two Crises: Cows and Current
description: CUMBRIA and Orange County belong to very different worlds. But the fells of northern Britain and the sprawl of Southern California are now both digesting yet more bad news. In Britain, despite the pyres of burning sheep and cattle, foot-and-mouth disease is now set to jump tenfold. This week Californians discovered the harshest consequence yet of their energy crisis: an immediate rise in electricity prices by as much as 50 percent.

title: For a New Bay Ridge, A New Tony Manero
description: IT was late on a Saturday night, a few minutes shy of midnight, when Maritza Gonzalez strode through the door of Club Rio in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.

title: Hebert Kicks Aside the Devils' Hex Over the Rangers
description: With help from two goals 12 seconds apart early in the second period and with some inspiring goaltending by Guy Hebert, the Rangers ended their streak of 23 regular-season games without a victory against the Devils with a 4-3 triumph today at Continental Arena.

title: Ideas & Trends: Women Lawyers; Justice Is Blind. Also, a Lady.
description: THE law is one of the last bastions of classically high-testosterone behavior, not far behind pro football. Firms and clients hire lawyers to win. That's all that matters.

title: Founder Describes Origins Of Fessenden House
description: To the Editor:

title: Word for Word/Bushspeak; The President's Sense of Humor Has Also Been Misunderestimated
description: HOW do you rib a man for his failings and foibles if he spends much of his time ribbing himself? That is a question that President Bush and his aides have clearly asked and just as clearly answered, and what they have decided is that there is no armor or inoculation as effective as self-effacement.

title: New Leader Sets Goals For Chamber of Commerce
description: Marsha Gordon took over last week as president of the Westchester County Chamber of Commerce, succeeding Harold E. Vogt, who retired after 30 years leading the chamber.

title: A Nose With An Eye
description: In the 60's, there was Airwick; the 70's brought us incense, the 80's, potpourri. Of late our olfactories have been bombarded by car deodorizers, magazine scent strips and Glade Plug-Ins. Isn't it time professional scenters brought us something a little more, well, natural?

title: Corrections
description: The Long Island Journal column last Sunday, about teaching yoga to children, misspelled the instructor's name. She is Lisa Trivell, not Trevill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARBOLINO, EILEEN MARGARET SNIDER
description: ARBOLINO-Eileen Margaret Snider, wife of Jack. Passed away suddenly on Sunday, March 25, 2001 at her home in Harrington Park, NJ. Mother of Philip Bayer and his wife Phyllis, Jennifer Page, Anne & husband Charles Kruger, John Paul and wife Maija. Sister of Donald Page Snider & wife Penny of Olympia, WA. Aunt of Page, Timothy and David Snider. Grandmother of Jonathan (Jamie), Risa, Lauren, Charlie, Jacob and John. Born in Oregon in 1924, she attended Washington State University and kept a life long passion for the beauty of the Pacific coast and mountains. She moved to NYC to study at Columbia University where she met Jack. With a degree in Art History, Certificate from New York School of Interior Design, Master Gardener, member of Guild for Christian Service at Community Church in Harrington Park, she studied and practiced oil and water painting, displaying locally. She supported many animal protection and wildlife agencies, volunteered and worked briefly at the Pierpont Morgan Library in NY studying art conservation. Her elegance, grace, independent spirit, broad intellect, spirituality, creativeness, artistic talent and rich sense of humor blessed us all. A memorial service in her honor will be held at the Community Church in Harrington Park 2:00PM on Sunday, April 22, 2001. Donations to the Humane Society of the United States or the National Wildlife Federation would be appreciated.

title: March 25-31; Supreme Court to Review Executions of Retarded
description: When it comes to imposing the death penalty on killers who are mentally retarded, the United States is out of step with the rest of the world: only two other countries, Kyrgyzstan and Japan, execute the retarded. Now the Supreme Court will decide whether the practice is out of step with the Constitution. The justices agreed to hear the appeal of Ernest P. McCarver, a retarded inmate on North Carolina's death row. In 1989, the court found no consensus that executing the retarded was ''cruel and unusual,'' but 11 states have since banned it, for a total of 25. Linda Greenhouse

title: The Enchanted Cottage
description: It was a tiny, nothing-special house cowering on a quarter acre in the backyard of a medium-size, nothing-special house on the wrong side of the Long Island Rail Road tracks in East Hampton. Which is to say the wrong side of Route 27, the black-asphalt line that slices through Long Island's tony summer communities, separating the we-spent-$12 million-and-every-shiny-nickel-shows neighborhoods from the ones lined not with privet and Porsches but with what would be called cottages or bungalows if they had a bit more charm and a bit less aluminum siding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSCHILD, KARL
description: ROTHSCHILD-Karl. Passed away Thursday, March 29, 2001 in his 96th year. Beloved husband of the late Wally Rothschild; loved father of Herbert and Marie Rothschild, Bernette and Irwin Bernstein; adored grandfather and greatgrandfather of 14 grandchildren and fifteen great-grandchildren. He lived a long and fulfilled life. He will be missed.

title: Even Adversity Couldn't Stop Douglas's March to Final
description: Last Monday, Katie Douglas scored only 2 points in the first half of Purdue's Mideast Regional final against Xavier. But Douglas did score 17 points in the second half, helping the Boilermakers advance to the Final Four. That was just Katie, most of her teammates thought with reverence, rebounding again.

title: Track Meet to Include Wheelchair Athletes
description: THE winner's trophies at the Loucks Games are some of the gems of the track and field world. A foot and a half high, they are heavy, bronze-colored and carry a stunning depiction of an athlete emerging from flames. Many are still cherished by former high school athletes who have gone on to win Olympic medals.

title: Corrections
description: The article about Claritin referred incorrectly to Dr. Sherwin D. Straus, a medical officer at the Food and Drug Administration in 1987 who reviewed the application for the drug, then known as loratadine. While he indeed developed multiple sclerosis, he did not die; he lives in Maryland, retired on disability.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: EASY SILENCE

title: The Funnier Side of Beethoven
description: Can music be humorous without the help of staging and gesture? Absolutely, says the pianist Alfred Brendel, who plays in recital at the McCarter Theater on Tuesday at 8 p.m. He has chosen as a proving ground ''Variations on a theme of Diabelli,'' Beethoven's last monster piano work. Mr. Brendel said, ''They are the greatest example of music that is predominantly humorous in spite of sublime moments.'' The Austrian-born pianist, musicologist and poet is in the United States for a monthlong concert tour. ''The Diabelli theme is already humorous,'' said Mr. Brendel, 70. ''Beethoven makes fun of that too, taking liberties he never took. Some variations are rather tricky and I make a sour face, although they are not sour in character.'' Leslie Kandell

title: Corrections
description: A credit was omitted in The Times Magazine last Sunday for the picture from the movie ''Rapture,'' with the article about the Iranian filmmaker Shirin Neshat. The photographer was Larry Barns.

title: More People May Not Save House Seats
description: Despite its strong population gains, New York City faces an intense fight to preserve its seats in the House of Representatives as political mapmakers in Albany begin to wrangle over new Congressional boundaries.

title: New Flights Are a Sign Of Confidence in Asia
description: UNITED AIRLINES is declaring its confidence in the Asian travel market today, with an expansion it hopes does not end up looking like an April Fool's joke. United is reinstating its around-the-world service -- which it suspended in spring 1999 because of Asia's financial crisis -- by adding flights from London to New Delhi and New Delhi to Hong Kong.

title: Tourism in 1999 Generated $1.05 Billion
description: Tourism generated $1.05 billion in revenue in Westchester in 1999, the highest amount in six years, according to Margo Jones, director of the County Office of Tourism. Hotel sales in 1999 were $225 million, up 9 percent over the previous year. Figures for 2000, which will be available later this spring, are expected to be even higher.

title: All Rise, Please. Send in the Clowns.
description: GIVE yourself a title with ''supreme'' in it and you invite high expectations. The supreme allied commander had danged well better win the war or he's going to have some explaining to do. (''Um, yes, technically I was the supreme commander, but I guess the guy on the other side was supremer.'') Bananas supreme had better be the best banana-related dessert ever invented, and the Supremes had better be a whole lot more talented than the Chiffons and the Shirelles.

title: Nurturing An English Flame In America
description: IT was late in the afternoon, midway through the fourth week of rehearsal. The cast of Theater for a New Audience's production of Shakespeare's ''Troilus and Cressida'' was working on a disturbing scene. The ill-fated love story of the title characters, set against the backdrop of the Greek siege of Troy, had reached the moment when the young Trojan woman Cressida, torn from Troilus and led to the enemy camp, must run a gantlet of war-weary Greek soldiers.

title: What You See Is Not What You'll Get
description: FROM a balcony on the top floor of a Hollywood hotel, Los Angeles is defined in a vast scrim of lights, winking in the distance. The actor who once called himself Oprah Noodlemantra stabs a hand-rolled cigarette into the corner of his mouth and gazes at the twitching city.

title: Lament Over Loss Of String Quartet
description: To the Editor:

title: Not for Sale? Well, Maybe Not Yet
description: IT was 6 a.m. when the first one arrived. ''Ignore them, they'll go away,'' Jean said to her husband. Bells and banging pierced the Saturday morning silence. At 7 o'clock, she opened the door to a persistent knocker. ''Not until 9 o'clock!'' she declared and slammed the door.

title: Habitats/Brooklyn; Fixing Up A Fixer-Upper
description: When Arturo Swayze rented an apartment in Dyker Heights, he knew it needed work. He did it himself, including a new kitchen counter. By Trish Hall

title: Cole, a Top Mets Prospect, Killed in Driving Accident
description: Brian Cole, a blossoming outfielder who was one of the Mets' top prospects, was killed today while driving from Port St. Lucie, Fla., to his home in Meridian, Miss. He was 22.

title: Vinyl Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Karla Cohen, Daniel Fisher
description: Karla Ann Cohen, a lawyer, and Dr. Daniel Clark Fisher, a cardiologist, were married last evening by Rabbi Joshua Skoff at the Oakwood Club in Cleveland.

title: 'Don't Call Us' List Takes Effect Today
description: More than a million households have signed up for a ''do not call'' registry created under a New York State law that goes into effect today and is intended to spare residents from most unwanted telephone solicitations.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-1-01: The Ethicist; Design Flaw
description: I am an interior designer. When I worked for myself, I registered with a carpet store that offered me a 10 percent commission on any business I referred to it. Now I work for someone who was unaware of this store until I told him about it. Recently, I sent that carpet store a customer who placed a big order. Can I keep the commission or must I split it with my boss? -- S.R., Long Island

title: Santa Fe Performers Get a Second Stage
description: The Santa Fe Opera, with its striking amphitheater and popular summer performances, has given Santa Fe, N.M., a reputation for leadership in the arts. But about the only place in New Mexico's capital where other organizations could perform were school gymnasiums and auditoriums. Helping to fill the gap, on April 20 a former Spanish-style movie house dating from 1931 will be dedicated as the Lensic Performing Arts Center, seating 820 in restored, ornate surroundings.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: March 25-31; Putin Shakeup
description: President Vladimir V. Putin shook up his government, placing his closest confidant, Sergei B. Ivanov, at the Ministry of Defense to undertake a sweeping reform of the military and its sprawl of defense industries. Mr. Putin also put a civilian in charge of the national police force and, most surprising, fired his minister of atomic energy, Yevgeny O. Adamov, who had been advocating the largest expansion of civilian nuclear power since its inception. His successor, Aleksandr Y. Rumyantsev, the director of the institute where the first Soviet A-bomb was designed, is a proponent of nuclear power, but may have more sensitivity than Mr. Adamov to concerns that Russia would turn into the world's largest nuclear waste dump. Patrick E. Tyler

title: Travel Advisory
description: Santa Fe Performers Get a New Stage

title: Cumberland Island
description: To the Editor: Having visited Cumberland Island numerous times, I read Claudia Dreifus's ''Cumberland's Peaceable Kingdom'' (Feb. 25) with interest. I have a different view of the island and its wildlife.

title: When Scouts Were Told to Jump in the Lake, They Did It
description: Camp Glen Gray evokes memories of a time when scouting was more rough and tumble than it is today, as illustrated by excerpts from ''Thirty Years of Scout Camping: History of Glen Gray and other Scout Camps in Northern New Jersey,'' by Luther E. Price, (privately published, 1941):

title: 'The Days Between' on Stage in Croton Falls
description: BY now theatergoers know that the Schoolhouse is not the place to see a play you may have heard of. And even if the playwright is well known, it's likely that the play isn't.

title: A Library First Requested in 1938 Finally Swims Into Sight
description: Mariners Harbor residents first requested a library for their neighborhood the same year that Orson Welles broadcast ''War of the Worlds'' on the radio. That was 1938. Three times in the last two years, the New York Public library came close to buying a site for a new library in the neighborhood, but each time the deal collapsed. As a result, some residents felt that Martians in a spaceship would probably arrive in Mariners Harbor before a library did.

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

description: Some last-minute tax filers get so panicky that they forget to sign their returns or put a stamp on the envelope. But even less-frenzied taxpayers may overlook money-saving opportunities.

title: INVESTING WITH/Richard A. Mayo; The Pelican Fund
description: FINALLY, it seems, value matters.

title: Album Party for Billy Hector
description: Billy Hector, a staple of the shore music scene for two decades, has characterized himself as a workingman's musician who keeps the music alive for club patrons. The innovative cross between the blues that first drew him to music and the rock 'n' roll that influenced his style is captured on his seventh album, ''Duct Tape Life,'' on the independent label Ghetto Surf Music of Spring Lake. Mr. Hector will play at an album release party at Jason's, South Belmar, at 10 p.m. Saturday. Karen DeMasters

description: Focus on O'Neill

title: Reliving the Well-Made Madness of 'Monday Night'
description: IN an abandoned armory here, John Turturro is wearing a terribly obvious black toupee and a canary yellow blazer. Makeup emphasizes the bags under his eyes. He slumps in a chair like an older man.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHAIKIN, SOL CHICK
description: CHAIKIN-Sol Chick. April 1, 1991. Now and forever in our hearts and minds. We lovingly remember your intellect, humor, humility and strength. We follow the precepts and examples you established in life. Eric, Stacey, Lee, Wendy & Shana

title: Changes at Getty Center In Hours and Parking
description: The J. Paul Getty Center in Los Angeles is opening at 10 a.m. on weekdays, an hour earlier than before. And what may be more important for many people, reservations for one of the 1,200 parking spaces -- though still the best way to guarantee entrance to the art museum -- are no longer necessary on weekends or after 4 p.m. on weekdays.

title: Exhaustion, Injuries . . . What Fun!
description: AN annual expedition race since 1995, ''Eco-Challenge'' is not new to television - but the edition that begins tonight is almost certain to be viewed in an all-new light. It is the first time ''Eco-Challenge'' has ever been the show from the man who brought you ''Survivor.''

title: For Every Hill, Another Stairway
description: I AM an urban hiker -- no sidewalkless, flora-cluttered nature trails for me. When I first visited Seattle 16 years ago, I knew I had found my walking city. Ranged on hills between two spacious bodies of water (Lake Washington and Puget Sound), the town is a pedestrian's paradise. Its streets are narrower than those of many other Western cities; and a number of those streets, when confronted with a change in altitude that can't be coped with by car, simply turn into staircases or pathways.

title: GETTING PERSONAL; Close To The Madding Crowd

title: A Week in Centuries Past

The old four-poster beds are enveloped in clouds of white mosquito netting that ripple under the clacking ceiling fans. In a concession to the 21st century, an electric mosquito coil is positioned discreetly in the high-ceilinged sitting room, furnished in dark antique hardwood and cane. It is evening at the 320-year-old New Oriental Hotel, snug within the ramparts of a fort above the harbor at Galle, on the south coast of Sri Lanka.

The main speech, full of passionate calls for respect for diversity, was given by a Mayan known as Commander Esther. The Mexico they strive for, she said, is ''one where being different is not the cause for death, imprisonment, persecution, ridicule, humiliation or racism.'' Ginger Thompson

title: QUICK BITE/Cherry Hill; Hold the Bamboo: Sushi in a Mall
description: When we moved to the small South Jersey town of Haddonfield a dozen years ago, we were amazed that it could support a great little Japanese restaurant. Then we learned that it couldn't. Not long after our move, the owners of Yanagi said they too were moving, to the Cherry Hill Mall a few miles away. Ugh, we thought, what could be worse than mall sushi? But what could be better, if it's made at Yanagi? Set among the pizza and sandwich stands at the food court of New Jersey's first mall, Yanagi does the run of Japanese food, but it outdoes itself in sushi. Yanagi's sushi chefs are speedier than most, as they would have to be in Food Court Land, but their preparations do not suffer for it. I'm partial to the octopus roll with hot and spicy soy dressing ($2.82) and the eel roll ($3.07). My wife, remembering our year-of-much-sushi on the West Coast, is a fan of the avocado-stuffed California roll ($2.82), while my young daughters go for the more traditional salmon ($3.07) or tuna ($2.82). Among the interesting combinations are the L.A. roll ($3.59), of tuna, avocado, cucumber, scallion and hot pepper, and the Garden roll ($3.59), of cucumber, avocado, pickles and Japanese squash. Though we're no wine mavens, we often have our Yanagi sushi with Champagne (which probably proves it) in a candlelit dining room on Saturday nights. It may not be Windows on the World, but somehow Yanagi makes our little corner of suburbia a bit more cosmopolitan. ROBERT STRAUSS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTZMAN, MAX
description: SALTZMAN-Max. 0n February 26, 2001 in Los Angeles, California. Max's health had steadily declined for the last year and he died peacefully during the night. He is survived by his wife Barbara Fish, M.D., his son Mark and two grandchildren. Born on April 17th, 1917 in Brooklyn, NY, Max received his B.S. degree in chemistry from the College of the City of New York in 1936. During World War II, he was in civilian service with the Chemical Warfare Service. Following the war, Max joined the technical staff of Harmon Colors (later a part of Allied Chemical Corporation). From 1945 to 1961 he served in various research & development positions in the field of color pigments and color measurement. From 1961 to 1973 he held several management positions at the corporate headquarters of Allied. He retired as manager of color technology in 1973. He was also an Adjunct Professor for 20 years at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's Color Measurement Laboratory. He was the co-author of the 1966 classic ''Principles of Color Technology'' (2nd Ed. 1981) which was recently updated by R. Berns. The book's philosophy reflected Max's penchant for quality control and common sense. After retirement Max was able to devote his full attentions to his passion for colorants and their history. His interest began during the early 1950 s while at Harmon Colors. He was often consulted on color and colorant issues by New York City museums such as the Museum of Natural History. In 1973, Max moved to Los Angeles and soon established a color laboratory in the Institute of Geophysics and Planetary Physics at the University of California at Los Angeles. Through this new laboratory, he performed research on ancient dyestuffs and the applications of color technology to art conservation science. A Fellow of the American Institute for Conservation of Historic and Artistic Works, he was asked to present the George L. Stout Memorial Lecture in 1984, one of their most prestigious honors. In 1986, he received the Macbeth Award from the Inter-Society Color Council for his pioneering research in dye identification of ancient textiles. The week before his death, the ISCC voted to give him the 2001 Godlove Award for his lifelong contributions to the field of color. He was also a member of the American Chemical Society, the American Association of Textile Chemists and Colorists, the Society of Plastics Engineers, the Optical Society of America, the Society of Dyers and Colourists (U.K.), The Colour Group (Great Britain), the Dry Color Manufacturers Association, the Los Angeles Society for Coatings Technology, and the Federation of Societies for Paint Technology. In 1967, he received the Federation s Armin J. Bruning Award. In Max's memory, a fund has been established to support student research in art conservation science using color technology. Donations to this fund should be made out to Rochester Institute of Technology: Saltzman Fund & sent to Roy Berns, RIT Center for Imaging Science, 54 Lomb Memorial Drive, Rochester, New York 14623-5604.

title: The Hyphen Is Dead; Viva the Asterisk
description: These days nothing is too small to merit a redesign -- even punctuation. Thus, the lowly hyphen has fallen out of favor when used in phone numbers. In invitations, press releases, catalogs or corporate stationery, the hyphen is being replaced with periods, underscores, asterisks or, sometimes, nothing at all. ''People started disowning the hyphen about a year ago,'' said Jane Wagman, founder of Janedesign, a graphic design firm whose clients include 60 Thompson, the SoHo hotel; Liz Lange Maternity; and Sephora. ''First, the hyphen got edged out by dots -- mostly by places that wanted to convey a European feeling, like art galleries.'' She said the trend has recently moved toward underscores (''It's a very Internet influence, used to create a young, high-tech effect.'') And while asterisks and bullets have also been visited, Ms. Wagman noted that ''it becomes too in-your-face.'' Her preference? Nothing at all. ''Leaving blanks keeps the phone number easy to read, but creates a spare, modern line.'' The time and date had better watch out.

But selling is selling, and the word ''Indian'' is considered more likely to pull in traffic.

The queen saved 29,000, roughly $41,500, last year on furnishings for the five royal residences. The queen and her family also scrimped to save 22,000 on electricity and an almost equal savings in phone bills for the fiscal year to March 2000, the most recent figures available.

title: To Some, a Movie Is Just an Outline for a Book
description: THOSE paperback books that retell the plots of current movies in novel form -- they're called novelizations -- seem like a relic of an earlier time, like drive-ins. And, like drive-ins in the 50's, novelizations also had a golden age: in the 70's, paperbacks based on popular movies like ''Jaws 2'' and ''The Omen'' sold in the millions. The numbers have declined for both, but drive-ins and novelizations have somehow survived into the digital age.

title: Heaven
description: I'm thinking of a place where the neighbors' secondhand smoke doesn't seep through the walls. I'm thinking of a place where, when the neighbor above passes out with his bathtub running over, the water rises instead of falls. Where even the relentless terrier owned by the woman downstairs no longer barks and barks and barks and barks. I'm thinking of a place where Babe Paley is floating on a lilac raft in the saltwater pool and Elsa Maxwell is threatening to give a party tonight and the Duchess of Windsor really is a man -- what a scoop! Spencer Tracy and I just saw all of her in the outdoor shower.

The clubs themselves settled here in the 1890's because others disdained the noises and smells of the Civil War-era stables that then dominated the street. Now it appears that the last of the stables are disappearing.

The study does not have figures for individual cities in New Jersey, where several mayors, led by Joseph Vas of Perth Amboy, are considering a class-action lawsuit to force the release of figures that use statistical sampling, which they believe will show their cities have larger populations. title: Churning Out Robust Italian Cuisine
description: NO wonder this place is busy,'' blurted out a first-time visitor at the new Cafe Al Dente in Hicksville after looking at the menu's modest prices and then glancing at an adjacent table and seeing four jumbo bowls of pasta virtually crowding everything else off it. Those oversized soup bowls were piled high with pasta, most of it delivering blunt, big-shouldered flavors. This cozy 44-seat spot, which opened in December at 106 Woodbury Road (516-932-9788), is owned by Philip Morizio, the chef and part owner of Al Dente of Oyster Bay, where prices are slightly higher. At the Hicksville site, a bowl of pasta with a rambunctious marinara sauce, accompanied by an exceptional house salad, cost $10.95 and a sloppy, runny, but tasty, thin-crusted, classica pizza, loaded with lots of cheese and tomato sauce, went for $5.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, JERRY, DPM. DR.
description: MILLER-Jerry, DPM. Dr. Jerry Miller of Boca Raton, FL. Formerly of Jamaica, NY. Died March 29, 2001 at the age of 82. The beloved husband for over sixty years of Jeanette. Father to Andrew and Richard. Father-in-law to Gail and Debbie and loving grandfather to Evan and Jody, Jarrod & Darren. Brother of the late Rose Caplan. A graduate of the New York School of Podiatry, he was the founder of Jerry Miller I.D. Shoe Company and retired as an executive officer of Gulf & Western which acquired his company in 1953. He was the past president of the Jamaica Jewish Center, the Boca Teeca Country Club and the B'nai B'rith Boca Teeca Chapter. A distinguished veteran of the U.S. Army; recipient of the Bronze Star and the Purple Heart; an avid golfer and gin player. Past member of Cedarbrook and Tam O'Shanter Golf Clubs as well as the Boca Teeca Country Club. He was a loving soul who brought happiness and smiles to everyone he met. Cristyne F. Lategano-Nicholas, president of NYC & Company, the city's convention and visitors bureau, said the average rate for a hotel room in the city (before taxes) in January 2001 was $210.54, a rise of 1.4 percent over January 2000, when it was $207.60. The rate in January 1999 was $196.24, meaning the rise that year was close to 6 percent.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: ISN'T that just like a director? He casts his own mother in a tiny part, then makes her a scene stealer. In APOLLO 13 (1995), when the astronaut James Lovell's wife and colleagues are terrified that Lovell is going to die in space and they very gingerly explain to his elderly mother (Jean Speegle Howard, mother of Ron) that her son is in a tiny bit of danger, she doesn't blink an eye. ''If they could get a washing machine to fly,'' she reassures her little granddaughter, ''my Jimmy could land it.'' And it turns out she's right. Tom Hanks, Bill Paxton and Kevin Bacon play the astronauts whose moon landing shot is canceled because of an oxygen tank explosion that creates a life-threatening, nation-uniting crisis. The people on the ground are memorable, too: Kathleen Quinlan as Lovell's wife, Ed Harris as the flight commander, Gary Sinise as the astronaut bumped from the flight because he'd been exposed to measles. And what an elating tribute to old-fashioned American know-how! -- Saturday at 8 p.m. on Channel 7.

''There are two things that are important in politics,'' explained Mark Hanna, the wealthy Republican strategist of the Gilded Age whom cartoonists depicted in a tight suit checkered with dollar signs and a diamond stickpin in his cravat. No interior-design details scream ''Look at me!'' No ornate chandeliers or flocked and moneyed Louis XVI wallpaper shrieks opulence. title: Books in Brief: Fiction; But This Is a Review
description: If David Markson is anything like Writer, a lugubrious fellow who pops up intermittently in THIS IS NOT A NOVEL (Counterpoint, paper, $15), his latest experimental outing, he seems to have written a book that's entertaining in spite of himself. Writer mopes around, feeling ''weary unto death of making up stories'' and ''equally tired of inventing characters.'' In an apparent bid to make his readers just as miserable, he wishes to ''contrive'' a ''novel'' without either. (Next on his to-do list: a disloyal dog and a flavorless cassoulet.) The result, like Markson's previous novel, ''Reader's Block,'' looks a bit like an old-fashioned commonplace book, a compendium of phrases, quotations, notions and facts, in this case mostly about famous writers, artists, composers, scientists and other historical figures. Despite its atomized condition, the book does, as Writer hopes, seduce the reader into turning pages. Why it should succeed at that when most other books with the same anti-narrative agenda fail isn't hard to explain. ''This Is Not a Novel'' may not be a story, but it is something equally addictive: gossip, with a dash of puzzle. Sexual improprieties aren't a primary focus, but professional sniping is, from Michelangelo calling Leonardo ''as ignorant as a maidservant'' to Orwell describing Auden as ''the kind of person who is always somewhere else when the trigger is pulled.'' Those with investigative proclivities can trace Writer's gloomy preoccupations through the items about how various notables died (and which in states of financial destitution). Other items are more enigmatic (why did Henry James hide behind a tree to avoid Ford Madox Ford?), and a handful have an evocative, lovely melancholy: ''When and where did the last person die who still believed in the existence of Zeus?'' Laura Miller

title: Keyless in Seattle: Alarm Mystery Unsolved

But there was no apparent reason for the spate of Seattle car alarms that sounded a few weeks ago. The only clue to the mystery was that all the cars in question had keyless entry systems.

title: Where India Flows At a Relaxed Pace
description: A CRUISE on a private houseboat through the backwaters of Kerala is the perfect antidote to the frantic chaos of India -- and the rest of the world. At the end of a four-week trip to India in January, my husband, Bill Brewster, and I found joy in the soothing solitude as we drifted for nearly two days through a labyrinth of canals and estuaries, rivers and rivulets, lakes and lagoons.

title: What Did the C.I.A. Do to His Father?
description: For a quarter of a century, a close friend of mine, a Harvard classmate, has believed that the Central Intelligence Agency murdered his father, a United States government scientist. Believing this means, in my friend's words, ''leaving the known universe,'' the one in which it is innocently accepted that an agency of the American government would never do such a thing. My friend has left this known universe, even raising his father's body from the grave where it had lain for 40 years to test the story the C.I.A. told him about his death. The evidence on the body says that the agency may have lied. But knowing this has not healed my friend. When I ask him what he has learned from his ordeal, he says, ''Never dig up your father.'' Then he laughs, and the look on his face is wild, bitter and full of pain.

title: On Police Beat, Charges and Countercharges
description: FELICIA COLLINS swung her patrol car out of the parking lot, the fingers of her right hand fluttering over the keyboard of the laptop that connected her to the Suffolk County Sixth Precinct, checking what was happening. At the stoplight, she flipped through laminated maps of Middle Island and Ridge, trying to get her bearings. Out on Route 25, she cruised past strip malls and stopped to assess a fender bender at an intersection. No trouble was brewing. So Officer Collins, 29, a Suffolk County police officer from Manorville, pulled into a hard-to-see spot behind a real estate office and let the motor idle. The light was fading, she said, and it was a good spot to catch drivers trying to the beat the red light.

The architect, Aldo Rossi, who died in 1997 at the age of 66, put psychology back on the architectural map. He was also a major artist who incorporated his own temperament into his design aesthetic.

title: Learning to Play With the History of Jazz

Marcus Roberts stands among jazz pianists as the most comprehensive historian to emerge in the last 20 years. Mr. Roberts has probed jazz piano tradition deeply to develop something distinctive. He does more than bring the history of jazz piano to life; he explodes and recombines that history in the moment, offering something old and new together, making his art powerfully original and compelling.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: BEING DEAD, by Jim Crace. (Picador USA, $12.) At the start of this boldly drawn tale, which won a National Book Critics Circle Award and was chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 2000, two middle-aged zoology professors lie murdered on a remote salt dune. The narrative then unfolds along several strands: one tracks the bodies' decomposition, another spools backward through the couple's final day and a third recalls their initial meeting on the same dunes 30 years earlier. ''Few novels are as unsparing as this one in presenting the ephemerality of love given the implacability of death, and few are as moving in depicting the undiminished achievement love nevertheless represents,'' Jim Shepard wrote here.

He was a graduate of NY Military Academy and the University of Rochester. Formerly with Young & Rubicam Advertising Agency, he became Vice President, Advertising Director of the Products Division and Member of the Corporate Staff of Bristol Myers Company. He was Chairman of the Association of National Advertisers, Board Member and Vice Chairman of The Advertising Council, and was a Director and Treasurer of the United Way of America. title: Murphy's Law

In 1942, then-Lieutenant Moorer, piloting a patrol plane, was shot down by the Japanese near Australia. A Philippine freighter rescued him and his crew, but it was sunk the same day. He assumed command of two lifeboats carrying his crew and the freighter crew. They were later rescued from an uninhabited island. He received the Silver Star.

title: In Defense of Soft Money

And all of this propelled the prohibition of soft money -- donations made to political parties and not subject to federal contribution limits -- to the top of the reform agenda.

description: Ethnic Albanian rebels, calling themselves the National Liberation Army -- a name that creates the same abbreviation in Albanian as the Kosovo Liberation Army -- were pushed back by Macedonian forces from the hills above the city of Tetovo. Fighting continued near the border with Kosovo, where the rebels are based and supplied, and which NATO decided it must try to seal. European diplomats trying to arrange an all-party conference of Macedonia's politicians to address minority Albanian grievances said they needed a few more days. Steven Erlanger

title: BOARDWALK WOOD
description: Asbury Park won a legal battle to use tropical hardwood to rebuild a section of its boardwalk last month, but under a bill introduced by state lawmakers last week, the state would not pay for similar projects. The bill, sponsored by Assemblyman Robert J. Smith, a Democrat from Washington Township in Gloucester County, would bar municipalities from using state Green Acres financing to replace or restore boardwalks using uncertified tropical lumber. The bill now goes to the Assembly Local Government Committee. Kirsty Sucato

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHUSID, JOSEPH G., M.D.
description: CHUSID-Joseph G., M.D. The Medical Board, Medical Staff, and Department of Neurology of Saint Vincents Catholic Medical Centers of New York-Manhattan are deeply saddened to hear of the death of Joseph G. Chusid, M.D., Founding Director and Director Emeritus of the Department of Neurology. He served the institution for 40 years during which he established a successful training program for neurologists. He was a well-respected teacher and a caring and sensitive physician who carried out the mission of St. Vincent's and that of the Sisters of Charity. He worked in experimental epilepsy in primates and was internationally known and respected. Upon his retirement, his loyal service to St. Vincent's, its patients, and the Sisters of Charity was honored through the establishment of a library in his name. His colleagues, students and other members of the St. Vincent's staff join us in extending our sincere condolences to his family. His son and daughter, Michael and Joanna, request that donations be made to the Chusid Library, Department of Neurology, St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York, 153 West 11th Street, New York, NY 10011. Enrique A. Bonfils-Roberts, M.D., President of the Medical Board Michael Garofalo, Jr., M.D., Chairman, Dept. of Neurology

The charity benefits the Royal Manchester Children's Hospital in Pendlebury, Manchester, England, where Mr. McIntosh's now 3-year-old daughter was treated for meningitis. He wants to expand the charity to benefit children's causes in New Jersey. Also appearing will be Joe D'Urso and Stone Caravan, Willie Nile and the Worry Dolls, Dave Sharp of the Alarm, and Charlie McIntosh and the Hard Travlers. Karen DeMasters

title: Opera Star in Her Home State
description: Even as a child, Frederica Von Stade, the Somerville-born mezzo-soprano loved to dress up and entertain. One of her opera delights is putting on costumes that have turned her into Hansel or Cherubino, as well as glamorous leading ladies. In concert, her acting skills add warmth to her singing. In line with the current trend, she brings an adventurous repertory to her recital today at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. Accompanied by Martin Katz, Ms. Von Stade is to perform songs by Mahler, Granados, Offenbach, Schoenberg and a number of prominent American composers. Thinking of her art and her repertory, she said, ''There's a great joy in finding ourselves in a medium of expression that is uniquely our own.'' Leslie Kandell

title: Murphy's Law
description: To the Editor: We were there on that October day on the Intracoastal Waterway when Betsy Wade was experiencing the problems of a broken drive shaft aboard Charles Miller's trawler (''Murphy's Law, Strictly Applied,'' Feb. 11). My husband and I were aboard Courage, a trawler that offered help to Charlie, whom we know. To extend Murphy's Law further, a larger trawler headed south far ahead of us also passed Charlie's boat and offered to help. Later, the same trawler passed us, headed north, back to Beaufort, unceremoniously under tow.

But almost all the older architecture has been torn down to make way for high-rises, there are few fine museums or major sights, and shopping at Gucci and Prada is not my idea of fun.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-1-01; Paperback Music
description: Even in the wake of the court decision that is, once and for all, forcing Napster to meet the concerns of copyright holders, it remains hard to discuss digital music without descending into jargon. But let's try. Begin with ''1,'' last year's compilation of Beatles hits. Nothing could be easier, using Napster or its knockoffs, than tracking down a bunch of free Beatles songs. Collected on compact disc, they go for a little north of $13. And yet at the very peak of Napster's popularity, ''1'' sold more than seven million copies. Why?

title: The Major Minor
description: It's a Wednesday afternoon in mid-January, and Charlotte Church is hanging out in a New York hotel room where, for one rare moment, neither her parents, her publicist nor her record-label chaperone is on hand. Having flown in from Wales the night before, she's sitting barefoot in the middle of a big unmade bed, listening to a Destiny's Child CD and preparing for a typically full week. First she will fly down to Washington to sing at a presidential Inauguration concert. Then back to New York, where she will perform on a bill with Eric Clapton, Whitney Houston and a handful of other superstars at a benefit concert at Carnegie Hall, after which she will attend a very adult, very late party at Lotus, the downtown club-of-the-moment. Then it's back down to Washington to wave from a float with the kid actors from ''Jerry Maguire'' and ''Home Improvement.'' Switching back into ''adult'' mode, she will attend the California Inaugural Ball, squeezing her rapidly blossoming curves into a corseted, exquisitely uncomfortable Oscar de la Renta gown. The next day, she'll be off to Los Angeles for meetings with producers and writers. And then she'll return to Wales, to her parents' home, her classes and her friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANGEL, FRANCES H.
description: ANGEL-Frances H. The National Board of the National Council of Jewish Women is deeply saddened by the loss of a distinguished leader and dear friend, Frances Hannah Levy Angel. Frances dedicated herself to improving the lives of women, children, and families here and in Israel, continuing the proud legacy started by her grandmother, NCJW founder, Hannah G. Solomon. Frances helped to launch the Charleston Section of NCJW in 1949. Her work-focusing on health, family, and women's rights issuesplaced her in the forefront of both challenge and change. Frances was a respected community leader in her hometown of Charleston, playing a prominent role in many medical, artistic, and service-oriented groups. In recognition of her efforts to improve the lives of others, Frances was awarded the prestigious NCJW Hannah G. Solomon Award named for her grandmother. Frances' work and spirit will remain an inspiration to us all. Memorial services will be held at 2 PM Sunday, April 1, 2001 at Temple Israel, Charleston, West Virginia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALSOP, PETER SCHUYLER
description: ALSOP-Peter Schuyler. Died on March 29 at Calvary Hospital. He was 64 years old. A graduate of Princeton University, Peter also attended the NYU Graduate School of Arts & Sciences, and the NYU Business School. He was a member of The Union Club. In addition to his work as an independent investment counselor, he was devoted to the arts. Peter was a member of Blue Hill Troop, Ltd., a charitable theatrical group dedicated to the works of Gilbert & Sullivan. He served on the Board of Trustees of The Hewitt School & in recent years devoted tireless energy to increasing the availability of technology in the public schools. A loving father and an inspiring friend and mentor, he will be sorely missed. In lieu of flowers, donations in Peter's name to Saint James Church or The Calvary Fund, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, New York 10461, would be appreciated. Peter is survived by his daughter Schuyler, his sister Elizabeth H. Hinchman, and two nieces and two nephews. Funeral services will be held at Saint James Church, 865 Madison Avenue, Tuesday, April 3 at 2:30. There will be a reception at The Union Club, 101 E. 69th St, immediately following the services.

title: Prescription For Profit
description: Stephen S. Hall (March 11) correctly points out that it takes substantial resources, a long-term dedication to research, marketing savvy and regulatory knowledge to create a successful drug like Claritin. However, he challenges the efficacy of Claritin by stressing that its clinical studies were conducted versus placebo. He fails to note that such studies are the standard that has been used to test all currently available antihistamines. He dismisses the evidence that millions of patients rely on Claritin to treat successfully their seasonal allergy symptoms.

title: The Lost Boys of Sudan; The Long, Long, Long Road to Fargo
description: One evening late in January, a 21-year-old named Peter Dut led his two teenage brothers through the brightly lighted corridors of the Minneapolis airport, trying to mask his confusion. Two days before, they had encountered their first light switch and tried their first set of stairs. An aid worker in Nairobi had demonstrated the flush toilet to them -- also the seat belt, the shoelace, the fork. And now they found themselves alone in Minneapolis, three bone-thin African boys confronted by a swirling river of white faces and rolling suitcases, blinking television screens and telephones that rang, inexplicably, from the inside of people's pockets. Here they were, uncertain of even the rug beneath their feet, looking for this place called Gate C31.

title: One Week in Bangkok

It is available from April 10 to June 1, a time when weather is generally very hot on Bangkok, and again Sept. 1 to 25, when it can be rainy. At other times of the year (December through February are the best months weather-wise), there is a surcharge of $77 to $252 a person. The package is sold by Natrabu Indo-American Travel, an Indonesian tour operator. Information: (800) 628-7228 or www.usindotravel.com .

title: CONVENTION CENTER LEASE-BACK
description: Atlantic City's Convention Center is technically under new ownership. title: Multifaceted Diet Approach
description: Ina Denburg is a yoga instructor, massage therapist and stress-reduction instructor. Her husband, Ron Denburg, is a tai chi teacher with a master's in environmental monitoring. The two, who live in Verona, are now also authors, of the self-published ''Diamond Diet.'' The book is a seven-week plan that is less about losing weight -- the topic doesn't come up until week six -- than about gaining awareness. Mr. Denburg read 16 top-selling diet books and concluded there was a ''plant school,'' which stresses plant foods and decries fat and processed foods, and an ''animal school,'' which singles out sugar and processed grains. The Denburgs don't take sides, but present what the schools have in common. The result is three seasonal menus, 80 recipes and a lot of education and awareness exercises. The book, $26 hardcover and $18 paperback, is available at bookstores and from on-line booksellers. Adrienne Bell

title: The Pavilionaire
description: If you've somehow grown tired of palaces, spacious ballrooms or other manifestations of your own grandeur, Jeffrey Cayle will build you a simple little hut. He is a designer of relaxed places, where you go to dissociate and unwind and think peaceful thoughts, and where you never need invite an unwanted guest. Though Cayle has turned into an architect of nature, his first jobs were in set design, and the stagecraft of his structures is unmistakable: they whimsically marry the pastoral and the theatrical. With twigs woven into them, thick rafters and funny-size windows in unlikely places, they appear as if they had sprung from the earth. They are like treehouses without the trees, or the Unabomber's shed without the Unabomber: a permanent and luxurious Outward Bound in your own backyard.

description: MILLER-Jerry, DPM. Dr. Jerry Miller of Boca Raton, FL. Formerly of Jamaica, NY. Died March 29, 2001 at the age of 82. The beloved husband for over sixty years of Jeanette. Father to Andrew and Richard. Father-in-law to Gail and Debbie and loving grandfather to Evan and Jody, Jarrod & Darren. Brother of the late Rose Caplan. A graduate of the New York School of Podiatry, he was the founder of Jerry Miller I.D. Shoe Company and retired as an executive officer of Gulf & Western which acquired his company in 1953. He was the past president of the Jamaica Jewish Center, the Boca Teeca Country Club and the B'nai B'rith Boca Teeca Chapter. A distinguished veteran of the U.S. Army; recipient of the Bronze Star and the Purple Heart; an avid golfer and gin player. Past member of Cedarbrook and Tam O'Shanter Golf Clubs as well as the Boca Teeca Country Club. He was a loving soul who brought happiness and smiles to everyone he met. title: Introduction

title: OMNICOM FORMS NET SERVICES UNIT

Terms were not disclosed. Omnicom will contribute to the new company its minority stakes in publicly traded Internet specialty agencies like Agency.com in New York; Organic in San Francisco, and Razorfish in New York, which had been managed by an Omnicom unit known as Communicade. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRUBEK, MAX, MD.
description: TRUBEK-Max, MD. Well-known NY internist, died Saturday in Litchfield, CT. Dr. Trubek graduated from Johns Hopkins University in 1922 and from the University of Maryland School of Medicine in 1926. He completed his training at NY's Bellevue Hospital. For the next two years he was associated with the internationally known pathologist, Dr. Harrison Martland. After his association with Dr. Martland, he went into private medical practice in NYC for 63 years. He was known for his diagnostic ability and his empathy and concern for his patients. He was a Professor of Clinical Medicine at NYU School of Medicine. He was past President of the Society of Bellevue Alumni. He is survived by his daughter, Helen Trubek Glenn of Litchfield, two grandchildren, John Martin Glenn and Jennifer Glenn Wuerker. Funeral service Thursday, 11 AM, Litchfield. Burial Friday, 2 PM, at East Ridgelawn Cemetery, Clifton, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made in Dr. Trubek's name to NYU School of Medicine, 550 1st Ave., New York, New York 10016.

Before the end of the week the Senate is to vote on a budget resolution incorporating Mr. Bush's ill-advised $1.6 trillion tax cut. title: VERISIGN DOMAIN-NAME CONTRACT CHANGED
description: The group that oversees the Internet's address system, the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, yesterday changed its agreement with VeriSign, the company that operates the .com, .net, and .org domain-name registries. The revisions modify VeriSign's right to operate all three registries until 2007 and create separate agreements for them. VeriSign's control of the .org registry will go to a not-for-profit organization on Dec. 31, 2002, and the .net agreement will expire on Jan. 1, 2006. The .com agreement will expire on Nov. 10, 2007, but VeriSign can get a four-year renewal if it satisfies other criteria. By agreeing to the changes, VeriSign will not be required to sell its lucrative registrar business. Susan Stellin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEFER, HELENE HOLLIS
description: SCHAEFER-Helene Hollis. Died on April 2, 2001 at her home. The cause of her death was cancer. Born in the Bronx, New York, 101 years ago, she became a longtime resident of Larchmont after her marriage to F.M.E. Schaefer, former chairman of the Schaefer Brewing Company. The mother of Henry R. Schaefer, Frederica H. Schaefer and Winifred S. Chesley, she was an active volunteer in Bundles for Britain in World War II, and for over 50 years a board member and dominant fundraiser for the Youth Counseling League (now Youth Consultation League) and an active board member of other charitable agencies. Her long-deferred dream to earn a college degree was realized when she, after her husband's death, received a B.A. degree at the College of New Rochelle in 1985, which gave her an honorary degree just before her 100th birthday in 1999. In 1989, she completed a Master of Arts degree from Manhattanville College at age 90. She was a role model in volunteer and academic fields. She had many avocations: an accomplished needlewoman, she was also an expert sailor, as was her husband. Each morning she raised the American flag on her flagpole, a beacon to sailors who would know that they were entering Larchmont harbor. Hundreds of her friends of all ages looked forward to celebrating her birthday on August 17th at her annual parties. She will be missed by all who knew and loved her. She is survived by her three children, 15 grandchildren and 14 great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church, Fountain Square, Larchmont, New York at 11:30AM on Thursday, April 5, 2001. Contributions in her name will be gratefully accepted by the College of New Rochelle, Helene H. Schaefer Scholarship for Adult Students, New Rochelle, New York 10805 or the Helene Schaefer Scholarship for Adult Students at Manhattanville College in Purchase, New York 10577, or Jensen Memorial Hospice, Tuckahoe, N.Y.

This honesty enriched every beautiful note that he played or wrote. We mourn at his passing, but celebrate the largness of his spirit. This will never die. His glorious canon of music forever speaks most eloquently of our time and our civilization. We miss him; we love him. R. Theodore Ammon, Chairman Gordon J. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, LOUIS M.
description: KLEIN-Louis M. Of Harrison, New York. On Saturday, March 31, 2001, at age 93. Louis's wife, Miriam Becker Klein with whom he was in love for sixty-four years, survives him. His children Honie Ann Peacock, Arthur C. Klein and his wife Patricia, Toby Jo Haynes and her husband Wilson, his grandchildren Chiara Peacock and her husband Ron, Justin, Zoe, Isaac and Joshua also survive Louis. Louis was Superintendent of Schools, Harrison, New York from 1935 to 1969. He was the youngest Superintendent of Schools in New York State and the first Jewish Superintendent of Schools. He was past President of the New York State Superintendent of Schools Association, The Louis M. Klein Middle School was renamed for him in 1970. Louis served two terms as Town Councilman, he was responsible for creating, locating and funding the Harrison Ambulance Corps. and he served several terms as President of the Harrison Lions Club of which he was a member for 70 years and served as chaplain for the last 20 years. He was President of the Harrison Children's Center, Board member & Chairman of the Board of Sound Federal Savings and Loan for many years. He was Captain of the Don Bosco semipro basketball team, Portchester, New York. Louis was a graduate of Albany State Teacher's College & received his Master's in Spanish Language and Literature from Cornell University. He taught at Cornell University and Pace University. He was a highly principled, ethical and humane individual. He judged people by their character. The family will establish a scholarship fund in his name for a deserving Harrison student. Friends may contact the family for details. Funeral services were Monday at Congregation Kol Ami, White Plains. Interment followed at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

description: The DuPont Company, seeking to move assets out of slow-growth businesses, said yesterday that it would cut 4,000 jobs, or about 4 percent of its work force, as well as 1,300 contract workers. About half of the cuts will come in DuPont's nylon and polyester businesses, and about 3,000 of the jobs will be eliminated in the United States. DuPont said the action would save $400 million a year.

title: Away From the TV Fray, Still Landing Punches
description: IT is fitting somehow that Bill Moyers runs his independent production company, Public Affairs Television, in an out-of-the-way Manhattan office building, on a quiet stretch of West 33rd Street near the West Side Highway. From his office window, Mr. Moyers looks out onto railroad tracks and trains heading south from Penn Station.

title: VITAL SIGNS: TIMING; Toilet Training, Without Any Guilt
description: A study by researchers from the Medical College of Wisconsin has found no relationship between the age of toilet training, a child's enrollment in day care and the working status of the child's mother.

title: At Last, Eagles Regain a Perch In the Lower 48
description: On a cold but bright winter morning, a gaggle of joggers and fitness walkers stopped dead in their tracks to gawk at an astonishing sight: a mature bald eagle dining on a duck it had plucked from Lake Calhoun here.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; At American Express, a Fall In Expectations And Earnings
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings would decline about 18 percent from the period a year earlier, chiefly because of bigger-than-expected losses on its junk bond investments. It also offered a fairly gloomy forecast for its corporate charge-card business.

title: Technology Stocks Plunge as Profit Outlook Weakens
description: Technology stocks plunged today, pulling the broader market sharply lower, as a seemingly unending drumbeat of corporate financial warnings gave investors little reason to believe that profits would improve soon.

The film, seen Sunday night at 12 on TCM, is actually an adaptation of Rafael Sabatini's 1915 novel about an English nobleman sold into slavery. It stars Milton Sills and Enid Bennett.

title: As Stocks Slump, Citigroup Begins Laying Off Workers
description: Citigroup became the latest Wall Street concern to respond to the stock market's slump by laying off employees as it started notifying at least a few hundred workers today that their jobs were being eliminated, a spokeswoman for the company said.

description: CENTURY WALKOVER-Mary. On April 1, 2001 at age 97. Loving mother of two sons, Frederick Century and Irving Centor.

title: Metro Business Briefing; CUTBACKS FOR ONLINE PUBLISHER
description: Internet.com, an online publishing company that has been hurt by the sharp overall declines in advertising, announced yesterday that it would cut 60 to 70 employees, about 15 percent of its work force, including positions in New York and Darien, Conn. Internet.com also runs news Web sites, including atnewyork.com, which covers Silicon Alley and technology businesses in the New York region. Officials said the cutbacks would affect virtually all areas of its operations worldwide. Many workers who remain will be reassigned to new jobs, officials said. The company, based in Darien, said some of the reductions involved positions made redundant by recent acquisitions, including some of the assets of EarthWeb. Jayson Blair

title: No Easy Way Forward With China
description: The most recent crisis in Chinese-American relations is escalating tensions with every passing hour and threatens to spiral the relationship out of control if not appropriately handled by the Chinese side. The Bush administration, for its part, has acquitted itself well so far by invoking international law and customary practice for dealing with such incidents.

title: FPL CANCELS ITS ACQUISITION OF ENTERGY
description: The FPL Group canceled a $15.8 billion acquisition of the Entergy Corporation after the two utilities fought over who would lead the combined company, and FPL said Entergy gave conflicting earnings forecasts. Entergy's chief executive, Wayne Leonard, said James Broadhead, FPL's chairman and chief executive, planned to renege on an agreement to make Mr. Leonard the chief executive of the new company. FPL found ''very large discrepancies'' between earnings forecasts given to FPL and those to be sent to regulators, Mr. Broadhead said. Entergy, based in New Orleans, offered to cancel the merger when FPL threatened to sue, he said. Mr. Leonard said Mr. Broadhead was confused because Entergy provided several earnings projections, each contingent on a different set of possibilities for the future. FPL said in July it would buy Entergy for about $7 billion.

title: Business Computer Secrecy Vulnerable to a New Flaw
description: New computer security flaws have been discovered in a popular wireless local area networking standard increasingly used by both corporations and consumers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, LAWRENCE P.
description: KING-Lawrence P. The entire NYU Law School community mourns the loss of a beloved colleague, Larry King. A preeminent scholar and leader of the Bankruptcy bar, he gave tirelessly of himself to better the law. Never one to compromise quality in any dimension, he also was a gifted and inspiring teacher. And, most of all, he was a model of the best one expects of a colleague and friend. We will miss him. Our thoughts and prayers are with his family. Lester Pollack Chair of Board of Trustess NYU School of Law Foundation John Sexton, Dean

title: BUSINESS OUTLOOK FALLS
description: The Bank of Japan's influential quarterly survey of business conditions for the quarter that ended March 31 showed a steeper-than- expected decline in the corporate outlook for business activity. But economists here said the forecasts were likely to fall even further in the next survey, which is known as the tankan, because large manufacturers are counting heavily on a rebound in exports that may fail to materialize. Additionally, companies traditionally tend to be their most optimistic early and revise their outlook downward after that. Stephanie Strom

Pictures of famous Italian-Americans like Frank Sinatra and Rocky Marciano hang from another. The menu offers ''Italian specialties'' like eggplant parmigiana and baked ziti.

He spoke to his elderly and ailing mother on his way to the park -- Bess Clemens sounded as if she was having a good day, he thought -- and that was before he paused to see the 2000 championship banner raised, before his pitching coach, friend and the cancer survivor Mel Stottlemyre threw out the ceremonial first pitch.

title: POLYONE TO CLOSE SOME PLASTIC AND PIGMENT PLANTS
description: The PolyOne Corporation, a chemical maker created by the merger last year of the M. A. Hanna Company and the Geon Company, said yesterday that it would eliminate at least one-third of its 34 plants that make pigments and plastics within two years. A total of 2,500 employees work at the 34 plants, the company said. Those sites, in the United States and Canada, are close to half of the 80 plants operated by the 9,000-employee company. The changes should bring pretax savings of $35 million to $50 million a year, said Dennis Cocco, chief communications officer at the company. Mr. Cocco said he did not know how many jobs would be cut. PolyOne is based in Cleveland.

title: A New York Debut With a Baton for an Old Hand
description: The pianist Murray Perahia established himself as a thoughtful Mozartean in the late 1970's, when he led the English Chamber Orchestra from the keyboard in an estimable recording of the complete piano concerto cycle. Having devoted himself largely to the Romantics during the 1980's and 90's, he began looking into Baroque music a few seasons ago, and he has proved an insightful interpreter of Bach, Handel and Scarlatti.
