description: BEIJING, April 3 - A United States-based Chinese scholar who has been in police detention for the last 51 days was formally charged today with working for an overseas organization to spy on China, a crime that potentially carries a long prison term if she is convicted.

title: American Embassy Officials Wait to See Plane's Crew

They are expected to meet the crew later today.

title: RAILTRACK SEES PROFIT DECLINE
description: Shares in the Railtrack Group fell 17 percent, to 570 pence, after the company, which owns Britain's railroad tracks and stations, said profit for 2002 would fall below analyst estimates despite 1.5 billion ($2.1 billion) in emergency government financing. Railtrack said profit would be hurt by poor train performance and increased maintenance costs. For instance, the company said the cost of embankments to protect tracks against landslides from floods would cost 250 million more than initial projections over the next five years. Suzanne Kapner

description: Darryl Strawberry, the former Yankees and Mets slugger who had been missing since late last week, turned himself in to the authorities tonight and was taken into custody, a Hillsborough County Sheriff's Office spokeswoman said.

title: Scope of Loss For Privatizing By Edison Stuns Officials
description: A plan to privatize five failing New York City schools suffered a more stunning defeat than either side anticipated, with 80 percent of the parents who voted rejecting it, according to the tally released yesterday.

title: Metro Business Briefing; DROP BOX DEAL DIES
description: Customers of Kozmo, the online delivery company based in Manhattan, will no longer be able to return videos to Starbucks Coffee locations, because a joint marketing agreement between the two companies has fallen apart. The agreement, which was signed on Feb. 12, 2000, ended on Sunday. The agreement called for Kozmo to pay $150 million to Starbucks in return for the coffee stores' serving as drop box locations. But after Kozmo officials decided to reduce the number of markets they served, instead of expanding as planned, they decided that $150 million was too much. Officials at the companies said they were unable to reach an amended agreement that would be viable for both sides. Jayson Blair

title: VITAL SIGNS: MENTAL HEALTH; Fight Depression, on Your Treadmill
description: Two new studies on exercise and mood looked at questions of timing: one found that walking could begin reducing symptoms of depression faster than many drugs could; the other found that the mental benefits of exercise could end when the workouts did.

title: Lumber Trade Dispute Escalates
description: The United States lumber industry quickly filed formal complaints yesterday accusing Canada of flooding the American market with construction-grade lumber, driving prices down and forcing more than 100 sawmills to close in the last year.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN DROPS. The yen fell after a report showed Japanese business confidence declined for the first time since 1998. In New York, the dollar settled at 126.66 yen, up from 125.52 yen on Friday.

title: Bermuda Cruise
description: Bermuda is too far north to be considered a Caribbean island, but it's far enough to the south that April usually means good weather. So an April 18 nine-day cruise aboard the all-suite Seven Seas Mariner from Fort Lauderdale to Bermuda looks even better with 50 percent off the regular rate for the second passenger in each cabin. Besides spending two and a half days in Hamilton, Bermuda, the ship also will stop at Nassau, the Bahamas, and Charleston, S.C. Prices start at $2,696 a person, based on double occupancy, including the half-price fare for the second person in the cabin. The fare includes all tips on board and wine with dinner, and each cabin has its own balcony. Guests who secure deposits with a credit card will receive a $200 per cabin in credits for on-board purchases. Information: (800) 285-1835 or www.rssc.com .

title: Photo Gives Weight To Einstein's Thesis Of Negative Gravity
description: A photograph of a distant exploding star has given astronomers the first direct evidence that a mysterious ''negative gravity'' force swept through and still pervades the universe, scientists announced at a NASA news conference yesterday in Washington.

title: Russian Held In New York Now Agrees To Swiss Trial
description: A Russian official detained in New York since January on Swiss charges of laundering millions of dollars in kickbacks from Swiss companies that renovated the Kremlin agreed yesterday to abandon his fight against extradition, saying he wanted to go to trial in Geneva and clear his name.

title: TECHNOLOGY STAKE TO BE SOLD
description: The British telecommunications company Cable and Wireless has reached an agreement to sell its 14.7 percent stake in Pacific Century CyberWorks, the troubled Hong Kong technology company, through a $1.5 billion bond offering. The offering, which came after CyberWorks failed to find a buyer for the stake, lifts some of the uncertainty that has hung over its shares. But it underscores how far out of favor CyberWorks has fallen since last year, when it acquired the Hong Kong subsidiary of Cable and Wireless in a $38 billion deal that left Cable and Wireless as its second-largest shareholder after the company's founder, Richard Li. Mark Landler

The current estimate by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call is for a loss of 1.19 Canadian dollars a share, compared with a loss of 28 cents a year ago. Mr. Milton said the airline would save 700 million Canadian dollars ($445 million) a year, beginning in mid-2001, as a result of taking over Canadian Airlines last year. Analysts still expect a profit of one Canadian dollar a share for the current year. Timothy Pritchard

title: Boys Don't Cry: Fashion Falls For a Tough Looker
description: Naturally, she is beautiful. Beauty is part of the job description. But hers is not the complex loveliness of her grandmother, the Italian film star Lucia Bose. Rather, it is closer to the austere, masculine elegance of another famous relative, her grandfather, the legendary Spanish bullfighter Dominguin. Ernest Hemingway once wrote of Dominguin that he ''was a charmer -- dark, tall, no hips, just a touch too long in the neck for a bullfighter, with a grave mocking face that went from professional disdain to easy laughter.'' With slight alterations to account for her sex, this description could also characterize Eleonora Bose, the model of the moment.

title: Metro Business Briefing; ELECTRICITY RATES FALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, ROBERT
description: MAYER-Robert. Age 84. Of Scarsdale, New York. Cherished husband of the late Ann Louise Levison Mayer. Died April 1, 2001 after a courageous battle with cancer. He is survived by his beloved sons Andrew and his wife Carolyn of Burlington, VT., and Geoffrey and his wife Rayne of Louisville, KY., and his grandchildren Bittany, Amy, Brock and Erin. Predeceased by brother Herbert Mayer of Greenwich, CT. Survived by his hero and brother Dr. Henry Mayer of Woodside, CA. He will be greatly missed by his dear friend and companion Betty Kahn. Bob graduated in 1937 from Princeton University, majoring in philosophy, where he won the Alexander McCosh Prize for Best Senior Thesis. He received a Graduate degree in Mechanical Engineering from Stevens Institute in 1939, and after graduation, founded the design firm Robert Mayer Associates. From industrial engineering, Bob later became a renowned specialist in the field of industrial lubricants. He had a tremendous enthusiasm for finding solutions to high tech industrial lubrication problems. Bob was an officer of Tribology Tech Lube and was published in several industrial journals. Bob will be sorely missed by his business associates. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society, 1-800-227-2345. A commemorative service will be held for family and close friends at the Women's Club of White Plains, 305 Ridgeway, Sunday, Apr 8, 11:30AM

title: EXCHANGE CONSIDERS MOVE
description: The London Stock Exchange is considering a move from the financial district, where it has been for the last 200 years, to Canary Wharf, the real estate complex that has recovered from near financial ruin to secure some of the largest investment banks as tenants. A spokesman confirmed that the exchange planned to vacate premises at Exchange Tower by 2004, and was looking at several locations, one of which is at Canary Wharf. Such a move would ruffle city officials, who have encouraged institutions to remain within the square mile that bounds London's financial district. The spokesman said that since switching to an electronic trading system in 1986, the exchange had required less space. Suzanne Kapner

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, JERRY, DPM.
description: MILLER-Jerry, DPM. Dr. Jerry Miller of Boca Raton, FL. Formerly of Jamaica, NY. Died March 29, 2001 at the age of 82. The beloved husband for over sixty years of Jeanette. Father to Andrew and Richard. Father-in-law to Gail and Debbie and loving grandfather to Evan and Jody, Jarrod & Darren. Brother of the late Rose Caplan. A graduate of the New York School of Podiatry, he was the founder of Jerry Miller I.D. Shoe Company and retired as an executive officer of Gulf & Western which acquired his company in 1953. He was the past president of the Jamaica Jewish Center, the Boca Teeca Country Club and the B'nai B'rith Boca Teeca Chapter. A distinguished veteran of the U.S. Army; recipient of the Bronze Star and the Purple Heart; an avid golfer and gin player. Past member of Cedarbrook and Tam O'Shanter Golf Clubs as well as the Boca Teeca Country Club. He was a loving soul who brought happiness and smiles to everyone he met. Services on Sunday, April 1, 2001 at 10 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

Alfa bought the stake from a foreign company, the British-based broadband service provider, Global TeleSystems, which had indicated that it wanted to focus on its business in Europe. title: Metro Business Briefing; KOZMO LOSES FINANCING
description: Kozmo, the Manhattan-based online delivery service, has lost $6 million in financing that was pledged as a part of a round of investments that the company announced weeks before it was expected to run out of cash, company officials said yesterday. The $30 million round of investments, led by Flatiron Partners, was announced in January. The $6 million was supposed to come from a group of foreign investors. But officials at Kozmo, which operates in nine markets, said the person who claimed to represent those investors could not produce the money. Stephanie Cohen Glass, a spokeswoman for Kozmo, declined to comment on the financing other than to say, ''The round is not closed.'' Kozmo recently dropped the dot-com from its name and said it would focus more on offline sales. Jayson Blair

title: HICKS, MUSE OFFERS $370 MILLION TO BUY OUT VLASIC FOODS

I had the feeling she did not really want to share any details with me about what was happening. And I didn't ask.

The company said it drew down about $880 million of committed loan facilities for general corporate purposes, including the retirement of about $825 million of commercial paper obligations as they become due. The idea of using the Internet to weave together thousands of independent PC's is not new. It has already been used by the Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence project, known as SETI, and by Juno, the Internet service provider, and several start-up companies. As part of the Intel project, computer users will be able to donate computer time to build a virtual supercomputer. title: F.T.C. DEAL ON ADS

The agency said the ads failed to disclose the need for additional equipment like a modem for mobile access to the Web and to send or receive electronic messages. Microsoft developed an operating system for the Pocket PC and licensed it to manufacturers including Hewlett-Packard; in April 2000 the two companies began to advertise the Pocket PC in newspapers and other national publications. The amended filing provides the number of shares to be sold, 33.9 million, and their price for the first time. Instinet would have 236.4 million shares outstanding after the public offering, the filing said. Assuming the company received $12.50 a share -- the middle of the estimated price range -- the total market value for Instinet would begin at $2.95 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, SHELDON S. (HACK).
description: WILSON-Sheldon S. (Hack). Died on Sunday, April 1, 2001 at his home in Napa Valley, California, after a brief illness. Mr. Wilson was founder and co-proprietor of the Chimney Rock Winery located in the Stags Leap District of Napa Valley. He is survived by his wife, Stella, of Napa Valley, California, his 3 children, Leigh of Westport, Connecticut, Cary of Los Angeles, CA., Drue-Ann of Sausalito, CA., two grandchildren, Nathan and Benjamin Wilson and his brother Irwin Robin (Ebs) Wilson of San Juan Capistrano, California. Mr. Wilson maintained a home in Beverly Hills, CA. since 1965 and a home in Napa Valley since 1981. The New York City born Mr. Wilson served in the United States Army-Air Corps, 2nd Bomber Command during World War II and rose to the rank of Major. Mr. Wilson was President of Rheingold Corporation (1964-1966), a NYSE listed company, headquartered in New York City and also served on the boards of serveral public companies in North America and Southern Africa. Funeral services are private. The Family requests that any donations be made to Hospice of Napa, 3299 Claremont Way, Napa, California, 94558.

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET ONLINE WINE SELLER CUTS JOBS Succumbing to the economic downturn, Wine.com , the leading online wine seller, laid off nearly two-thirds of its staff yesterday in an effort to stave off financial ruin. The layoffs included 160 jobs in Napa, Calif., and San Francisco and followed the layoff of 75 workers in January. In December, the company said its year-to-year sales had tripled during 2000 along with the number of customers. The company, known as Virtual Vineyards when it was founded in 1994, acquired the assets of Wine.com in September 1999 and changed its name and Internet address. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Gabrielle Hamilton
description: I FIRST tasted Breton butter cake, or Kouing-Aman, when I was 5 years old. My mother, who is French, would take us to Bnodet, a tiny seaside town in Brittany, where we would have lunches of thick slices of bread spread with Brittany's distinctly salty butter and a tall platter of fruits de mer. Later, we'd stop in a pastry shop for a slice of this flaky, dense, sweet and salty cake.

title: Mr. McCain's Journey
description: Senator John McCain's grin told the story. So did the headline yesterday on The Times's front page: ''A McCain Victory.'' By any measure, the Arizona senator scored what all of Washington recognizes as a big win. He got a bill embodying his signature issue, campaign finance reform, passed over the opposition of the Congressional leadership of his own party. President Bush, who had opposed the measure since he and Mr. McCain faced off in the presidential primaries, will probably sign the bill if it gets through the House of Representatives. As an editorial page that supported the legislation sponsored by Mr. McCain and Senator Russell Feingold, we savored their victory. Mr. Feingold and the Senate Democratic leader, Tom Daschle, both played important roles. But it was Mr. McCain's presidential campaign that galvanized public support, so this seems an appropriate moment to ponder the unusual life and political evolution of John McCain and to speculate on his future.

title: Metro Business Briefing; RESTAURANTTRADE BOARD MEMBERS
description: RestaurantTrade, which sells Web-based software for independent restaurants and suppliers, announced five appointments to its board on Monday. The privately held company, based in Manhattan, was started last fall. It provides software that links chefs to vendors, and accounting systems for ordering, tracking and paying for goods. The new board members are Dorothy Cann Hamilton, the chief executive and founder of the French Culinary Institute; George Faison, president of D'Artagnan; Rocco DiSpirito, executive chef at Union Pacific; Kenneth A. Himmel, president of the Palladium Company; and Robert W. Rudzki, senior director at BEA Systems. Jayson Blair

title: RIGHTS TO GENE TREATMENT
description: Introgen Therapeutics, a gene therapy company, said it had gained back full rights to its lead product candidate from Aventis, which is restructuring its gene therapy activities. Introgen, based in Austin, Tex., and Aventis, a big French-German pharmaceutical company, have worked since 1994 to develop a therapy for head and neck cancer that is now in the final phase of clinical trials. The treatment involves injection of a tumor suppressor gene that is known as p53. Andrew Pollack

title: Critic's Notebook; Architecture Hands Off the Baton to Preservation
description: The Trans World Airlines Flight Center at Kennedy International Airport was designed to evoke the spirit of flight, but I don't have to tell you that that glorious bird flew away many years ago. Eero Saarinen's unbroken flow of organic space was not made for the era of metal detectors, nor had the terminal's red-carpet aura been conceived for an era of mass travel. Saarinen's building, on the contrary, was designed for glamour, freedom of movement, and, above all, ethereality. Ascending those shallow steps, with their curved wisps of railings, your head inched toward the clouds, the terminal's ceiling of billowing white concrete.

title: Ninfa Segarra
description: First appointed by the Bronx borough president, Fernando Ferrer, in 1990, but split with him and emerged as a conservative on social issues, eventually aligning herself with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who reappointed her in 1994 . . . Deputy mayor for education and human services from December 1993 to April 2000, when she became a vice president of the City University of New York . . . Supports privatization and abolishing the Board of Education to give the mayor more control . . . Has a B.A. from New York University, a J.D. degree from New York Law School, and was admitted to the bar in 1983.

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES BUYS AN AIR-CONDITIONING BUSINESS
description: The United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that its Carrier air-conditioning unit had bought the heating and air- conditioning business of the closely held Climatic Corporation, to expand in the Southeast. Terms were not disclosed. Climatic, which is based in Columbia, S.C., had 2000 sales of about $100 million and employs 175 people. It distributes Carrier, Bryant and Payne residential and commercial products. Climatic has sales and distribution offices in North Carolina, South Carolina and Arkansas. Carrier, the largest maker of heating, air-conditioning and refrigeration products, is projected to have 2001 sales of $1.5 billion.

description: Dennis Winston, the football coach at the University of Toledo who played 11 seasons as a linebacker for the Pittsburgh Steelers and the New Orleans Saints, said yesterday that some of his missing mementos were found in a trash bin in Kentucky last week.

title: ENTERGY QUARTERLY PROFIT GLIDES ABOVE EXPECTATIONS
description: The Entergy Corporation, whose $15.8 billion acquisition by the FPL Group Inc. collapsed on Monday, said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings beat expectations because of higher profit from electricity generation and trading. Profit was 66 cents a share, or 15 percent more than a 57-cent analyst estimate given to IBES International Inc., an Entergy spokeswoman, Yolanda Pollard, said. Entergy, which will report earnings on April 25, made $114.2 million, or 48 cents, in the period a year earlier.

description: John Gielgud's home in Buckinghamshire, England, was a baronial estate, his own Brideshead, filled with memories and memorabilia, art and artifacts gathered during a lifetime in the theater. The contents of that house will be auctioned at Sotheby's in London tomorrow. An estimated value of $710,000 to $998,000 has been placed on the collection.

description: Secretary of State Colin N. Powell declared today, ''We have nothing to apologize for'' in the collision of an American spy plane with a Chinese fighter, while President Bush briefly emerged to warn China ''it is time for our servicemen and women to return home.''

description: The chief of Singapore Telecommunications, Lee Hsien Yang, defended his company's winning bid for the Australian phone company Cable and Wireless Optus at a news conference today, calling the terms fair and final after a week in which unimpressed investors punished both companies' shares.

title: AIRLINE STOCKS SLIDE
description: Spain's biggest airline, Iberia, went public on an especially bleak day for European airline stocks, and fell 1.7 percent, to 1.17 euros ($1.03) a share in its first day of trading, despite a last-minute 44 percent reduction in the offering price. The SAirGroup, parent of Swissair, fell 21 percent, to 141 Swiss francs ($81.28) a share, a day after reporting a huge loss and serious problems in the regional airlines in which it holds stakes. Its chief executive, Mario Corti, who joined the company last month from Nestl, said on Monday that SAir's strategy of investing in smaller airlines, rather than joining a global alliance, had failed. Alitalia's stock fell 4.6 percent, to 1.67 euros ($1.47), after it reported worse losses than expected and no progress finding a foreign partner.

title: Powell Begins New Talks With Leaders Of Caucasus
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell opened peace talks here today on a longstanding conflict between Azerbaijan and Armenia, hoping that the sun-splashed setting of this resort and the presence of America's principal diplomat would help nudge the presidents of the two countries toward a settlement.

title: Holding The Sauce, Not the Flavor
description: HEALTHFUL food was not on Tom Colicchio's mind when he opened Craft three weeks ago. Minimalism was. But there is as much on the menu for those who want to eat plain fish and unadorned roasted asparagus as for those who wish to indulge in foie gras and creamy pured potatoes.

title: Two Discoveries From Brazil, One in the Family
description: Two new Brazilian musicians, who really aren't that new at all, performed together on Friday night at Town Hall. The first was Moreno Veloso, the 27-year-old son of one of Brazil's most important musicians and songwriters, Caetano Veloso; the second was Virginia Rodrigues, who at age 37 began her recording career just four years ago, when she was discovered by Caetano Veloso. Despite the wide array of new music being made in Brazil today, the upstart artists who find their way to United States concert halls tend to have the imprimatur of a legend.

title: The Columbia Queen
description: Bargains can leave you with a warm feeling, especially when the deal includes a blanket from the Pendleton Woolen Mills. The Columbia Queen, a 161-passenger ship, is offering savings of $500 a person on cruises along the Columbia, Snake and Willamette rivers in the Pacific Northwest in April, May and June. The offer is good on selected cabins and must be booked by June 1. The rates, including the discount, start at $1,910 in April, $2,210 in May and $2,410 in June. Prices are per person, based on double occupancy, and include port charges, transfers and taxes; air fare to Portland, Ore., the shipis base, is extra. Besides seven nights on the Columbia Queen, there is also a one-night stay in the Embassy Suites Downtown in Portland. Information: (800) 297-3960 or www.columbiaqueen.com .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, JOHN
description: LEWIS-John. The House of Steinway & Sons is profoundly saddened by the passing of its beloved friend and devoted Steinway Artist John Lewis, on March 29 at the age of 80. As pianist, composer, arranger, and as the musical director of the famed Modern Jazz Quartet, Mr. Lewis was an artist of exceptional creativity and taste. The public was blessed by his long and illustrious career, and his affiliation with our firm for more than four decades is treasured. His music and his acclaimed discography will keep his legacy alive for future generations. All who knew John Lewis will cherish his grace and humility, rare personal qualities in so distinguished an artist. To his wife, Mirjana, his children and his family we extend our heartfelt condolences. His loss is deeply felt. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P., Worldwide Concert & Artist Activities

title: SOLECTRON WILL CUT ANOTHER 1,075 JOBS AND CLOSE PLANT
description: The Solectron Corporation, a contract electronics manufacturer, said yesterday that it planned to cut 1,075 jobs, a 1.5 percent reduction, and would close a Georgia plant because of slowing demand. Workers at the plant, in Suwanee, Ga., will be laid off over the next few months, said Bob Kula, a company spokesman. Some could get an option to move to another Solectron plant, depending on demand, Mr. Kula said. Solectron said last month that it had cut 8,200 jobs and that it would take a $300 million to $400 million charge this quarter for the dismissals and to reconfigure factories. The cuts are in addition to those in March, and no additional charge is planned, Mr. Kula said.

title: Navigating a Dreamlike Land of Assimilation, Fluent in Passion and Hope

It's hard to describe; each has a touch of dreaminess that lifts it off the floor of credible reality, but only by a few inches. Call it semi-magic realism: enough otherworldliness to infuse the stage world with an uplifting faith, but insufficient to conquer gravity entirely.

title: Heady Stew From Greens

Some pages were crammed with as many as 40 frames, while others were airy and bordered by exquisite floral designs. One page, with a circuitous illustrated diagram that simultaneously led the reader through the story of an unanswered telephone and a family history, took a good 10 minutes to get through, but at the end came a denouement so logical and tidy that it left readers reeling.

She seems no match for the larger-than-life statue she passes -- that of the late mayor and police commissioner Frank L. Rizzo, whose iron-fisted defense of the police knew no bounds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORCHARD, HELEN MARSHALL
description: BORCHARD - Helen Marshall. April 2, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Bernard P. Borchard; devoted mother of William M. Borchard and his wife Myra; cherished grandmother of Jillian and Thomas; loving sister of the late Madelaine Simon. She was always ahead of her time. She was a woman's suffragette as a teenager, introduced women's golf tournaments to her country club, was a children's entertainer performing at the White House and formed a children's summer theater program at the 92nd St Y, where she and her mother served as Directors for a period spanning 80 years. Her interest in childen also led her to be a founding director of Eisman Day Nursery and of SCAN New York. Her greatest joys were her husband and her son. Contributions in her memory may be made to the 92nd St Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Assn, 1395 Lexington Ave, NY NY 10128. Service Friday, April 6, 2001, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEFER, HELENE HOLLIS
description: SCHAEFER-Helene Hollis. The College of New Rochelle community records with sorrow the death of Helene Hollis Schaefer '85, LHD '99, at the age of 101. The embodiment of the pursuit of lifelong learning, her enduring passion and unabashed delight in learning brought her the Bachelor of Arts degree at the age of 85 and the Master of Arts degree at 90. As she approached 100, the College was honored to confer on her the honorary degree, Doctor of Humane Letters. Her life, lived in three different centuries, was animated by a generous spirit and was filled with wisdom, warmth, and wit. We mourn her loss and celebrate her life. Stephen J. title: Rebates Help Vehicle Sales Remain Strong

title: McGrady Injury Helps Knicks to Victory
description: The Knicks finally found a way to guard Tracy McGrady: with a Madison Square Garden security officer. And yet, even as McGrady spent most of last night's game in the Orlando locker room with a leg injury, it still took the Knicks until the final quarter to recover their sense of urgency and defend the remaining Magic players.

description: A day after the Senate approved an overhaul of the campaign finance law, a coalition of House supporters began a drive to bring the legislation to a vote before Memorial Day and promised to remind freshmen Republicans whose campaigns were supported last year by Senator John McCain of their commitment to changing the system.

title: Pinot Noir, the Red Riddler
description: NO matter how you approach it, pinot noir is maddening. It gives growers fits because it is so difficult to maintain in the vineyard. Its inconsistency frustrates even the most experienced winemakers, while in the glass, it is a regular Lon Chaney, a wine of a thousand faces, alternately soft and seductive, then tightening into reticence before blooming again. It may be a simple fruity delight, or it may deepen into profundity, testing the vocabulary of wine writers, who grapple with similes and metaphors before smashing their glasses and retreating to, well, ''maddening.''

title: AS STOCK TRADING EBBS, AMERITRADE ANNOUNCES NEW FEES
description: The Ameritrade Holding Corporation said it would add new fees on customers' accounts to generate revenue as the rout in stocks deters individual investors from trading stock online. Ameritrade, like its online brokerage rivals, has been hurt as plunging stock prices have calmed once hyperactive individual traders. The fee, a quarterly maintenance charge, comes less than a week after Ameritrade, which is based in Omaha, announced its second round of job cuts this year. The company said it would lay off 170 employees at its Omaha and Fort Worth call centers after laying off 330 in January.

title: COSMETICS RESTRICTIONS PASS
description: The European Parliament voted to ban sales of all new cosmetic products that have been tested on animals. If accepted by national governments, the ban would be phased in by January 2005 on all new cosmetic products -- including makeup, shower gels, shampoos and creams -- using ingredients tested on animals. The ban would also apply to all animal-tested cosmetics imported into the European Union. Advocates of animal rights welcomed the decision. But European Union officials warned that some countries may oppose the tough new rules. France and Italy conduct the most cosmetic testing in the European Union. Only three countries in the union currently have bans on cosmetic animal testing, Britain, Austria and the Netherlands. Paul Meller

title: Mahlerian All the Way, Right Down To the Angst

Perhaps those performances were flukes, or perhaps they were a stage in the developing chemistry between Mr. Chailly and his players. At any rate, in two performances at Avery Fisher Hall -- a Mahler concert on Sunday afternoon, and works by Webern and Brahms on Monday evening -- much of the lushness and glow were back, along with currents of both subtlety and sheer visceral power.

title: A Breeze From India Blows Away the Clichs
description: INDIAN cuisine sometimes feels like a perennial lost cause, perhaps because it's too much of a good thing. There are too many regional styles, too many spices, too many heady aromas for most diners to make sense of. Because the United States lacks the close ties to India of a country like Britain, Indian food has not been translated well here. It's stuck in the same sad spot as Mexican cooking was a decade ago, its diversity edited down into a tired list of old standbys. The favored setting, heavy on beads and brass, with an endless sitar loop playing in the background, only reinforces the dreary impression that one Indian restaurant is all Indian restaurants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMB, GEORGE CHARLES JR.
description: LAMB-George Charles Jr. Died peacefully on April 3, 2001, at Duke University Medical Center with his family by his side. George was born in Middletown, OH, on June 9, 1925. A top tennis player in the Middletown area, he was Junior Tennis Champion while in high school. After high school he enlisted and served in the U.S. Air Force during WWII. Following the war he attended the University of Virginia where he met Pat (Elizabeth Boteler Lamb), his wife of 49 years. He then earned a law degree from the University of Cincinnati. George began work for the United Parcel Service in 1952 and never left the company, becoming UPS's National Operations Manager in 1972 and Chairman and Chief Executive Officer in 1980. George headed the company until retirement in 1984. He remained on the companies Board of Directors until 1990. George guided UPS through an unprecedented period of growth and success and was especially proud of the companies business ethics. He was truly honored to have worked for a company that exemplified the high integrity which was the guiding principle of both his business & personal life. He was a religious & charitable man who supported medical research at Duke University, The University of Virginia and Vanderbilt University, which is home to the Elizabeth B. Lamb Center, a pediatric research facility. He also launched UPS's first employee United Way Campaign. Today UPS is the second largest United Way contributor in the country. George is survived by his wife Pat; children, George Lamb III, William Lamb, Claire Solley and Margaret Lamb; grandchildren, twins, Elizabeth and Carolyn Lamb, Joseph and Elizabeth Reed Solley and Charlsea and Ellen Lamb and his sister, Sally Rigby. They love and miss him very much. A memorial service will be held Friday at 11 A.M. at The First Presbyterian Church of Durham, NC, where he was a member.

Oakes, who infused the opinion pages of The New York Times with his crisp reasoning, passionate convictions and liberal political views for more than 40 years, 15 of them as editor of the editorial page, died early today at Mt. Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 87, and lived in Manhattan and Martha's Vineyard, Mass.

title: Metro Business Briefing; POWER INDUSTRY SHAKEOUT
description: MyUtility Inc., the New York-based Internet energy company, has bought some of the assets of Utility.com, which competed with power companies in states with deregulation by trying to sell electricity at discounted rates. Utility.com, based in Emeryville, Calif., is now liquidating its assets. It had offered discount-rate power along with long-distance telephone and Internet services. But last month, the company fell victim to skyrocketing power prices and supply shortages in California and stopped offering all of its services everywhere. Jayson Blair

title: DEBT CONFLICT IN ECUADOR
description: The Paris Club of creditor countries has suspended debt negotiations with Ecuador's government because of the failure of Congress to approve tax revisions, giving the creditors the right to demand immediate reimbursement for interest payments that have been suspended since 1995, Finance Ministry officials said. The legislature's refusal to ratify a highly unpopular increase of 3 percent in the value-added tax also brings Ecuador close to violating a restructuring agreement it signed with the International Monetary Fund. Larry Rohter

title: A Team From Yale Shows Market Agility
description: A team of five students from the Yale University School of Management has won first prize in a competition that required them to decide where to invest after hearing proposals from five real-life technology start-ups. The team had to defend its selections, which were evaluated by partners from venture capital firms. The Yale students beat contenders from 31 other business schools in the contest, held at the University of North Carolina last weekend. The winning students -- Cebra Graves of Brooklyn, Andrea Goldman of New York, Claire Hughes of Boston, Eugene Podkaminer of San Francisco and Oded Sten of Tel Aviv -- will split $10,000 and share a trophy. It is the first time that a team from Yale competed in the contest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORCHARD, HELEN MARSHALL
description: BORCHARD - Helen Marshall. April 2, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Bernard P. Borchard; devoted mother of William M. Borchard and his wife Myra; cherished grandmother of Jillian and Thomas; loving sister of the late Madelaine Simon. She was always ahead of her time. She was a woman's suffragette as a teenager, introduced women's golf tournaments to her country club, was a children's entertainer performing at the White House and formed a children's summer theater program at the 92nd St Y, where she and her mother served as Directors for a period spanning 80 years. Her interest in childen also led her to be a founding director of Eisman Day Nursery and of SCAN New York. Her greatest joys were her husband and her son. Contributions in her memory may be made to the 92nd St Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Assn, 1395 Lexington Ave, NY NY 10128. Service Friday, April 6, 2001, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St.

title: MATTEL TO LAY OFF 980 WORKERS AND CLOSE A PLANT
description: Mattel Inc. will close its last United States manufacturing plant and lay off 980 workers to cut costs, the company said yesterday. The plant, in Murray, Ky., makes Fisher-Price toys. It will be shut down over the next 18 to 24 months, a spokeswoman, Lisa Marie Bongiovanni, said. Production will be moved to Mexico.

title: NASA May Recast Space Station to Cut Costs
description: The International Space Station should be able to fulfill many of its objectives despite a projected $4 billion cost overrun that would force the United States to scale back some of its planned contributions to the project, the NASA administrator, Daniel S. Goldin, said today.

title: Clemens Gets More Rest For His Bruised Arm
description: Roger Clemens will be pushed back one day in the rotation so that he can rest a bruised lower right forearm that he incurred during the season opener. Clemens was injured when Carlos Febles smashed a one-hopper that hit between the pitcher's wrist and forearm in the eighth inning of the Yankees' 7-3 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

title: 3 Companies Will Try to Identify All Human Proteins
description: Three companies announced yesterday that they would jointly undertake a project that could make the sequencing of the human genome look easy by comparison. They will spend up to half a billion dollars to identify all the proteins in the human body and all the interactions between those proteins.

title: Governor to Speak on Crisis
description: Gov. Gray Davis of California asked television stations statewide for five minutes in their evening news programs Thursday for what his office called an important announcement about the state's energy crisis. The governor's aides said that major stations in the state were granting his request to speak at 6:05 p.m., the first time since 1992 that a California governor has sought such access.

title: SEARCH PROVIDER FOR NBCI AND EXPLORER
description: GoTo.com, an Internet search service, announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement with NBCi and renewed a deal with Microsoft to provide pay-for-placement search results for the two companies. Under the NBCi agreement, which will last two years, GoTo will provide sponsored search results to the 15 million users of NBCi Web sites. The Microsoft deal, originally signed in January of last year, offers sponsored results to those who use the search button on the Internet Explorer Web browser. GoTo, based in Pasadena, Calif., says it has more than 40,000 advertisers. It surprised analysts last month when it said its earnings would beat Wall Street expectations. Andrew Zipern

title: Accepting the Sea's Risk Doesn't Ease the Pain of Losses

Nearly every year, usually in twos and threes, young men from the Seattle fleet die in the Pacific Ocean: 634 in the last century, 85 in the last decade.

The first was caused by a Baltimore Gas & Electric feeder line at Camden Yards; Hideo Nomo caused the second, holding the Orioles without a hit last night on the earliest calendar date in history that a no-hitter has ever been pitched.

description: The number of unemployed Germans increased by 12,000 in March, to a seasonally adjusted 3.8 million. The unemployment rate remained unchanged at a seasonally adjusted 9.3 percent. Because a decline in the jobless rate was forecast, the increase for the third consecutive month was unexpected. The Federal Labor Office said the continued increase reflected not only the unusually bad weather but also the impact of a slowdown in economic growth. Petra Kappl

Last fall, the company released a hybrid version of its popular I-Zone camera called the I-zone Digital and Instant Combo Camera, which produced both digital and film-based photos. In April, Polaroid will release the PDC 640 Modem Camera, which draws a direct line between the camera and the Internet, cutting out the PC in the middle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, ESTHER
description: SMITH-Esther, 77. Died on April 4 after a long and valiant fight with cancer. Lifetime fighter for social justice, Yiddish Scholar, Union Organizer, leader in Stuyvesant Town anti-discrimination fight, V.P. Women's Division American Jewish Congress, Director Medical Committee for Human Rights (medical arm civil rights movement), Director Committee of Responsibility (providing medical care for war injured Vietnamese children) Assistant to President, Health and Hospital Corporation, Activist in Democratic Party, member Democratic National Committee, Associate Director Post Graduate Center for Mental Health, founding member U.S./Israel Women to Women. Daughter of Isadore and Rose Frank (deceased). Esther's spirit will be treasured in the love of her: husband for 57 years David Smith, her sister Eleanor Tilson, her daughters Karen and Abby, grandson Jesse, granddaughter Sonja, son-in-law Maarten, and nephews Mark, Andrew & Daniel. Esther's example of leadership made her an early feminist role model. Her courage and tenacity to stand firmly for social justice will remain as her inspirational legacy. A memorial will be held in the near future.

description: On selected flights from April 15 to June 30, AeroMexico Vacations will upgrade travelers to its business first class, and throw in a room upgrade, too. The Ultimate Upgrade Promotion requires that bookings be made with a MasterCard by June 24, on flights between Atlanta and Cozumel or Merida; New York and Cancun, San Diego to Los Cabos, Los Angeles to Puerta Vallarta and Miami to Cancun. For Atlanta departures, for example, a four-night stay at the Coral Princess in a one-bedroom suite is $619 a person, based on double occupancy (Sunday to Wednesday departures). For New York to Cancun, the package prices include $854 a person, double, for five nights at the Presidente Inter-Continental, in an oceanview room (Sunday departures only). The packages from Los Angeles to Puerto Vallarta include $900 a person, double, for four nights at the all-inclusive Solare Resort Vallarta Sunset Bay, in a standard villa with a shared pool (Sunday to Wednesday departures). Information: (800) 245-8585 or www.aeromexicovacations.com . Packages are not available May 25 to 28.

description: Korean economic policy makers today prescribed a huge dose of government money to brace a stock market that has declined to its lowest level since the economic crisis that swept Asia in 1997-98.

title: In the Desert's Warm Embrace
description: IT is amazing how many water-loving palm trees and petunias are still forced to grow in central Arizona, where temperatures commonly reach 110 degrees. But here and there, in the sprawling suburbs that have eaten up almost 500 square miles of desert, a growing number of designers are building houses and gardens that fit the arid landscape.

title: Corrections

title: YAHOO AND SAP FORM WEB SITE VENTURE

The alliance is intended to combine the marketing reach of the two companies in the highly competitive field of designing gateways to corporate Web sites. Such portals are intended to help customers, investors and employees gain access to information and corporate computer applications linked to the site. Barnaby J. Feder

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, JOHN
description: LEWIS-John. The House of Steinway & Sons is profoundly saddened by the passing of its beloved friend and devoted Steinway Artist John Lewis, on March 29 at the age of 80. As pianist, composer, arranger, and as the musical director of the famed Modern Jazz Quartet, Mr. Lewis was an artist of exceptional creativity and taste. The public was blessed by his long and illustrious career, and his affiliation with our firm for more than four decades is treasured. His music and his acclaimed discography will keep his legacy alive for future generations. All who knew John Lewis will cherish his grace and humility, rare personal qualities in so distinguished an artist. To his wife, Mirjana, his children and his family we extend our heartfelt condolences. His loss is deeply felt. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P., Worldwide Concert & Artist Activities

description: Stocks continued to struggle yesterday after two days of heavy losses as concern about corporate earnings dominated the market.

title: SUPERVALU CUTS JOBS AND TAKES A CHARGE TO EARNINGS
description: Supervalu Inc., a food distribution and supermarket company, said yesterday that it would cut 4,500 jobs, or 7.3 percent of its work force, as it consolidates distribution centers and leaves some retail markets. The company took a charge of $153.9 million, or $1.16 a share, against earnings in the quarter that ended Feb. 24 to reflect the moves, Supervalu said. The revamping follows the loss of a food-distribution contract with Kmart that is expected to reduce revenue this year by $1.7 billion and per-share profit by 18 cents to 22 cents a share, the company said. Supervalu, based in Eden Prairie, Minn., also released results for the period, the fourth quarter of its fiscal year, and said it lost $93 million, in contrast to a profit of $72 million a year earlier.

title: Counties Can't Account For All Ballots Reported in 2000
description: The examination of disputed Florida presidential ballots reported today by The Miami Herald and USA Today demonstrated not only how difficult it is to count ballots with ambiguous markings. It also showed how hard it is to find the ballots that produced the Florida postelection chaos.

title: Translation: 'The How-To Book of Terrorism'
description: When testimony in the embassy bombings trial showed that three men had based their surveillance of the American Embassy in Kenya from an improvised darkroom in a cramped Nairobi apartment, it sounded like something taken from a manual called Terrorism 101.

title: CURRENTS: SPANISH ARTS COMPLEX; If It Worked in Bilbao, Why Not Try It in Galicia
description: Bilbao envy? Don't suggest that to Manuel Fraga, the president of the Galicia region of northwest Spain. On Tuesday at the Spanish Institute in New York City, Mr. Fraga unveiled his ambitious plans for an arts complex called the City of Culture of Galicia. He wants the project, designed by Eisenman Architects of Manhattan, to aid tourism in the town of Santiago de Compostela. Bilbao, 300 miles east, transformed itself in 1997 with Frank Gehry's $100 million Guggenheim Museum. For $125 million, Mr. Fraga is planning six buildings (the first is scheduled to open in 2003), including a museum of Galician history, a technology center and a 1,500-seat music theater. ''It's like creating a jazz sextet where different instruments play together,'' Peter Eisenman, the project's architect, said. Above, an interior perspective of the theater; below, a lobby rendering. RAUL A. BARRENECHE

title: Beijing Steps Up Its War of Words Over Air Collision
description: BEIJING, April 4  China hardened its position today on the midair collision of an American spy plane and a Chinese jet, with President Jiang Zemin personally insisting that China receive an official apology and the country's foreign minister accusing the United States of being wrong-headed and "arrogant."

title: MIXED OUTCOME IN AUTISM DRUG TRIAL
description: The Repligen Corporation reported mixed results yesterday from a clinical trial of secretin, a potential treatment for autism, in 136 young children. When the children were evaluated by their parents, those who took the drug showed a statistically significant improvement, compared with children who got a placebo. But when the evaluation was done by psychologists, there was no significant difference between the two groups. Repligen, based in Needham, Mass., characterized the results as positive, but its stock lost about a third of its value, falling 81 cents to $1.84. The trial was being closely watched because Secretin has received substantial media attention after some parents said the drug led to improvements in their children. Andrew Pollack

title: Trinh Cong Son, 62; Stirred Vietnam With War Protest Songs
description: Trinh Cong Son, an antiwar singer and songwriter whose melancholy music stirred Vietnamese on both sides of the war, died on Sunday and was buried today at a Buddhist temple near Ho Chi Minh City. He was 62.

title: Both a Nation and a Novelist Getting Too Little Sunshine
description: Shot in deep, sad black-and-white, Oskar Roehler's ''No Place to Go'' is a study in minutely contrasting shades of gray -- visual, moral and psychological. The film covers the euphoric revolutionary days of November 1989 like a damp blanket, showing us the unraveling of East Germany through the eyes of one of its West German sympathizers, a novelist named Hanna Flanders (Hannelore Elsner), whose own collapse is at the film's dramatic center. Though its context and some of its interest is political, the movie is motivated by something deeper and murkier than ideology. Hanna Flanders is explicitly based on Mr. Roehler's own mother, the West German writer Gisela Elsner.

title: INTERACTIVE ADS TAKE ON SUBSTANCE ABUSE
description: The Partnership for a Drug-Free America in New York has introduced its first entirely interactive ad campaign to help teenagers learn about the physiological effects of drugs like cocaine and heroin. The banner ads, created by i-traffic in New York, the interactive marketing division of Agency.com, make use of vivid images to convey the unpleasant consequences of drug use. ''The shock value is critical to break through the clutter that's out there,'' said Bea Bartolotta, deputy director for creative development at the antidrug group. ''This is a really skeptical audience.'' A goal of the banner ads, she added, is to encourage viewers to use the option to forward them to friends and to click on links to the group's Web site for more detailed information about drugs. The ads were initially placed on Web sites like StudentAdvantage.com and CollegeClub.com. Allison Fass

description: The Bush administration has proposed dropping testing for salmonella in ground beef for the federal school-lunch program and letting schools serve beef that has been irradiated, a procedure that kills salmonella and all other harmful bacteria but is mistrusted by many consumers.

title: BUSH'S TAX PLAN GETS LIFT IN HOUSE, BUT SENATE BALKS
description: The House of Representatives voted today to repeal the estate tax, a big item in President Bush's tax plan, but in the Senate the president's proposal for $1.6 trillion in tax cuts over 10 years appeared to be in jeopardy.

title: Boy, 13, Arrested After Taking Stun Gun to School
description: A 13-year-old Queens boy was arrested yesterday after he took a stun gun to school, the police said. Apparently unaware of its danger, investigators said, the boy and several friends used it on each other, and four received minor burns.

title: A Bubble Overhead, a Splashy Ball Below
description: As predictably as daffodils come up every year, bowling makes comeback after comeback. To hold an overflow crowd, Tom Shannon, who renovated Bowlmor Lanes in Greenwich Village in 1997, has opened Pressure, below, a 16,000-square-foot lounge in a tennis bubble on the roof of the Bowlmor building (110 University Place; 212-352-1161). It was designed by Office for Global Architecture in Manhattan as a place to dance, watch old movies, shoot billiards and wait for lanes to open. Beepers alert bowlers when lanes are available. To turn heads in Pressure, bring a Brunswick Viz-a-Ball; there are 20 designs, including the fish, above; $130, without drilled holes, at www.viz-a-ball.com. Soon, customers can send in an image and have it turned into a ball. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Galleries for the Mind and Body
description: Richard Gluckman, a partner at Gluckman Mayner Architects in Manhattan, knew how to design museums -- his portfolio includes the Georgia O'Keeffe Museum in Santa Fe and the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh. But he had an outdated notion of what a spa was -- ''a place in Clearwater, Fla.,'' he said, ''an old building with hot baths and older people trying to lose weight.'' So when he was asked to design Mii Amo, a spa for the Enchantment Resort in Sedona, Ariz., he translated what he knew about contemplative art galleries into meditative spaces for the spa. Mii Amo (pronounced me-AH-moe) is the Yuman term for passage or journey. The spa caters to affluent visitors in their 40's.

title: Facing Justice and Pettitte Isn't Child's Play
description: Imagine being Blake Stein for the last few days. You leave New York on Monday afternoon when you learn that your wife is about to give birth. You witness the birth of your daughter in Kansas City that night and hustle back to be with the Royals yesterday. You return about five hours before starting against the three-time defending World Series champions at historic Yankee Stadium, where you have actually pitched two of the best games of a modest career.

description: DaimlerChrysler A.G., Fiat S.p.A. and other carmakers that sponsor Formula One teams said today that they would set up an alternative to the motor races because their new owner plans to move some events to pay television.

As the pilot struggled with his controls, radio operators began sending coded messages back to base reporting a possible confrontation. Partway through the second message, the transmission stopped. Minutes later the aircraft crashed into the East China Sea, killing all 16 crewmen. The date was Aug. 23, 1956.

description: The two American literary prizes that have the most prestige are the Pulitzer Prize and the National Book Award. Since few writers, no matter how talented, ever get the distinction and psychic lift of being a contender for one or both, it's probably not overstating it to say that for the author it borders on tragedy for a book worthy of consideration not to get it because its publisher forgot to submit it. That has happened before, and now it has happened again.

title: EUROPEAN PRODUCER PRICES
description: Industrial producer prices in the 12-nation euro zone rose 0.2 percent in February from the previous month, Eurostat, the European Union's statistical office, said. The rise was in line with analysts' expectations. Prices of nondurable consumer goods had the largest monthly rise at 0.5 percent, durable goods prices rose 0.3 percent, and capital goods increased 0.2 percent. But the prices of intermediate goods remained flat at January's level. Paul Meller

title: Diversity and the Police
description: After more than three decades of effort to diversify its ranks, the New York City Police Department still has only a handful of black male senior officers and too few black men overall. The department's failure to produce a force that better reflects the diversity of the city's population is both a cause and a consequence of its strained relationship with the city's black community. The department needs to expand its recruiting of black candidates dramatically, and the city itself needs to re-evaluate the obsolete Civil Service rules that have stymied black advancement in the department.

title: Escaping Hong Kong's Streets, Aided by an 8-Year-Old
description: Don't dismiss ''Durian Durian'' as a feature film biography of a British pop band, although the writer/director's unlikely name, Fruit Chan, sounds like the title of a Duran Duran song. This delicate film, to be shown tonight at 9 and Saturday at 6 p.m. as part of the New Directors/ New Films festival, is broken into two parts. It follows the path of a young woman, Yan (Qin Hailu), as she struggles in a dirty precinct of Hong Kong and her reimmersion into family life after she abandons the world of prostitution in the city. Mr. Chan shows us Yan's world through the eyes of an 8-year-old named Fan (Mak Wai Fan).

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET SEARCH PROVIDER FOR NBCI AND EXPLORER GoTo.com , an Internet search service, announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement with NBCi and renewed a deal with Microsoft to provide pay-for-placement search results for the two companies. Under the NBCi agreement, which will last two years, GoTo will provide sponsored search results to the 15 million users of NBCi Web sites. The Microsoft deal, originally signed in January of last year, offers sponsored results to those who use the search button on the Internet Explorer Web browser. GoTo, based in Pasadena, Calif., says it has more than 40,000 advertisers. It surprised analysts last month when it said its earnings would beat Wall Street expectations. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

description: People loved New York long before the television jingle made the phrase popular. The New York State Museum in Albany covers the state's geological, biological, anthropological and human history. Curators and researchers have gathered together more than five million artifacts and specimens, including a collection of 170 bird species, photographs of 1920's Harlem, a life-size recreation of an Iroquois longhouse, horse-drawn vehicles and cloth dolls.

Whether the sites are animated American Sign Language dictionaries, information and debates on signing and the role of hearing devices, medical primers, or soapboxes to vent anger over societal attitudes, there is hardly a page intended for deaf people that is not an eye-opener for everyone.

title: ROCKWELL TO STOP NEWS CORPORATION VENTURE
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said yesterday that it would stop investing in the company's In-Flight Network joint venture with the News Corporation because no airlines have signed up for the service, which provides live television and Internet access. Rockwell, which makes automated controls and aerospace equipment, will take a $16 million charge in the fiscal second quarter to write off its investment, a spokesman, Don McGrath, said. News Corporation pledged to invest hundreds of millions of dollars in the venture when it was formed last year. Rivals for in-flight entertainment business like the Boeing Company have also been slow in signing up customers because airlines are demanding greater control over revenue.

title: An Electronic Swirl for a Claustrophobic Labyrinth

Yet in between, rather than offering a linear narrative, the book traps K. inside a repetitious circle of bureaucratic and legalistic absurdities. As a metaphor for the surrealism of the totalitarian state, ''The Trial'' is hard to beat. But as the framework for an opera it poses special problems.

title: A Hidden Bombay in Brooklyn
description: Hidden behind an unmarked door, a 2,000-square-foot loft space in a warehouse in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn contains hundreds of pieces of Anglo-Raj-style furniture. It is known to those in the decorating trade, but not to other shoppers: there is no sign on the door. But by appointment, Sanyu Desai, left, is happy to sell to anyone. There are antiques as well as reproductions made of wood -- rosewood, teak and mahogany -- reclaimed from vintage furniture. Mother-of-pearl inlaid armchairs start at $475, rosewood dining chairs with hand-caned seats from $675. English sofas, in distressed leather, start at $3,200; two 19th-century wood columns are $1,800. The antique rosewood folding chair that Mrs. Desi is sitting on is $2,200. Mrs. Desai will drive you to the warehouse from her lighting shop, Lumiere, at 315 East 84th Street; (212) 535-6111. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Hold That Floor for Evidence!
description: While renovators rip out the linoleum, historians are reconstructing its history. ''Linoleum: History, Design, Architecture, 1882-2000'' ($45; Hatje Cantz) is largely drawn from the archives of Armstrong DLW in Germany, where linoleum was showcased by Modernist architects like Mies van der Rohe in the 1920's. Walter Gropius called linoleum -- a cork, jute and oxidized linseed-oil product patented in England in 1863 -- a ''perfect floor covering.'' In many ways, it still is. (Advertising brochures from the 1920's, right, and a 1955 floor design, above.) Linoleum is inexpensive, simple to lay, decorative and easy to clean. And it pools blood neatly. Agatha Christie installed it to puddle a nice piece of evidence for Poirot, her police inspector, in ''One, Two, Buckle My Shoe'' (1940), passages from which are included in ''Linoleum.'' WILLIAM L. title: The Rural Life; Gravel Chutney
description: Let me summarize the situation. Daylight saving time has begun. Snow lies 20 inches deep in the upper vegetable garden, 22 inches deep in the lower one. The southern slope of the pasture, bare for a few hours two weeks ago, is covered in snow. Everything is covered in snow except the road, which on good days dries from mulligatawny to gravel chutney. Last week three inches of slush fell -- as slush -- and it has managed to remain slush ever since. The sun has gone down the woodchuck hole in the high bank by the side of the road and refuses to come out. There's more light at the end of the day now, but that's not where we need it. We need it in the middle.

What's great fun about the film is that it is like a peek behind the Great Oz's curtain. And surprise! He's back there cackling up a storm. Actually, there are two of them: Dan Sonney and David Friedman, the pioneering hustlers who gleefully fleeced the moviegoing public from the 1930's through the 60's. These venerated scamsters are part of the American tradition of turning the forbidden into a three-ring circus and profit center.

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET CYBERSQUATTING DRAWS HEAVY PENALTY Adding another chapter to a two-year-old legal battle, a federal judge has ordered a Web pornographer to pay $65 million in damages to the rightful owner of a domain name that is used to operate a sex Web site. Judge James Ware of United States District Court in San Jose, Calif., ruled that Stephen Cohen used fraud when he took over use of the domain name www.sex.com five years ago. Since then, Mr. Cohen has built sex.com into a thriving pornography business. Gary Kremen, the Internet entrepreneur who filed the lawsuit against Mr. Cohen, said that he had been granted use of the domain name in 1994 and that Mr. Cohen had usurped it by forging a letter to Network Solutions , which grants the rights to domain name. The award is considered the largest ever in a cybersquatting case. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: GENERAL MOTORS RECALLS 6,000 MIDSIZE SPORT UTILITIES
description: General Motors said yesterday that it was recalling about 6,000 of its 2002 midsize sport utilities because of a faulty suspension part. The company has idled an Ohio plant that makes the vehicles until April 16 to resolve the problem, affecting about 2,500 of the 3,900 workers there. The company has produced about 30,000 of the redesigned Chevrolet Trailblazer, GMC Envoy and Oldsmobile Bravada sport utilities and is recalling those that had been sold, said a spokesman, Dan Flores. The recall was prompted by a part in the suspension that was not made to specifications, Mr. Flores said. The part came from an outside supplier, which G.M. would not identify. No accidents or injuries have been reported as a result of the problem, Mr. Flores said.

title: Florida's Unchanging Lessons
description: Supporters of George W. Bush were heartened this week by the results of an initial newspaper examination of the roughly 60,000 Florida ballots that failed to register a vote for president last November. The review by The Miami Herald and USA Today of ballots still available indicated that Mr. Bush would have emerged the winner under most standards of counting, if the United States Supreme Court had allowed the recount to go forward. A comprehensive examination of ballots statewide is also being conducted by a consortium of The New York Times and seven other news organizations, and it is not yet known if its results will mirror or differ from those reported this week. Both journalistic groups are also looking at an even larger group of ballots -- about 110,000 -- that were rejected because they bore markings for more than one presidential candidate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLWELL, PAMELA MEREDYTH
description: COLWELL - Pamela Meredyth. Died peacefully on April 4, 2001 in Manchester, Massachusetts at the age of 94. She was predeceased by her husbands Lt. Gordon Calthrop Thorne, DSO of England and Kent Galbraith Colwell of Morristown, New Jersey. She is survived by a daughter, Jennifer C. Hayden and her Husband Malcolm of Harpswell, Maine and a son Frederick G.P. Thorne and his wife Susan of Manchester, Massachusetts. She is also survived by a stepdaughter Ann Catherine Menniger of Franconia, New Hampshire and a stepson David Galbraith Colwell and his wife Edna of Fallsbrook, Calfornia. She is also survived by her former daughter-in-law Phoebe T. Colwell of Nyack, New York. She leaves 14 grandchildren and 17 great-grandchildren. Pamela Colwell was born in London, England, the daughter of Grace Potter Grant and Captain Stuart Colquhoun Grant. Her first husband, Lt. Col. Gordon C. Thorne, was killed during World War II. In 19 she married Kent G. Colwell of Morristown, New Jersey. She was in active numerous community affairs including the Morristown Memorial Hospital, The Mount Kemble Home, The Episcopal Diocese of Newark, The Victoria Home and the Daughters of the British Empire. She was an honorary member of the Princeton University Class of 1917. She was a woman of conviction, courage and wit. A marvelous communicator, she skillfully held a large family together with love, warmth, and understanding. She was a woman deeply loved by her family and friends and will be missed. A memorial service will be held on April 17, 2001 at 11:00AM at Emmanuel Church, Manchester, Massachusetts. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be sent to the Victoria Home for Retired Men & Women, North Malcolm Street, Ossining, new York. 10562; Morristown Memorial Hospital, Madison Avenue, Morristown, New Jersey 07960; or the Quebec Labrador Foundation, Main Street, Ipswich, Massachusetts 01938.

title: PHONE DIRECTORY FOR SALE

Any divestiture would hinge on a report being prepared by British regulators as to whether Yell enjoys unfair dominance in the directories market. British Telecom declined to comment. title: When Movies Fomented a Cultural Revolution

In a voice over narration that opens the movie and recurs twice, Howie lists some of the highway's victims: the singer-songwriter Harry Chapin, the filmmaker Alan J. Pakula and his own mother, who died in a car crash on Exit 52. ''It's taken a lot of people,'' Howie says, ''and I hope it doesn't get me.''

title: Disney Cruise Line

Children ages 3 to 12 can travel as third and fourth passengers in a cabin for rates starting at $399. There are two different seven-night packages available: a combination cruise on the Disney Wonder and visit to Walt Disney World, or cruise-only through the eastern Caribbean on the Disney Magic. The dates available are Aug. 30 through Dec. 13 (except for two dates in mid-November) on the Disney Wonder and Sept. 1 to Dec. 15 (except for the Nov. 17 sailing) on the Disney Magic. Cruises must be booked by June 30; rates are subject to availability and do not include taxes and some other charges. Information: (888) DCL-2500 or www.disneycruise.com .

title: PRUDENTIAL SAYS IT WON'T RAISE AMERICAN GENERAL BID
description: Jonathan Bloomer, the chief executive of Prudential of Britain, said yesterday that the company would not raise its $20 billion bid for the American General Corporation after the American International Group topped the offer two days ago. ''We've said all along that we've got a deal, and it's strategically a very sensible deal,'' Mr. Bloomer said. ''We've agreed on it, and that's the way it's going to stay.'' A.I.G., the world's biggest insurance company, offered $23 billion, or $46 a share, for American General.

title: BIBLIOFIND HEADED FOR AMAZON FOLD
description: Bibliofind, an online service for finding used, rare and out-of-print books, said that after May 7 visitors to its Web site would be transferred to Amazon.com. Bibliofind was acquired by Amazon in April 1999 but has continued to operate independently. Last month, Bibliofind took part of its service offline after disclosing a four-month hackers' spree that left 98,000 user names, addresses and credit card numbers exposed. In a letter to customers, the company said that it would not transfer any personal information to Amazon.com. Last month Jeffrey P. Bezos, the chairman of Amazon, above, said that Amazon would have its first operating profit by year-end.

description: Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman has disavowed a departmental proposal to eliminate testing for salmonella in ground beef for the federal school lunch program.

title: The Mountain Had Other Plans
description: It was the last race of the season, and in the start house at Montana's Big Mountain Resort two weeks ago stood Bill Johnson, desperate for a top-five finish. In the sixth month of an improbable ski racing comeback at age 40, Johnson -- the brazen, boastful Olympic downhill champion of the 1984 Sarajevo Games -- needed to get the attention of American coaches to have any hope of making it to the 2002 Olympics.

title: L'OREAL'S SALES ARE UP
description: L'Oreal S.A. said its firstquarter sales rose 13 percent after adding its first Japanese brand and several new lines in the United States. L'Oreal, which makes Maybelline and Lancme cosmetics said sales grew to 3.4 billion euros ($3.1 billion) in the quarter from 3.02 billion euros in the period a year earlier. The company, based in France, has added brands like Dark & Lovely, Opticurl and Kiehl's in North America, Ylang in Latin America and Shu Uemura in Japan. L'Oreal spent $1 billion on acquisitions last year.

title: NO SLOWDOWN IN EUROPE
description: The economies of the 12 nations adopting the euro currency are still growing moderately, not slowing down, according to new figures from Eurostat. Retail sales rose 2.3 percent in January from a year earlier, an increase from the 1.7 percent annual rate recorded in December; sales of household goods were especially strong. Revised fourth-quarter gross domestic product figures put overall growth at 0.7 percent from the previous quarter, well ahead of the United States, and 3 percent for the year.

title: Long After Napoleon's Conquests, a Tale of Intrigue Leads to Court
description: In 1814, Napoleon I and the allies who had defeated his armies -- Frederick William III of Prussia, Francis I of Austria and Alexander I of Russia -- signed the Treaty of Fontainebleau. Under its terms, Bonaparte abdicated, renounced his claim to conquered lands and was sent into exile on the tiny island of Elba.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAFER, DR. DONALD.
description: SHAFER-Dr. Donald. The Board of Directors and Medical Staff of Manhattan Eye, Ear & Throat Hospital express deep sorrow at the passing of Donald Shafer, MD. Dr. Shafer, an esteemed member of our medical staff since 1948 and Surgeon Director Emeritus, served with great distinction as Chairman of the Department of Ophthalmology from 1973-77. A pioneer in the field of Vitreo Retinal surgery, a respected teacher, researcher and staunch patient advocate, he was dedicated to the highest standards of medicine. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. James S. Marcus, Chairman Board of Trustees Philip P. Rosenthal, Executive Director Steven Fochios, President Board of Surgeon Directors Jack M. Dodick, Chairman Dept of Ophthalmology

title: 2 Accused of Fraud Using Shell Companies
description: Chipping away at the wall of secrecy surrounding the operations of offshore banks, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, announced the indictment yesterday of two prominent lawyers on charges that they helped orchestrate an international stock fraud operating in New York and Britain.

title: IDEX SAYS IT WILL CUT 250 JOBS AND COMBINE TWO PLANTS
description: The Idex Corporation, a maker of pumps and dispensing equipment, said yesterday that it would cut about 250 jobs, or 6 percent of its work force, and combine two production plants in Michigan. Idex said the moves would result in a charge of $5.5 million, or 11 cents a share. The company, based in Northbrook, Ill., said reduced demand in manufacturing had hurt sales. Savings from the cost-cutting measures are expected to exceed the charge, Idex said.

title: U.S. and China Using Letters to Come to Agreement
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  President Bush and President Jiang Zemin of China are exchanging drafts of a letter that would express regrets for last Sunday's aircraft collision, establish an investigatory body and pave the way toward release of the 24 Americans held in China, administration officials and a senior Senator said today.

title: BOOK SELLER TAKES CONTROL OF ENEWS
description: Barnesandnoble.com and its parent company, Barnes & Noble, said they had acquired a majority stake in enews, an online magazine subscription retailer. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. The companies said they hoped to raise Web and retail sales of magazines. Barnesandnoble.com has owned part of enews since December 1999. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: AVENTIS CROPSCIENCE DECISION PLANNED
description: The French-German pharmaceuticals group Aventis S.A. said it would decide by July on either taking the agrochemicals unit Aventis CropScience public or selling it. Schering A.G., which holds a 24 percent stake in the unit, could block either decision and has said it will not approve a deal at the current low market valuations. According to a German newspaper, Schering would be demanding 2 billion euros. Aventis confirmed having sent sale proposals to the United States companies Monsanto, DuPont and Dow Chemical, and the German companies Bayer and BASF. After having expressed interest in parts of the unit, Bayer said yesterday that it was considering buying the whole unit. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Theodore Gottlieb, Dark Comedian, Dies at 94
description: Theodore Gottlieb, who as Brother Theodore performed apocalyptic one-man shows about life, death and broccoli in Greenwich Village nightclubs to dazzling and disturbing effect, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 94.

title: In New Campaign Attack, DiFrancesco Releases Old News to Try to Hit Rival With Tar
description: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco took his revenge on his Republican opponent for governor today by releasing a sheaf of court records and newspaper stories, most of them old and well known, outlining crimes and misdeeds of people connected to Mayor Bret Schundler's Jersey City government.

title: U.S. Treasury: No Lending; With Big Budget Surpluses, Some See The End of New Bonds and Notes
description: A world without a Treasury market? That was unimaginable a few years ago, when budget deficits stretched as far as the eye could see. But with a rising government surplus, the unthinkable no longer seems beyond the pale.

title: JURY RULES IN FORD'S FAVOR IN SUIT OVER SPORT UTILITY
description: A Texas jury has exonerated Ford Motor of liability in a $50 million wrongful death claim involving an Explorer sport utility vehicle. It was the first Explorer defective-design case to go to trial, a Ford spokeswoman, Kathleen Vokes, said. The verdict was issued late Wednesday. Ford faces about 200 product-liability cases, many involving Explorer rollovers that occurred after Firestone tires failed. In the Texas case, Nathan Maier, a 47-year-old engineer who drove a 1995 Ford Explorer, died in a 1997 multiple-car accident outside Dallas. His family sued Ford in state court, contending that Ford knew it was selling a sport utility vehicle with a defective design and ignored its own engineers' recommendations to reduce rollover risks.

title: On the Net, Baseball Takes a Swing and Misses
description: The second life of www.mlb.com -- Major League Baseball's World Wide Web site -- was not supposed to begin this badly.

title: In Suffolk, Bill for Day Laborer Center Is Vetoed
description: After two Mexican day laborers were badly beaten in Suffolk County in September, the region's long-simmering racial tensions were laid bare -- residents waving American flags clashed with brown-skinned immigrants, and a county legislator, Brian X. Foley, wrote a bill to try to bridge the divide.

title: In Bush Stronghold, Tax Plan Helps Few
description: Carrie Villa of Helena., Mont., has a dream -- a house of her own on a nearby mountain.

title: March Unemployment Rate Rises, Driven by Job Cuts
description: Businesses lost 86,000 jobs last month in the largest such reduction in nearly a decade and the unemployment rate crept up a notch, the Labor Department said today, providing further signs of weakness in the economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALMY, RICHARD, JR.
description: ALMY-Richard, Jr. Age 68. Of South Dartmouth, MA. on April 3, 2001, at home after a courageous struggle with prostate cancer. Beloved husband of Anne Taylor Almy. Devoted father of Richard T. Almy of Old Greenwich, CT., Heather L. Almy of Norwalk, CT. & Gretchen H. Almy of Middleboro, MA. Also survived by a sister, Caroline A. Gerry of Locust Valley, N.Y. & sister-in-law Mrs. David Almy of Hamilton, MA. Predeceased by his younger brother David Almy in 1996. Memorial services will be held Sunday, April 8th, 3 PM at the First Congregational Church of Greenwich, Old Greenwich, CT., and on Saturday, April 14th, 11 AM at the Congregational Church of South Dartmouth, Padanarum, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory for prostate cancer research to the Dana Farber Institute, 1309 Beacon St., Brookline, MA. 02446.
