title: BANK LOSSES EXPECTED
description: Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group, one of the four leading banking groups in Japan, announced that it planned to report an extensive loss for the year ending March 2001, reflecting a decision to write off bad loans and paper losses from its stock portfolio. The banking group said that Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, the leading institution within the group, was due to report a loss of 150 billion yen ($1.2 billion) instead of a profit of 90 billion yen. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Law School Wins Reprieve on Admission Policy
description: A federal appeals panel ruled yesterday that the University of Michigan's law school could continue using affirmative action in admissions pending the appeal of a lower court ruling last week that its policy illegally considers applicants' race.

title: Instant Inspiration: Just Add Water
description: THIS review ought to come with scent strips for sampling an array of fresh aquatic fragrances. Swiss Lake. Old Salt. Seascape Spray. River Bouquet. Eau de l'Eau. Or just take this paper down to the river and imagine some of the architectural visions that could take shape there. ''Architecture + Water,'' a new exhibition at the Van Alen Institute in Chelsea, presents five sparkling projects for sites related to water use. As New York lurches fitfully forward to a renewed waterfront, here are some alternatives to Chelsea Piers, retrograde esplanades and luxury housing by Richard Meier. These five visions are actually being built.

title: Court Gives Bhutto a Victory, Ordering Graft Case Retrial
description: NEW DELHI, April 6  Benazir Bhutto, twice elected Pakistan's prime minister and twice forced from office on corruption charges, won an important legal victory today. The Supreme Court in Islamabad set aside her conviction in a kickback scheme and ordered a retrial for both herself and her imprisoned husband.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNULTY, EDWARD C., D.M.D.
description: McNULTY-Edward C., D.M.D. With profound sorrow the faculty, students and staff of The New York University College of Dentistry record the sudden passing of our esteemed colleague, teacher and friend, Dr. Edward C. McNulty. A distinguished educator and clinician, Dr. McNulty served the NYU College of Dentistry as clinical professor and acting chairman of the Department of Orthodontics. He was admired by all who knew him, and will be deeply missed. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Lynn, and her entire family. Michael C. Alfano, D.M.D., Ph.D. Dean

title: Weaving an Intricate Web To Trap a Wily Kidnapper
description: ''I have never seen a man work so hard at being busy,'' Vickie (Anna Maria Horsford) says to Dr. Alex Cross (Morgan Freeman), the meticulous forensic psychologist slaving away at distracting himself in ''Along Came a Spider.'' Vickie's remark could serve as an assessment of this overplotted, hollow thriller, which crams in so much exposition that characters speak in fetid hunks for what seems like minutes at a time. And Vickie, a minor figure who has some unexplained relationship with Cross, disappears after delivering that line.

title: Metro Business Briefing; CO-OP VOTES TO EXTEND CONTRACT
description: Shareholders in Penn South, the nonprofit cooperative in Chelsea, voted by more than 2 to 1 on Wednesday to extend its contract with New York City until 2027, keeping favored tax treatment in return for forgoing profits on the resale of apartments. The nonbinding vote, a referendum conducted throughout the 10-building complex, was 1,466 in favor of the extension, the position favored by the co-op's board of directors, and 614 in favor of allowing shareholders to sell their apartments at market rates after the current contract expires in 2012. Edwin McDowell

title: SYCAMORE WARNS OF LOSS
description: The fiber optic equipment maker Sycamore Networks forecast a third-quarter loss on lower-than-expected sales and said it would cut 140 jobs, or about 13 percent of its work force. Excluding special items, the loss will be $38 million to $45 million, or 16 cents to 19 cents a share. Revenue in the period ending April 28 will be $50 million to $60 million, as little as one-third the previous quarter's sales. Sycamore will take a charge of $140 million to $150 million.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS UNIT TO ALTER CLAIM ABOUT INFANT FORMULA
description: The maker of Enfamil infant formula agreed yesterday to alter claims that its formula was more nutritious than a generic product after a federal judge ordered the company to remove promotional materials from pediatric offices. The company, Mead Johnson Nutritionals, a unit of Bristol-Myers Squibb, will revise the claims its sales representatives have been making to pediatricians since the end of January, said Peter J. Paradossi, a spokesman for Mead Johnson. The judge's order was a result of a lawsuit filed against Mead by a competitor, PBM Products, which distributes a generic infant formula. The Mead materials assert that a generic formula distributed by PBM falls short of recommended calcium levels. However, the PBM formula meets standards set by the Food and Drug Administration. Michael Brick (NYT)

title: U.P.S. SAYS IT PLANS TO PUT ASIAN CARGO HUB IN PHILIPPINES
description: United Parcel Service said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent with the Philippine government to put an Asian cargo hub in that nation. The company will create teams to look into air routes, aircraft and sites for the hub, United Parcel said. The company also said it would consider putting the center at Clark International Airport, a former United States Air Force base in Pampanga, Philippines. The planned hub would speed up deliveries within Asia and improve the reliability of the U.P.S. network as it expands international operations, the company said.

title: In California, Reversal on Energy Rates
description: Bowing to the inevitable, Gov. Gray Davis of California tonight dropped his longstanding opposition to higher electricity rates, proposing increases of up to 46 percent for the largest users and warning in a statewide televised speech that only aggressive conservation and increased generating capacity could solve the state's long-term energy problems.

title: MALAYSIAN DEBT WARNING
description: The rating agency Standard & Poor's lowered its outlook for Malaysia's long-term foreign currency debts, citing a growing budget deficit, declining foreign reserves and an uncertain political and economic future. The announcement intensified an already gloomy mood in Malaysia's stock market, where the benchmark index has fallen more than 8 percent this week. With other Asian currencies sliding in value, analysts fear that Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's insistence on pegging the Malaysian ringgit at 3.8 to the dollar will undermine exports. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Texas Nears Creation of State Public-Defender System
description: After months of intense national scrutiny of its treatment of criminal defendants, Texas is moving closer to creating its first statewide public-defender system.

Loving husband of the late Kathleen (nee McCabe). Dear father of Anne Thompson & her husband James. Beloved grandfather of Sean Patrick. Beloved brother of Mary Ellen (Judy) Stevens. Visiting Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 10-25 150th Street, Whitestone, NY, Sat & Sunday 2-5 & 7-10 PM. Mass at Holy Trinity RC Church, 14-51 143rd Street, Whitestone, NY, Monday 9:45 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to Holy Trinity RC Church may be made in his name.

title: DIFRANCESCO URGES JUSTICE TO RESIGN IN PROFILING FUROR
description: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco called today on Justice Peter G. Verniero to resign from the New Jersey Supreme Court, saying that even given ''every benefit of doubt,'' he misled the State Senate about racial profiling in his confirmation hearings two years ago. But Justice Verniero turned aside the request, as he has a growing number of calls for him to quit.

title: Marine Corps Report Links Fatal Osprey Crash to Software Malfunction
description: In its final report on the crash of a V-22 Osprey last December, the Marine Corps said today that malfunctioning software had caused the aircraft to swerve wildly out of control before plummeting to the ground and bursting into flames, killing all four marines on board.

title: CYBERSQUATTING DRAWS HEAVY PENALTY
description: Adding another chapter to a two-year-old legal battle, a federal judge has ordered a Web pornographer to pay $65 million in damages to the rightful owner of a domain name that is used to operate a sex Web site. Judge James Ware of United States District Court in San Jose, Calif., ruled that Stephen Cohen used fraud when he took over use of the domain name www.sex.com five years ago. Since then, Mr. Cohen has built sex.com into a thriving pornography business. Gary Kremen, the Internet entrepreneur who filed the lawsuit against Mr. Cohen, said that he had been granted use of the domain name in 1994 and that Mr. Cohen had usurped it by forging a letter to Network Solutions, which grants the rights to domain name. The award is considered the largest ever in a cybersquatting case.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: TOBACCO PAYMENT RISES New York State will receive $518 million this year as its annual payment from a 1998 settlement with tobacco companies, the state attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer, announced yesterday. Of this, New York City will receive $138 million, Nassau County $14 million, and Westchester County $10 million. The amount, $77 million more than last year's, is part of a settlement that requires tobacco companies to pay $206 billion to states and territories, with New York State receiving about $25 billion over the first 25 years. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Mori Says He Will Quit Before Party Elections
description: Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori told his cabinet today that he was preparing to resign later this month, before the scheduled date of elections to choose a new leader for the governing Liberal Democratic Party.

title: Dutch Farmers Facing Mass Foot-and-Mouth Slaughter
description: Jan Willem Horstmann spent the last 18 years grooming a line of breeding sheep that he sold to farmers for up to $2,000 a head. Today, he made preparations to slaughter them all.

title: CRITICAL PATH RESTATES RESULTS
description: Critical Path, the Internet messaging company that warned that there might be material misstatements in its recent revenue reports, said yesterday that its revised financial results for the third and fourth quarters were worse than feared. In its annual report, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Critical Path revised its revenue to $135.7 million from $155 million. Its annual loss, excluding special charges, was widened to $78.9 million, or $1.31 a share, from the $57.2 million, or 95 cents a share, originally reported. The company also took a $1.3 billion restructuring charge to reduce the value of its assets. Critical Path said some revenue from software licensing agreements should have been reported later or not at all. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: For Love of Ivy, And Civility
description: Perhaps the greatest pleasure Oxford University offers its many visitors is the hope, never disappointed, of unexpectedly coming upon an utterly disarming view or an exceptionally beautiful old building. While Yale University cannot match Oxford's antiquity, neither is it, at three centuries old this year, a parvenu.

description: MOAK-Arthur Allen. Died in his home in Kingston, New York, on Sunday, Mar. 25 after an extended illness. Originally from Brooklyn, New York, he was graduated from Cornell University, 1939 and is survived by his wife Blanche (Hertzfeld) whom he married in April of 1941, his daughter Patricia Ann (Pam), his son Jeffrey, five grand grandchildren & two great grandchildren, his brothers Lester of Chevy Chase, MD. and Stuart of Larchmont, NY. Services and cremation were held Tues, March 27.

title: Album of the Week: Daft Punk's 'Discovery'
description: DAFT PUNK: "Discovery" (Virgin). The French electronic invasion has slowly crept up on popular music over the last few years, and now we are in the midst of a full-scale onslaught, with recent releases by Mirwais, Benjamin Diamond and Daft Punk, soon to be followed by the new Air album and Etienne de Crecy's first album for V2 Records. On its first album, "Homework,' the French duo Daft Punk staked its claim as one of the best Chicago house bands not in Chicago. With its follow-up, "Discovery," the band members show they are not Chicago specialists but true generalists. Here, Daft Punk branches out into everything from pure club pop (a la "Music Sounds Better With You") to Jean-Michel Jarre new-age journeys to imitation heavy metal guitar solos to Kevin Saunderson-style Detroit techno.

Yes, Mr. Depp is a gifted actor, but his talent for dramatic understatement is sometimes overwhelmed by his sheer charisma. Though he makes even dull films watchable -- you can't take your eyes off him -- his enigmatic reserve can make everyone else look like a shameless ham.

title: MEDINOL ACCUSES BOSTON SCIENTIFIC OF THEFT AND FRAUD
description: Medinol Ltd., a supplier of stents used in artery-clearing angioplasties, sued the Boston Scientific Corporation yesterday, accusing it of stealing Medinol technology and of defrauding the federal government. Boston Scientific, a medical devices maker that markets Medinol's products, said the suit had no merit. Medinol, based in Tel Aviv, said that Boston Scientific set up a shell company to steal trade secrets, develop replacements for Medinol products and fraudulently obtain Food and Drug Administration approval. Boston Scientific has been trying to buy Medinol in a dispute over delays in developing stents. The delays caused Boston Scientific's market share in stents to drop to 17 percent last year from 30 percent in 1999.

title: FLAW IN TAX SOFTWARE UNCOVERED

The software saved the passwords onto the hard drives of computers of users who downloaded financial information from sites run by services providers like Fidelity Investments and Vanguard Group. Because hackers or other intruders could potentially steal the passwords from users' PC's, Intuit advised users to change the passwords.

title: BRITISH CREDIT CARDS SOLD
description: As it reported lower-than-expected preliminary results, People's Bank said it would sell its British credit card operation to Citigroup for $526 million. People's Bank, based in Bridgeport, Conn., established the British subsidiary in the mid-1990's as American card issuers sought a share of the British market. Citigroup, which will acquire credit card accounts owing about $426 million, is the world's biggest card issuer with $118 billion in loans. People's Bank said that its first-quarter profit would be 20 to 22 cents a share, less than half of analysts' forecasts. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: China's Demand for Apology Is Rooted in Tradition

title: AUTONOMY EXPECTS PROFIT SHORTFALL

The plants are in Colorado, Indiana, Kentucky, New York, Ohio, North Carolina and Pennsylvania, said Donna Reynolds, a spokeswoman for Temple-Inland, which is based in Austin, Tex. The Chesapeake plants can make 100,000 tons of boxes a year, which could increase Temple output by about 5 percent. Chesapeake, which has struggled to meet profit forecasts, said in January that it planned to sell its box plants and other businesses to focus on making packaging for consumer products.

title: MP3.COM, ONLINE MUSIC PROVIDER, IS FINED
description: The online music provider MP3.com must pay about $300,000 to the independent music label Tee Vee Toons for copyright infringement, a federal jury ruled yesterday. Tee Vee Toons, the largest independent label in the nation, asserted that MP3 infringed on its rights to 145 songs and asked for $8.5 million in damages. Tee Vee Toons, which is based in New York, is one of more than a dozen labels that have sued MP3.com for distributing their songs on the Internet. MP3.com, which is based in San Diego, stored digitized copies of Tee Vee Toons compact discs in its computers. It provided access to music from that database, allowing its subscribers to listen to CD's from their personal collections on any computer if they could show they already owned the disc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, JUDD GARY, M.D.
description: GOODMAN-Judd Gary, M.D. Age 49. Gynecologist who devoted his professional life to providing safe services to women, died in Fort Worth, TX on March 26, from complications due to cancer. Dr. Goodman graduated Harper College, Binghamton, New York in 1974. He studied at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, TX from which he graduated in 1978. He completed his residency at Beth Israel Medical Center in New York City. He practiced gynecology in Hollywood, CA, New York City, and Fort Worth, TX. His love for medicine and women's health was but one side of this enigmatic person. He was an entertainer-only Jackie the Jokeman knew more jokes than Judd. He was a wonderful piano player. He was witty and erudite, a lover of classical and contemporary music. He was a scientist, an amateur astronomer and a master mechanic who could fix anything. He was a loving husband and devoted father. In addition to his daughter Julie Ellen Goodman, he is survived by his wife Evelyn, mother and stepfather Esta and Richard Friedman, sister Claudia Goodman, niece Loni Goodman, numerous aunts, uncles and cousins. He will be sorely missed by everyone who knew him. A memorial service was already held. Donations can be made either to NARAL or Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, TX.

He painted and sculpted for Broadway shows at the Nolan Brothers Scenic Studios from 1954 to 1973. He served as the Art Director for Radio City Music Hall from 1973 to 1980 and finished his career sculpting and painting for the Metropolitan Opera from 1980 to 1997. His capacity for joy and playfulness will be greatly missed. A private ceremony for family April 20th in Fishkill. An open house in John's memory will be held April 21st at his home from 3-7PM.

title: Sizing Up the Tax Cut
description: The Washington scorekeepers are confused. Was the vote for a $1.27 trillion tax cut a victory for President Bush or a defeat? The way it looks to us, Mr. Bush suffered a legislative setback in not hitting the $1.6 trillion figure that he declared to be ''just right.'' But in broader terms, he scored a significant political gain that he can sell to the American people as delivering on a campaign promise. He can also brag that he forced the Democrats to abandon their opening bids of $500 billion, then $900 billion, and wound up pulling 15 of them well past $1 trillion.

title: SOUTH KOREA'S RATES STEADY
description: South Korea's central bank held interest rates steady as accelerating inflation, stoked by a weakening currency, prevented a rate cut. The Bank of Korea left the benchmark call rate, the interest it charges on overnight loans to commercial banks, at 5 percent at its monthly policy meeting. The bank has left rates unchanged for two months after cutting them a quarter-point in February, when it cited a slowing economy.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about some New Jersey lawmakers' calls for Justice Peter G. Verniero to resign from the State Supreme Court misstated the number of Republicans in the State Senate. There are 25, not 24.

title: Court Clears Plan to Build Power Plants
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that the state power authority can continue building several mini-power plants around New York City, determining that state officials did follow environmental laws in choosing locations for the plants, despite a rushed schedule.

title: The Exploitation of Man and Beast
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: One California Utility Files For Bankruptcy Protection

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Thursday about the selection of Ninfa Segarra as president of the Board of Education referred incorrectly in some copies to the year that she broke over AIDS instruction with Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, who appointed her. It was 1992, not 1990.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: A Tijuana Singer's Take On Alternative Latin Rock
description: Julieta Venegas

title: A Sick Tribe And a Dump As a Neighbor; Mohawks Press G.M. Over Decade-Old Impasse
description: On this frigid day, on the land where his people have lived for centuries, Paul Thompson is stomping through the snow, offering a tour of the landmarks of his childhood.

title: Francis Grasso, 52, 60's D.J. And Master of the Club Mix
description: Francis Grasso, a pioneering club disc jockey credited with first mixing records together in the late 1960's by matching their rhythms, was found dead on March 23 at his home in Brooklyn. He was 52.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: A Movie That Wasn't
description: To the Editor:

title: Southern Italian Fare Takes Up Residence
description: IN a space that for years has been something of a revolving door, a new Italian restaurant called Seminara's is now ensconced. Despite its Post Road address, the restaurant is in Colonial Green, a small shopping complex in Westport that is set back from the road.

title: Raise a Genius
description: Last summer, after much consideration, Toby Rosenberg announced to his friends and family that he had decided to change his name. ''Toby,'' he felt, was ''a little boy's name.'' Going forward, he would be called Karl, like his father before him. His school made note of the switch. His parents had no argument. Toby -- now Karl -- was 5 years old.

title: Dallas Has Its Cool Club Scene
description: THINK of America's coolest, most exciting neighborhoods, and no place in Texas comes automatically to mind. That's a mistake. Just outside downtown Dallas is a 20-block concentration of shops, boutiques, bars, restaurants and nightclubs that pulsate with energy. The neighborhood, Deep Ellum, has emerged from a long period of neglect and decay. As recently as 20 years ago it was a dangerous place to go after dark. For a while after that it was punk heaven, with Mohawk haircuts and safety-pin earrings the look of choice. It still has some of that edge, but as it becomes a weekend destination for people from the Dallas area, it may suffer the fate of New York's SoHo and other once-hip neighborhoods that were overwhelmed with money, tourists and uptown chic.

title: Back-Flip a Motorcycle
description: So you want to do a back flip on a motorcycle. In the world of motorcycle sports, that puts you in the extreme section. The Supercross circuit is the older, more conservative wing. It is simply about racing -- whoever has the fastest time wins. Freestyle is the rowdy younger brother. According to Carey Hart, one of the leading freestyle riders, it is about ''going out, hitting jumps and doing tricks.''

title: Gain for Entrepreneurial Women
description: The 1990's were good to women with an entrepreneurial spirit.

title: Ronald Van Dunk, 68, Chief Red Bone of the Ramapough Mountain Indians, Is Dead
description: Ronald Van Dunk, who led the Ramapough Mountain Indians in their continuing fight to win federal recognition as a tribe, died last Sunday at a nursing home in Suffern, N.Y. He was 68 and had lived in Hillburn, N.Y.

title: Using the Art of Graffiti To Start a Conversation
description: Every few months, Stephanie Diamond of Forest Hills, Queens, gets itchy for a conversation, and so decides to break the law.

title: Chipped Nails To Flaunt
description: At Henri Bendel on April 12 and 13, the celebrity manicurist Maria Salandra (who has prettified the fingertips of Sarah Jessica Parker, Meg Ryan and Angelina Jolie) will begin administering ''diamond manicures,'' in which nails are painted and then decked out with actual single-point diamonds. Sponsored as a promotional event by Defile cosmetics, the manicure costs $60, but that amount will also be applied toward the purchase of Defile products -- and not just nail polish. Appointments must be booked in advance by calling (212) 373-6389.

title: An Archipelago Called Russian
description: IF a guy wants to be able to talk in bed with his new Russian wife, this guy needs one vocabulary; but if he wants to deal in the Moscow oil business, the guy needs another,'' explains Boris Shekhtman, a merry-eyed despot of a language teacher who is ready for either American urge these days.

title: Commercial Property/Web-Based Products; For Realty Concerns, Internet Is a Disappointment
description: ANDREW FARKAS insists that he is still the ''mean, wicked geek'' he proclaimed himself to be about a year ago as he prepared to inaugurate the Edi ficeRex Internet residential service portal and other Internet-based products.

title: London
description: To the Editor: Readers who admired Jonathan Player's gorgeous photographs and Richard Ruda's interesting descriptions of the Inns of Court, but feel daunted by the prospect of finding their own way, might consider a guided walking tour.

title: Word-Starved In Heidelberg
description: WHEN you travel alone in a foreign land for the first time, you are by definition an outsider, but never more so than when you stand outside the local language, treading uneasily around the outskirts of its sentence structures, its conjugations, its argot. It was my struggles with what Mark Twain called ''the horrors of the German language'' that had chased me out of Heidelberg's Old City across the Neckar River to the deserted cobblestone path that hugged its far bank. No sooner had I reached the quay than a rainstorm descended, making wet polka dots on the cobbles and sending me scurrying under a stone archway of the 18th-century bridge known as the Alte Brcke.

title: Active Managers Await the Verdict
description: FALLING stock prices, which offer precious little consolation to anyone but short-sellers, have at least given actively managed mutual funds a chance to prove something they have long claimed: that in bear markets, they are better equipped to outperform their passively managed index-fund cousins.

title: JERSEY CITY LEGAL BILLS
description: Jersey City's biggest waterfront developer is paying for special legal expertise to defend a lawsuit against it and the city filed by other Hudson County communities seeking to overturn 15 tax abatements. As the recipient of four of the abatements and a co-defendant with the city in a 1998 state civil suit led by neighboring Secaucus, the developer, the Lefrak Organization, said it sought to hire the state's foremost abatement lawyers, Anne Babineau, of Wilentz Goldman & Spitzer. But because the firm already does work for the city in other matters, city officials would not allow Lefrak to hire Ms. Rabineau as its own lawyer in the suit. Rather, a deal was struck in which Ms. Babineau would represent the city in the suit, and her bills would be paid by Lefrak, including an $83,000 bill last week. Steve Strunsky

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: LIES A Diary, 1986-1999. By Ned Rorem. Counterpoint. $30.

title: Wall of Park Avenue Building Collapses, Disrupting Metro-North
description: The rear wall of a vacant, four-story building on Park Avenue collapsed shortly after 5 p.m. yesterday, disrupting service on the Metro-North Railroad and forcing emergency crews to prop up what remained of the building to prevent it from falling into a larger apartment house next door.

title: This Marriage Takes A Bit of Explication
description: A RENOWNED scholar and an accomplished poet, married for 36 years, have just gone through hell together -- line by line. They are in the midst of purgatory at the moment, and will soon start on paradise.

title: Salvage A Portfolio
description: With Nasdaq halved and the Dow flirting with bear-market territory, the idea of protecting your portfolio from downside risk may seem a little like buying flood insurance when your living room is under four feet of water. But there's reason to believe that the worst may not be behind us. Short interest on Nasdaq -- the number of shares investors borrow and then sell in hopes of repurchasing them later a lower price -- rose to a record level in March. And even after the demise of all those dot-coms, many workers still have their fortunes bound up in a single stock.

title: Panama
description: To the Editor: We recently returned from a vacation in Panama, a highlight of which was our visit to Boquete. We stayed in a very comfortable two-room cabin at Villa Marita Lodge, which has a Web site at www.panamainfo.com/marita.

title: Private Sector; Standing Up to the Men, With Nerve and a Step Stool
description: With Jacques Nasser of Ford, Jack Welch of General Electric, Christopher Galvin of Motorola and 54 other Fortune 500 chief executives in attendance, Sheila Wellington, president of Catalyst, the nonprofit women's research organization, had the right audience last Monday -- and pulled no punches. Speaking in New York at her group's annual awards dinner, she said companies could no longer use the ''pipeline excuse'' -- that women entered the work force later than men -- to explain the lack of women at the top of corporate America.

title: Political Briefing; Pennsylvania G.O.P. Looks for a New Star
description: Since the end of World War II, Democrats and Republicans have alternated control of the Pennsylvania governor's office, switching every eight years. If that pattern holds next year, the current Republican incumbent, Gov. Tom Ridge, who is limited to two four-year terms, will be succeeded by a Democrat.

title: How to Download and Use Napster
description: At the present time, Napster is still the best way to get music online. Its selection has been greatly diminished by recent court-mandated actions, but it is still a wildly popular and diverse service. To learn more about the recent legal battles, click here. For a look at the alternatives that may take its place, read a recent article from the Times' Circuits section by David Gallagher.

title: Despite Recent Record, Duval Exudes Confidence
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7  Despite having won just one golf tournament since the beginning of 2000, David Duval does not lack confidence. When asked what he expected from himself entering this year's Masters, Duval shot back an answer that was as direct as one of his piercing drives off the tee.

title: Two Hamlets Explore New Paths in an Old Terrain
description: HAMLETS proliferate in Britain -- indeed, in Europe -- but it has been a long time since two leading English actors played the same role in New York within such a short period as Adrian Lester and Simon Russell Beale are about to do at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Disney Goes High Tech With New Parade
description: The Main Street Electrical Parade at the Magic Kingdom in Walt Disney World made its final exit last month after more than 500 performances and has been replaced by a new high-tech parade called SpectroMagic.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: HAVANA BAY, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Ballantine, $7.99.) The Russian detective Arkady Renko, the melancholy, world-weary hero of ''Gorky Park'' and ''Polar Star,'' resurfaces in sunny Cuba, where his suicide plans are interrupted when he is brutally attacked while investigating the suspicious death of an old friend. ''It's a richly intricate mystery, made more compelling by its setting,'' Carl Hiaasen wrote in the Book Review in 1999. ''Smith's panorama'' of Old Havana ''is both dazzling and dead-on depressing.''

title: April 1-7; The Senate Shows A Mind of Its Own
description: The 50-50 Senate showed it is going to follow its own drummer. On two separate high-profile issues, the Senate refused to follow President Bush's lead but instead found its own politcal center.

title: An Arts Festival (Plus Azaleas) in Norfolk
description: A staging of ''The Tempest'' by the Royal Shakespeare Company of London and performances by the violinist Midori, the Moscow Festival Ballet and the Mark Morris Dance Group are among the highlights of the Virginia Arts Festival, being held in Norfolk and nearby cities April 20 to May 20.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, HARRY
description: GOTTLIEB-Harry, 93, Apr. 1, 2001. Beloved father of Jane Ragals & Joseph. Devoted grandfather of Jonathan, David, Rachel, Sara. Loving great-grandfather. Our parent, friend, counselor, scholar and teacher will always be with us.

title: Letters: New-Economy Worth
description: To the Editor:

title: Tell if Your Parents are Spying on You
description: Because you know they are. Unless you live in a family in which you can put a lock on your door (and you don't), rest assured that your loving parents will rifle through your stuff at some point. The trick isn't so much keeping them from knowing as knowing what they know and when they knew it.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on March 25 with an article about the choral group the Sixteen misstated the location of Canterbury Cathedral, where the group was shown performing. It is in Canterbury, England, not London.

title: Ideas & Trends; Selling to Gen Y: A Far Cry From Betty Crocker
description: AMERICAN identity -- a mix of cultural politics, social mores and generational crosscurrents -- has never been more difficult to pin down. And nowhere has that identity become more racially nuanced than among Generation Y, those newborns to early twentysomethings who represent the largest population swell since the baby boom and probably the biggest ever in United States history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLAX, ARTHUR
description: FLAX-Arthur. Temple B'nai Sholom mourns the loss of our dear longtime member. Services at Gutterman's, Tuesday, April 10, 2001 at 1 PM. Shiva will be at 10 Lenox Road, Rockville Centre. May the bereaved family find solace and consolation amongst all mourners in Israel. Dr. Barry Dov Schwartz, Rabbi Dr. Alvin S. Morrison, President

title: MetroStars Win Physical Opening Game
description: Football line markings and bare patches on the grass, caused by XFL games at Giants Stadium, took a little something away from the look of the MetroStars' 2-1 victory over the New England Revolution tonight.

title: Drop the Gun
description: State troopers are probably the experts when it comes to firearms. So how hard can it be for them to choose a new pistol to replace the aging weapon they now carry?

title: Fire I. National Park Said to Be Endangered
description: The Fire Island National Seashore is one of the 10 most endangered national parks in the country because of potential damage from a $100 million Army Corps of Engineers project to rebuild beaches and dunes in private communities, a park advocacy group said last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLUGER, ERICA
description: KLUGER-Erica. On April 6, 2001, at 18. She was a loving daughter of Carol Glassman and Barry Kluger, stepdaughter of Hope Kirsch and Matthew Glassman, granddaughter of Lee and Len Kluger, Lorraine Shuster and the late Marvin Shuster, sister of Zachary and Alley Glassman, niece of Alan Kluger and Judge Amy Dean, Dr. Deborah Shuster and Tom Warren, Andra Shuster and Glenn Hugo, and a friend of many. She loved dancing, music, and was a shining light to everyone who knew her and was touched by her. Her sense of humor, smile and love was infectious and her memory will endure forever. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, April 10, at 10 AM, at Sinai Mortuary, 4538 North 16th St., Phoenix, AZ, 602-248-0030. In lieu of flowers, donations to: Erica Kluger Scholarship Fund, The Stroud School of Dance, PO Box 1134, Stony Brook, NY 11790.

title: Royal Club Drops Sails on Admiral's Cup
description: Four short years ago, by virtue of a dramatic come-from-behind performance in the deciding race of the Admiral's Cup, the three-boat United States team was on top of the offshore racing world. The victory, ensured by the American skipper John Kolius's roll-the-dice end run in the waning stages of the classic Fastnet Race, was the first for the United States since 1969.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HERTZ, MOE
description: HERTZ-Moe. April 10, 1974. Another lonely Passover without you. Forever in our thoughts. Honey, Harvey, Barry, Carol, Mo

title: The Blinding Power of Data
description: THROW away the performance tables in this week's quarterly mutual funds report!

title: It's Home to Shea, La Guardia . . . And U.S. Indians
description: No one is more surprised that Queens has so many American Indians than the American Indians in Queens. Nearly 6,300 American Indians and Alaskans called Queens home on the 2000 Census, more than in any other county in the state.

title: A Classroom With Quiche At the Bell
description: WE landed in language-school heaven in Nice after facing up to a painful question: For how many decades could two otherwise intelligent Americans study French without truly learning it?

title: Officials See Program Cuts
description: Funding for a program that let the New York City Police Department put more than 1,000 officers on the street by hiring civilians for administrative tasks would be reduced under President Bush's budget, two Democratic officials said yesterday.

title: Cafeteria-Free Dining
description: Dining hall food is a constant college complaint, and although every college town is chockablock with restaurants and fast-food places, students in dorm meal plans often feel compelled to eat on campus. Now students can take advantage of all those off-campus culinary options. University Meal Deal, based in Sharon, Mass., has introduced a prepaid debit card that lets members eat at 20 or so local restaurants. Meal plans are available in Boston (Boston College, Boston University and Newbury College); Ithaca, N.Y. (Cornell University and Ithaca College); and College Park (University of Maryland). Prices are competitive with dining halls', ranging from $1,626 a semester (19 meals a week) to $282 (three a week) for students who have a mandatory meal plan.

title: Personal Business; Fighting Back When Someone Steals Your Name
description: TWELVE years ago, Felycia Martin's purse was stolen from the hospital while she was giving birth to her son. A year ago, she started receiving dozens of bills for charges she did not recognize.

title: Responding To Rap, R & B Is Reborn
description: PERHAPS you've seen a music video called ''I Wish -- Remix (To the Homies That We Lost).'' It opens with a burst of gunfire on a crowded playground, and the bloody aftermath unfolds in a somber hospital room, as a doctor announces that a man is dead. The victim's best friend wanders the streets, wild with anger, frustration and grief. The beat starts up, and he delivers a homily pockmarked with sudden bursts of silence that obscure two dozen utterances of a common racial epithet.

title: Wild Hawaii
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Discovering Wild Hawaii, Gently'' (March 4): We suggest a visit to the National Tropical Botanical Gardens, which has three sites on Kauai and one on Maui.

title: Preparing to Sell A Scout Camp
description: To the Editor:

title: After the Downsizing, a Downward Spiral
description: FOR the generation of Americans who entered the work force after World War II, giant corporations like AT&T were the place to be, much like Microsoft has been the place to be in the last decade. In the quarter-century after the war, Ma Bell, General Motors and other staid blue chips represented the pinnacle of what capitalism had to offer workers because of the extraordinary job security and the cornucopia of benefits that these companies provided.

title: In Search of Just Enough Audience
description: NOW is the time for regional theaters to send out pitch letters, to talk up next season to the audience before show time, enticing subscribers to renew and wooing new ones. And everybody is asked to spread the word, please.

title: Inside a Lifelong Dream of Desert Light
description: RODEN CRATER, which James Turrell has been trying for more than 20 years to turn into one of the biggest works of art in the world, is a black and red volcano overlooking the Painted Desert, at the edge of the Navajo reservation 40 miles north of Flagstaff.

title: Kitchawan Institute to Sell Center to a Research Group
description: The Kitchawan Institute, a research institute and conference center that opened last September, plans to sell its Yorktown headquarters to the Kenneth S. Warren Institute, a medical research group based in Tarrytown.

title: The Diamond Game, Shedding Its Mystery
description: ON a chilly February afternoon, about 45 diamond merchants and manufacturers gathered in the nondescript cafe at the Diamond Dealers Club, on the 10th floor of a building at 47th Street and Fifth Avenue in Manhattan. Down the hall, at tables along the windows, dealers from around the world squinted into loupes and negotiated for stones. Wall clocks displayed the time in Mumbai, Tel Aviv, Antwerp, Johannesburg and Tokyo, all major diamond centers.

title: Which Way to Go After the Bear Market
description: PRETEND that you don't own a cell phone or a Palm VII. Pretend that at the end of August 1998, you went to the most remote place on earth and stayed there, incommunicado, until the end of last month.

title: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; The Work That Drains Life
description: IT'S springtime, and my daughter, a senior in college, is pondering her next steps. She is clear that she wants her work ''to make a difference,'' but she also wants to have time for friends, relationships and fun.

title: A Fan's Lament
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Sector; Amid a Plunge, Waiting to Land
description: Life has been frustrating lately for Larry Ellison, the chief executive of Oracle, who is accustomed to getting his way. Although he is still one of the world's wealthiest men, the value of his holdings in Oracle has fallen by about two-thirds over the past year. His latest home, an imperial Japanese-style retreat on 23 acres in Silicon Valley that has been under construction for years, remains unfinished. And now, San Jose won't let him land his plane at night.

title: Isles Lose To End A Season To Forget
description: Another disappointing Islanders season ended last night, with a 4-2 loss to the Bruins in Boston. Dave Scatchard, the team's feisty center, said he planned to go home to Alberta and ignore the Stanley Cup playoffs for the fifth consecutive spring. To watch the games on television would be torture, he said.

title: Environmental Rollbacks
description: Republican moderates are exasperated by President Bush's posture on environmental issues. They are not alone. In less than three months Mr. Bush has begun to remind people of the country's last genuinely anti-environmental president, Ronald Reagan. But where Mr. Reagan's attitude was one of careless indifference -- ''You've seen one redwood, you've seem 'em all,'' was a typical Reaganism -- Mr. Bush's retreat on isses as large as global warming and as localized as poisoned drinking water seems aggressively hostile.

title: Sports of The Times; Stopping Shots and Starting a Life
description: COMMUNICATION is actually the easier part of assimilation. As in the goal, when she can study the shooter's eyes and intuitively know what is inside her head, Gao Hong has found ways to get across her pleasure, and pain.

title: Are Index Funds Great Literature?
description: IN the pantheon of great investors, index fund managers are all but invisible.

title: Gardiners Island: May It Rest in Peace
description: As someone with intimate knowledge of the comings and goings on Gardiners Island [''Gardiners Island: The War of Wills,'' March 18], I very seriously doubt that Alexandra Creel Goelet, a Gardiner descendant, and her husband, Robert G. Goelet, have any intention whatsoever of development.

title: London
description: To the Editor: I haven't seen the London theater e-mail newsletter you mentioned in ''London Theater Buzz, Delivered by E-Mail,'' (Travel Advisory, Jan. 21), but I can recommend the free newsletter put out by Brian McKinney, who runs a ticket agency as well as a Web site, www.goodshow.com.

title: Children Recycle to Create The Soul of a New Sculpture
description: What do you do with a used computer? Recycle the parts into artworks, if you are a student of Erik Wood, a Murray Hill artist who runs workshops that show children how to do just that.

title: Corrections
description: A review on March 18 about ''Empire Statesman: The Rise and Redemption of Al Smith,'' by Robert A. Slayton, included an erroneous reference from the book to the judicial career of Joseph Proskauer, a political adviser to Gov. Alfred E. Smith of New York in the 1920's. Proskauer became a justice in the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court; he was never a member of the Court of Appeals.

title: Where Exuberant Dreams Often Sink Out of Sight
description: THERE have always been at least two Floridas, the real one and the imagined one. As a mythical place, it promised the earth's bounty centuries ago to whichever adventurers were hardy enough to help themselves to it. It was in Florida, in 1513, that the Spanish explorer Ponce de Len began searching for the legendary Fountain of Youth. But ever since the late 1700's, when settlers were offered generous land grants, Florida's history has also been that of aggressive land speculation measurable in square miles and real-world profits.

title: In a Colorful Campaign in Peru, 3 Points of View Emerge
description: Only a year ago, Peruvians went to the polls to choose a president in an election so clumsily fraudulent that it eventually forced the winner, the two-time incumbent, Alberto K. Fujimori, to desert the country and resign from exile in Tokyo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUELS, ROBERT
description: SAMUELS-Robert. We will miss your spirit, enthusiasm for life, friendship and love. You will forever be in our hearts. Elaine Marsh, Myra and Marvin Marsh and Pauline and Morty Farber.

title: Is Food Just Another Scapegoat?
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Married Today
description: To the Editor:

title: Invent a Brand Name
description: As of December, Bill Nguyen had nearly everything he needed to start a successful business. He had a grand vision for the post-PC world: the current technobabble of cell phones, PDA's, pagers and other wireless gadgets could be woven into a unified global data-information network by a single company offering the right software. He had a proven record; at age 29, he had already been a key player in five start-ups, three of which had gone public. He had $34 million in venture capital and 60 eager employees. What he still didn't have, with his company's March inaugural date just two months away, was a name.

title: Reckonings; Two Untrue Things
description: Was the Senate's vote to give George W. Bush only $1.2 trillion in tax cuts a famous victory for moderation? For one thing, the battle over the size of the tax cut is by no means over. Soon Mr. Bush will be out there telling the voters once again that it's time for the federal government to give back its excess cash, and that he wants to give all of us a tax break. And his handlers will try once again to create that aura of inevitability, so that despite the qualms of moderates the tax cut in all its $1.6 trillion glory (which is to say with its true cost of $2.5 trillion plus) will be enacted.

description: Opera

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: Music listings on Pages 38 and 39 of Arts & Leisure today carry outdated references to the soloist for the Brooklyn Academy of Music's presentation of Bach's ''St. Matthew Passion'' today, Tuesday, Wednesday, Friday and Saturday. After the section had gone to press, the soprano Heidi Grant Murphy was replaced by Suzie LeBlanc because of illness. The outdated reference also appeared in the arts pages on Thursday in a brief report in the Footlights column.

title: Another Country
description: It was the last week in March, spring break, at the stately Gasparilla Inn, in Boca Grande, Fla. On a wall in the main foyer of this determinedly old-school resort, visited regularly by the Bush family, a clipboard held a list of daily arrivals. Next to it, a pair of old reading glasses was hanging so guests could peruse names as if in a Henry James novel. While it was impossible for an outsider like me to know any of the names on the list, something far more obvious was in the air.

description: MY STORY

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTERSON, RAYMOND R.
description: PATTERSON-Raymond R. Poet, died April 5, 2001. A viewing will be held Thursday, April 12, 9-10 AM, funeral 10 AM-noon, at Benta's Funeral Home, 630 St. Nicholas Ave at 141st St, NYC.

title: Peace of Mind, and More, at the Push of a Button
description: LIKE would-be millionaires on television, drivers can use lifelines now and then. More than a million motorists now have them in the form of hands-free wireless links to central call centers, where operators are standing by to lend a helping hand.

title: The View From/Greenwich; For Abandoned Baby, It's Love to the Rescue
description: IT was a stormy start for Baby John Doe, who was born during a rainstorm and left abandoned on the side of a cul-de-sac called Stormy Circle Drive in the Byram section of Greenwich.

title: New Composers in the Spotlight
description: The Nash Ensemble has made the trip from London to Princeton again, spending its usual week in workshops and performances. The eight instrumentalists are to complete the Nash residency this afternoon, with a concert in Richardson Auditorium that includes world premieres of two pieces by Princeton graduate students. ''Composers vie to participate,'' said Van Stiefel, a doctoral fellow whose ''Octet'' is one of the new works. (The other is Alan F. Shockley's ''Morgenstreich.'') Leslie Kandell

title: Talks Set to Begin On Sex Offender Site
description: SINCE a federal judge ruled last week that the state's registry of sex offenders violates the due process rights of the people whose names, addresses and photographs appear on it, the question remains how to remedy it. The judge has asked both sides to work out a solution, and tomorrow afternoon that process will begin.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on March 25, about charges for 800-number phone calls from hotels, misstated the title for John Winston of the Federal Communications Commission. He is a spokesman for the Enforcement Bureau, not head of the bureau.

title: Senators Are Nearing Compromise on Rescuing Failing Schools
description: Moving closer to a deal on education, Senate Republicans and Democrats say they have tentatively agreed to a White House-backed plan to help buttress failing schools and hold them more accountable.

title: Accidents, Like Careers In Acting, Do Pan Out
description: IF geography and background are destiny, then John Ortiz and Rosie Perez should have met long ago. Both are Brooklyn natives in their 30's. The two self-described accidental actors also have family roots in the same small oceanside town of Aguadilla in the extreme northwest of Puerto Rico.

title: White House Plans to Revise New Medical Privacy Rules
description: The Bush administration has concluded that federal standards to protect the privacy of medical records, adopted with much fanfare by President Bill Clinton in his last month in office, are unworkable and must be revised, administration officials say.

title: Susan Lee, Stephen Ko
description: Susan Jean Lee, a daughter of Chung-Ja Lee and Jung-Keun Lee of Burke, Va., was married yesterday to Stephen Youngsuk Ko, a son of Shinyoung Ko and Dr. Nam Kyu Ko of Warren, Ohio. The Rev. William J. Fuerstenau performed the ceremony at the New York Avenue Presbyterian Church in Washington.

title: It Takes a Village a Year To Unearth Local History
description: It started with an e-mail over the building list-serve: Does anybody know the history of Park West Village? Winifred Armstrong, a resident of 30 years, knew some of it, and wrote back, and then gave a lecture on the subject. title: QUICK BITE/Pluckemin; What Else in Pluckemin but Chicken?
description: A chicken restaurant in Pluckemin? ''Just a coincidence,'' said David Weber, owner of David's Country Roasters. But there it is. Although, as Mr. Weber puts it, his place is ''tucked away and a little hidden'' in a renovated carriage house in Somerset County, people obviously have no trouble finding it. Especially at lunchtime when people from nearby businesses descend. One of them recently was Lisa Chapple from New Brunswick, who works in a local insurance office and on this particular day was digging in to one of Mr. Weber's best-sellers, Chinese chicken salad ($8.50 for a large portion, $6.50 for small). It's only one of his chicken-dish variations, including chicken pot pie ($4.95), rotisserie or fried chicken ($5.50 to $8.50, with two sides and corn bread) and Buffalo wings ($3.50 for 6 up to $10.95 for 24). The side dishes include homemade roasted-garlic potato salad and tangy cranberry supreme (cranberries, oranges and more), and there are 22 kinds of sandwiches ($5.95 to $7.95), including pulled barbecue chicken and a chicken chili wrap. David's is self-service with diners selecting what Mr. Weber calls ''fast food with a flair'' at a counter before settling at indoor or outdoor tables or taking their food away. When Mr. Weber, who is 39, opened his place four years ago it was like returning to his roots: his father, Bernard, a partner in the venture until his death last fall, also used to be a partner in Sammy's Romanian Restaurant in Manhattan, where David once waited on tables. Mr. Weber says he is looking for locations for new Country Roasters. How about Egg Harbor? Norman Oshrin

title: Endpaper; Life With Mama
description: In her early years in this country, my mother was a restless and turbulent woman. Recalling her then, the sense I always get is of someone who had to rebuild the universe but had only five days instead of the six God took for himself. She worked five days a week hunched over a machine that stitched fine straw hats, her right foot welded to the power pedal, her fingers deftly gliding around the treacherous, pummeling needle. On many nights, after she had spent the evening hours cooking and washing up, I glimpsed her sitting stoop-necked on the edge of the sofa, moistening a tip of thread with her lips and straining with her tired, myopic eyes to slip the thread through the eye of the needle so she could restore a button on my or my brother Josh's shirt.

title: Run A Successful Silicon Valley Business
description: After putting in a half day at the high-tech company in Silicon Valley where she works, Mandy heads up the freeway toward San Francisco in her sports car. Billboards for deceased dot-coms flash by like relics from a lost world. At about 1 p.m., she pulls into an upscale hotel near the San Francisco airport, where she has a room reserved. Dashing across the parking lot with her large black shoulder bag, she looks as if she could be on her way to a marketing seminar. She's a bright-eyed, upbeat woman dressed in a silky blue top, black pants and black boots, her blond hair pulled back in a girlish ponytail. She checks into a room on the top floor, with a view of the surrounding foggy hills, and takes out the tools of her trade -- candles, magazines, bubble bath, fragrant oil from the Body Shop and condoms. Then she goes into the bathroom to prepare for her first guest. Over the next four hours, she will have sex with three men, and she will earn about $1,200.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-08-01; How to E-Mail Like a C.E.O.
description: Microsoft may be broken up, Nasdaq may never get off the mat, but one artifact of the digital revolution is healthier than ever: e-mail remains the most popular online application, with more than 6.1 billion messages sent daily. Not only has e-mail opened up a whole new medium for personal correspondence, it has also launched the modern corporation into the Internet age with the promise to free workers from the tyranny of too much paper and too little time. It succeeded so spectacularly, however, that what was once blissfully asynchronous is now woefully chronic. For even moderately busy e-mailers, a hundred new messages a day is nothing out of the ordinary. Just as the answering machine gave us a reason to avoid the phone, e-mail has given us a new incentive to delay work in the morning: in-box dread.

title: Climbing in Nepal
description: To the Editor: I would like to comment on ''Reaching a Goal in Nepal'' (Feb. 11), by Edward Wong, describing the Annapurna Circuit. As these things go, the climb up to the Thorung La at 17,765 is not that hard. It is the descent. There is more than 5,000 feet of altitude loss -- all of it experienced in one day -- until you reach the next destination of Muktinath, if you follow the popular counterclockwise route. To put this in perspective, the top floor of the Empire State Building is about 1,200 feet high.

Mr. Nelson also continues to record, with ''Milk Cow Blues'' on Island Records his latest offering. He will appear at the Washington Township Center for the Performing Arts in Sewell on Thursday, the Union County Arts Center in Rahway on Friday, the War Memorial in Trenton on April 19, the Count Basie Theater in Red Bank on April 20 and the Community Theater in Morristown on April 27. title: Multitask
description: Who can remember life before multitasking? These days we all do it: mothers, air-traffic controllers, ambidextrous athletes, high-flying executives who manage to eat, take conference calls, write e-mail and conduct board meetings all at the same time. We lionize those who appear to multitask effortlessly and despair at our own haphazard attempts to juggle even two tasks, secretly wondering if there exists a race of superior beings whose brains are hard-wired for multitasking feats. Only recently have neurologists begun to understand what our brains are up to when we do it. What they've learned offers hope to all multitasking delinquents out there.

title: Get Into College After Being Rejected
description: Catesby Holmes scored 800 on the verbal section of the College Boards. She was on the honor roll for four straight years, and she lettered in field hockey and won awards for music, Latin and horseback riding. Yet she did not get into college. Harvard, Princeton, Yale, Columbia, Brown and Wesleyan rejected her; after putting her on the waiting list, so did Amherst and the University of Chicago. ''I spent the spring watching friends put college stickers on their cars while I tried to figure out what I was going to do with my life,'' Catesby remembers. ''As in, what was I at this point if not 'collegebound'?''

description: George Prussin, a wealthy Tenafly resident, has withdrawn his offer to redevelop and finance a $1 million upgrade of Geissinger Field, the high school playing area, in the face of opposition by neighboring residents. The board of education president, Bobbie Frankfort, announced his decision at a board meeting last week. No reason was given, but Mr. Prussin was expected to give one at the next meeting on April 30. He would have resurfaced the field with artificial turf and built a new snack bar, press box, bathroom and bleacher section that doubled seating capacity to 1,600 people. Neighbors especially voiced concerns about a plan to put up four 80-foot light towers. George James

title: Bellying Up to the Bar

I play basketball. And I lift dumbbells, an activity my wife, Lori, takes great joy in mocking: ''Me see weight. Me lift weight. Me go get something to eat.''

title: Patterned Glass That Lets Light In
description: FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT never wrote as extensively about his patterned glass windows as he did about his architecture and building materials, even though his designs drastically altered the function of stained glass in architecture. The words stained and leaded have been used since the Middle Ages to describe such windows, but Wright considered them inaccurate when applied to his windows. The glass he used was not made opaque by being painted or stained by hand; it was clear and colored industrially, and the metal strips he used to secure the panes were, for the most part, zinc rather than lead.

Von Trier and Wagner, a Bond Sealed in Emotion

His movies -- particularly the trilogy of ''Breaking the Waves'' (1996), ''The Idiots'' (1998) and ''Dancer in the Dark'' (2000) -- routinely make critics' best and worst-film lists. Film enthusiasts have reportedly come to blows over his work. ''Dancer in the Dark'' won the Golden Palm at Cannes. Yet A. O. Scott, in two thoughtful reviews in The New York Times, saw the ''real struggle'' of that film as between Bjork's ''artistic conviction'' and Mr. von Trier's ''aestheticized cynicism,'' and wrote that the final scene of ''The Idiots,'' which I found among the most moving artistic experiences I've encountered, ''descends to truly contemptible emotional brutality.''

title: Run In 2004
description: In just 45 months, someone will be taking the oath of national office. The Republicans, in all likelihood, have their man. While Al Gore ponders his options, Capitol Hill teems with Democratic rivals. Consider yourself one of them. Your strategy is to leave Gore alone -- he's going to emerge as the presumed nominee or dejectedly fade away, and you won't want to be seen as anything but a spectator to either fate. Instead, focus on building your name, your stamina and your bank account. Most important, you'll need to learn the lessons of the last race before anyone else does.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the first and second days of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: PrivateSector; Amid a Plunge, Waiting to Land
description: Life has been frustrating lately for Larry Ellison, the chief executive of Oracle, who is accustomed to getting his way. Although he is still one of the world's wealthiest men, the value of his holdings in Oracle has fallen by about two-thirds over the past year. His latest home, an imperial Japanese-style retreat on 23 acres in Silicon Valley that has been under construction for years, remains unfinished. And now, San Jose won't let him land his plane at night.

title: Frederick Rath, 87, Pioneer Of Historical Conservation
description: Frederick Rath, a pioneer of historical conservation in a country devoted to replacement and redevelopment, died in his sleep on April 1 in Cooperstown, N.Y. He was 87 and lived in Cooperstown.

His grandmother cooked with curry, and he loved baseball and school. ''I was either going to play for the New York Yankees or be a doctor,'' said Mr. Sealey, who arrived in the United States from Panama at age 8.

title: Word for Word/Tips for Terrorists; Lose the Toothpick, Don't Talk to Cabbies and Watch Where You Park
description: ACCORDING to federal prosecutors in Manhattan, the bombings of the American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in 1998 involved intricate research, planning and execution. Just look at page 71 of a terrorist training manual linked to the attacks: ''A special operation must have stages. 1. Research (reconnaissance) stage. 2. Planning stage. 3. Execution stage.''

title: Opera Cancels June Performances
description: The New Jersey State Opera has cut its season short with the cancellation of Puccini's ''Madame Butterfly.'' Citing a scheduling mixup, the opera's public relations director, Astera Argyris, said the New Jersey Performing Arts Center could not hold the dates promised for the opera, June 1 and 3. Though NJPAC, which is now scheduled to run a production of ''Ragtime'' through that weekend, offered alternative dates to the opera, the performers for ''Madame Butterfly'' could not be assembled for the new dates, Ms. Argyris said. Shelley Roberts, director of press affairs for NJPAC, confirmed the scheduling mishap and said: ''It's unfortunate. We are sorry it didn't work out.'' Ms. Argyris said the short season is not an indication of money problems and the company will continue its community outreach programs. Jillian Hornbeck Ambroz

Traditionally few teams in the National Football League have put more effort into the April ritual. title: The Close Reader; The Case of Pius XII
description: You could fill a room in the Vatican Library with all the books about Pius XII. Few popes have suffered as many posthumous reversals in reputation or had their names invoked as often by critics of the church. Unlucky enough to head the Vatican during the reigns of Mussolini and Hitler; praised effusively by world leaders at his death in 1958; blisteringly condemned in Rolf Hochhuth's 1963 play, ''The Deputy,'' for his apparent indifference to the murder of the Jews; and puzzlingly nominated for beatification one year later, Pius XII today serves mainly as a battleground in the continuing war between conservative and liberal Roman Catholics. The bickering over him also threatens to unravel the dtente between Catholics and Jews.

Only drivers using E-ZPass will be able to use the entrance. This will be the first fully automated toll plaza operated by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and a first step in installing an E-ZPass system that will eventually operate only with overhead sensors that will allow drivers to maintain their speed, officials said. Drivers paying cash will be diverted to another exit. Karen DeMasters

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: YOU don't have to hate Alexander Woollcott (or even know who he was) to appreciate William Keighley's film version of THE MAN WHO CAME TO DINNER (1941). Nor do you have to have loved Nathan Lane in last year's Roundabout Theater revival. Sheridan Whiteside, the character based on Woollcott, played almost flawlessly by Monty Woolley in the film, is an ogre you'll love hating on sight. When Whiteside's nurse suggests that a box of fudge is probably not good for an injured man, he replies: ''My great-aunt Jennifer ate a whole box of candy every day of her life. She lived to be 102. And when she'd been dead three days, she looked better than you do now.'' The story of Whiteside, who takes over a nice Ohio family's house after injuring his leg there, is a comedy for the ages. Bette Davis is the great man's secretary, who falls for a local newspaperman. Ann Sheridan is the famous actress who drops by to interfere. Oddly, Jimmy Durante isn't nearly as good as Lewis J. Stadlen, who played Durante's character, Banjo, at the Roundabout -- Saturday at 9 p.m. on Channel 13.

In a move that now seems prescient, the fund's portfolio managers, Lawrence Auriana and Hans Utsch, shifted more than a quarter of its assets into cash last year. title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; A Hat Comes With It
description: Buster Keaton (1895-1966) had something more than what is now called ''physical presence'' -- he had a true mastery of the physical realm. BUSTER KEATON REMEMBERED (Abrams, $45), written by Keaton's widow, Eleanor, and the film historian Jeffrey Vance, offers superb visual documentation of the great silent filmmaker. The 225 superb photographs marshaled by the photo editor, Manoah Bowman, mix images from the sets of his greatest films with some unexpected shots: Keaton looking sexy in pictures by George Hurrell, and even the rarest of the rare, Keaton smiling. Many are published for the first time, thanks in part to the contribution of Eleanor Keaton, who worked with Vance before her death in 1998. The authors provide a succinct biography and candid background about each film. Keaton's devotion to craft was single-minded, and he was happy to sacrifice his body on the altar of comedy, breaking his neck on a stunt and only finding out about it 11 years later. He once said that his landmark film, ''The General,'' had to be ''so authentic it hurts.'' Eleanor Keaton's oddball appendix -- How to Make a Porkpie Hat,'' about her husband's signature accessory -- evinces some of the perfectionism that made Keaton himself a legend. Ted Loos

All he heard was what he couldn't do against Martnez. (That year Martnez would finish 17-8 with 305 strikeouts and an earned run average of 1.90.) ''Everyone was saying: 'Good luck. You're not going to get any hits off him,''' remembers Estalella, a Giants catcher who was then with the Phillies. ''I don't want to sound cocky, but I was saying I was going to do well.''

title: Harvest a Live Organ
description: Right now, more than 17,000 people are on the waiting list for liver transplants in this country. This year, fewer than 5,000 of them will get a liver, and more than 1,000 will die. But doctors like Lewis Teperman, the director of the transplant program at New York University Medical Center, are working on a new solution. Taking advantage of the liver's unique ability to regenerate itself, surgeons have been cutting out large chunks of live donors' livers and transplanting them into adults. Both parts of the tag-team process -- removing most of the donor's liver and installing it in the recipient -- are grueling, daylong surgical marathons, taking more than twice as long as a kidney transplant. The removal is the more harrowing, because it means risking a healthy person's life, a prima facie violation of the Hippocratic directive to do no harm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAFER, DR. DONALD M.
description: SHAFER-Dr. Donald M. A noted vitreoretinal surgeon, educator, clinical scientist and leader in the field of ophthalmology, died on April 4, 2001 at the age of 89. He was a graduate of Columbia University Medical School and retired lieutenant colonel of the US Army Medical Corps. During his illustrious career, he made numerous clinical and scientific contributions to the subspecialty of vitreoretinal surgical diseases. A gifted surgeon and teacher, he will be remembered most for his innovative work on the detection of findings indicative of retinal tears and detachments, known as ''Shafer's Sign.'' Above all, his pioneering work in vitreoretinal surgery set the stage for further developments leading to technological advances which made it posssible to remove and replace the vitreous in order to repair complex retinal detachments. He was equally prominent as a teacher and administrator. An elite corps of trainees represent a new generation of vitreoretinal surgeons who have already distinguished themselves within the diagnostics and management of vitreoretinal diseases. Each will remember Don as a teacher with wisdom, wit and warmth. As an administrator, he served as surgeon director and president of the medical board at the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital for more than 3 decades, and he was chairman and professor of the department of ophthalmology at Cornell University Medical School for more than 11 years. He leaves a legacy of numerous clinical and scientific publications which led to international admiration, esteem and prestigious awards such as the Lucien Howe Prize from the New York Medical Society and the Pocklington Memorial Lectureship in London. As a result of his distinguished work, he was a member of the most elite vitreoretinal societies, including the Jules Gonin Club and the American Retinal Society. A former Westport, Connecticut resident, he spent the latter part of his life living in Dunedin Isles, Florida, where he lived with Ann Brady, his wife of 63 years. He is also survived by his two daughters, Susan of Westport and Nancy DeVries of Baltimore, and three grandchildren. Donations in his memory may be made to: The Macula Foundation, Inc., Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital 210 East 64th Street, New York, New York 10021

title: Rob A Bank
description: Bank robbers come in two types, note jobs and takeovers. The first involves written demands and discretion (only a single teller needs to know), the second, barked threats, brandished weapons and a greater chance for Hollywood-style violence. Note jobs, according to the F.B.I., make up about 95 percent of bank robberies in an average year, about 8,000. Takeovers secure, on average, some ten 10 times more loot, about $28,000 per. The most popular time to rob a bank is Friday morning.

title: Cafeteria-Free Dining
description: Dining hall food is a constant college complaint, and although every college town is chockablock with restaurants and fast-food places, students in dorm meal plans often feel compelled to eat on campus. Now students can take advantage of all those off-campus culinary options. University Meal Deal, based in Sharon, Mass., has introduced a prepaid debit card that lets members eat at 20 or so local restaurants. Meal plans are available in Boston (Boston College, Boston University and Newbury College); Ithaca, N.Y. (Cornell University and Ithaca College); and College Park (University of Maryland). Prices are competitive with dining halls', ranging from $1,626 a semester (19 meals a week) to $282 (three a week) for students who have a mandatory meal plan. Advantages, according to Meal Deal, are flexibility (a student whose morning ''meal'' is a glass of orange juice has extra funds for a hearty lunch), convenience (athletes and students active in clubs can eat off hours) and a cash-free wallet. Plus, parents can rest assured that food money won't morph into beer money. DAVIDSON GOLDIN

title: Bill 25 Hours in One Day
description: The lawyer's billable hour, like the quark or the gluon, is a convenient fiction. Its measurement varies from observer to observer and depends upon position. Take, for example, the one-minute phone call. Because many law firms bill in minimum quarter-hour increments, those 60 seconds are magically transmogrified into 15 billable minutes. Or take two hours of research spent on Client A's legal problem, which turns out to be the same as Client B's problem. Through a process of legal alchemy known as double billing, lawyers can make two into four. While double billing is condemned by the American Bar Association, lawyers are not bound by A.B.A. rulings, and are free to bill both clients for the same work. Associates are told that any time spent thinking about a client's legal woes, even while eating or jogging, should be billed. Herewith, if not an actual time sheet, a plausible one:

title: A User's Manual for Modern Living
description: The only thing you really have to know how to do these days is turn on your computer, and strictly speaking, even that is not essential. You could always call the tech guy and get him to do it. One of the wonders of the service economy is that so many of the things we used to do for ourselves are now done by others. We turn gratefully to the experts and the professionals because it is easier and because so many of life's essential tasks -- automobile maintenance, for example, and income-tax preparation -- are now bewilderingly complicated, far beyond the ken of ordinary mortals. The tax code is incomprehensible even to those who wrote it, and you couldn't tune you own car engine if you tried -- not unless you hacked into the on-board electronic ignition system. Even such formerly simple-seeming activities as exercising and eating have turned out to be far too risky to be undertaken by the novice, which is why we now have personal trainers and nutritionists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAGLE, EDWARD P.
description: NAGLE-Edward P. Was born in Manhattan, NY on February 5, 1913, but called Long Island his home for most of his life. He went to work in the mailrom of the NY Times in 1929. He then went on to work in Auditing where he supervised the Tabulating Department. He was a self-educated man, but early in his career his talents were recognized specifically with regard to his ''analytical nature, his ability to grasp the essence of a matter, and think clearly, and practically.'' During his tenure with the company, he worked as Systems Analyst in the Systems Department, and as the Manager of the General Accounting Department. He retired in 1970 as the Manager of Electronic Data Processing Services after 41 years of loyal service. Various letters, including ones from then President and Publisher, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, acknowledged Edward's many accomplishments and thanked him for his devoted service. Edward's most notable accomplishment was the service he provided the News Department in November 1956 in setting up and directing an IBM Election Night Innovation. The innovation allowed the NY Times to tabulate and publish the National Presidential Election results ahead of the Associated Press. He also played on the NY Times Baseball Team. Edward enlisted in the Navy and served his country from 1944-46 with pride during World War II. His skills with tabulating equipment made him a prime candidate to support the Navy in Special Services. Edward's professional and military accomplishments were many, but he was more than just a resume of job titles. He was deeply loved by all his surviving family, especially by his wonderfull wife, Margaret, to whom he was married for sixty-five years. His daughters, Margaret Drum, and Patricia Zanchelli, remember him for his many wonderful qualities including his incredible sense of fairness. To his nine grandchildren and nine great grandchildren, he was affectionately known as ''Poppie''. He shared much with them including the joys of sand dunes, tadpoles, fishing, and boating at his home in East Hampton, NY. He gave his grandchildren fonder memories of youth than a child could ask for. Edward passed away on March 29, 2001 after a long illness and was laid to rest with military honors at Calverton National Cemetery in New York. A New York Times colleague of his once wrote of him ''The Times is a considerably better company with you as one of their officials than they could ever be without you.'' To his family, the world was a considerably better place with him than without him and we are all far better people because he touched our lives. His memory lives on in the hearts of those who love him.
