description: LYNCH-Roberta. On Saturday, April 7, 2001, of Bethesda, MD. Beloved aunt of Mary Highland Burrows, Margaret Anne Grossmann, Patricia Highland Law and Kathryn Highland Biladeau. Great-aunt of Daniel and Grace Grossmann, Mark Law and Kelly Biladeau. Friends will be received at Pumphrey's Bethesda-Chevy Chase Funeral Home, 7557 Wisconsin Avenue, Bethesda, MD, on Tuesday from 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at St. Bartholomew's Catholic Church, 6900 River Road, Bethesda, MD, Wednesday, April 11, at 11 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society, 11331 Amherst Ave, Silver Spring, MD 20902.

title: Minority Staff Members In Journalism Are Fewer
description: The math presented by the American Society of Newspaper Editors 24th annual survey of minorities was simple: 596 minority journalists were hired in 2001 and 698 left the profession, dropping the total number to 6,563 from 6,665. Minorities now make up 11.64 percent of journalists, the survey showed, compared with 31 percent of the national population.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUCH, JOSEPH, D.D.S.
description: STRAUCH-Joseph, D.D.S. On April 8, 2001. Longtime companion of Adeline Sherr. Father of Diana. Brother-in-law of Margaret. Also survived by his nephews and nieces. Inerment Tuesday, April 10, 11:30 AM, at Mt. Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, NJ.

title: Cyrus Gordon Dies at 92; Studied Ancient Languages
description: Dr. Cyrus H. Gordon, a scholar of Near East culture and a leading expert on ancient languages, died on March 30 at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 92.

title: MediaTalk; ABC May Have Some Comedy Contenders
description: The long wait at ABC for the next successful series may be over.

title: For Levy, Can-Do Business Style Runs Into Education Reality
description: After Harold O. Levy became the first corporate executive to lead the New York City school system last year, a string of successes seemed to affirm the can-do confidence that he articulated his first day on the job.

Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: Northwest Airlines and Mechanics Avert Strike
description: After a weekend of hard bargaining, Northwest Airlines today reached a tentative agreement with the union representing its mechanics, averting the threat of a strike and resolving a deadlock over pay and other benefits that had ground on for four and a half years.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a teachers' strike in Hawaii referred incorrectly to next year's election for governor. Lt. Gov. Mazie K. Hirono plans to be a candidate, but she will not be running against Gov. Benjamin J. Cayetano. He is prohibited by law from seeking a third term.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the work of the graphic artist Chris Ware, a creator of alternative comic books, misspelled the surname of a fellow cartoonist from Chicago. He is Ivan Brunetti, not Burnetti. The article also misstated the name of the Chicago alternative weekly that publishes Mr. Ware's work. It is Newcity, not New City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLNER, WILLIAM A.
description: KELLNER-William A. 74, of Rockville Centre, passed away April 7, 2001. Husband of Aileen. Father of Michael, Peter and Paula. Gramp to Nathan and Matt. A loving, generous and caring man. Funeral services were held privately. Contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering.

title: Gay Republican Will Run White House AIDS Office
description: Scott Evertz, a leader among gay Republicans in Wisconsin, will be named director of the White House Office of National AIDS Policy, senior White House officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSCHMIDT, HENRY J.
description: GOLDSCHMIDT-Henry J. April 7, 2001. Beloved and loving husband of Beatrice. Father of Lawrence and Ellen. Father-in-law of Maya. Grandfather of Alix, Erica and Lisa. Brother of Edward and Charles. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Henry J. Goldschmidt Scholarship Fund, Columbia Law School, 116th St at Amsterdam Ave, New York City. Service Monday, 1 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave, corner of 81st St, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, ROBERT ALAN
description: ROSE-Robert Alan. On Saturday, April 7, 2001, we lost Our Hero Robbie. Our family will mourn him deeply. Phyllis and Sy Rose, David and Alycia Rose, Diane and Jeffrey Chalal, Christopher, Samantha and Andrew Rose, Isaac, Aaron and Hannah Chalal. He fought the good fight. Services on Tuesday, April 10, at 11 AM, at Bloomfield Cooper Chapels, 44 Wilson Ave, Manalapan, NJ. As per Robbie's wishes, contributions may made to The Make A Wish Foundation of Greater New York.

title: Article 2001040991583901365 -- No Title
description: April 5, 2001

title: Confession Begets Connection: Details of One Life Resonate With Another
description: Many writers pretend that they don't read reviews of their books and that in particular life is too short to subject themselves to reading bad reviews. Kingsley Amis said that a bad review might spoil your breakfast, but you shouldn't allow it to spoil your lunch. Jean Cocteau suggested: ''Listen carefully to first criticisms of your work. Note carefully just what it is about your work that the critics don't like -- then cultivate it. That's the part of your work that's individual and worth keeping.''

title: America Is Borrowing Trouble
description: Many have criticized President Bush's proposal for a deep and lasting cut in income taxes, but hardly anyone has addressed its implications for what may well be the greatest potential danger facing the economy in the years to come: the large and growing deficit in our international trade balance. A massive, permanent tax cut would make the international economic position of the United States worse, not better. This is in addition to its other disadvantages.

title: Woods Wins Masters for His 4th Straight Major
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8  After making his final putt, an 18-footer for birdie that secured his two-stroke victory today over David Duval, Tiger Woods put his cap over his face and cried softly, finally able to exhale.

title: Nets Play Team With A Purpose
description: The Nets are treading water until the merciful end of the season, down two star players, seven in all to injury, and filling holes with players on extended 10-day contracts.

title: The M.L.S. Season Opens With Upsets
description: This season is supposed to be a rebuilding one for D.C. United and the San Jose Earthquakes, but both teams scored upsets as Major League Soccer opened its sixth season Saturday night. United edged the Kansas City Wizards, the defending champions, 3-2, and the Earthquakes upset the Los Angeles Galaxy by the same score.

title: Tougher U.S. Tone On Spy Plane Crisis
description: Striking a slightly stiffer tone, the Bush administration warned China that its relationship with the United States was being hurt and that it risked further harm with every day that the crew of an American spy plane remained in detention.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Bankruptcy Filing of California Utility Tests the Limits of the Court
description: When the Pacific Gas and Electric Company filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday, a shudder swept through corporate suites across the nation, for not only is California's largest utility directly challenging the authority and power of regulators to set retail rates, but it will test the reach of the federal bankruptcy judge overseeing a case unprecedented in its scope, industry experts and bankruptcy lawyers said.

title: At Niagara Falls, It's Time for a Face Lift
description: To the Editor:

title: Clash of Cellular Towers and Hudson Valley Vistas
description: First the city folks grabbed up the country estates, then the big-box developments threatened to blight the landscape. Now another alarm is being sounded through the Hudson Valley: invasion of the cell phone towers.

title: Essay; The Purloined Treaty
description: You will be relieved to learn that France's copy of the Treaty of Fontainebleau -- signed by Napoleon Bonaparte in 1814 but which mysteriously vanished from the French national archives in 1988 -- has been safely in F.B.I. hands for five years.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Bronx Journal; A Comeback Season for Bruising Irish Sports at Gaelic Park
description: Yesterday had the kind of cold, damp weather that the Irish call a soft day, but on the field at Gaelic Park, the play was anything but.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Senate passage of a budget resolution misstated the measure's allocation of a saving of some $450 billion. The sum, obtained by reducing President Bush's proposed 10-year, $1.6 trillion tax cut, would be divided between spending on education and reductions in the national debt. It would not all be spent on education.

title: If the Incomplete Tuxedo Fits, Wear It
description: If Harry Nilsson was gazing down from heaven's piano bar on the Loser's Lounge Thursday night, he surely loved David Driver's rendition of ''Without You,'' the Badfinger song Nilsson made a hit in 1971.

title: Ballet Leaders for Houston and Boston
description: The Houston Ballet and the Boston Ballet, both of which recently announced the resignations of their artistic directors, have named new administrators. Ben Stevenson, who stepped down as artistic director of the Houston Ballet in February after 25 years, will serve as co-artistic director with his assistant, Trinidad Vives, effective in July. Mr. Stevenson had asked to be named artist in residence at the company.

title: Power in House Is Weak In Bringing Home Bacon
description: Every election year, members of Congress campaign by boasting of how much federal money their experience has steered to their districts, but a new study by the Center for National Policy suggests that individual House members affect those totals only slightly.

description: On the tee of the 170-yard 16th hole, David Duval was tied for the Masters lead with Tiger Woods at 15 under par.

title: Los Angeles Warms to Labor Unions as Immigrants Look to Escape Poverty
description: For decades this city was known as an antiunion town, but now Los Angeles seems to have warmed up to unions, largely because of the huge influx of Hispanic immigrants.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Ifs, Ands or Buts of Drugs for Restless U.S. Children
description: By pure coincidence, two documentaries on two different channels are arriving back to back tonight and tomorrow to examine the same issue: the widening and sometimes harrowing use of psychoactive drugs in America to modify children's behavior. Suffice it to say that the programs -- the first on A&E, the other on PBS -- are in many ways redundant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOBART, FRANCINE
description: HOBART-Francine. Age 80, on April 5, 2001. Beloved wife of David, devoted mother of Pamela Obolsky and Valerie Peck, adored grandmother of Jason Obolsky and Joshua and Jocelyn Peck. Services were held April 6. Contributions in her memory may be made to NYU Medical Center.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WIENER, GABE
description: WIENER-Gabe. Beloved Gabe you are forever present in our hearts. Always missed, always loved. Part of us for infinity. Our love, M, D, and F.

description: It was another epic battle that will have fans of sensational drama yearning for a postseason encore.

title: In America; School Board Mystery
description: Last Wednesday morning, Sandra Lerner, a Board of Education member from the Bronx, thought she was about to be elected president of the board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTERSON, RAYMOND R.
description: PATTERSON-Raymond R. Poet, died April 5, 2001. A viewing will be held Thursday, April 12, 9-10 AM, funeral 10 AM-noon, at Benta's Funeral Home, 630 St. Nicholas Ave at 141st St, NYC.

title: Posada Off to Impressive Start With a Prodigious Show of Power
description: Paul O'Neill was sitting in his customary position at the far end of the Yankees' clubhouse this weekend and gushing about Carlos Delgado. Sometimes, O'Neill said, he wonders if there should be a higher league for Delgado because he is too superb a hitter to be simply in the major leagues. After lavishly complimenting Delgado, he made a revealing segue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ACKERMAN, MILTON J.
description: ACKERMAN-Milton J. Died suddenly on April 7, at North Shore University Hospital. Beloved husband of Sue Ackerman. Devoted father of Carole A. Feuerman, Barbara Pat Ackerman and Richard Ackerman, and father-in-law of Ronald Cohen and Irene Ackerman. Cherished grandfather of Lauren Feuerman Leahy and her husband William, Sari Gibson, Dr. Craig Feuerman and Amanda Ackerman, and great-grandfather of Hannah Rachel Leahy. Loving brother of Toby Hinderstein and Marilyn Weiss, and brother-in-law of Lee Hinderstein and Howard Weiss. He was a graduate of New York University School of Business. He was a NYC medallion fleet owner. He was an officer in the Miami Beach Power Squadron, a past Commodore of the Sands Point Yacht Club, a Vice Commodore of the Neptune Flamingo Yacht Club in Florida, and an officer in the Air Force during World War II. Services Tuesday, 1 PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Interment at Beth David Cemetery. Contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: 16th Hole Foils Mickelson and Duval
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8  On the tee of the 170-yard 16th hole, David Duval was tied for the Masters lead with Tiger Woods at 15 under par.

title: Tax Enforcement Falls
description: Enforcement efforts by the Internal Revenue Service against individual taxpayers have fallen by at least half since the early 1990's, the Justice Department and the I.R.S. say. The agency is less likely to question unreported income, take taxpayers to court or seize their property.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPTOOK, NATHAN PHILIP
description: LAPTOOK-Nathan Philip. Age 95, died April 6, 2001, in New Rochelle, NY. Beloved husband of Pauline. Loving father of Kenneth and Laura. Adored and adoring grandfather of Jennifer, Alexandra, Eve and Julia. Cherished father-in-law of Diana and Robert. A most wonderful man whom we all loved very much. Let us in some way be like him. Funeral services Tuesday, April 10, 2 PM, at George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 Lecount Place, New Rochelle, 914-632-0324. In lieu of flowers, donations may be given to the national office of Women's American ORT, 315 Park Ave South, NYC 10010.

title: Russia Seeks Sanctions Against Pakistan for Aid to Taliban
description: Russia is expected to lead a drive this month to persuade the Security Council to impose sanctions on Pakistan, the strongest supporter of Afghanistan's militant Islamic government, the Taliban, diplomats and United Nations officials say.

title: Riley and Ilian Victorious in Florida
description: Schuyler Riley and her Dutch-bred horse, Ilian, cleared all nine fences on the jump-off course yesterday to win the richest equestrian grand prix in the United States, the $300,000 American Grand Prix Show Jumping Championship in Wellington, Fla. The 29-year-old Riley, who is based in Wellington, also capped off a victory in each of show jumping's three major events by taking the blue ribbon and the $90,000 winner's prize.

title: U.S. Women Drop Seventh World Final
description: Canada survived a last-minute rush by the United States tonight to win its seventh women's world hockey championship, 3-2, and extend its winning streak in this tournament to 35 games.

title: A 'Decency Panel' and Filtered Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Gay Leader to Direct Bush's AIDS Office
description: Scott Evertz, a leader among gay Republicans in Wisconsin, will be named director of the White House Office of National AIDS Policy, senior White House officials say. Mr. Evertz, 38, will be the first openly gay person to serve in a Republican administration, his allies among gay advocacy groups say. The White House officials declined to discuss Mr. Evertz's sexuality or its significance, saying Mr. Bush did not take such concerns into account when making appointments.

title: Carefully Scraping Along, With the Senses Atingle
description: Occasionally there comes along a concert that takes you by surprise and starts you listening all over again. It happened on Thursday night at Miller Theater when, as part of Helmut Lachenmann's weeklong residency, the program included his classic ''Gran Torso'' for string quartet, performed by members of the Ensemble Sospeso, his much more recent piano work ''Serynade,'' and his teacher Luigi Nono's late composition ''La Lontananza Nostalgica Utopica Futura'' (''The Utopian Future in the Nostalgic Distance'' for violinist and recordings.

title: Patents; For tax season, a software package that helps end the hunting for pieces of paper.
description: BY next week, millions of Americans will have fulfilled their obligation to tell the Internal Revenue Service how much they earned last year. More than 120 million tax returns will come from individuals, most from people who drop their paperwork in the mail. But a significant number will be filed electronically. Last year, 30 million returns were delivered via computer, and the I.R.S. projects that number will reach 64 million in 2007.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBIN, BERNARD S.
description: LUBIN-Bernard S. Of Longboat Key, FL, formerly of Harrison, NY, on April 6, 2001, at the age of 7,8 after a valiant battle with lymphoma. Survived by his wife of 56 years, the former Rita Klausner, a daughter Jane (Wayne Stouffer), sons Michael and James (Matthew Wise) and a brother Robert.

title: Masters Rating Up; XFL Still Struggling
description: Tiger Woods's surge to the lead of the Masters during the third round Saturday produced a 7.9 preliminary overnight rating for CBS, up 20 percent from 6.6 a year ago. It was the best third-round overnight rating since 1997, when CBS posted an 8.6.

title: A Politician Returns to the U.S. as a Voice for Yugoslavia
description: WHEN Milan Protic reopened the embassy of Yugoslavia last month, it was like stepping into a haunted house, he said. Most of the furniture was in storage and a thick layer of dust and grime coated the few items that remained: a cheap phone and an ancient computer.

title: Compressed Data; When the Digitally Enhanced Face the Elements
description: The weary business traveler trying to juggle cell phone and hand-held computer might soon be a less common sight -- at least when it rains.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREIFUSS, WALTER
description: DREIFUSS-Walter. Beloved husband of the late Rhoda Dreifuss, devoted father of David and Janet, and father-in-law of Lynn and Albert. Loving grandfather of Rebecca, Samantha and Julia. Funeral at Hewlett East Rockaway Jewish Centre, April 10, 9:30 AM.

title: Test Results From States Reveal Gaps In Learning
description: Test scores to be released today show most states improving the performance o eighth graders in math but few gaining in fourth-grade reading and even fewer narrowing stubborn gaps between black or Hispanic students and white students, a goal President Bush has said schools should have to meet to receive federal education aid.

title: A New Royal Blush in Britain's Press
description: This time it was a minor royal who caused a major flap.

title: Mets Take Braves, 9-4
description: NEW YORK -- The New York Mets never stopped celebrating after raising their National League championship banner.

title: Rangers Should Expect an Off-Season of Change
description: It was time to look to the future today as the Rangers cleaned out their lockers early for the fourth consecutive spring.

title: Calcavecchia Content Despite Costly Bogey
description: Mark Calcavecchia's tie for fourth place at the Masters was his best finish at a major championship since he won the British Open in 1989. While Calcavecchia was disappointed not to win after starting today's final round just two strokes behind Tiger Woods, he was happy with his overall performance.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the second day of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Rivals Say VeriSign Still Has Advantage
description: VeriSign Inc., the designated keeper of the database that stores the Internet's .com addresses, won a big victory last week from Icann, the international organization that oversees the Internet's entire address system.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on March 30 about the smuggling of oil from Iraq to Turkey in violation of United Nations sanctions referred incorrectly in one passage to the Kurdish political party in Iraq, headed by Masoud Barzani, which resells oil and fuel that it buys from the Iraqi government. As noted elsewhere in the article, it is the Kurdistan Democratic Party, not the Kurdistan Peoples Party.

title: German Utility Close to a Deal For Powergen
description: E.ON, the large Germany utility, is close to an agreement to buy Powergen, a British gas and electricity supplier, for $7.4 billion, people involved in the talks said today.

title: Cornell Will Open A Medical School In the Persian Gulf
description: In one of the biggest deals yet in the growing export of American higher education, Cornell University is establishing a branch campus of its medical school in the Middle East, where students will receive the same diploma as those 6,700 miles away in New York City.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He's not like anyone we've seen before in the game.''

title: Orchestrating Broadway; Aside From Talking Up Shows, O'Donnell's Sidekick Coaches Stars
description: Every morning on her talk show, Rosie O'Donnell chats about what she did the night before. And every morning the person she chats with is John McDaniel, who leads her show's band, John McD and the McDLT's, and shares with Ms. O'Donnell his cultural excursions of the previous evening.

title: Will That No-Nonsense Dr. Gideon Be Returning for More House Calls?
description: In the last few months, Ben Gideon -- an uncompromising doctor at a Boston hospital, brought fiercely to life by Andr Braugher -- has treated patients with cancer, hemophilia and congenital deafness. He nearly discovered a miracle cure for the lung cancer of his chief resident's father, a hard-living charmer played by Billy Dee Williams with a savvy allure that makes you wonder where the actor has been. And in a crossover episode with ''The Practice,'' Ben even saved Ellenor's (Camryn Manheim's) unborn child. What he has not done is to find the magic pill that would guarantee himself another season on the air. Yet there is no better drama on network television than ''Gideon's Crossing.''

title: Wings Clipped, the Concorde Set Gets By; After Crash, Hope for Return to Days of the Quick Trans-Atlantic Hop
description: Go ahead, raise an eyebrow. But it isn't easy being subsonic.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 28 about pressure on Prime Minister Ariel Sharon to retaliate against Palestinians for attacks on Israelis referred imprecisely to Pisgat Zeev, a Jewish neighborhood built in 1984, which was the destination of a bus attacked by a Palestinian suicide bomber. While the Palestinians consider it a settlement, the Israelis say it is part of municipal Jerusalem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZARRIN, PHILIP CARY
description: ZARRIN-Philip Cary. Age 59, on April 6. Beloved husband of Sydni. Loving father of Gayle Ellen and Amy Rebecca. Devoted son of Minnie. Dear brother of Lynne. Always in our hearts.

title: Toledo Leads in Peru Election, but May Still Face Runoff
description: Alejandro Toledo, the former shoeshine boy who climbed out of poverty to lead the opposition against former President Alberto K. Fujimori, stood closer today to winning the presidency. But he appeared to fall far short of the majority required to avert a runoff.

title: Twins Adopted on Internet Must Be Returned to U.S.
description: LONDON, April 9  A High Court judge ruled today that American-born twins adopted over the Internet and brought here in December by a British couple must be returned to the United States.

description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Compressed Data; Register for a Nest Egg Instead of a Gravy Boat
description: Amid the death watch for gimmicky consumer Web sites, there was a startling sign of life last week: a new dot-com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUELS, ROBERT P.
description: SAMUELS-Robert P. Born March 6, 1930, in Washington Heights, NY. Beloved husband of Shirley. Devoted father of Laurie and Jeffrey, and Steven and Janet. Loving poppa of Randy, Brian, Matthew and Julie. You will be missed not just as a husband, father and grandfather. You will be missed as the best friend anyone could ever have. Sharing life's joys and pleasures, you were also the one we all turned to for advice, to solve problems or to just make us feel better. How lucky we were to have had you there for us.

title: Fears on Privacy Law Spur Warning by Armey
description: A top Republican leader in the House is sending a strong message to lawmakers hoping to address the privacy worries of their constituents this year: go slow.

title: Talks Are Stalled as the Deadline Comes Closer
description: As April begins to edge toward May 1, the deadline in contract negotiations by the writers of Hollywood films and television series and the studios and networks that buy their scripts, there is growing concern about when the stalled talks will resume and whether there will be enough time to forge an agreement before the deadline hits.

title: With Help, Family's Wandering Comes to an End
description: There was no elevator, so the four children raced up five flights of stairs to their new temporary apartment, in a tenement shelter for homeless families in East Harlem. It came with a sign-in sheet, a curfew, and a bed check by intercom every night. But to the children and their ailing grandmother, it held the promise of home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNULTY, EDWARD C., D.M.D.
description: McNULTY-Edward C., D.M.D. The Board of the William J. Gies Foundation for the Advancement of Dentistry wishes to express its condolences to the family of our esteemed colleague, Dr. Edward C. McNulty. His leadership, wisdom, and dedication to the profession of dentistry will be missed. Allan J. Formicola, D.D.S., Pres.

description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: An Art Deco David Battles The Multiscreen Goliaths
description: In the soothing Art Deco splendor of the Senator theater, a plot for the ultimate movie-house saga takes shape: Commander Megaplex, box-office force of the universe, versus Tom Kiefaber, underdog throwback to the past, when moviegoing seemed more a stylish event of personal escapism than mass merchandising.

title: U.S. Envoys Meet With Entire Crew Detained in China
description: HAIKOU, China, April 9  Two United States diplomats met with all 24 detained crew members of an American surveillance plane here this evening, as President Bush warned in Washington that United States relations with China could suffer if the crew were not freed soon.

title: Footlights
description: EVENTS

description: BASEBALL

title: Pacer Is a Winner, Not Just a Survivor
description: For most of his racing career, he was just another horse, plain brown and, at best, modestly successful on the racetrack. But that would change forever last Thanksgiving, when a fire roared through a stable at Gaitway Farm in Manalapan, N.J., killing 20 standardbreds -- every horse in the barn but one, Netback. And that plain brown horse is back racing, winning and reminding everyone that sometimes from tragedy come small miracles.

title: Now Entering the Ring, a Sprite on the Run
description: Ani DiFranco staggered around the stage of Carnegie Hall on Friday, arms raised in awe, as if it was a boxing ring and she had won the match merely by arriving. ''Practice, practice, practice indeed!'' she said, raising that old joke about how musicians get there. The screams that greeted her slightest gesture represented her other transportation: her fervent fans, whom she quickly and copiously thanked.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday about the laying of sod at Bryant Park misstated the number of new folding chairs to be put on the park's lawn when it opens in mid- to late April. Only 700 chairs, not all 2,200, will be new.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAGLANEAS, REVEREND THEODORE E.
description: BAGLANEAS-Reverend Theodore E. Formerly of New York, Rhode Island and Cape Cod, died Saturday. He was the husband of the late Mary (Joakim) Baglaneas. He is survived by a son John T. Baglaneas of Northboro, MA, and a daughter Anita Devlin of Centerville, MA, also a brother Spiros Baglaneas and sister Anatoula Baglaneas both of Athens, Greece, also four grandchildren. A presanctified Liturgy will begin at 9 AM, Tuesday at the George Greek Orthodox Church, Rte 28, Centerville, MA, followed by a funeral service at 11 AM. Burial will follow at Mosswood Cemetery in Cotuit, MA. Visiting hours will be Monday 5 to 9 PM, at the Doane, Beale & Ames Funeral Home, 160 West Main St, Hyannis, MA. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to the Boston Alzheimer's Center c/o the Reverend Theodore E. Baglaneas Memorial Fund, 434 Jamaica Way, Boston, MA 02130.

title: Sports of The Times; With Stakes Raised, Woods Draws a Straight
description: The question made Tiger Woods hesitate more than he had in assessing any shot in accomplishing what no professional golfer had ever done: winning four consecutive professional major championships.

title: In Third Visit, U.S. Diplomats Meet With Only 8 of 24 Detained Americans
description: Despite asking for ''unfettered'' access to the detained crew members of a downed American surveillance aircraft here, American diplomats were allowed early today to meet with only 8 of the 24 at their third meeting with the crew members and were denied a fourth meeting later in the day.

title: E-Commerce Report; A reservation site owned by the airlines has raised competitive concerns in the travel industry.
description: LAST week's eTravel World conference in New York included the usual dot-com forums on marketing and customer service, with keynote speeches detailing broad visions of the online travel industry. One topic missing from the formal agenda -- but well represented in informal discussions -- could be labeled ''Let's Talk About Orbitz.''

title: U.S. and China Look for a Way To Say 'Sorry'
description: The 24 American servicemen and women passing their days at a Chinese military camp on this steamy onetime treaty port are not only hostages to politics, but hostages to language.

title: Four in a Row for Tiger Woods
description: The purists will say that what Tiger Woods accomplished yesterday when he won the Masters in Augusta, Ga., was not technically the completion of golf's Grand Slam, and technically they will be right. So let us call it the Tiger Slam or the Grand Sweep or the Fantastic Four. Whatever the label, Woods has done something truly amazing in the history of all sports, let alone the history of golf. Beginning with the United States Open last summer, and continuing on through the British Open and the P.G.A. Championship, Woods has now won golf's four most prestigious championships in a row. Looked at another way, Woods is only the second golfer in the history of the game to be able to put the trophies of the four major tournaments on his coffee table, or wherever it is he puts them, at the same time.

title: MediaTalk; Lou Dobbs May Yet Help Out 'Moneyline'
description: Nearly four weeks ago, Stuart Varney, the co-anchor of CNN's ''Moneyline News Hour,'' left the network. Since then, the chair next to Willow Bay's has been empty.

title: Finally, Space for a Dinner Party
description: Those in the New York opera world, like all urban artists, face a difficult question: where to live in gracious style on modest means. For Stephen Pickover, a freelance opera director who works for the Metropolitan Opera and the Riverside Opera, the answer was the pre-war neighborhood of Washington Heights in Upper Manhattan. In fact, parts of Washington Heights, particularly above 181st Street, are sometimes referred to as the "Opera Ghetto" because of the large number of singers and musicians living there.

title: A Publisher Is Appointed at the Free Press
description: Martha K. Levin, 48, has been named vice president and publisher of the Free Press, an imprint of the Simon & Schuster book publishing division of Viacom. Ms. Levin was previously vice president and publisher of Hyperion, a Walt Disney Company book-publishing division.

title: Woods Wins the Masters For His 4th Straight Major
description: After making his final putt, an 18-footer for birdie that secured his two-stroke victory today over David Duval, Tiger Woods put his cap over his face and cried softly, finally able to exhale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIEL, GERDA
description: DANIEL-Gerda. Beloved mother of John and Eva. Devoted mother-in-law of Judie and Alan. Cherished grandmother of Derek, Adrianne and Stephanie. Services Tuesday, 11:30 AM, at ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel,'' 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLUGER, ERICA
description: KLUGER-Erica. On April 6, 2001, at 18. She was a loving daughter of Carol Glassman and Barry Kluger, stepdaughter of Hope Kirsch and Matthew Glassman, granddaughter of Lee and Len Kluger, Lorraine Shuster and the late Marvin Shuster, sister of Zachary and Alley Glassman, niece of Alan Kluger and Judge Amy Dean, Dr. Deborah Shuster and Tom Warren, Andra Shuster and Glenn Hugo, and a friend of many. She loved dancing, music, and was a shining light to everyone who knew her and was touched by her. Her sense of humor, smile and love was infectious and her memory will endure forever. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, April 10, at 10 AM, at Paradise Memorial Gardens, 9300 E. Shea Blvd, Scottsdale, AZ, 480-860-2300. In lieu of flowers, donations to: Erica Kluger Scholarship Fund, The Stroud School of Dance, PO Box 1134, Stony Brook, NY 11790.

title: For the Poor, a Lawyer With 1,600 Clients
description: Last year, Sean P. Sullivan had 1,600 clients, all of them poor and charged with crimes. He did not have to hustle to get the work. His thriving law practice came courtesy of New York City, whose courts appointed him to all the cases, a record number for one lawyer in a single year.

title: Seizing the Phone Giants' Turf; Upstart RCN Digs In Despite Industry's Turmoil
description: David C. McCourt, the RCN Corporation's chairman and chief executive, says he did not set out to become a pioneer, at least not in the telecommunications industry.

description: The billboards loom large over highway intersections, showing people from various walks of life. One features a yuppie in rimless eyeglasses and a tie, the next a village womn with a gold tooth wearing a head scarf and embroidered dress.

title: Hispanic Voter Is Vivid In Parties' Crystal Ball
description: Ever since she became an American citizen 20 years ago, Ana Maria Guerrero has voted for Democrats. Even so, Mrs. Guerrero, 46, a cannery worker, is the kind of Hispanic voter that politicians of both parties see as a golden prize: one whose party loyalties are up for grabs.

title: OPPOSITION BUILDS TO SPENDING CUTS IN BUSH'S BUDGET
description: Even before Monday's formal release of President Bush's detailed budget and the cuts it would make in various domestic programs, influential constituencies have begun to howl in protest.

description: Most of the headlines concerning the business ventures of the billionaire Craig O. McCaw in the last year have focused on his high-stakes maneuvering to pursue his dream of creating a satellite communications empire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSLER, LOUIS
description: OSLER-Louis. 86, on April 6, 2001. Husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather one to whom life was never a bother, a lover of life no matter what it dealt, his abscence today and forever will be felt. Survived by his wife of 62-1/2 years Sylvia, his children, Miriam and Steven and David and Martha, his grandchildren, Shari and Dan, Jonathan, Evan and Jeremy and great-granddaughter, Rebecca. Also survived by his sister Miriam and brother Abraham.

title: The Reluctant Feminist

title: Media; Those who want to control information find an ally in a public that seems to accept restrictions.
description: NEWSPAPERS' basic needs are simple. They need money for presses, paper and workers. They need readers, the better to get advertising revenue. They need information, the better to get readers.

title: Sports of The Times; Costly 'T' Caps Bad Week for Van Gundy
description: PRAYER erupted recently as an issue with the Knicks. The issue of speaking to a higher authority before games, and possibly after, got Knicks Coach Jeff Van Gundy embroiled in controversy. He said that some Knicks might be distracted from the goal at hand -- winning games -- because of: (a) time taken away from their brow-furrowed basketball concentration to attend pregame chapel services, and (b) fraternization at such meetings with the repellent rival.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, ARNOLD
description: GOTTLIEB-Arnold. December 1, 1916-April 7, 2001. Died with a big smile at home. Incredible husband to Joy and devoted father to Andrew and Jill. Adoring grandfather to Ethan and Kyle. Loving brother to Lester. Harvard graduate, class of 1937. Harvard Law School, 1940. Army Air Corps veteran. Practiced law for over 50 years in New York. Senior partner of Hofheimer, Gartlir, Gottlieb and Gross.

title: China's Costly Rigidity
description: China's insistence on a formal American apology for last week's midair collision off Hainan island is unreasonable, considering the lingering uncertainty about the incident. Beijing's unyielding position suggests that it is unwilling or unable to put this episode into perspective and look at the long-term consequences for relations between the United States and China.

title: New Economy; The steamy side of the Internet, pervasive and resilient to recession, is the underpinning of a new online cash venture.
description: WITH the dark clouds of hard times filling the skies, many high-technology companies are cutting back and hunkering down. But some brave entrepreneurs are continuing to innovate. Take Duocash, a New York company that is pursuing one of the fondest longtime dreams of technology entrepreneurs and privacy advocates alike: anonymous, secure payments over the Internet.

title: Baghdad Journal; O Iraqi Youth, Dig It, the Time Has Come to Rock
description: ''What's wrong with you guys? You're all such a bunch of quitters!'' said the brittle-voiced young woman doing the afternoon stint as disc jockey on the most popular radio station in Iraq, Voice of Iraq FM.

title: Under Brendel's Fingers, A Much Earthier Haydn
description: The pianist Alfred Brendel is celebrating his 70th birthday this year, and so far the occasion has been commemorated in style. Vox Records, which holds the rights to Mr. Brendel's early recordings, has just issued them as a six-CD set, and Philips, for which he has recorded for the last three decades, has released a 25-CD overview of his work, as well as some new recordings. His two books of erudite reflections on the repertory have been reissued with a few new entries as a single volume, ''Alfred Brendel on Music.'' Naturally, recitals also figure in the party plans, and Mr. Brendel offered one at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening.

title: Devils Are the Choice to Win the Cup
description: With only 16 of 30 National Hockey League teams in the Stanley Cup playoffs, all the qualifiers are deserving and so are two of the also-rans. The Boston Bruins and the Phoenix Coyotes, who did not make the cut, should play a consolation game to fill the television void before the tournament begins Wednesday night.

title: Management Walks a Unified Line in the Hollywood Talks
description: Normally, they are the best of enemies, scrapping over film and television projects, competing to sign major stars, plotting to outmaneuver one another for the prime release dates, sometimes even going so far as to take undisguised glee in the misfortunes of the others.

description: In the first management changes since Jean-Marie Dru replaced Michael Greenlees last month as president and chief executive at TBWA Worldwide in New York, part of the Omnicom Group, the agency is promoting several top executives.

title: Powell Warns of Damage To Ties as Crisis Drags On
description: Striking a slightly stiffer tone with China, the Bush administration warned Beijing today that its relationship with the United States was already being hurt and that it risked further harm with every day that the crew of an American spy plane remained in detention.

description: A man arrested Friday after he was found spraying a foul liquid on a salad bar in Midtown has also been charged with a similar offense that day at Grand Central Terminal, Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials and the police said yesterday.

description: When Robert J. Harth, the newly appointed executive and artistic director of Carnegie Hall, is asked to describe his vision for the venerable institution, he answers that he doesn't have one. At least, not yet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OAKES, JOHN B.
description: OAKES-John B. Clean Air Campaign mourns the loss of John Oakes. His unfailing integrity, courage and grace under fire will be sorely missed. His lucid columns inspired citizens fighting for a park along the Hudson River without environmentally damaging development in the waters of the river itself, and for the preservation of natural systems in all rivers, wetlands and coastal waters.

title: Volkswagen revamps the Beetle campaign to be more informative.
description: FOR only the second time since they brought back the offbeat Beetle in 1998, Volkswagen of America and its agency, Arnold Worldwide in Boston, are revamping the way it is marketed. The shift, evident in a television, print and Internet campaign that begins today, is emblematic of the changes made by auto makers when the economy starts to soften and enthusiasm flags among car buyers.

title: How to Get Into College After Being Rejected
description: Catesby Holmes scored 800 on the verbal section of the College Boards. She was on the honor roll for four straight years, and she lettered in field hockey and won awards for music, Latin and horseback riding. Yet she did not get into college. Harvard, Princeton, Yale, Columbia, Brown and Wesleyan rejected her; after putting her on the waiting list, so did Amherst and the University of Chicago. "I spent the spring watching friends put college stickers on their cars while I tried to figure out what I was going to do with my life," Catesby remembers. "As in, what was I at this point if not 'collegebound'?"

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

description: Your initial box office encounter tells you that ''Hooray for Iceboy'' is going to be something different. The ''ticket'' you're given is an Ice Cubes chocolate.

title: Quebec Journal; A Chain-Link Fence Rankles an Old Walled City
description: Separation has always been entwined in the raison d'tre of this beguiling bit of France, a walled city perched on a towering promontory and defined by the limits of geography, language and politics.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GASOLINE RISES. Gasoline rose as inventories fell below levels a year earlier as demand picks up before the summer driving season. In New York, gasoline rose 2.2 cents, or 2.3 percent, to 99.12 cents a gallon.

title: Mr. Bush's Distorted Budget
description: The budget of nearly $2 trillion submitted by President Bush yesterday made room for the administration's limited increases in military, medical research and education spending. But because the budget was warped by Mr. Bush's proposal for a $1.6 trillion tax cut, there was little room for growth of discretionary spending anywhere else. Indeed, Mr. Bush's financial plan will open a new round of battles with Congress, where even Republican leaders say they will not accept his deep cuts in farm programs, environmental enforcement and energy. Now as they focus on reversing these harsh spending cuts, lawmakers should reconsider the outsized tax scheme that is the driving force behind them.

title: Metro Business Briefing; GAP CONSOLIDATING STORES
description: Gap Inc. said it would shut six of the company's 35 Manhattan stores over the next year as it expands some existing stores, opens bigger ones and consolidates smaller locations. The stores to be closed are 2,000 square feet to 3,000 square feet in size, said Jack Dougherty, a spokesman for the company, which is based in San Francisco. The Gap's flagship store on 54th Street and Fifth Avenue is 36,000 square feet, and its store at 34th Street and Broadway is 57,000 square feet. The Gap plans to relocate affected employees to other locations, Mr. Dougherty said. It also plans to increase its total retail square footage in New York by 18 percent this year.

description: Two big moves are being made by Havas Advertising in Paris.

description: Lou Dobbs, the business news anchor who left CNN in a public dispute with its management nearly two years ago, has agreed to return to his former network.

title: FIRST BUSH BUDGET PROPOSES TO RAISE AID FOR EDUCATION
description: President Bush unveiled his first budget today, describing his plans to increase federal spending on education and biomedical research while curtailing what he described as ''recent explosive growth'' in other federal programs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, RANDI ELLEN
description: FINKELSTEIN-Randi Ellen. Age 39. Passed away April 6, 2001. She leaves behind her loving and devoted parents Florence and Jerry Finkelstein, sister Nancy and brother-in-law Jeremy Garment, grandparents George and Francie Rosen. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, April 11th at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave, White Plains, N.Y. at 2PM. The family will hold an open house Saturday and Sunday from 2-6pm at their home in Westhampton, N.Y. Contributions in her memory may be made to a cancer research society of your choice. She is greatly missed.

He is Don Nickles, not Nickels.

title: A Reason We Call Our Cheddar 'Sharp' and Shirts 'Loud'
description: People who claim to taste shapes, feel sounds and see numbers or letters in color are often dismissed as having particularly vivid imaginations. Skeptics say many of them probably learned to associate colors with letters as toddlers, from activities like playing with refrigerator magnets.

title: Pregnancy Prevention, the Morning After
description: Three million unintended pregnancies occur each year in this country, followed by about a million medical abortions. Yet if the women knew about and used emergency contraception, better known as the morning-after pill, at least half of these could be prevented.

title: Finding Cancer Drugs in the Most Unlikely Places
description: On Dr. Steven Soignet's wooden desk at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan is an old-fashioned medicine bottle. It is about six inches tall, the kind a country doctor might have used to dispense drugs years ago. Inside it is a silvery powder that has clumped into what looks like little nuggets of shiny gravel. The yellowed label identifies the contents: arsenic.

description: The professional football and basketball teams here are not especially beloved, contemporary art has almost no presence, and much of the time even politics is low-key to the point of boredom.

title: A Makeover for Mr. Familiar; In Race for Mayor, Mark Green Seeks a New Image
description: Mark Green bounced up the steps of the last stop on the No. 7 train in Flushing the other day, grinning broadly at what awaited him on the sidewalk: television crews, news photographers, microphones, reporters and onlookers drawn by the bustle of the candidate with his escort of government and campaign aides. ''It's like late October,'' Mr. Green exclaimed of the turnout as he headed up Main Street to tour one of New York's most heavily Asian-American neighborhoods.

title: Metro Business Briefing; TOWER DEVELOPER CHOSEN
description: The Giuliani administration has selected Edward J. Minskoff to develop a 34-story office tower on a New York City-owned site in TriBeCa. Mr. Minskoff said yesterday that he planned to build a 1-million-square-foot granite and glass building on an L-shaped lot bounded by West and Greenwich Streets, between Warren and Murray Streets. He said he would begin building the tower, designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, in a year, with or without a major tenant. It would be the first new office building in Lower Manhattan in more than a decade. Robert M. Harding, the deputy mayor for economic development, said yesterday that the project ''would make a significant contribution to meeting the growing demand for commercial space.'' The city's Economic Development Corporation did not disclose the sale price for the land. Charles V. Bagli

title: NEWELL RUBBERMAID NAMES PRESIDENT OF NEW DIVISION
description: Newell Rubbermaid Inc. announced the appointment yesterday of Steven R. Scheyer as president of a new division intended to increase sales of the company's products to its biggest customer, Wal-Mart Stores Inc. Wal-Mart accounted for about 15 percent of Newell Rubbermaid's $6.93 billion in sales last year. Newell Rubbermaid makes Calphalon cookware, Rolodex organizers and Levolor blinds, among other products. The move follows the creation last week of units to increase sales at leading home-improvement chains. The new chief executive of Newell Rubbermaid, Joseph Galli, is trying to revive sales through marketing, new products and the consolidation of business units, rather than relying on acquisitions for growth.

description: How the president's budget proposes to alter programs: Pages A16-17.

title: Mozart Never Imagined A Hero in Pajama Bottoms
description: The Henry Street Music School on the Lower East Side of Manhattan boasts an intimate 350-seat jewel-box theater with a nice-size stage, a serviceable orchestra pit and lively acoustics. Recently refurbished, the theater is now home to the Henry Street Chamber Opera, a new company devoted to presenting lesser-known works in professional productions at affordable prices, which fits with the school's long tradition of community outreach.

title: Still Acting as a Leader, Aikman Departs on Top
description: In the past few months, quarterback Troy Aikman has heard from a number of people -- family members, friends, former teammates and others -- who either directly or subtly said he should retire from the National Football League.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in the special Education Life section on Sunday ranking authors by popularity, with an article about the wars over literature curriculums, misspelled the middle name of one author. He was Edgar Allan Poe, not Allen.

title: BMW'S SALES INCREASE
description: Worldwide car sales at BMW jumped 9.7 percent in the first three months of this year, compared with a year ago, the company reported. BMW, the Munich-based manufacturer of luxury cars, thus escaped the steep declines that have plagued both its home market in Germany and its biggest export market, the United States. BMW said it sold 220,000 cars in the first quarter, which included a surprisingly strong increase of 12 percent in the United States and 8 percent in Europe. Edmund L. Andrews

title: A Universal Library
description: In the emerging information-based economy, Americans need access to knowledge and learning across a lifetime. Teaching workers new technology skills is as important as teaching farmers new agricultural skills was before the turn of the last century. But the Internet and digital communications are being largely wasted as a resource for the kind of broad education the future demands.

title: KENNAMETAL TO ELIMINATE AT LEAST 200 ADDITIONAL JOBS
description: Kennametal Inc., a maker of industrial tools and equipment, said yesterday that it would cut additional jobs and take a restructuring charge, warning that falling sales would hurt profit in its fourth-quarter. Kennametal, based in Latrobe, Pa., said it would eliminate 200 to 250 salaried jobs, mostly in North America, where a slowdown in manufacturing has affected sales. The company, which has about 13,000 employees, said the reductions represented 6 percent to 8 percent of its salaried work force. The company will take a fourth-quarter charge of $4 million to $6 million for the restructuring, which is expected to save about $10 million to $15 million annually. The announcement follows several months of layoffs and attrition that resulted in the elimination of 500 jobs.

title: AT&T PLANS TO SELL CABLEVISION STOCK
description: AT&T is seeking to sell its interest in Cablevision Systems, one of New York's largest cable television companies, the latest move by AT&T to raise funds through the sale of a large shareholding. AT&T said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it wanted to register to sell 30 million Cablevision shares valued at about $1.98 billion. The shares represent about a one-third stake in Cablevision. Cablevision shares closed yesterday at $64.50, down $1.60. Simon Romero

title: U.S. Shies Away From Threats In Plane Standoff With China
description: President Bush's senior advisers have concluded for now that the most severe acts of retaliation they could threaten in the spy-plane standoff with China -- selling advanced arms to Taiwan, restricting trade, derailing Beijing's bid for the Olympics -- would not speed the release of the 24 American crew members and could harm longer-term interests in Asia, administration officials said.

title: A Scientist's Tragic Hubris Attains Critical Mass Onstage
description: On May 21, 1946, Louis Slotin, a physicist working on the bomb development in a secret laboratory near Los Alamos, N.M., was demonstrating a procedure known as a crit test. The test was meant to verify that the plutonium core of an atomic bomb had the right size and heft -- the critical mass -- to sustain the chain reaction among atomic particles that would cause an explosion. Performing the test was risky; Richard Feynman, the Nobel Prize-winning physicist, referred to it as ''tickling the dragon's tail.''

description: PAPAJOHN-Alice. 86, on April 7. Devoted wife of the late Harry Papajohn. Beloved mother of the late Mary. Loved sister of Angeliki and the late Panos. Friends may call from 79PM on Tuesday at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: Unlimited Golf Package

title: LEADING LEATHER RETAILER TO ACQUIRE BENTLEY'S LUGGAGE
description: A leading retailer of leather goods, Wilsons the Leather Experts Inc., said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Bentley's Luggage Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. Wilsons, with sales of about $637 million in the year ended Feb. 3, said the move was part of a plan to reach $1 billion in sales. Bentley's, based in Miami and privately held, sells travel products and accessories from 106 stores in the United States. It expects fiscal 2001 sales of about $100 million. Wilsons has 574 stores in the United States, Canada and Britain.

title: Hollywood Talks to Restart
description: The Writers Guild of America and Hollywood movie and television studios said today that they would resume negotiations on a new contract April 17, about two weeks before the union's contract is set to expire. Earlier discussions between the guild and the studios broke off March 1 after six weeks of talks. The guild's contract expires on May 1, and the Screen Actors Guild's contract expires on July 1. The studios are represented by the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers. Strikes by both unions would stop production of most films and TV shows and would cost the Los Angeles area $1.8 billion a month or more in lost revenue, economists and industry executives have said. The last major writers strike, in 1988, lasted six months.

title: E.ON TO BUY POWERGEN
description: E.ON confirmed that it had agreed to buy Powergen for 5.1 billion ($7.3 billion) to become Europe's second-largest electricity supplier behind Electricit de France. E.ON also said it planned to sell its nonenergy assets, including Degussa A.G., a large specialty chemicals group, over the next five years, a decision that may speed approval for the deal, at least in the United States, where regulators frown on conglomerates owning utilities. E.ON will pay 7.65 a share for each Powergen share, and will assume 4.5 in debt. Shares of Powergen rose 2 percent, to 7.195, while E.ON shares fell 17 percent. In a sign that E.ON's buying spree is not over, the chairman, Ulrich Hartmann, said ''the acquisition of Powergen is one major step, but certainly not the last one.'' Suzanne Kapner

title: Retail Gasoline Prices Rise
description: WASHINGTON, April 9  Retail gasoline prices jumped 5.8 cents in the last week, the biggest gain in 10 months, reaching a national average of $1.50 a gallon, according to a Department of Energy survey. The weekly gain was the biggest since mid-June and pushed prices above year-ago levels for the first time in six weeks. Prices were 2.5 cents higher than in the week a year ago, the survey of about 800 filling stations showed. Prices were the highest on the West Coast, where a gallon of regular rose 2.3 cents, to $1.66 a gallon, and in the Midwest, where gasoline rose 7.2 cents, to $1.52. Regular gasoline was the cheapest in the region from Alabama to New Mexico, where prices rose 5.9 cents, to $1.413 a gallon. Retail diesel fuel rose 0.6 cent, to $1.397 a gallon, the department said. Diesel prices are 2.2 cents lower than a year ago.

title: SAWTEK TRIMS PROFIT FORECAST AND SAYS IT WILL CUT JOBS
description: Sawtek Inc., a maker of cellular-phone components, said yesterday that profit and sales for the rest of 2001 would be lower than in 2000 and that it would cut 35 jobs in Costa Rica because of a slowdown in the wireless and communications markets. Sawtek projects revenue to be 15 percent to 20 percent lower in fiscal 2001 than it was in fiscal 2000 and net income to be down slightly more than revenue. Sawtek, based in Apopka, Fla., said it was reducing work hours and encouraging workers to take early retirement in addition to the layoffs in Costa Rica. The company said it would continue to recruit engineers and sales personnel. The shares of Sawtek fell as low as $12.61 in after-hours trading. The stock closed at $14.18 in regular trading, and has fallen 69 percent this year.

He has a carefully picked and polished jazz hall of fame in his mind, and on many occasions -- albums, interviews, concerts -- he will show in words or music exactly why Jelly Roll Morton or James P. Johnson or Fats Waller or Thelonious Monk was so impressive.

title: 'A New Improved Me': Now Appearing Everywhere
description: ''I'm a better person than I used to be'' may seem the exclusive mantra of former presidents, chastened lovers and veterans of the analytic couch. But if a series of studies by two social psychologists offers any indication, the conviction that today's self is a new and improved version of yesterday's is, in fact, ubiquitous.

title: SALTON WARNS OF REDUCED SALES AS ORDERS FALL
description: The appliance manufacturer Salton Inc., with products including George Foreman grills and UltraSonex toothbrushes, said yesterday that sales fell in its third quarter and revenue would be hurt this quarter as retailers reduced orders. The company may also buy a manufacturer in Europe, Salton said. Sales in the quarter ended March 31 were $152 million to $156 million, down from $172.1 million last year, Salton said. Its shares are down almost 33 percent this year.

title: From One Chief Executive to Another, Zany Grins
description: LARRY DIVNEY's bags are packed. The habitually irreverent chief executive of the terminally irreverent cable channel, Comedy Central, celebrating its 10th anniversary as television's only all-humor-all-the-time destination, is leaving the country. But no, he hasn't been deported because of last week's inaugural episode of ''That's My Bush,'' the network's zany take on the balancing act between connubial bliss and presidential posturing now in progress inside the White House.

title: TV Film Rekindles Dispute Over Anne Frank's Legacy
description: Anne Frank was 15 when she died with her sister at the Nazis' Bergen-Belsen camp only a few weeks before British troops liberated the prisoners there. Anne's diary of her years in hiding before being seized by German soldiers is the most widely read Holocaust document, an intimate chronicle of remarkable optimism in the face of evil.

About 70,000 of the cars covered by the recall have been exported, mostly to Europe. None of the vehicles were exported to the United States. Miki Tanikawa

title: Metro Business Briefing; TWO CUSHMANS, THEN ONE

The combined company would have revenues of about $900 million, with 965 real estate brokers in 174 offices. The companies did not disclose the sale price. The boards of both companies must approve the deal. Arthur J. Mirante II, chief executive of Cushman & Wakefield, said the pending deal underscored the need for consolidation among brokers as the economy cools. John C. Cushman III and his twin brother, Louis, founded Cushman Realty 23 years ago after leaving Cushman & Wakefield, which was founded by a grandfather, J. Clydesdale Cushman. Charles V. Bagli

title: Metro Business Briefing; WHITE PLAINS REDEVELOPMENT
description: Cappelli Enterprises has signed a contract with Tishman Speyer Properties to buy a three-acre site in downtown White Plains and build a $225 million entertainment, residential and retail complex. The redevelopment of the site, which has remained vacant since Macy's left it in 1996, has been the cornerstone of the city's plan to revitalize its commercial district. Tishman Speyer bought the property for $12.2 million in 1998 and planned a $125 million project with a multiplex and shopping center, but withdrew the proposal after having problems with financing. A Cappelli spokesman would not disclose the purchase price or specific tenants, but said the closing is scheduled for April 23, with demolition due to begin this summer. The company will meet with the White Plains Common Council and the mayor on April 24 to present the proposal, city officials said. The company, based in Valhalla, N.Y., and owned by Louis Cappelli, developed the New Roc City sports, entertainment and retail complex in New Rochelle, N.Y., and recently announced plans for a 320-foot tower nearby, which would be the tallest building in Westchester. Corey Kilgannon

title: Impassioned Mourners, Pained and Puzzled
description: From the opening chorus, there is visceral drama in Bach's ''St. Matthew Passion.'' In gravely undulant phrases, one group of choristers implores, almost commands, another to come and mourn Jesus. ''See ye!'' they sing; ''The Bridegroom see! See Him!'' The confused second group sings back, virtually shouts back: ''Whom? . . How?'' These sputtered responses are shocking. Almost operatic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNARD, DAVID A.
description: BERNARD-David A. , 55 years old. Of West Palm Beach, FL, died suddenly on Wednesday, April 4, 2001. Born in Toronto, Canada, he was the son of Seymour and Evelyn Bernard. He was educated at Cheshire Academy in Cheshire, CT and graduated from Teaneck High School in Teaneck, NJ. Mr. Bernard was a lifelong member of the B'nai B'rith of New York and a member of the Sky Club of New York, NY. He was registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission as an investment Advisor, with the NASD as a broker/dealer & with the CFTC as a commodity trading advisor. Currently he was President of the Indianapolis Securities Inc., a twelve-year-old NASD registered full service broker dealer, with offices in Florida and Michigan. He was also president of June Fourth Corporation in Boca Raton. Previous experience included Chief Operating Officer and member of the Board of Directors of Milestone Properties, Inc., a New York Stock Exchange listed company. He was co-founder and director of Concord Assets Group Inc. of Boca Raton, FL, and NY, NY from 1981 until 1986. Early in his career, he was vice president of Mortgage Corporation of America of NY and President of Tower Funding, Inc., also of NY. He is remembered as an entertaining raconteur with a wonderful sense of humor and of the absurd. He was a devoted husband and father whose constant love remains unquestioned. He is survived by his wife, Francine Gouvin Bernard; his daughter, Claire Rose Bernard; and his son, Maximilian David Bernard, all of West Palm Beach. Committal Services will be held at 11AM on Friday, April 13, 2001 in the Riverbend Cemetery of Westerly, RI. For information, Quattlebaum Funeral Home, West Palm Beach, FL, (561) 832-5171. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to the Napatree Fund, a fund established by Mr. Bernard in 1986 to assist with the education expenses of his children, nieces and nephews, c/o Eric. J. Gouvin, Esq., 84 Benedict Terrace, Long Meadow, MA. 01106.

United edged the Kansas City Wizards, the defending champions, 3-2, and the Earthquakes upset the Los Angeles Galaxy by the same score.

title: Leftist Ex-President Makes Surprising Comeback in Peru
description: It was only 11 years ago that Alan Garca left the presidency as a political pariah, blamed for presiding over an inflation rate of more than 1,000 percent, rising terrorist violence, army massacres, food rationing, huge devaluations of the currency and uncontrolled government corruption.

title: RULING AGAINST RETAILER
description: A court in Paris ruled that the British retailer, Marks & Spencer violated French labor regulations when it announced last week that it would close 18 stores in France, jeopardizing 1,700 jobs, without formally consulting with its French workers. But Marks & Spencer said the ruling would probably not delay its plan to close all its stores in Continental Europe, including the unprofitable French stores, in an effort to increase profitability. The decision by Marks & Spencer caused particular anger among French labor unions and leaders of the leftist government, since it was announced the same day the French food group, Danone, announced a reorganization of its cookie-baking activities, with the loss of several thousand jobs. John Tagliabue

title: PHONE CONCERN'S PROFIT IS UP
description: China Mobile(Hong Kong) Ltd., an arm of China's biggest mobile-phone company, said profit last year almost quadrupled because of income from mobile-phone networks it purchased from its parent in 1999 and 2000. The company said net income rose to 18 billion yuan ($2.2 billion) in 2000, compared with 4.8 billion yuan in 1999. Operating profit rose, reflecting contributions from 10 wireless networks China Mobile bought from its parent, the government-owned China Mobile Communications Corporation, in October 1999 and October 2000.

title: NEC TO HALT D-RAM CHIP PRODUCTION IN U.S.
description: The NEC Corporation said yesterday that it planned to halt production of dynamic random access memory chips in the United States by the end of June. Citing a severe downturn in demand for 16-megabit old-generation memory products, NEC Electronics will close part of its semiconductor assembly and test operations in Roseville, Calif. It will focus instead on production of advanced-system large-scale integrated circuits and logic devices, NEC said. The company, a Japanese semiconductor maker, had announced Friday that it would cut 700 of the 1,600 employees at the Roseville plant.

title: PAPER COMPANY SEEKS CREDIT
description: The Asia Pulp and Paper Company, which stopped repaying its $12.2 billion of debt last month, asked creditors for another $200 million in working capital and 12 months to prepare a proposal to reschedule its debt, according to creditors who attended the meeting. In its first meeting with creditors since stopping the debt payments, the company, Asia's biggest pulp and paper maker outside Japan, also asked creditors to stop all legal action including attempts to seize collateral. That would allow the company to stabilize operations and assess the assets it will sell.

title: Curbing Small Arms
description: From Colombia and Afghanistan to the Balkans, Sri Lanka and the multiple war zones of Africa, the most prolific killers in the last decade have relied not on complex high-tech weapons systems but on cheap and portable small arms. Low-tech weapons like assault rifles, machine guns, pistols and hand grenades have been responsible for as much as 90 percent of the world's conflict-related killing in the decade since the end of the cold war. The availability of small arms has magnified ethnic conflicts, empowered warlords and contributed to an appalling toll in civilian casualties.

title: A 60's Legend Returns With Old Tunes and New Faces

Even though his original band's best-known members, Geoff Muldaur and Maria Muldaur, both recently released separate albums in which they performed versions of the same material purveyed by the Jug Band -- 1920's to 50's blues, jazz, and folk -- Mr. Kweskin's new act featured all new members.

title: Gene Study Shows Ties Long Veiled In Europe

And although the only data it records are who is related to whom, this information can be leveraged into a vivid and otherwise unattainable account of the movement of different groups as people spread out across the globe.

title: FOUNDRY NETWORKS REVENUE FALLS

Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had expected the company, based in San Jose, Calif., to have revenue of about $92 million.

title: VIGNETTE EXPECTS TO REPORT LOSS
description: The Vignette Corporation, which develops software used to build Web sites, said yesterday that it expected to report a first-quarter loss. Revenues for the quarter were better than had been predicted by market analysts, but the company said it anticipated a loss of 1 cent a share. ''While our revenue is within the range of financial analyst estimates, it did not meet our own expectations,'' said Greg Peters, chief executive of Vignette. The companybased in Austin, Tex., said revenue for the quarter would be about $90 million. And Mr. Peters said the company should finish the quarter with about $420 million in cash. Changing the ''economic climate'' of the company and cutting costs, he said, improved the financial outlook. In January, Vignette cut its work force by 15 percent, laying off more than 300 of its 2,300 employees.

title: Funeral March Fit for a Queen and a Leap Across Time

Then without a break, three centuries of harmony are crossed, and the solid minor chord of Purcell's close is followed by the vaporous tonality that opens Luciano Berio's Requies, now played by the orchestra that had been waiting on the platform.

title: The Week in Science: Inelegant Fixes
description: Einstein could never make his mind up about the cosmological constant, an inelegant fix he cooked up to make his cosmological equations come out right. The fix amounted to positing that there exists a weak repulsive force in the universe that counteracts the effects of gravity. Having announced the fix, Einstein then repudiated it. But in the last few years cosmologists have resurrected it, and now a Hubble telescope snapshot of a star that exploded when the universe was young has provided experimental support for the dubious constant. [See Article One]

title: The City Life; Ancient Tulips
description: I know a horse trainer who says that if you could just carry square one with you, you'd never have to go back to square one. I heard that at a county fairground in eastern Wyoming, but it came back to me on Park Avenue yesterday. I was standing in the median crosswalk north of 63rd Street and there, in a small raised plot, were the first two tulips I've seen blooming this spring. They are a species of tulip called Tulipa schrenkii, discovered by Europeans in 1585 but native, as the tulip historian Anna Pavord writes, to the steppes and low mountains of Crimea and Transcaucasia. Their presence this spring on Park Avenue indicates the growing importance of gardening with heirloom and antique plants -- the botanical equivalent of carrying square one with you.

description: The unyielding insistence on an American apology in the spy plane affair provides a revealing and disturbing picture of high-level decision-making in Beijing. Despite yesterday's formal statement of regret by President Bush, the influence of the military leadership could delay a speedy resolution of the affair and distort the future course of relations between the United States and China.

title: GILLETTE LOWERS ITS SALES FOR THE LAST 2 YEARS
description: The Gillette Company said yesterday that it would lower its sales of the last two years by almost 1 percent as it restates results to change how it accounts for coupons and other promotions. Gillette, which makes Mach3 razors and Duracell batteries, changed its accounting for promotions this year. To make the previous years comparable, sales each year will be lowered by about $60 million to $80 million, with no effect on earnings, a spokesman, Eric Kraus, said. Gillette reported sales of $9.30 billion last year and $9.15 billion in 1999. Last year, the Financial Accounting Standards Board mandated that companies no longer include coupons, rebates and free products as part of sales.

While the schoolgirls begged producers to let them into the studio for the day's taping of ''Total Request Live,'' Adam looked on dour-faced. title: REPORTS OF BANK TAKEOVER
description: The parent company of Singapore's largest bank, DBS Group Holdings, suspended trading in its shares amid speculation that it had agreed to buy control of the Dao Heng Bank Group of Hong Kong, the latest in a string of acquisitions in Asia. DBS will offer to pay 63.5 Hong Kong dollars ($8.14) a share for the Guoco Group's 71.5 percent Dao Heng stake, The Hong Kong Economic Times reported. The South China Morning Post reported DBS will pay 54 Hong Kong dollars ($6.92) a share. That represents a premium of 44 percent to 69 percent, and values the bank as much as 44.3 billion Hong Kong dollars ($5.7 billion). A spokeswoman for Guoco, which is based in Hong Kong, Dora Kuo, speaking for Dao Heng as well, declined comment as did a DBS spokesman, Chuck Newton. Dao Heng operates 72 outlets in Hong Kong.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, SEYMOUR J. RABBI, PH.D.
description: COHEN-Seymour J. Rabbi, Ph.D., died at home on April 9, 2001 after a long illness. Beloved husband for 55 years of Naomi Greenberg Cohen. Loving father of Grace (Ira) Grossman, Marc (Laura Leon) Cohen & Dr. Leeber (Elizabeth Jacob) Cohen. Cherished grandfather of Dov and Ari Grossman, Michelle, Susan, Stephen and Jonathan Cohen, fond brother of Eugene J. (Ada) Cohen, Phyllis Marcus and the late Mickey (Paula) Cohen. Caring uncle to many nieces & nephews. Born in New York in 1922, he earned a BS at CCNY in 1942, was ordained at the Jewish Theological Seminary in 1946, and earned a Ph.D. in Economics at the University of Pittsburgh in 1953. He studied at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem and worked with Holocaust survivors in Italy and France. Rabbi of the Patchogue (NY) Jewish Community Center, B'nai Israel, Pittsburgh, and Anshe Emet Synagogue, Chicago. He led many Jewish organizations. He served as President of the Rabbinical Assembly of America, was President of the Synagogue Council of America and chaired the American Jewish Conference on Soviet Jewry. In 1965, he led the first Eternal Light Vigil for Soviet Jewry in Washington, DC. He taught Human Relations at the University of Pittsburgh, was a visiting professor of Judaism at St. Mary of the Lake Seminary in Chicago and was co-chair of the Interreligious Committee against Poverty. Author of numerous volumes, through his translations he opened up to English readers the genre of medieval Jewish ethical literature. Graveside services will be held in New York on Wednesday at Union Field cemetery at 2PM. Shiva will be in New York after Passover. Contributions may be made to the Jewish Theological Seminary Library.

First-quarter earnings were 23 cents to 26 cents a share, excluding good will, less than the forecast of 30 cents to 34 cents, the company, based in San Jose, Calif., said. Revenue was $262 million, below Cypress's earlier estimate of $280 million. Second-quarter profit is expected to be less than 10 cents a share before good will, Cypress said.

title: FINANCING FOR 'LAST MILE' FIBER COMPANY
description: CityNet Telecommunications Inc., a company that solves the problem of bridging the ''last mile'' of fiber optic lines to buildings by sending cable-laying robots into sewers, said it had secured $275 million in financing. The company, based in Silver Spring, Md., got $175 million in cash and $100 million in equity financing from five investment firms, including the Carlyle Group and Berkshire Partners. The company got a $100 million round of financing in April 2000. ''We're tremendously excited about it,'' said Robert G. Berger, chief executive of CityNet -- especially in light of the financing problems other technology companies have faced recently. ''These are definitely interesting times,'' he said. John Schwartz

title: ENRON PAYMENT DISPUTE
description: The financial woes of the Dabhol Power Company in India, 65 percent owned by the Enron Corporation, have deepened with the government of India's refusal to pay the $22 million that the company says it is owed under its contract with the Maharashtra State Electricity Board. Both the state and central governments had guaranteed that they would pay the bills for the huge power plant if the electricity board failed to do so, but are refusing on the ground that the company owes a penalty for a technical failure to meet other contractual terms. The dispute now goes to a conciliation panel, and, if that fails, to arbitration in London. American diplomats have warned that the government's failure to live up to the guarantee could endanger future foreign investment in India. The Dabhol project is the largest foreign investment ever made in India. Celia W. Dugger
