title: Abandoned as a Boy and Downhill Since
description: ''Joe Dirt'' stars a self-consciously poignant David Spade as a man who was abandoned by his parents during a family trip to the Grand Canyon when he was a boy. When he emerged from digging through a garbage can, he was alone. He's spent the rest of his life trying to find his family, a feat made all the more difficult because he can't remember his last name, which isn't really Dirt. The film, written by Mr. Spade and Fred Wolf, teeters on the fine line between condescending and corrupt, because it makes fun of Joe, who is a hapless trailer denizen, but also wants us to feel sorry for him.

title: Freezing Government
description: President Bush described the budget he unveiled Monday as a ''new way of doing business in Washington'' that faithfully reflected the ''compassionate conservatism'' he espoused during his campaign. The budget was compassionate in one sense. It did not contain the harsh language that earlier Republican administrations and the Newt Gingrich crowd used to describe the federal role. The Bush team has obviously learned the virtues of speaking softly. Basic services will survive and no departments will be eliminated. Yet a careful reading of the fine print does little to dispel the impression that on the whole the budget's conservatism outweighs its compassion, even though there are some surprising cuts in corporate welfare in the form of budget reductions for the Export-Import Bank and for shipbuilding subsidies. But in general this is a business-friendly budget with a lean, carefully targeted approach to spending on social programs.

title: Business Travel; As airlines iron out labor woes, the travel industry must deal with corporate belt tightening.
description: BUSINESS travelers now have two fewer things to worry about this spring and summer. On Monday, Northwest Airlines and its 9,800 mechanics and custodians reached a deal to forestall a long-feared strike. The same day, the threat of work disruptions at American Airlines was averted when its 11,000 unionized pilots agreed on terms for assimilating the 2,400 pilots of the newly acquired Trans World Airlines into their ranks.

title: Miami Beach's Alexander Resort
description: Summer is the hottest time of the year in southern Florida, but it's also the most convenient time for families to take a vacation. At least there are some price breaks at Miami Beach hotels. For example, the Alexander Resort, an all-suite hotel on the oceanfront with 150 units, has Summer Splash rates starting at $185 a night for a one-bedroom suite and $299 for two bedrooms, with a minimum two-night stay. That includes a daily buffet breakfast for adults and $100 in credits toward resort amenities. Rates are available May 1 to Sept. 30; they are subject to availability, and taxes are extra. Information: (800) 327-6121 or www.alexanderhotel.com .

title: Ireland Arrests I.R.A. Dissident Suspected of Omagh Bombing
description: LONDON, April 11  Ireland has arrested the alleged leader of the dissident Real IRA, the group that blew up the market center of Omagh three years ago, and Irish and British officials plan to base their prosecution on the testimony of an American who succeeded in infiltrating the ruling council of the clandestine group.

title: MARCONI CUTTING JOBS
description: Marconi P.L.C. of Britain said it would eliminate 3,000 jobs, or 5.5 percent of its staff, as it faces a slowdown in demand for phone equipment. The layoffs will help save more than 200 million ($287 million) by the end of fiscal 2003, the company said. Despite the slowdown, Marconi said it was on track to report operating earnings of 800 million for the year ended March 31, which is in line with analysts' expectations. Shares jumped 10 percent to 3.41 ($4.89), though they are down 53 percent this year. Marconi joins other phone equipment makers in eliminating jobs. Siemens of Germany said yesterday that it would cut 2,000 jobs, and the Nortel Networks Corporation, Lucent Technologies and Alcatel have cut their work forces. Suzanne Kapner

title: How to Get Into College After Being Rejected
description: Catesby Holmes scored 800 on the verbal section of the College Boards. She was on the honor roll for four straight years, and she lettered in field hockey and won awards for music, Latin and horseback riding. Yet she did not get into college. Harvard, Princeton, Yale, Columbia, Brown and Wesleyan rejected her; after putting her on the waiting list, so did Amherst and the University of Chicago. "I spent the spring watching friends put college stickers on their cars while I tried to figure out what I was going to do with my life," Catesby remembers. "As in, what was I at this point if not 'collegebound'?"

title: Put On a Public Face
description: Hello Naomi,'' the e-mail message began. It had arrived out of nowhere, a request for me to explain everything I knew about whether e-mail was more like speech or writing. After presenting me with a long list of questions, the sender, a graduate student working on his master's thesis, closed with, ''OK NAOMI . . . I really need your information as soon as possible.'' I responded (politely and briefly), though ''OK NAOMI'' seemed rather casual from a person who was, after all, seeking my help.

title: McGraw-Hill Appointment
description: The McGraw-Hill Companies said yesterday that it had appointed Scott Marden, 46, president of its information and media services unit, which runs the BusinessWeek Group and Platts. Mr. Marden was recently a partner at Compass Partners International , where he helped issue equities for a European leveraged buyout fund. Mr. Marden previously directed publishing, licensing and software activities at the Marvel Entertainment Group. The information and media services unit also owns Aviation Week & Space Technology magazine. The division had revenue of $1.07 billion in 2000.

title: Reckonings; Muddled in the Middle
description: Last year's election revealed a nation sharply divided by geography. The ''heartland'' -- the largely rural interior -- went solidly for George W. The Electoral College gives states with small populations disproportionate weight, so Mr. Bush now resides in the White House even though Al Gore got more votes.

title: Off to the Cemetery With Laughter, Tears and Belches
description: As ''Kingdom Come'' lurches jovially between low vaudeville farce and teary-eyed pathos, it's easy to see why this essentially serious comedy feels compelled to flail in so many directions at once. For in its heart of hearts this portrait of a troubled African-American family coping with the sudden death of a patriarch is a realistic, downbeat drama of people struggling for a living and of generational and marital strife aggravated by economic hardship.

His favorite is Big Shane, a 1,300-pound gray gelding that Robinson bought 16 years ago when he was a star defenseman for the Montreal Canadiens. ''He's almost 21 years old now,'' said Robinson, the 49-year-old coach of the Devils. ''He's a big, strong, old man. Every time I get out on him, he gives a few little bucks like he's still a young kid.''

title: LONDON FOG TO EMERGE FROM BANKRUPTCY, LAWYER SAYS
description: London Fog Industries, the maker of raincoats and outerwear, is set to emerge from bankruptcy next week after shedding more than $100 million in debt, a lawyer for the company said yesterday. London Fog filed for bankruptcy protection in September 1999 after an aggressive plan to open retail stores hurt its profits. The company, based in Seattle, has since reorganized, closing 119 stores. Under the company's Chapter 11 reorganization plan, bondholders will swap $111 million in claims for about 96 percent of the company's shares, said Kelley Cornish, a bankruptcy lawyer in New York who is representing London Fog. Other creditors will get the remaining 4 percent of the stock. ''Barring any appeals, the plan will go into effect April 17. and we'll emerge from bankruptcy,'' Ms. Cornish said yesterday.

title: Now It's Torn Up, Now It Isn't. Photos Differ on Spy Plane.

title: FACTORY 2-U, DISCOUNT CLOTHING RETAILER, WILL POST LOSS
description: Factory 2-U Stores shares fell 12 percent yesterday after the company, a retailer of discount clothing, said it would have an unexpected fiscal first-quarter loss, partly because it cut prices to clear out spring clothing. Factory 2-U, based in San Diego, will have a loss of 7 cents to 11 cents a share in the quarter ending May 5 because colder-than-expected weather damped demand for spring apparel, the company said on Monday. It was expected to earn 13 cents by analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. Factory 2-U earned $1.6 million, or 12 cents, in the first quarter a year ago.

And then, as soon as the island itself comes within view, there are the welcoming scents of oregano, thyme, sage, honey and salt mingling on the sea breeze, an aroma that could be bottled as Ikaria's own seductive perfume.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA ENRON PAYMENT DISPUTE The financial woes of the Dabhol Power Company in India, 65 percent owned by the Enron Corporation , have deepened with the government of India's refusal to pay the $22 million that the company says it is owed under its contract with the Maharashtra State Electricity Board. Both the state and central governments had guaranteed that they would pay the bills for the huge power plant if the electricity board failed to do so, but are refusing on the ground that the company owes a penalty for a technical failure to meet other contractual terms. The dispute now goes to a conciliation panel, and, if that fails, to arbitration in London. American diplomats have warned that the government's failure to live up to the guarantee could endanger future foreign investment in India. The Dabhol project is the largest foreign investment ever made in India. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: KENNARD JOINS HANDSPRING BOARD
description: Handspring Inc., a maker of hand-held computers, said William E. Kennard, the former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, had joined its board. Appointed to the F.C.C. in late 1997, Mr. Kennard worked to foster competition in local telecommunications markets. One of his last official acts was to approve the merger of America Online and Time Warner after imposing conditions that he said would ''preserve the openness of the Internet.'' Handspring, a competitor of Palm Inc., has been gaining market share with its popular Visor line of personal organizers. ''We are only beginning to witness a great fusion between hand-held computing and wireless technology,'' Mr. Kennard said in a statement. Shares of Handspring rose $2.01, or 18 percent, to $13.10, on the news. Andrew Zipern

title: MAKER OF BILLING SOFTWARE TO LAY OFF HALF OF PERSONNEL

The job reductions represent 52 percent of the company's work force. Daleen, which is based in Boca Raton, Fla., will shut facilities in Atlanta and Toronto and consolidate its Boca Raton operations. Daleen said it expected to post a loss of 46 cents to 56 cents a share, excluding acquisition costs and restructuring charges. Daleen was expected to lose 34 cents by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call.

title: Taking Audits Personally

And I suspected I was an overly stressed grown-up when every April left me vowing to start earning less and spending (i.e. deducting) more, so that I'd owe less to the government. In a few particularly taxing years I even had perverse moments of regret that I was so very healthy (no medical deductions). All this is followed by more existential questions: Has it really been a year since I last did this? Where did the time go? If I'm working so hard, why don't I have more to show for it? Have I lost all balance in my life to a balance sheet?

description: For years political experts have talked about the day when this city's surging Latino population would shape the outcome of local elections. In Los Angeles this morning, there was an unavoidable feeling that that moment had arrived.

title: A Place to Wash Up Made of Wok or Wood
description: ''I looked at a wok, and said why not?'' said Eric Walton, a Manhattan furniture designer and woodworker who is turning woks into Zen-spare sinks. He buys 18-inch-wide stainless steel woks, drills a hole in the bottom and inserts a drain. ''It's an unconventional application of something we take for granted,'' he said. The wok sink, bottom, is $1,650, including stand, backsplash and drain. Mr. Walton also makes sinks from waterproofed wood, below. He carves each sink with a chisel, smooths it with sandpaper and steel wool and seals it with 10 layers of polyurethane; $750. (212) 539-6558. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Makeover Saves Brush Factory
description: TWO years ago, Oliver Vogt and Hermann Weizenegger, young designers working in Berlin, noticed a dusty shop window across from their studio where heavy-duty brushes were sold. The brushes, the kind used by sanitation workers, had been handmade at the Berlin Institute for the Blind factory for 120 years by blind workers employed by the German government. But with sales slumping, the factory was about to close.

title: U.S. and Europeans Agree on Deal to End Banana Trade War
description: The United States and the European Union reached an agreement yesterday that ends a costly trade war over European banana imports, a dispute that pushed Chiquita Brands International to the brink of bankruptcy and led to punitive tariffs on a range of European goods.

title: STRIDE RITE HIRES AN AGENCY TO MANAGE ITS BRANDS
description: The Stride Rite Corporation hired the Beanstalk Group licensing agency to help the company expand its namesake brand beyond children's shoes. The products Stride Rite is considering licensing include clothing and accessories, cribs, car seats, children's room decorations and play gear, a spokeswoman, Barbara Scott, said. Sales of Stride Rite children's products have outpaced its other brands in three of the last four quarters. Children's group sales rose 11 percent in the first quarter, which ended March 2.

title: I.B.M. JOINS GENE VENTURE
description: I.B.M. said it would join with LabBook Inc. to market software for analyzing genetic data and would take a minority stake in LabBook, a closely held company in McLean, Va. Terms of the arrangement were not disclosed. I.B.M. said it would integrate LabBook's programs for gene researchers, including a specialized Web browser, with its own software for running large Web servers and databases.

title: Adieu to the Louvre; Its Director Retires, Proposing a Lottery to Save France's Art
description: In a country with ancient and deeply entrenched cultural institutions, even Pierre Rosenberg's seven-year stint as a high-profile director of the Louvre may eventually merit only a footnote in the history of the museum. Yet as he prepares to retire from the post on Thursday, the eve of his 65th birthday, this affable and loquacious art historian with the trademark red scarf has begun one final campaign that, if successful, may well become his principal legacy.

description: The level of violence in the 17-year-old ethnic conflict between the Sri Lankan government and separatist rebels has dropped sharply over the last three months, and there are signs that the warring parties are slowly moving toward resuming peace talks, which broke off six years ago.

Only half the music, though, was American, and none of that was new, which left rather little space for the visionary. Presumably the players were playing what they wanted to play, but their criteria were mighty hard to discern.

title: Fighting Eviction With a Jackpot of Jingles
description: ALL children -- until they grow up, at least -- think their mothers are magical, but Terry Ryan's mother was more magical than most. During the 1950's, Evelyn Ryan was a Midwestern housewife with 10 children and a husband who drank away his factory salary as regularly as he earned it. With such a large family to care for, Mrs. Ryan couldn't work outside the home, so she did one of the only things a woman of her era could do to help support her family: she tried to win the prizes then offered by the ubiquitous jingle, slogan and poetry contests staged by corporations to promote every kind of consumer product. You name it, she wrote it.

title: Where None Will Cry Over Spilt Milk
description: This is what heaven might look like if it were a fashion showroom: a 3,000-square-foot expanse of white, designed by Suzan Wines, far left, and Azin Valy, left, partners in I-Beam Design in Manhattan. They created the room, at 1400 Broadway (39th Street), for Gokaldas Images, a clothing manufacturer. ''We designed a seamless, liquid floating environment,'' Ms. Wines said. They covered the concrete floor with white epoxy and white polyurethane. The reception desk, above right, has a wood base clad in carved foam and covered in white epoxy. The bench, left, is also carved foam, glossed with white epoxy. The screen between the waiting room and the showroom is plastic mesh nailed to the floor. Ms. Valy spackled the screen and painted it with white epoxy. Then she carved the epoxy to make it lacy at the top, to filter light. The budget was $150,000. ELAINE LOUIE

title: MOORE LEAVING INTEL BOARD
description: The Intel Corporation, the giant chip maker, said that Gordon E. Moore, left, the co-founder of Intel whose prediction that the number of transistors on a computer chip would double every 18 months became known as Moore's Law, would retire from its board in May. Reed E. Hundt, a technology consultant and venture capitalist who served as the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission from 1993 to 1997, will take his place. Mr. Moore, who has served on Intel's board since the company was created in 1968, will continue to advise it as a director emeritus. Moore's Law, based on an observation made by him in 1965, has come to embody the industry's drive to pack more components onto each silicon wafer, resulting in higher processing power at lower costs. In 1971, the first Intel microprocessor, the 4004 chip, held 2,300 transistors. Since then, the number of transistors has multiplied 21,000 times, to 48 million transistors on the Pentium 4.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLSON, WILLIAM JAMIESON
description: NICHOLSON-William Jamieson. April 9th, 2001, at age 70, of heart failure while running in Fair Lawn, NJ. He was Professor Emeritus of Community Medicine at Mount Sinai School of Medicine. Working with Dr. Irving J. Selikoff, he did extensive statistical studies of the excessive rates of cancer and deaths among exposed asbestos workers as well as the health hazards of vinyl chloride, PCBs in the Hudson River, dioxin and Agent Orange. He was a leader in countering the disinformation campaign of the asbestos industry. Raised in Kirkland, WA, he graduated from MIT in 1952. In the US Air Force, he studied ionizing radiation effects during atomic bomb testing in the Nevada desert. Receiving a PHD in physics from the University of Washington in 1960, he joined the staff of the IBM Watson Laboratory at Columbia University. In 1966 he ran for US Congress as a Peace Party candidate and was a delegate to the 1968 Democratic Party Convention in Chicago. An enthusiastic athlete, he ran the Boston and New York Marathons, completed the gold level of the Canadian Ski Marathon and at 67 was the oldest cyclist to finish the 154-mile RAMROD, a one day ride around Mount Rainier. Bill is survived by his companion, Valerie M. Josephson, two daughters, Jamie Nicholson Leener of New York City, Darcy Nicholson of Santa Fe, NM, a son David of Seattle, WA, one grandchild, and many cousins in the Shetland Islands and Scotland. His famiy and friends miss him dearly. Donations in his memory may be made to the Nature Conservancy, 4245 N. Fairfax Drive, Arlington, VA 22203.

title: How to Get Into College After Being Rejected
description: Catesby Holmes scored 800 on the verbal section of the College Boards. She was on the honor roll for four straight years, and she lettered in field hockey and won awards for music, Latin and horseback riding. Yet she did not get into college. Harvard, Princeton, Yale, Columbia, Brown and Wesleyan rejected her; after putting her on the waiting list, so did Amherst and the University of Chicago. "I spent the spring watching friends put college stickers on their cars while I tried to figure out what I was going to do with my life," Catesby remembers. "As in, what was I at this point if not 'collegebound'?"

title: DUPONT CONSIDERS A PUBLIC OFFERING OF UNIT
description: The DuPont Company said it was considering either a partial initial public offering or sale of its drug business and a decision could come within months. DuPont, the No. 2 chemical maker in the United States, told analysts at a meeting in New York that selling shares in the business might be attractive. Analysts said the business could sell for $4 billion to $7 billion, depending on whether Cozaar, a blood-pressure drug co-developed by Merck & Company is included in the sale. DuPont officials previously said the business, with annual sales of $1.5 billion, is too small to compete with larger rivals. Now, the company has reached the opposite conclusion, telling analysts that DuPont Pharmaceuticals has 21 compounds in development for conditions like heart disease, cancer, arthritis and obesity.

title: Metro Business Briefing; CLUB OWNER MAY SELL
description: Peter Gatien, who owns the Limelight and the Tunnel and once owned the Palladium, has been considering selling the two Manhattan clubs, according to his lawyer, Benjamin P. Brafman. The announcement, first reported in The New York Post, came on Tuesday, a day after a 16-year-old boy died in a brawl that the police said started inside the Tunnel, which has been plagued with drug arrests and violence. In 1998, Mr. Gatien was acquitted of federal charges that he used his clubs as drug bazaars. ''Mr. Gatien is very tired of being blamed for incidents that neither he nor his clubs have anything to do with,'' Mr. Brafman said. He said his client had been considering getting out of the club business for months. After the stabbing death on Monday, Deputy Mayor Rudy Washington complained that the courts had refused the city's repeated requests to shut down Mr. Gatien's clubs. Shaila K. Dewan

title: BORDERS CONFIRMS AMAZON DEAL
description: The Borders Group confirmed yesterday that it would close its money-losing online bookstore and that Amazon.com would operate a store on its behalf. Starting in August, customers going to the Borders.com will see a customized version of Amazon's Web store that will also have the Borders name. The merchandise, book reviews and prices will all be Amazon's. The site will have some information from Borders, including the locations of its stores and a list of coming events. Borders will pay Amazon a fee to set up the site and will receive a commission from Amazon on any sales that the site generates. The companies declined to specify exact terms of the arrangement, but people close to the situation said that Amazon's payments to Borders would be similar to the standard 5 percent commission it pays to affiliates, as it calls Web sites that refer it customers. Customers will generally not pay sales tax and will not be able to return books to Borders stores. The arrangement does not require Borders to promote the Borders-Amazon Web site.

Dr. Schmierer served as staff and consulting pediatrician and specialist in newborn care at Maimonides Medical Center for well over five decades. His devotion to patient care, clinical teaching and to the community served by Maimonides Medical Center was exemplary. He was a superb pediatrician for children here in Borough Park for his entire professional career. He was referred to often as the pediatrician's pediatrician. His love and support for the Department of Pediatrics is legendary and his name and contributions will continue to be recognized through the Department's Annual Israel Schmierer Lecture. To his family, the Department of Pediatrics sadly mourn his loss and wish them strength and courage in these days without him. Steven P. Shelov, M.D., M.S. title: Metro Business Briefing
description: RAISE FOR CON ED CHIEF Consolidated Edison tripled the compensation of its chairman, Eugene R. McGrath, to $9 million last year, according to papers the company filed this week with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Much of the increase for Mr. McGrath, who is also the chief executive, came in the form of restricted stock valued at $6.2 million, a benefit he had not received in previous years, according to the company's April 9 filing. In addition, his salary was increased 9.1 percent to $1.03 million and his bonus 67 percent to $981,000. A statement included in the filing credited Mr. McGrath with several achievements, including "good financial and operating results," "motivating the company's work force" and "continued progress in achieving the goal of environmental excellence." Con Edison's stock price gained nearly 12 percent last year over the previous year, but the company also confronted some problems, including the shutdown of the Indian Point 2 nuclear reactor for 11 months because of a small radioactive leak.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPANA, GERALD JOHN
description: CAMPANA-Gerald John, M.D., Ob/Gyn, passed away April 11, 2001, at home, age 58. Devoted father of Christian, Ryan, Justin, Alyssa, and loving companion of Marge Schmitt. Grandfather to Dylan, Joshua and Nicholas. Funeral service will be held at 3:00 PM, Saturday, at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave., White Plains, NY. Family will receive friends from 7-9 PM, Thursday and Friday, at the Funeral Home. Cremation will be private. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Kidney Cancer Association, 1234 Sherman Ave., Suite 203, Evanston, IL 60202-1375, or Hospice Care, 100 South Bedford Road, Mt. Kisco, NY 10549.

title: ARM HOLDINGS PROFIT INCREASES
description: ARM Holdings, one of Europe's largest semiconductor designers, said it earned 7.73 million ($11.1 million), or 0.8 pence a share, in the first quarter, up 16 percent from the quarter a year earlier. Sales increased 52 percent, to 32.5 million. Because it sells designs to mobile phone companies and has no manufacturing costs or inventory risks, ARM says, it is less vulnerable to an industry slowdown, and it expects to meet forecasts for the next two quarters.

title: Anheuser-Busch Joins Industry Promotion
description: A campaign by the American Advertising Federation in Washington to promote the value of advertising, made more timely by the economic slowdown, has signed another well-known marketer as a participant.

title: Comden and Green's Office. They're on Broadway. Any Message?
description: The last time ''Bells Are Ringing'' opened on Broadway, in 1956, a pay phone cost a nickel, the Internet wasn't wired, and you certainly did not have to remind theatergoers to turn off their cell phones before the show.

title: Here Come Israel's Passover Police!
description: Alexander Dardikman had unusual visitors at his restaurant on Monday.

title: Singapore Bank Plans Hong Kong Deal
description: Southeast Asia's largest bank, DBS Group Holdings, said it would acquire a big Hong Kong bank, the Dao Heng Bank Group, for about $5.4 billion.

title: She's Venus, He's Mars, in a Regimented Match
description: Jos Rivera writes with half his mind on credible reality and the other half in fantasyland. His characters tend to live in a world where magical and concrete forces coexist, where life's anchoring burdens do battle with uncommonly potent wishes and dreams.

title: PRESIDENT OF SALLIE MAE RESIGNS TWO POSITIONS
description: USA Education Inc., known as Sallie Mae, said James Lintzenich, its president and chief operating officer, resigned. Mr. Lintzenich, 47, was formerly chief executive of USA Group, which Sallie Mae bought for $770 million in August. He is stepping down after helping combine the two student loan companies, Mr. Lintzenich said in a statement. Sallie Mae, once a government agency called the Student Loan Marketing Association, is the country's largest buyer of government-guaranteed student loans, with a portfolio of $67 billion.

description: CANTOR-Arthur. The Brooklyn Academy of Music mourns the passing of a dear friend and BAM Theater supporter. Karen Brooks Hopkins, President Joseph V. Mclillo, Exec Producer

title: MORATORIUM ASKED ON SUITS THAT SEEK TO PROTECT SPECIES
description: The Bush administration has asked Congress to set aside, at least for a year, a provision of the Endangered Species Act that has been the main tool used by citizens' groups to win protection for plants and animals.

description: NEW YORK

title: A Battery Recharges The Remote Road Warrior
description: It is a common occurrence on the sidewalks of America, a stream of blue-tinged invectives as a caller realizes that the cell phone battery is dying in the middle of a critical call. With no electrical outlet or charger available, what is one to do?

title: Turning Introspective and Retrospective
description: ''From the Horse's Mouth'' is entering its third year in somewhat glossier form than the original living documentary. Conceived by Tina Croll and James Cunningham as a look into the heart and history of dance, the show has its changing cast tell stories and perform a structured improvisation.

title: Videodiscs With You As Director
description: TO do-it-yourself moviemakers, nothing is more frustrating than the current chasm between the technology for creating digital movies and the technology for distributing them. The first part is easy: using a $700 digital camcorder, you can capture footage with astonishing detail, sharpness and color fidelity. Using editing software, you can add credits, fade-ins and fade-outs, and music from an audio CD. The quality of the result is simply spectacular -- when played back on your computer monitor or the camcorder's little flip-out screen.

title: Michel Fribourg, 87, Trader Who Opened Soviet Market
description: Michel Fribourg, a Belgian-born American who negotiated groundbreaking sales of wheat and rice to the Soviet Union in the 1960's and 1970's, died on Tuesday in New York. He was 87.

title: Holding Onto Harlem
description: The story is familiar. An inner-city neighborhood, long besieged by poverty and economic abandonment, suddenly becomes fashionable because of a combination of economic growth and public investment. As more affluent, usually white, families move in, property values and rents rise. Lower-income working families, often African-American or Hispanic, are forced to leave just when their dream of a more livable neighborhood is about to become reality. Now this story is moving to Harlem, a neighborhood with unique importance to African-Americans nationwide. And this time, New York should rewrite the ending.

title: In Radio Feud, a Higher Kind of Superpower Irks Italy
description: Italians have rarely displayed much faith in institutions, whether the post office, the tax police or health inspectors. Now the country is experiencing an epidemic of mistrust, and its epicenter is in Cesano, a small north Rome suburb where many residents say that radiation from the Vatican's nearby radio transmitters causes cancer.

title: Metro Business Briefing; REZONING MAY LEGALIZE LOFTS
description: Hundreds of loft apartments carved out of industrial buildings in Brooklyn could be legalized under a rezoning of 131 buildings proposed yesterday by the City Planning Commission. The fate of such lofts has been in dispute since the city evacuated 60 residents from a factory building in December, citing safety hazards. The planning chairman, Joseph B. Rose, said the mixed-use zoning would embrace the new loft housing, preserve manufacturing space and guard against residences in inappropriate industrial areas. From a Fire Department list of buildings suspected of having lofts, the planners said 45 buildings with 616 lofts were suitable for rezoning, while 19 buildings with 46 lofts were not. In addition, the planners found 86 loft buildings suitable for rezoning, but did not say how many units they had. A tenant leader, Eve Sussman of the Brooklyn LiveWork Coalition, said she welcomed the zoning concept but disputed the list of buildings as incomplete.

title: Recyclers to Pay Millions in Lead Dumping
description: Two recycling companies have agreed to pay $3.75 million in fines and penalties to settle accusations of improperly disposing of lead waste at a factory in Rockland County for a decade, State Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer's office said yesterday.

title: Addenda: Management Changes at Initiative Media Unit
description: Management changes are being made at Initiative Media North America, part of the Initiative Media Worldwide unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies .

description: Polls out this week show George W. Bush's job approval rating has begun to drop in the wake of the China standoff, the stock market plunge, and Senator John McCain's successful stewardship of the campaign finance reform bill through the Senate.

title: Bush to Employ Medical Privacy Rules
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  President Bush announced today that he would allow sweeping rules to protect the privacy of medical records to go into effect on Saturday. But he said the rules, issued by President Bill Clinton, could be modified later to address "legitimate concerns" of the health care industry.

title: Hopkins Refuses to Act His Age
description: Bernard Hopkins is a scholar of the human body. He is 36. He knows about the laws of nature that govern things like musculature and respiration and heart rate. But do not bother him with such trivialities.

title: A New Source For Stem Cells Is Reported
description: A New Jersey company said yesterday that it had developed a method to extract a novel kind of stem cell from the placenta and that the cells were the equivalent of human embryonic stem cells, which can transform into every tissue of the adult body.

title: China Policy, Without Regrets
description: Thanks to patient diplomacy, Secretary of State Colin Powell, his team and their counterparts in China have resolved the standoff on Hainan Island. As President Bush said yesterday, it has been a difficult situation for both nations. But while the crisis is over, this is not a time to think we can return to business as usual. On the contrary, there are lessons to be learned in how to deal with a China that will be increasingly capable and, if we are not careful, increasingly willing to frustrate American interests in East Asia.

description: IN Just-spring the other day, a mud-luscious corner of the Bronx was throwing forth the first daffodils, the trees were in bud, and Marco Polo Stufano, director of horticulture at Wave Hill, moved among his beloved plants like E. E. Cummings's goat-footed balloon Man, from the tiny blue-purple Glory of the Snow (Chionodoxa) that has stubbornly self-seeded itself across a hillside to the towering 38-foot false cypress (Chamaecyparis) he brought with him as a four-inch-tall seedling when he took the job in 1967. It has been a long, long winter here in Zone 6.

title: Delicate Diplomatic Dance Ends Bush's First Crisis
description: The United States and China resolved their standoff today after President Bush approved compromise language saying the United States was ''very sorry'' for the loss of a Chinese pilot, and for an American spy plane's emergency landing on Chinese soil. But in a letter to Beijing, Washington accepted no responsibility for the midair collision on April 1 that now seems certain to color Mr. Bush's next encounters with China.

title: FRENCH BANK TAKES A STAKE IN TRUST COMPANY
description: One of France's biggest banks, Socit Gnrale, will acquire a 51 percent controlling stake in the privately held asset management group Trust Company of the West in a share swap worth about $1.2 billion. Under the terms of the deal, which represents a major push by Socit Gnrale into the North American market, Socit Gnrale will initially offer 14.1 million of its own shares for the 51 percent stake in Trust Company, then gradually lift its stake to 70 percent by 2006, with the remaining 30 percent remaining in the hands of Trust Company executives.

title: Ashcroft Says Victims' Kin Can See McVeigh Execution
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Attorney General John Ashcroft said today that survivors and relatives of victims in the Oklahoma City Federal building bombing will be permitted to witness the May 16 execution of Timothy McVeigh by way of a secure, closed-circuit television broadcast.

Graham Vick met with disaster at the Metropolitan Opera this season, amusing audiences and annoying members of the cast. Now his colleagues at the English National Opera are having a go of their own, with a production of Verdi's opera that opened at the London Coliseum on Monday night.

title: Metro Business Briefing; RAISE FOR CON ED CHIEF
description: Consolidated Edison tripled the compensation of its chairman, Eugene R. McGrath, to $9 million last year, according to papers the company filed this week with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Much of the increase for Mr. McGrath, who is also the chief executive, came in the form of restricted stock valued at $6.2 million, a benefit he had not received in previous years, according to the company's April 9 filing. In addition, his salary was increased 9.1 percent to $1.03 million and his bonus 67 percent to $981,000. A statement included in the filing credited Mr. McGrath with several achievements, including ''good financial and operating results,'' ''motivating the company's work force'' and ''continued progress in achieving the goal of environmental excellence.'' Con Edison's stock price gained nearly 12 percent last year over the previous year, but the company also confronted some problems, including the shutdown of the Indian Point 2 nuclear reactor for 11 months because of a small radioactive leak. Randal C. Archibold

title: CHINESE OIL PROFITS
description: The dominant offshore oil producer in China, CNOOC Ltd., whose $1.3 billion public stock offering attracted wide attention in February, reported sharply higher profit for 2000, stemming from high prices and stepped-up production. Net income rose to 10.3 billion yuan ($1.24 billion) from 4.1 billion yuan in 1999. The company pumped 18 percent more oil than last year, but natural gas output fell slightly; still, revenue rose 58 percent.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The American people, their families and I are proud of our crew and we look forward to welcoming them home.''

title: I.B.M. Tries to Convert Desktop From Dump Into Open Space
description: A truly clutter-free desktop has long been the Promised Land -- within sight, but somehow out of reach. This week I.B.M. announced it would redouble efforts to combat desktop sprawl by adding a wireless keyboard and a wireless mouse to its NetVista X40 line. The keyboard and the mouse use radio frequency signals to communicate with the C.P.U., which is itself unobtrusively tucked behind the machine's flat-panel monitor. I.B.M. says it takes up to 75 percent less space than a traditional desktop system. (The keyboard and the mouse can also be purchased separately for $99 and added to most U.S.B.-equipped machines.) For an extra $219, you can get a stand that suspends the NetVista above the desk, essentially eliminating the computer's footprint.

title: Family Balances Its Grief With Love For Boy Accused of Killing His Mother
description: When Brenda Jones got a call last October saying that her 15-year-old nephew, Douglas Wright, was at a police station, she thought something had happened to his mother, her sister. A car accident, maybe. Geraldine Wright, overworked and underrested, had had a few in recent years.

title: Judge Orders City to Shelter 2 Suffering Homeless Families
description: Describing the city's handling of homeless families as disturbing, a State Supreme Court justice yesterday ordered the Giuliani administration to find more permanent shelter immediately for two suffering families, and to prepare yet another plan to relieve the hardship facing dozens of others.

title: Essay; Stop Conference Roulette
description: A generation ago, at 5 in the morning in a basement room of the Cannon House Office Building, bleary-eyed members of the House Ways and Means and Senate Finance Committees met in secret conference to hammer out compromises in both houses' versions of the 1982 tax bill.

title: Ending the Spy Plane Deadlock
description: With some accommodation by both sides, the spy plane stalemate between Washington and Beijing has been resolved and the 24 detained Americans are on their way home. That is a great relief to their families and the entire country. Beijing's approach was needlessly confrontational at times. But in the end, both governments acted sensibly to conclude the affair before it seriously damaged their overall relationship.

title: To Sit and Contemplate A Master's Thoughts
description: Some people never go out of style. In 1935, the architect and designer Le Corbusier created two 16-foot drawings while lecturing at Princeton University. Those drawings -- one on architecture, one on urban planning -- can be seen until June 16 at the university's art museum, in Princeton, N.J. Now George H. Marcus has gathered many of Le Corbusier's drawings of interior designs and furniture designs in ''Le Corbusier: Inside the Machine for Living'' (Monacelli Press, $50), left. For those who prefer to experience the furniture in person, Cassina has reintroduced his 1934 Daybed, below, designed for his Paris office ($4,560 in leather). title: CROSS TIMBERS OIL HAS $250 MILLION DEVELOPMENT BUDGET
description: The Cross Timbers Oil Company has budgeted $250 million for oil and gas development in 2001, according to the company's 2000 annual report. As it has done before, the company expects to finance the development program with cash flow from operations. About 50 percent of the development budget will be spent in East Texas, with the balance allocated among other properties. Exploration spending is expected to be about 4 percent of the 2001 budget. In 2000, Cross Timbers' cash expenditures for exploration and development totaled $155.4 million, compared with $91.6 million in 1999.

title: AVON SAYS IT EXPECTS TO EXCEED PROFIT FORECAST
description: Avon Products Inc., the largest direct seller of cosmetics, said yesterday that it expected first-quarter earnings to slightly exceed forecasts as it increased sales of more-profitable cosmetics and reined in costs. Avon is expected to earn 33 cents a share, the average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. Sales growth was in line with analysts' forecasts of about 3 percent, the company said, the slowest pace in more than a year. The company's chief executive, Andrea Jung, said Avon's operating profit margin widened for the 13th consecutive quarter as it cut the cost of supplies and increased United States sales of its more profitable makeup and fragrances by 5 percent. Shares of Avon rose $1.90, or 5.2 percent, to $38.67.

Viatel and its financing arm will not make payments by Sunday on 12.75 percent senior notes due in 2008 and on 7.75 percent trust certificates, the company said in a statement late Wednesday. Its auditors will include a paragraph in financial statements raising substantial doubt about whether Viatel can stay in business, the company said. Viatel owes bond investors more than $2 billion. The company's shares fell 47 cents, to 39 cents.

The National Highway Transportation Safety Administration said that the states were Maine, New Hampshire, Vermont, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Connecticut, New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland, West Virginia, Ohio, Indiana, Michigan, Illinois, Wisconsin, Minnesota, Iowa, and Missouri as well as the District of Columbia. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INGALLS, GEORGE L. GEORGE LEWIS INGALLS
description: INGALLS-George L. George Lewis Ingalls, 86, of Binghamton died Tuesday afternoon, April 10, 2001 at Our Lady of Lourdes hospital. Mr. Ingalls is survived by his wife of 58 years Dorothy Joggerst Ingalls, Binghamton; three sons and daughters in law, Bryan W. and Jane Ingalls, Chevy Chase, MD, Robert G. Ingalls, Binghamton, John S. and Kate Ingalls, Rancho Santa Fe, CA. A daughter and sonin-law, Janet Ingalls VanDine and Robert W. VanDine, Binghamton; eight grandchildren, Lennea, Robert, Dorothy and Ellen VanDine; Ryan and Georgia Ingalls, John and Caroline Ingalls; two brothers, James E. and June Ingalls, Sebring, FL., Ralph C. Ingalls, Brooklyn, CT.; a sister Ellen Ingalls Gausch, Manchester, MO. Mr. Ingalls was born in Danielson, CT. A Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Amherst College in 1935 and Magna Cum Laude graduate of Syracuse University College of Law in 1939. He was associated with the Binghamton Law Firm of Keenan, Harrison and Coughlin, became a partner in 1946 and at the time of his death was of counsel to the firm's succesor, Coughlin and Gerhart. Mr. Ingalls, who practiced law in Binghamton for 50 years, was Republican Majority Leader of the New York State Assembly from 1961-1964 and Minority Leader in 1965. After retiring from the NYS Assembly in 1966, he was appointed to the NYS Power Authority in 1967. Mr. Ingalls was the longest serving trustee in its history and was NYPA's Vice-Chairman until his retirement in 1990. He was chairman of the Broome County Republican Committee from 1975 to 1977. In September 1990, the trustee of the New York Power Authority designated the Blenheim-Gilboa Pumped Storage Power Project as the George L. Ingalls Pump-Generating Plant in honor of his long standing tenure as a trustee of the NY Power Authority. Mr. Ingalls was a member of the Binghamton Club and the Binghamton Country Club, where he took immense pleasure in hitting a golf ball long and straight. His presence on the golf course will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held at the J.A. Mc Cormack Sons Funeral Home, 141 Main Street, Binghamton Saturday at 11 A.M. Rev. Msgr. James D. Kane, Pastor of Blessed Sacrament Church, Johnson City will officiate. Burial will be in Calvary Cemetery, Johnson City. The family will receive friends at the Mc Cormack Funeral Home on Friday from 5-8 P.M. In lieu of flowers, expressions of sympathy in memory of George may be made to Lourdes Hospital Foundation, 169 Riverside Drive, Binghamton, New York 13905 on any charitable organization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLSON, WILLIAM J., PH.D.
description: NICHOLSON-William J., Ph.D. The Faculty and Staff of the Department of Community and Preventive Medicine mourn the passing of our esteemed colleague, William J. Nicholson, Ph.D., Professor Emeritus in Occupational and Environmental Medicine. Dr. Nicholson joined the faculty in 1969 at the request of Dr. Irving J. Selikoff to develop an asbestos exposure assessment unit for the Environmental Sciences Laboratory. A physicist by training with degrees from MIT and the Univ. of Washington, Dr. Nicholson created a quantitative approach to assessing asbestos exposure. His analysis of construction activity of the World Trade Center Towers led to studies of asbestos-related air pollution in lower Manhattan. His findings led to a ban on spraying of asbestos insulation in the city in 1971. The Environmental Protection Agency issued a national ban the following year. Dr. Nicholson's extensive research included projections of the magnitude of the asbestos epidemic and analysis of mortality rates of vinyl chloride-exposed workers and pressmen exposed to polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons. His work led to the development of asbestos exposure standards internationally and OSHA's 1986 regulations. An activist in public health, Dr. Nicholson will be remembered for his great contributions to protecting the health and safety of working men and women in America and around the world. Our heartfelt condolences go out to his companion, Valerie Josephson, his children, Jamie, Darcy and David. Philip J. Landrigan, MD, MSC Ethel H. Wise, Professor of Community and Preventive Medicine Mount Sinai School of Medicine

title: ROCKWELL SAYS IT PLANS TO SPIN OFF AVIATION UNIT BY JULY
description: Rockwell International, the largest maker of factory-automation equipment, has filed a plan with the Securities and Exchange Commission to spin off the company's Collins aviation business by July. Shareholders will receive one share in Rockwell Collins for each share held, the company said. The spinoff was first announced in December. Sales at Rockwell's automated-controls business are increasing about 3 percent a year, while sales at its avionics unit have risen about 14 percent annually over the last five years. Spinning off Collins will bring more visibility to its earnings potential and allow each company to focus better on its individual businesses, the company has said. Rockwell Collins makes cockpit-display equipment and provides services like movies, games and other in-flight entertainment.

title: A City Workers' Contract
description: With so many of New York City's workers laboring without contracts, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani desperately wanted at least one city union to agree on a wage package as soon as possible. Such an agreement could provide the structure and pay guidelines for difficult negotiations now going on with other unions, primarily for teachers and police officers. So Wednesday's announcement that the city had forged a tentative contract proposal with District Council 37, the city's largest municipal employees' union, brought widespread relief at City Hall. Such relief may be premature. Although this agreement could jump-start sluggish negotiations with other city unions, it is hard to see what Mr. Giuliani got in return for the healthy pay raises and promises of no layoffs for 150,000 municipal employees ranging from social workers to zookeepers.

Well, maybe it's not that extreme, but a golf package at the 700-suite Westin Innisbrook Resort in Palm Harbor, Fla., 25 minutes from Tampa's airport, may require participants to be ready for some hot weather. It is available May 24 to Sept. 23, at $159 a person, based on double occupancy, per night. That includes a daily round of golf at one of Innisbrook's four courses (one of which, Copperhead, is the site of a PGA Tour event) and a second round free at the Highlands North or South course when booked on the same day of play. The price also includes daily breakfast, unlimited use of the practice ranges, club storage and a daily golf clinic. Children ages 4 to 18 play free with a green-fee paying adult. Information: (800) 456-2000 or www.westin-innisbrook.com .

title: The Less-Desperate Jets Look Forward to Draft

title: Ameritrade Cuts More Jobs
description: The Ameritrade Holding Corporation says it has cut 270 to 300 jobs, as much as 76 percent more than the firm said it planned last month, as declines in American stocks curtailed online trading. The company also said it would cut its $200 million advertising budget as much as $60 million. Ameritrade said its customers made an average of 12 percent fewer trades a day in March than in February. The company expects to save $12 million from the job cuts.

title: U.S.-Russia Relationship Warms Up a Bit
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and the Russian foreign minister, Igor S. Ivanov, decided today to turn the page from last month's tit-for-tat spy expulsions and agreed during a session in Paris that their leaders would have their first meeting by the end of July.

title: 2 Retailers Report Disappointing Sales
description: Two of the nation's largest retailers reported monthly sales yesterday that disappointed investors and warned that quarterly profits would fall below Wall Street's expectations.

title: Crew Destroyed Secret Materials Before Surrendering to Chinese Troops
description: BEIJING, April 13  As Chinese troops surrounding the aircraft waved their guns and shouted at them to stop, the crew of the crippled American spy plane that landed on Hainan Island spent 15 furious minutes destroying secret materials before surrendering, senior American diplomats said today.

title: Australia Stops Flights of 767's By Ansett Line
description: Australian aviation officials ordered Ansett Australia to ground all 10 of its Boeing 767 jets indefinitely today and threatened to cancel the airline's operating license because of what they said were maintenance and safety lapses.

description: The International Center of Photography is presenting a retrospective of Hans Bellmer, whose doll images, like ''La Poupe'' (1935), right, continue to unsettle and disturb.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro rose against the dollar on signs that consumers are spending less in the United States. In New York, the euro settled at 89.28 cents, up from 88.79 cents on Wednesday.

title: 2 New Studies Tie Rise in Ocean Heat to Greenhouse Gases
description: Using two different computer simulations of climate and the oceans, separate research teams have concluded that a buildup of heat in the seas over the last five decades was almost certainly caused by the heat-trapping effect of greenhouse gases released into the air by human activities.

title: Arbuckle Shorts, Fresh and Frisky
description: On screen it takes Fatty Arbuckle about 15 seconds to establish himself. Facially he resembles Babe Ruth. His agility and foot speed are remarkable for anybody, let alone a 300-pounder, even allowing for the speeded-up camera work in short films around 1920. The most amazing thing about him is his freshness, a kind of wild curiosity and readiness for anything. There isn't an ounce of contrivance. Arbuckle just prances forth and lets fly.

description: Axis Gallery

title: At a Tribute, a Composer, 70, Explains Heaven and Earth
description: Sofia Gubaidulina is 70 this year, and eternally a child. At the Kosciuszko Foundation on Tuesday evening for the Lyric Chamber Music Society's tribute to her, she looked at once determined and vulnerable. Over her compact face, with eyes staring warily or piercingly or gleefully out of deep shadow, the Muscovite crown of her hair is still black, an inheritance from her Tatar ancestry. She smiles openly and easily, with a child's delight. When the musicians played Mozart, she sat back and listened, intently. When they performed her works, she leaned forward to watch, intently.

title: Cisco to Offer 6-Month Severance
description: Cisco Systems said today that it would offer as much as six months of severance pay and discontinue additional products as part of its plans to reduce its full-time work force by as many as 5,000 people.

title: Pataki Names A Democrat As Secretary Of State
description: Gov. George E. Pataki appointed a self-described ''Pataki Democrat'' to a high-level cabinet post yesterday, naming Randy A. Daniels as his new secretary of state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAIDEL, SARA F.
description: SAIDEL-Sara F. Died suddenly on April 10. She was much loved by her children Marc & Sheri Saidel, Barbara Saidel and Edward Goldberg; her grandchildren Eric and Tahl Saidel, Jenna and Michael Lebowich, Anna & Isaac Goldberg; and her great granddaughters Eliana Saidel & Marina Lebowich. She made friends everywhere and was so full of life.

title: SILICON WAFER SUPPLIER WARNS ON SALES
description: The Ibis Technology Corporation, which supplies chip makers with manufacturing equipment and materials, lowered its revenue projections, citing a substantial decrease in wafer forecasts from one of its largest customers. The company declined to identify that customer, but Fred Wolf, an analyst with Adams, Harkness & Hill in Boston, said I.B.M. and Bookham Technology, a British optical-chip maker, had been Ibis's largest customers. Ibis shares fell $5.48, or almost 20 percent, to close at $21.95. Ibis makes silicon wafers for the integrated circuits used in PC's, mobile phones, hand-held computers and optical sensors. The company said it now projected second-quarter revenue to be 50 percent to 60 percent of what it was in the fourth quarter of 2000. Andrew Zipern

title: EARNINGS NEWS LIFTS BLACKBERRY MAKER
description: The shares of Research in Motion Ltd., which makes wireless hand-held communications devices, gained $6.34, or 28.9 percent, to $28.27 in Nasdaq trading yesterday, a day after the company reported fourth-quarter profit of 10 cents a share, 40 percent higher than analysts had expected. Research in Motion, the developer of the BlackBerry line of mobile e-mail and Internet-connection handsets, said its profit for the quarter ended Feb. 28 was $8.3 million, compared with $3.2 million a year earlier. Quarterly sales more than tripled to $90.1 million. Timothy Pritchard

title: Season Within a Season for Yanks and Red Sox
description: Under the balanced schedule that was scuttled before this season, the Yankees and the Red Sox were like congressional colleagues battling a couple of times a year but always at a safe and polite distance.

title: PETROBRAS OIL RIG EVACUATED
description: An oil and gas leak forced the evacuation of an offshore oil rig operated by the Brazilian oil company, Petrleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras, in the latest in a string of incidents that has damaged the reputation of the state-owned giant. At least 3,500 gallons of oil leaked from a pipe that was being tested on the P-7 rig, which is in the Campos Basin, 75 miles off the coast of Rio de Janeiro State. Last month, a fire and explosions killed 11 workers and sank a $500 million oil platform at a nearby site. Petrobras said that the P-7 spill was being contained and that there were no injuries. Jennifer L. Rich

title: In New League, Women Get Payoff and Payday
description: Coaches in all sports like to say that good players make good plays, and if that is the case, the Women's United Soccer Association should be the home of the best women's soccer in the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYROWITZ, PAUL
description: MEYROWITZ-Paul. Of Great Neck, NY and Hallandale, FL. On April 12, 2001 at 86. Beloved husband of Jannette, his wife of 60 years, devoted father of Robert and David, cherished father-in-law of Ellen and Susan, devoted grandfather to Stacy, Alyson, Eric, Melissa, Jessica and Andrew and great-grandfather to Jackson and Charlotte. An attorney who founded the law firm of Simon Meyrowitz and Meyrowitz LLP in 1939, an active participant and contributor of Israeli Bonds from its inception, a former president of the Marine Park Jewish Center, a member of the Board of Directors of Temple Israel of Great Neck, member of the Board of Directors of the Merchants Bank of New York for 44 years and a member of the Advisory Board of Valley National Bank. A brilliant, noble mind and a wonderful spirit. His kindness and sense of humor will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Funeral services will be held on April 13, 2001 at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck at 12 noon.

title: Metro Business Briefing; GRANTS TO CLEAN UP LAND
description: New Jersey has awarded $764,031 to five cities and towns so that they can investigate, clean up and reuse so-called brownfields -- useless, abandoned and polluted sites -- officials announced yesterday. The sites include a former hazardous waste storage site in Jersey City where chemicals may have been discharged and an abandoned house in Lower Township in Cape May County that may have leaked oil. The money comes from the Hazardous Discharge Site Remediation Fund, administered jointly by the Department of Environmental Protection and the Economic Development Authority. The grants are awarded to municipalities that have acquired such sites, determined the cleanup costs and tried to develop them. Other recipients are Kearny, Perth Amboy and Rahway. Steve Strunsky

description: BASEBALL

title: KOREA PREDICTS ECONOMIC GROWTH
description: The Korea Institute for Industrial Economics and Trade, a government research organization, predicted that the Korean economy would grow 4.3 percent this year. The institute, which had forecast a 5.9 percent increase in December, joined other forecasters in lowering its estimate as a result of the slowdown in the United States and Japan. The Bank of Korea was expected to cut its estimate of a 5.3 percent increase in growth to 4 percent, less than half the 8.8 percent rate last year. Don Kirk

title: When the Medium Really Was the Message
description: There's no more stimulating patch of art turf in Manhattan than the Islamic wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It may not feel that way at first. Lights are low; visitors are few; silence prevails. But the sights are spectacular: flower-scattered Ottoman tiles, ivories from Andalusia, glinting North African goldwork and an entire 18th-century courtyard, marble floor and stained-glass windows intact, magic-carpeted in from Damascus.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: After endless delays, Beppe finally opened on March 12, and now its sunny terra-cotta facade beams on East 22nd Street like a great big smile.

title: The Gold Glover Wins a Game With His Bat
description: When Rey Ordez was scheduled to lead off the ninth inning on Wednesday, Mets Manager Bobby Valentine called for a pinch-hitter. It was a cold night, Valentine reasoned, and he had pinch-hitters who had spent the game in the clubhouse, keeping warm. Valentine regretted the move, and not just because it did not work. ''I kicked myself a little,'' Valentine said last night. ''He's swinging the bat too well.''

title: Race and the Uses of Law
description: Why is affirmative action in universities so unpopular when it seems to be working so well? Statistical studies show that the policy has improved racial diversity not only in the classrooms but later in life, in business and the professions, as well, and contributed to improved understanding among races.

title: That Poetry of Mamet, Aboard a Boat, Dammit
description: ''Lakeboat'' might have been subtitled ''How I Spent My Summer Vacation in a David Mamet Play.'' The film, directed by a Mamet mainstay, Joe Mantegna, was written by Mr. Mamet, and it concerns a young graduate student (he says he goes to school ''in Massachusetts, near Boston,'' which is widely recognized code for Harvard) who spends a season working on the Seaway Queen, a Lake Michigan freight boat. On board he meets an assortment of brawny, big-talking characters, and you can see him drinking up their profane aper-->us and rambling tall tales with a writer's eager attention. And, of course, a writer is what he will become. The better subtitle might be: ''Where My Plays Come From, by David Mamet.''

title: STRIKE BEGINS AT GUINNESS
description: A strike by five of the six unions at the Guinness Ireland Group, a unit of Diageo P.L.C., shut down the company's Irish plants, including its flagship brewery in Dublin, for the first time since 1974. Union leaders and management continued government-sponsored talks over the fate of the company's 294-year-old packaging and bottling plant in Dundalk, which the company plans to close at the end of the month to save 8 million Irish pounds ($9 million). The talks collapsed on Tuesday but are likely to continue over the weekend. A long strike would cause inventories of Guinness, as well as other beers brewed by the company, to run out in days. Brian Lavery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIBOURG, MICHEL
description: FRIBOURG-Michel. The Board of Directors, senior management and staff of Overseas Shipholding Group, Inc. mourn the passing of Michel Fribourg, a founding shareholder and a member of our Board of Directors from the inception of the Company until his recent retirement. We will deeply miss his wise counsel, wisdom, and vision, and most of all, his friendship. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Mary Ann, his sons Paul, Robert and Charles, his daughters Nadine Newman and Caroline Rosen, and to the entire family. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman and CEO Overseas Shipholding Group, Inc.

description: Disputes involving promoters, television networks and various boxing organizations often delay, or prevent, certain fights from taking place. People are still waiting for Lennox Lewis to fight Mike Tyson, or for Roy Jones Jr. to fight a compelling contender.

description: Gen. Colin L. Powell came to Bosnia for the first time today and used his stature as secretary of state to try and douse the flames of nationalism that stoked three and a half years of war here and still threaten the peace.

title: France to Evacuate 15,000 Living Near Old Ammunition Dump
description: Thousands of people living near a stockpile of artillery shells and chemical weapons left over from both world wars were ordered to leave their homes in northern France today after experts said the bombs might explode.

title: DAEWOO SELLS UNIT
description: Daewoo Motor sold off its technical research unit in Britain as evidence of its dedication to cutting its overseas operations in hopes of an offer from General Motors. Daewoo said that the Tom Walkinshaw Racing Company, which specializes in automotive engineering for sports cars, had purchased its Worthing Technical Center. The price for the unit, which designed and engineered some of Daewoo's most popular passenger cars, was reportedly about $8 million. G.M., meanwhile, said it remained interested in Daewoo and was committed to making a decision as soon as possible on buying the company. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Aetna's Chief Financial Officer Will Leave
description: Four days after Aetna said its earnings for the first quarter would be ''significantly lower'' than expected and its shares dropped sharply, the company announced yesterday that its chief financial officer, Alan J. Weber, would leave.

title: GUINNESS STRIKE ENDS
description: After just one day on the picket lines, five unions at the Guinness Ireland Group, a unit of Diageo P.L.C., called off a nationwide strike that had threatened to dry up Ireland's supply of beer. The walkout ended when management agreed to postpone the closing of a packaging and bottling plant in Dundalk that employs 140 people. The two sides will resume government-supervised talks next week about the future of the plant and about the company's plans to reorganize its Irish operations. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: A Threatened Act
description: It was probably just a matter of time before the Bush administration tried to shorten the reach of the Endangered Species Act. The act is the most controversial of the great wave of environmental statutes enacted in the early 1970's. It also greatly annoys some of President Bush's core constituencies, like the logging and mining interests, which argue that by protecting habitat for the spotted owl and other species, the law inhibits economic development. Mr. Bush's own appointee as interior secretary, Gale Norton, once filed a brief challenging the constitutionality of the act, and now she is in charge of administering it.

title: Corrections
description: A picture credit on the television page on April 5 and in the Thursday highlights of the Television section on April 1 for the documentary ''They Came for Good: A History of the Jews in the United States'' misstated the ownership of a photograph of workers at the Boston Matzo Baking Company. It belongs to the American Jewish Historical Society, not to Connecticut Public Broadcasting.

title: Good Friday in Jerusalem: Many Police, Few Visitors
description: It was a street scene found only in Jerusalem: a blood-smeared, bare-chested man playing the part of Christ, flanked by a pair of plastic-helmeted Roman soldiers and toting a heavy wooden cross, was blocked in his progress up the Via Dolorosa by a dozen heavily armed Israeli police officers. Above the blue caps and bulletproof vests, just the crown of thorns was visible.

title: Graziella Sciutti, 73, Soprano and Director
description: Graziella Sciutti, an Italian soprano and opera director whose purity of sound and deft characterizations won her admiration in Mozart, Puccini and Verdi roles, died on Monday in Geneva. She was 73 and lived in Geneva and London.

title: CZECH MEDIA EXECUTIVE CHARGED
description: The Czech po lice filed charges accusing a prominent media executive, Vladimir Zelezny, left, of tax evasion and customs fraud involving importation of artwork, adding to charges earlier this week of damaging a creditor, a criminal offense under Czech law. Mr. Zelezny has been embroiled in a lengthy dispute with the American cosmetics heir Ronald S. Lauder over control of a Czech television station, TV Nova. Mr. Lauder has won several recent court and arbitration rulings on the matter. A complaint from Mr. Lauder's company, CME, started the criminal investigation of Mr. Zelezny, prosecutors said. A spokesman for Mr. Zelezny said all the charges against him would be shown to be unsubstantiated. Katka Fronk (NYT)

title: Global Jazz:Everything Is Fusing With Everything
description: PARIS  Jazz is in the process of becoming the musica franca, the one language spoken everywhere, a glue in the global village, the musical common denominator; like English. It will not necessarily remain "America's only native art form" forever.

title: Strains in Mr. Bush's Party
description: President Bush has now been tested by his first foreign policy confrontation and his first major negotiation with Congress over a domestic policy issue, namely tax cuts. The successful conclusion of the standoff over the downed American spy plane in China has surely pleased most Americans this holiday weekend. As for approval of his budget priorities, Mr. Bush got significantly less than what he wanted from the Senate. What has emerged from these two battles is a picture of the strains between the two wings of Mr. Bush's party. He may have to contend with conservative Republican resistance to his moderate foreign policies and moderate Republican resistance to his conservative domestic program.

title: Hale House Postpones Fund-Raiser After One Award Recipient Withdraws
description: Buffeted by recent bad publicity, Hale House, the Harlem charity that provides shelter for children of drug-addicted and H.I.V.-infected mothers, has postponed its June fund-raiser until October, a spokeswoman said yesterday.

title: Steel Makers In Japan Plan Joint Effort
description: Two of Japan's five giant steel makers, the NKK Corporation and the Kawasaki Steel Corporation, said today that they had agreed to merge their operations to compete better globally in an industry whose main customers, car makers, are also consolidating around the world.

title: U.S. SAYS SPY CREW WIPED OUT SECRETS IN FRANTIC LANDING
description: As Chinese troops surrounded the crippled American spy plane on April 1, waving their guns and shouting, the crew spent 15 furious minutes after their emergency landing destroying secret materials before opening the hatch and surrendering, senior American officials and diplomats said today.

title: New Attention for the Idea That Abortion Averts Crime
description: In the last several years, many causes have been enthusiastically advanced to explain the dramatic drop in crime in the United States over the past decade: innovative policing, tougher sentencing laws, the waning of the crack epidemic, better enforcement of gun laws and an improvement in the economy. Many scholars have leaped to promote a pet theory, which often coincided with a favorite policy recommendation. But one theory has come along that no one, not even the authors, is eager to embrace as policy: abortion.

title: Winfield Chooses Padres Over Yanks
description: Before he played for the Yankees, he played for the San Diego Padres, and that is why Dave Winfield has decided his plaque at the Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y., will depict him in a Padres cap. It is the biggest upset the Yankees have suffered since they lost to the Cleveland Indians in the first round of the 1997 playoffs.

title: Mets Continue a Pattern of Letdowns
description: The Mets have settled into a disturbing habit in the first two weeks of the season. They have played well against the rival Atlanta Braves only to have letdowns against presumably lesser opponents.

title: Mayor Says City Paid Price For Union's Raised Hopes
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani accused some of his potential successors, particularly Fernando Ferrer, of heightening expectations among city employees and making contract negotiations with them harder by supporting large salary increases.

title: Spring Bike Trips
description: Biking trips are growing in popularity, and for those who would like to try one for the first time while reducing the financial risk, GORPtravel is offering a 50 percent discount for the second of two people traveling together on any of five biking trips this spring. For example, a tent-camping trip along the Kokopelli Trail in Colorado May 7 to 11 is $845 a person or $1,268 for two. A six-day inn and camping trip from Bryce Canyon to Zion National Park in Utah will be $935 a person, or $1,403 for two; there are five departure dates June through July. A five-day tent-camping ride along the Grand Canyons North Rim is $845 a person, $1,268 for two, available May 21 to 25, July 2 to 6 and July 9 to 13. Similarly priced trips are also available from Telluride to Durango, Colo., and through the hot springs area of Idaho. All prices include meals, shuttle transportation from the trips meeting point, support vehicles, all permits and entry fees and two guides. Difficulty levels vary. Information: (877) 440-4677 or www.gorptravel.com .

title: Gypsies Fiddle Madly as Classical Spirits Hover
description: The performance was born of a good idea: to contrast Hungarian classical music familiar from the concert hall -- Liszt, Dohnanyi, Bartok -- with original Gypsy prototypes. And for its Thursday night concert at the 92nd Street Y, the second of two explorations of Roma (Gypsy) music this month, the Perspectives Ensemble found some good musicians in the two Roma musical groups they invited from Hungary to join them. They failed, however, to go the extra step to knit the whole thing together into a meaningful whole, and the concert was thus less a focused exploration than an uneven medley.

title: Abroad at Home; The Two George W. Bushes
description: In bringing the imbroglio with China successfully to an end, President Bush displayed qualities that had not been evident since he entered the White House. He was measured, and sensitive to the other party's interests and political needs.

title: When a Mixture of Idioms Promotes the Cuban Sound
description: On the opening night of his week-long run at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday, Chucho Valds appeared in clothes that could not have been worn by someone of middling talent: a white suit with a long jacket ending just above his knees over a red satin shirt and tie.

title: The Need for Calm in the Mideast
description: The daily violence between Israelis and Palestinians has not only stretched into a seventh month, it has escalated dangerously toward open warfare. Washington should be making a greater effort to convince both sides of the need to practice restraint. The Bush administration reasonably decided that it would not seek to micromanage Mideast peace talks the way the Clinton administration did. But the United States cannot stand aside while the region slides toward deeper conflict.

A memorial service will be held at Huguenot Memorial Church, 901 Pelhamdale Ave, Pelham Manor, N.Y. 3PM Saturday, April 21st. description: Flanked by center-left leaders who have governed Italy since 1996, Francesco Rutelli, 46, who is campaigning to become Italy's next prime minister, presented a dense, chart-filled report this week showing how unemployment, public debt and inflation have dropped on his coalition's watch.

title: Robert Moon, an Inventor of the ZIP Code, Dies at 83
description: Robert A. Moon, a career postal employee who in 1963 won a 20-year fight for what was to become the ZIP code, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Leesburg, FL, 34748. He is the undisputed father of the first three digits in the code.

title: Baseball and Editors' Group Compromise to End Dispute
description: Nearly two weeks into the season, Major League Baseball announced it had compromised with the news organizations that cover its games. Yesterday, the groups ended their dispute over how much control baseball and its teams could exercise over information, particularly photographs, sent out from a stadium during a game.

title: Officials Move To Increase Police Recruits
description: With a deadline fast approaching, applications for the coming police test have lagged, suggesting that interest in a career with the New York Police Department remains anemic. While unwilling to concede they have a recruiting problem, police officials said yesterday that they would make a wide range of changes to the recruitment program.

title: JAPAN LEAVES INTEREST RATE UNCHANGED
description: The Bank of Japan voted to keep its monetary policy unchanged, leaving the interest rates effectively at zero. The central bank moved to lower the rates to near zero last month to avert a serious economic downturn. The decision by the bank's policy board, which ended a two-day meeting had been widely expected. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: After Complaints, Yahoo to Close Access to Pornographic Sites

title: The Rewards of Obsessing About Film

And when he was a student, he loved keeping track of election returns, baseball averages and the number of cities with populations larger than 25,000. He still remembers the state that had the most cities of that size during his boyhood, and it happened to be Ohio.

A group representing black firefighters objected to the hiring.

description: Robert Kravitz was 9 years old in 1959 when Hoover introduced ''the electric broom,'' a vacuum cleaner that was attached to the end of a long pole. ''My mother kept saying, 'Oh my God, I want an electric broom, I want an electric broom,' until finally we had to get it for her,'' Mr. Kravitz said. ''It made a great Mother's Day present.''
