description: KLEIN-Esther. A great matriarch has died too young on a fortnight and some before her 105th birthday. Beloved & adored mother, sister, grandmother, great-grandmother, aunt, cousin and friend. Daughter of Rascha and Velvel Ohsie, born April 28, 1896, in Vilna, Lithuania. She was predeceased by her beloved husband of 49 years, Irving Klein. Cherished mother of Shirley Shapiro and Leona Kern, Harris Shapiro and Ralph Kern. Adoring grandmother of Elaine Appellof, Beth and James Steele, Bill Kern and Mariye Inouye, Mariane and Bennett Borko, Franklin and Julie Kern, Diane and Bari Shamas, and her beloved surviving sister Lillian Rosen. A great-grandmother giving unconditional love to Rachel, Ellie, Sarah, Jacob, Emily, Seth, Allison Melanie, Adam, Raphi and Irene. Esther's radiant smile, the sound of her laughter and her boundless love and affection will be forever in all of our hearts and minds.

title: How to Get Into College After Being Rejected
description: Catesby Holmes scored 800 on the verbal section of the College Boards. She was on the honor roll for four straight years, and she lettered in field hockey and won awards for music, Latin and horseback riding. Yet she did not get into college. Harvard, Princeton, Yale, Columbia, Brown and Wesleyan rejected her; after putting her on the waiting list, so did Amherst and the University of Chicago. "I spent the spring watching friends put college stickers on their cars while I tried to figure out what I was going to do with my life," Catesby remembers. "As in, what was I at this point if not 'collegebound'?"

description: Italian industrial produc tion fell for the second consecutive month in February, another indication that an economic slowdown in the United States was hurting Italy, the euro region's third-largest economy. Output at Italian companies was 0.3 percent less in February than in January, when production fell a revised 1.9 percent, the statistics institute Istat said. Economists had expected a drop of 0.7 percent. Production advanced an adjusted 3 percent in February 2000.

title: Old Wounds in Cincinnati
description: This week's riots give Cincinnati expatriates of a certain age an eerie feeling. In 1968 I was 9 years old and heard on the radio that someone named Martin Luther King had been shot. I remember yelling the news to my mother upstairs, and hearing her groan with sadness. We lived -- my parents still live -- in North Avondale, a liberal paradise, as I've come to realize. It was lower- to upper-middle-class and black and white, with subtle boundaries, to be sure -- but we all went together to elementary school and played in each other's backyards and basements. When the riots started, some of my playmates offered to put a ''Soul Brother'' sign on the lawn below our house so the mob, like the angel of death, would pass this Jewish family by.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENSTEIN, TRUDY

description: Nyree Dawn Porter, who entranced millions of television viewers around the world when she starred as the beautiful Irene, trapped in a loveless marriage in the BBC adaptation of John Galsworthy's ''Forsyte Saga'' in the late 1960's, died on Monday at her home in London. She was 61.

title: R.R. Uses Boxes for Bidding, With Predictable Results
description: One of the most popular characters in the bridge world is the Rueful Rabbit, created by the late Victor Mollo. R.R. regularly achieved triumphs as a result of accidents that left his opponents groaning. R.R. showed up at the Spring Nationals in Cincinnati in March, and held the West cards on the diagramed deal from the Open Pairs. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, SIDNEY
description: GROSSMAN-Sidney. With the deepest sense of loss, his devoted family announces the passing of our indomitable patriarch. For every day of his 86 years he lived life to the fullest, with unconditional love for his family, commitment to philanthropic causes and passion for all that is just and decent in the world. His playful sense of humor, breadth of interests and boundless energy rendered every day of his life an adventure. He will be profoundly missed by Bunny (Beatrice), his beloved wife of 62 years; his children Nancy, Judy and Steven, Gary and Lynn; his grandchildren Robert and Amy, Andrew and Alyson, Michael and Daniel; his great-grandchildren Adam and Julie; and his sister and soulmate Shirley. The Legend will live in our memories forever. Services on Monday, April 16, 2001 at 10:30 AM, Hewlett East Rockaway Jewish Center, 295 Main Street, East Rockaway.

title: TALKS FOR PHONE STAKES
description: Despite heavy debts, British Telecommunications P.L.C. said it had negotiated options to buy stakes of about 5 percent in three lucrative mobile phone units owned by the Japan Telecom Company for $550 million by Sept. 29. The announcement intensified the British Telecommunications rivalry in Asia with Vodafone P.L.C., the world's biggest wireless operator, which already owns 26 percent of J-Phone Communications, a holding company for the mobile units. Vodafone is maneuvering to become the biggest shareholder in Japan Telecom, in which British Telecom has a 20 percent stake. With debts of some $43 billion, British Telecom did not say how it would pay for the purchase if it exercised the options. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Journal; What Big Test?
description: Bush's Big Test,'' as headline writers had it, was actually more like a pop quiz. The 24 ''detainees'' never morphed into ''hostages.'' The ''accident'' never became a ''crisis.'' The 11 days never became ''13 Days.'' The closest the incident ever came to escalating into a TV mediathon was when Sandy Berger and Lawrence Eagleburger tried to outdo each other in on-air bloviation, as they unsuccessfully vied to shove a resurgent Henry Kissinger out of the spotlight. title: Mudville Can Never Die
description: Baseball is not a metaphor. Life does not imitate the World Series. Whoever wants to know the heart and mind of America had better learn professional wrestling. People who agree with all this might still enjoy a new edition of Ernest L. Thayer's CASEY AT THE BAT: A Ballad of the Republic Sung in the Year 1888 (Handprint/Chronicle, $17.95; ages 9 to 12), splendidly illustrated by Christopher Bing. If you manage to slide safely past the dedication -- to all those children of spring who have found moments of heaven in the smell of a freshly mowed ballpark . . .'' -- you'll find that Bing has imagined something called The Mudville Sunday Monitor, which in June 1888 reports on Casey's legendary at-bat, while other news appears at the bottom of each page. The unusual pen-and-ink scratchboard drawings give this Caldecott Honor Book the look of a late-19th-century paper. Interspersed throughout are pertinent advertisements as well as editorials from another fictional publication, The National Sports Reporter & Gazette, one of which argues against the forthcoming exclusion of black players from organized baseball. Thayer's mock-heroic verse is, as Donald Hall said, a celebration of failure, and perhaps for that reason has always seemed especially popular in New England. The poet grew up in Massachusetts and attended Harvard, and the illustrator ''lives and dies'' (mostly dies) with the Boston Red Sox; even Bing's catcher looks a lot like another Harvard man, Henry Louis Gates Jr. This book should appeal to Red Sox fans of all ages, and prepare the young ones for the failures to come: ''Oh, somewhere in this favored land the sun is shining bright; / The band is playing somewhere, and somewhere hearts are light; / And somewhere men are laughing, and somewhere children shout; / But there is no joy in Beantown -- mighty Manny has struck out.'' David Kelly

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRIGHT, BEN G.
description: WRIGHT-Ben G. Died April 10, 2001 at the age of 89 in Colorado Springs, Colorado. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Dolly Wright, a daughter Mrs. William Cogswell and her husband Bill of Colorado Springs, two grandchildren, Meghan and Ben. Mr. Wright was the former publisher of Field and Stream magazine and later the president and chairman of This Week Magazine. In World War II he served with the Air Force in Europe, where, with the Ninth Air Force he organized and operated press camps for war correspondents from Normandy to Berlin for which he was awarded the Legion of Merit. His university, Eastern Michigan, awarded him a Doctor of Letters degree in 1967. His interests were wide and varied. He was a Trustee of the Falcon Foundation, the Correspondents Fund, the New York Infirmary, a former director of the Home Life Insurance Company, a Jimmy Doolittle Fellow of the Aerospace Education Foundation. He was active in the affairs of the Overseas Press Club and on two occasions in its early days headed campaigns to raise the funds to establish a World Press Center and the Edward R. Murrow library. The proceeds from these campaigns funded the purchase of the Republican Club in New York, for many years the press club's headquarters. A sportsman and dedicated conservationist Wright traveled much of the world and wrote numerous articles for sporting magazines, mostly about shooting and photographic safaris in Africa, and salmon fishing in North America, Scandinavia and the United Kingdom. He considered the Atlantic Salmon on a dry fly the most exciting fishing experience.

Pataki of New York had exceeded his authority in approving the St. Regis Mohawk casino in the Catskills and that the tribe would have to seek approval through the New York State Legislature. The Legislature is largely anti-casino and is considered likely to reject casino projects. A casino in the Catskills would surely siphon gamblers away from Atlantic City. Park Place Entertainment, which owns the Bally's, Caesars and Hilton casinos in Atlantic City, had persuaded members of the Mohawk tribe to scuttle an earlier casino project in the Catskills and become partners in a $500 million casino on the site of Kutsher's Resort and Country Club in Monticello, N.Y., 80 miles from the New Jersey border. The chief executive of Park Place, Tom Gallagher, said, ''We remain committed to working with the St. Regis Mohawk tribe and the State of New York.'' Donald J. Trump, owner of three Atlantic City casino hotels, was not so measured, calling the decision ''a positive for Atlantic City and a positive for New Jersey.'' Bill Kent

title: Folk Rock for Small Folk
description: For parents who can't take the commercial blitz of Mars 2112 or ''Pokmon 3: The Movie,'' Dan Zanes and his band, Rocket Ship Review, are offering a hip, folky take on kiddie entertainment. Last month, Mr. Zanes began putting on weekly Sunday family concerts at the Park, the new Chelsea restaurant owned by Eric Goode (of Area and MK fame) and Sean MacPherson. In the restaurant's backroom, Mr. Zanes (who was the lead singer and songwriter for the Del Fuegos through the 1980's) performs roots-rock music for children -- much of it from the new band's first album, ''Rocket Ship Beach,'' which includes appearances by Sheryl Crow, Suzanne Vega and Lisa Loeb. Apparently, ''Polly Wolly Doodle,'' Bob Dylan-style, has charms that extend beyond the toddler set: in the audience last Sunday were Gwyneth Paltrow, Stella McCartney and Liv Tyler. The Sunday before, David Duchovny and Ta Leoni followed their daughter onto the dance floor. The response has inspired Mr. Zanes to start his own record label, Festival Five Records, on which the band's second album is scheduled for release in September. The musicians include, from left, Rosita Isles, Barbara Brousal, Mr. Zanes John DeNicola and Alyssa Lamb. ''There's so much soulless, corporate-produced stuff out there,'' Mr. Zanes said. ''Hopefully, we're making music that has a do-it-yourself feeling, as though a bunch of people got together to sing and have a good time. I want it to be homemade and fun.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE ALESSANDRINI DI NEUENSTEIN, DR. LUIGI MARIA
description: de ALESSANDRINI di NEUENSTEIN-Dr. Luigi Maria. Died on April 10th. He was 82 and lived in New York City. Born on August 3, 1918, in Genoa, Italy. He graduated from the University of Genoa's Medical School on June 18, 1943 and received his OBGYN specialty on November 16, 1949. He served as Lt. Col. Medical Doctor during World War II in the Italian Marines. He was Health Immigration Officer from 1948-49. His interest in exploring life and seeing the world brought him to Uruguay where he met, fell in love with and married Alfa Morales on April 26, 1950. They lived in Portofino, Italy, where he practiced medicine. He was Assistant Professor of OBGYN at the University of Genoa until 1957. On April 21, 1957, he came to the US and established a private medical practice in Virginia and was on the Boards of Norfolk General and De Paul Hospitals. During his career, he also worked at Mount Vernon, Riverside and Eastern State Hospitals, where he received a specialty in Psychiatry. On May 21, 1965, Luigi was made Vice Counsel of Italy for the State of Virginia by the Italian Ministry of Commerce and Foreign Affairs and confirmed by Dean Rusk, U.S. Secretary of State. After spending 1970-73 in Italy, he returned to Virginia in 1973. In 1978 he became Assistant Professor at the Eastern Virginia Medical School. During the 70s and 80s he assisted with clinical research in the field of OBGYN, contributing to the discovery and treatment for various venereal diseases. Between 1975-1988, he became Clinical Director of the Portsmouth Health Department and was part of the National Family Planning Board, sponsored by the White House. In recognition of his contribution to special medical education programs, he was made Fellow of The American Academy of Family Physicians in October 1983. He loved his wife dearly. They have been loving friends & companions for 51 years. Alfa survives him as do his sons, Paolo and Enrico, daughters-inlaw, Jackie and Ellen and grandchildren, Alexa and Giulio. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be sent to Cabrini Hospice C/O Cabrini Medical Center, 227 East 19th Street, NY, NY, 10003.

title: Keeping Up With the Shidhayes
description: There is an expression you hear nowadays in Aurangabad, a city of about a million souls located 150 miles northeast of Bombay, that would have made absolutely no sense when I lived there 25 years ago. People will say, ''The traffic is too-too bad in old Aurangabad,'' or ''The shopping is still cheaper in old Aurangabad.'' Back in 1976, when I served as a junior lecturer on the English faculty of the Maulana Azad College and its affiliated Ladies' Section, everything in Aurangabad was old. The city had decayed, but otherwise not much else had changed since the glorious moment in the late 17th century when Aurangzeb, the last of the great Mogul emperors, moved the capital from Delhi to this little outpost at the top of the Deccan Plateau. And in fact, the city that I knew, with its dusty lanes filled with the insane honking of scooters and motorbikes and three-wheeled auto-rickshaws and its sleepy sweet shops and its ancient wooden houses, hasn't changed a bit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITTELSEY, DANIEL CHAUNCEY
description: WHITTELSEY-Daniel Chauncey. Age 77. Of Mt. Lake Park, formerly of Coral Gables, FL, passed away on Tuesday, April 10, 2001, in Morgantown, WV. He was born January 24, 1924, in Bay Shore, Long Island, and was a son of the late Daniel I. Whittelsey and Freda (Peck) Whittelsey. Mr. Whittelsey graduated from the Taft School in 1943, and from Yale University in 1950. He was a veteran of World War II where he served as a Lieutenant in the United States Navy. He was the founder and CEO of Whittelsey Wood Products and Jacaranda Incorporated in Miami, FL. Mr. Whittelsey was a member of the Yale Club and the Deep Creek Yacht Club. He enjoyed local politics and was a columnist for the Republican newspaper in Oakland, MD. He is survived by his wife, Elisabeth (Luckey) Whittelsey; two sons, Daniel I. Whittelsey and his wife Deborah of Cincinnati, OH, and Thomas F. Whittelsey and his wife Mari of Miami, FL; two daughters, Lee Saba and her husband David of Ashburn, VA, and Carol P. Bonella and her husband Robert of Sarasota, FL. Mr. Whittelsey has nine grandchildren and a sister, Katherine H. Whittelsey of Charlottesville, VA. Interment will be in the Putnam Cemetery in Greenwich, CT, on Thursday, April 19 at 3 PM.

title: The Bismarck's Grave
description: It's a long way to go to see a major relic of World War II, and it isn't cheap at $37,500 a person, but the wreck, the German battleship Bismarck, was one of the most famous warships in World War II. Zegrahm Expeditions, a Seattle company that has been leading submersible expeditions for over a decade, is offering the trip June 11 to 24, with departure from Cork, Ireland. The Bismarck, sunk by the British in May 1941, is under more than 15,000 feet of water off Ireland's coast. Participants will make one visit of 11 to 12 hours to the wreck in a pair of two-passenger submersibles, built in 1987, previously used to explore the Titanic site. The voyage is aboard the Akademik Keldysh, a 6,240-ton research ship built in Finland in 1981 that holds 110 people, including crew and passengers. The trip will include lectures by experts in deep-sea diving. For information, call (800) 628-8747 or visit www.deepseavoyages.com. JOSEPH SIANO

title: The Past Tense of Feel
description: In Alice Fulton's poetry, those charged instances when the literal and the metaphysical (and the sensual and the philosophical) overlap are often mediated by wordplay -- a pun, a double entendre, a witty turn of phrase. The title of her marvelous fifth collection, FELT (Norton, $22), is meant to signify both an emotion once experienced -- or, as one poem is called, ''The Permeable Past Tense of Feel'' -- but also the fabric constructed by fibers that are forcibly pressed, rather than woven, together. In ''Fair Use,'' these two meanings fuse, so that felt represents the joyous and maddening experience of human interconnectedness -- a fabric of entanglement == / my consciousness felted with yours.'' (Fulton sparingly uses an amplified version of Emily Dickinson's dash -- double equal signs, which look like little train tracks along which one image speeds into the next.) Throughout these kinetically textured lyric poems -- they have varied indentations and line lengths, and are aurally rich with slant rhymes and musical rhythms -- the meanings of words shift, contort and refract (one point of creating art, as Fulton puts it, is ''to / origami thought''). In the long poem ''About Music for Bone and Membrane Instrument,'' written in a series of 13 sections, a Japanese fan metamorphoses into fan's other usage -- a devotee or admirer -- as the loss of self shared by both a star performer and a swooning audience member is revealed. In poems obsessed with identity, yearning and intimacy, the power of Fulton's verbal pyrotechnics is that they precisely animate these mutable, ever-changing states. Megan Harlan

title: What Goes Around Comes Around
description: When an irresistible force (youth) meets an immovable object (age), something's got to give. And it's no better if you reverse the terms to make the irresistible the weight of experience and the immovable the demands of innocence. Once you find yourself on the ''Songs of Experience'' side of things, you have to fight the slightly rancid satisfaction of constantly using words like ''immature'' and ''derivative,'' followed by a long list of previous artists who've done much the same thing only better. Inside every bright young writer is an angry old man or woman ready to cite the literary failings of the new generation in a prominent magazine essay. Which will be answered, or has been anticipated, by an aggressive manifesto from the young, who rarely fail to insist that they are thinking and feeling the truly important things in a way never thought or felt before. Innocence can be quite bellicose.

The British firm Future Systems (remember their aluminum entrance tunnel for Comme des Garons in New York?) designed Marni's first free-standing shop, which opened recently in London. Frank Gehry is ''kibitzing'' on a new Issey Miyake store, designed by his protege Gordon Kipping, which will open this fall in TriBeCa. title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: OF all those stagy Technicolor Bible epics in the 1950's, THE ROBE (1953) has never stood out, but it's the first movie ever made in Cinema-Scope, and one of the most original. Based on the novel by Lloyd C. Douglas and directed by Henry Koster, it's the story of Marcellus (a young Richard Burton), a powerful Roman centurion who infuriates the Emperor Caligula by outbidding him at a slave auction and finds himself posted to undesirably far-away Palestine just long enough to preside over the crucifixion of Jesus. Marcellus is so affected by this event that at first he seems to be having a breakdown, then he does a little reflecting and joins Jesus' followers. Jean Simmons stars as Burton's patrician love interest, Victor Mature as his Greek slave and Jay Robinson as a strangely unmalicious Caligula -- Sunday at 8 p.m. and Sunday/Early Monday at 1:45 a.m. on AMC.

title: The Nation; Discretionary Spending, Where the Money Isn't.
description: IN preparing his new budget, President Bush focused his attention on a particular type of spending, the sort subject to annual appropriations by Congress.

title: Political Briefing; Democrats Prepare To Take On Jeb Bush
description: Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida hasn't said yet whether he will run for a second term next year. But Democrats contend he almost certainly will, and they are gearing up to take him on.

title: When 200 Women Are Happily Crammed Into a Boutique
description: THREE women, their blond hair ironed straight, tore through a rack of denim jeans as if the pockets were stuffed with $100 bills. Nearby, a cluster of fashion editors in teetering heels circled a cozy Henley sweater. It was a must, they agreed. Disco was blasting. Think of the fervor of an exclusive sample sale. Multiply by two. Add cocktails, and you have a fashion phenomenon -- the shopping party.

title: In Tibetan Rituals, Metaphors for Freedom
description: IN a former army munitions warehouse on the outskirts of Paris, 18 Tibetan monks in saffron- and crimson-colored robes chop vegetables and tell jokes about the ineffable relationship between movement and meditation that is part of their monastery's spiritual discipline.

title: Willows You Never Expected
description: THE last time I fell in love with a willow was at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden when a variety called melanostachys waved its black velvet catkins with their red anthers at me. Of course I had to have this black pussy willow, and planted a small one on the edge of my vegetable garden at the farm. Who knew that these delicate stems would develop into a hulking bush that now shades out half my lettuce patch? Or that these spectacular black and red fuzzies would last only a few weeks?

description: THE MONEY AND

title: April 8-14; D.E.A. Direct
description: Something to think about next time you decide to ride the rails: Amtrak has acknowledged that one of its ticketing offices has been ''sharing information'' about passengers with the Drug Enforcement Administration, and then taking a 10 percent cut of any assets seized from drug couriers.

title: Winning Coach Faces His Biggest Challenge
description: THE Horace Greeley tennis team is trying to extend a remarkable streak this season. Under Coach Tom Baker, the Quakers have won the Conference II League A championship for the last 11 years.

title: Life After Wartime
description: Sullivan may be unduly optimistic about the ''new cultural settlement.'' It will take only one change to reverse the balance on the Supreme Court.

description: MALLER-Julius B. Dr. April 15, 1901-May 8, 1959. Remembered with love and admiration.

title: Bedding Down With History
description: MANY United States hotel chains have long prided themselves on having a historic hotel or two in their portfolios, but now almost all of them have at least several, already open or under reconstruction.

title: San Francisco Journal; Case of a Fatal Mauling By Dogs Fascinates City
description: The arraignment was scheduled for Friday at 9 a.m., but the television crews started arriving at 7 a.m. to claim the choice parking spots at the Hall of Justice.

title: Tumult at the Top Leaves a Company in a Whirl
description: THE twists and turns of events at the Boston Ballet over the last seven weeks sound like the unfolding of a melodrama with the curtain ringing down on the surprise exit of the protagonist when the play had scarcely begun. Maina Gielgud, who had been appointed the next artistic director of the Boston Ballet in September, resigned at the end of February. She had been working for the company on a half-time consultant's contract when she gave notice.

title: His Music Can Leap and Fall, Tickle and Appall
description: PLAYING the double bass probably gives you a funny perspective on music, which might help explain the curious and crazy art of the Austrian composer Heinz Karl Gruber, known professionally as ''H. K.'' and to his friends as ''Nali.''

title: Corrections
description: The Good Eating column on April 1 misstated The New York Times's rating of the restaurant AZ. It received three stars, not two, on July 26, 2000.

title: Word for Word/Cloak and Greasepaint; When a Little Production in Hollywood Freed Six Americans Trapped in Iran
description: IT took intense diplomacy and some linguistic gymnastics last week to end the spy plane standoff with China and bring home 24 American crew members. Twenty-one years ago, the Central Intelligence Agency freed six American diplomats in a very different way.

title: Introduction
description: A courtroom, some readers insisted, is no place for artistic judgment, even to settle questions like those raised in the March 18 article on fake art and the Getty Museum. Also on the art front, our March 25 article on Julian Schnabel led a high-school classmate down memory lane.

title: Roses and Revenues For a Tribe
description: MANY Indian tribes around the country have turned to casinos to boost their fortunes. Not Roy Crazy Horse, chief of the Powhatan Renape Nation; he has turned to roses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARSCOTT, LOIS COFFIN
description: ARSCOTT-Lois Coffin. On March 23. Beloved wife of the late John R. Arscott. Loving mother of David and John and mother-in-law of Ann and Martha. Cherished grandmother of David, Devon, Jennifer, John, Philip and Tristram. Great grandmother of Ian, Luke and Mary Teresa. A memorial service in Princeton is planned for this summer. Donations in her memory may be made to Cornell U. 55 Brown Road, Ithaca, NY 14850.

title: Pot Luck
description: COMFORT ME

title: Amid Elegance, a Variety of Indian Dishes
description: IN terms of decor, Nirvana has done as much as possible to fulfill one meaning of its name: a place or state characterized by freedom from or oblivion to pain, worry or the external world. One might also add peaceful and otherworldly.

title: Bush Isn't All Wrong About the Endangered Species Act
description: The Bush administration has again outraged environmentalists, this time by proposing that Congress modify the budget for the Endangered Species Act. The administration wants to place financial restrictions on a process called ''designation of critical habitat,'' which maps areas occupied by endangered species.

title: The Gantlet Of Mortgage Approval
description: FOR those seeking a mortgage to buy a house or apartment, it quickly becomes apparent that getting the loan does not end with filing the application. Even borrowers who have been preapproved for a mortgage soon discover that the approval is often subject to conditions, contingencies and verifications before the lender writes a check for the mortgage.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Paramus; In Shopping Mecca, Houses Sell Well Too
description: LIVING in the most densely packed shopping area in New Jersey has its advantages. The 10.57-square-mile borough of Paramus has a tax rate that is in the lowest third of Bergen County's 70 municipalities. Yet, its award-winning school system spends $9,900 per pupil annually, which is nearly $1,000 above the state average.

title: Another Look at a Restaurant in Croton
description: IT'S the old story: after the dash and dazzle of the opening months, many restaurants run out of steam. Maintaining the standards of a good restaurant requires constant vigilance.

title: Entrepreneur Sails in Free Time
description: Philippe Kahn, the California-based technology entrepreneur who in the last two years has come out of the clear blue to become a major force in the sport of yacht racing, gives sailing its own version of Mark Cuban. Like Cuban, the owner of the Dallas Mavericks of the National Basketball Association, Kahn has earned vast wealth in Internet-related enterprises. And he has directed big chunks of it toward his sporting interests.

title: Fellow Educator Praises Rice Family
description: To the Editor:

title: Jam Band Finds Flood of Devotion, 60's Style
description: AS part of the current jam-band phenomenon created by the Grateful Dead in the 1960's, the Juggling Suns are poised to join the ranks of national successes like the Dave Matthews Band and Phish.

title: POSTINGS: At 51st Street and First Avenue, Near Beekman Place; A 32-Story, 89-Apartment Condo
description: It has taken 11 years, but the last of three modest buildings dating from 1902 to 1966 is to be bulldozed later this month, paving the way for a new 32-story condominium at 400 East 51st Street at First Avenue, a block from Beekman Place, the two-block enclave that runs parallel to First Avenue and the East River.

title: Raising Voices at a Library Over the Supply of Jewish Books
description: Members of the Forest Hills Action League, a community group, are arguing with the Queens Borough Public Library over whether the library has provided enough books on Jewish themes to the Forest Hills branch while supplying other Queens branches with anti-Semitic books.

title: A 1939 Theater Is Restored and the Area Is Looking Up, Too
description: Six years ago, when Stewart Epstein bought the American, a 1939 Art Deco theater in Parkchester, homeless people slept beneath its silk-covered walls and pigeons roosted near its chandeliers. One million dollars later, the American is a spotless 1,400-seat multiplex.

title: Private Sector; Once Burned, but Still Bold
description: RARELY does Robert E. Knowling Jr. find himself in a corporate situation that does not lend itself to a line borrowed from one of his favorite films. A staff meeting, say, might call for ''Failure is not an option'' (from ''Apollo 13),'' or a convention speech might include an aphorism from ''The Lion King'': ''You can either run from it, or learn from it.''

title: Reckonings; Let Them Shovel
description: It's not easy to top Marie Antoinette, but Curtis Hebert, chairman of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, may have pulled it off. Even free-market Republican lawmakers, like Senator Gordon Smith of Oregon, have accepted the idea that temporary price caps are a necessary part of the solution to the power crisis in the Western United States. But last week Mr. Hebert, who has the authority to impose such caps, rejected the idea once again. Instead he told Californians to ''start putting shovels in the ground'' and build more power plants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINGER, SUSAN
description: RUBINGER-Susan. The Jewish Community Relations Council of New York extends its heartfelt condolences to Bob and our past Board member, Nancy Rubinger, on the passing of their beloved daughter, Susan. A former staff member, Susan will be remembered for her kindness and devotion to others. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Gedale B. Horowitz, Pres. Michael S. Miller, Exec. V.P.

title: . . .And See a Sticky Wicket In the Form of Liquor Sales
description: In much of South Asia, people feel about cricket the way Americans feel about football. So to Kawal and Lalta Persaud, two brothers who played the sport competitively in India, it seemed a shrewd business move to open Indoor Cricket USA in Richmond Hill, an area heavily populated by South Asian immigrants.

title: Grief and Fury at Funeral for Slain Youth
description: Inside a packed church today, the black community's grief reached a crescendo with the singing of a hymn about suffering and resolve addressed to Jesus: ''I've been up and I've been down, but I'm not going to turn around because I'm fighting.''

title: Those Lipstick Marks on Brad: Loving Wax Figures Too Much
description: Regis Philbin lost a finger. Donald Trump and Baby Spice have bad hair days. And Brad Pitt doesn't stand a chance. Stargazers at Madame Tussaud's wax museum on West 42nd Street have been doing more than rubbing elbows with their favorite celebrities. New Yorkers and visitors here like to get personal.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 18 about the Mexican director Alejandro Gonzles Irritu misstated the name of the production company of his film ''Sex, Shame and Tears.'' It is Titn Producciones, not Altavista. The article also misstated the number of siblings he has; it is four, not six. The article misidentified a college friend who later became a partner in his company Zeta Film. She is Mariana Garca, not Martha Sosa.

title: April 8-14; Florida's New Water Plan
description: With drinking water beginning to run scarce, Florida is planning to embark on a controversial new effort to store vast quantities of surface runoff underground for dry-season recovery. The plan, which needs federal approval, is opposed by environmentalists, who fear that fecal coliform bacteria in the runoff might contaminate aquifers. But state officials say that the bacteria cannot survive underground and taxpayers will save hundreds of millions of dollars if the water is not first treated, as usually required under the Safe Drinking Water Act. Douglas Jehl

title: April 8-14; Spy Plane Tensions Persist
description: China released the 24 crew members of an American spy plane that had collided with a Chinese fighter plane, but only after the United States sent an official letter saying it was ''very sorry'' for the loss of the Chinese pilot and for the Americans' emergency landing on Chinese soil. The United States, angry that China was portraying its letter as taking responsibility for the accident, accused China's air force of a pattern of aggressive and reckless flying. The damaged plane remained in China, but American diplomats in Beijing said the crew had destroyed much of its secret material before surrendering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEPPER, ANITA GOLDEN, DR.
description: PEPPER-Anita Golden, Dr. In loving memory of our wife, mother, dearest friend, teacher, who died April 7, 2001 at her home in Montague, MA on her 46th wedding anniversary at age 73. Professor, passionate advocate for peace, social justice, healthcare for all, the special concerns of mothers and children; she delighted also in the domestic arts of fine cooking and baking, knitting and quilting, gardening. A special voice for peace and justice in the Middle East. Gifted teacher, inspired and inspiring human being. Burial was at Old South Cemetery, Montague, MA Memorial Celebration on Sunday, May 13, 11AM at National Yiddish Book Center, Hampshire College, Amherst, MA. Max, Sara, Thomas

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, MARTIN R., ESQ.
description: FRIEDMAN-Martin R., Esq. 92. Formerly of Astoria, Queens. With a deep sense of loss his family announces his peaceful passing on April 12, 2001 in Great Neck, NY. Devoted husband of the late Charlotte. Beloved father of Barbara and Stephen Weisen. Adored grandfather of Daniel and Carly. Cherished brother of Beatrice Oshinsky. Dearest uncle. Graduate of Brooklyn Law School and attorney in private practice for over 65 years. He loved his family dearly and was committed to many philanthropic and humanistic causes. He lived his life fighting for freedom for the underprivileged of all races and religions. Passed president Colonel David Marcus Lodge B'nai Brith. Founding member National Lawyers Guild. Charter member New York Florist Club. Community activist for a span of over 50 years. He will always be remembered with love as a man of kindness, humor and generosity. Services Monday, 11:30 AM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: A New Era May Dawn for Trout
description: On a frigid day this past February, I took a short walk along the West Branch of the Delaware River, just above the pool where it joins the East Branch and forms the longest undammed stretch of river -- 282 miles -- east of the Mississippi.

title: Discount Shoe Chain Opens New Stores in County
description: Shopping for shoes just got easier -- and cheaper -- in Westchester. Marty's, the discount shoe chain, has opened new outlets in Cortlandt, Yorktown and Mamaroneck. The stores are at the Cortlandt Town Center, the Triangle Shopping Center in Yorktown and and 626 East Boston Post Road in Mamaroneck.

title: Streetscapes/Apartment-Building Canopies; An Aspect of City Life Usually Taken for Granted
description: EXCEPT in rain and snow, New Yorkers tend to walk past building canopies as if the canopies were not there. Well, for a long time, until the turn of the last century, they usually weren't.

title: An Egg Roll For 12
Stockpiling More Than Half of the Country's Mercury
description: At the Somerville Depot in Hillsborough Township, the federal government maintains warehouses for a variety of materials, including more than half of the nation's stockpile of mercury, which can be hazardous to humans. The depot attracted local attention after mercury from another storage facility in Binghamton, N.Y., was relocated there late last fall. The mercury will stay in Hillsborough at least until the conclusion of a three-year study to determine what can be done with it, as plans are made for closing storage depots across the country over the next 20 years. James Farley, depot manager, recently talked the mercury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELAMBILY, CAPT. ROBERT W.
description: DeLAMBILY-Capt. Robert W., 76, Master Mariner, USMM. Died April 7, 2001. Resident of Lanoka Harbour, NJ, and Stuart, FL. Surviving are his wife Marguerite; son Robert W. DeLambily Jr., Haddonfield, NJ; daughters Suzan Hale, Toms River, NJ, Barbara Rodgers, Sugar Hill, GA. Memorial service April 22, 2001, First United Methodist Church of Island Heights, NJ. Contributions may be made to Salvation Army.

title: Cajun Cotillion
description: Some of the debutantes are wearing expensive outfits that are unattractive and unflattering. They could pay a lot less and look a lot better, especially those sitting in awkward positions.

title: Life After Wartime
description: The last time Andrew Sullivan displayed any real passion was last year when he wrote admiringly in your magazine of his testosterone-enhanced emotions. Are we to believe that political fervor is dead from a guy who reserves hyperbole for looking in the mirror?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMERMAN, FAY
description: HAMMERMAN-Fay. A true matriarch. Beloved mother of Robert, Elly and Steve. Beloved grandmother of Ira and Karen, Charles and Robin, Michael and Elissa, Caryn and Daniel. Beloved great grandmother of David, Stephanie, Jonathan, Sam, Morgan, Adam, Amanda, Harris, Adeena, Olivia, Douglas, Jason and Ilana. Beloved sister of Gert, Syd, Bea, Norman and the late Hy. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, 1:30PM Monday.

title: Paying for Repairs In a Co-op
description: Q. My co-op apartment occupancy agreement requires the corporation to ''provide and pay for all necessary repairs, maintenance and replacements on project property, including the member's dwelling unit'' with the exception of painting, kitchen appliances, kitchen flooring and damages caused by a member's negligence or misuse. Recently, some board members expressed the desire to alter the occupancy agreement so that fees can be charged for repairs. Would such a change be legal? . . . David H. Fox, Linden Hill, N.Y.

description: THE LAMP, THE ICE, AND

title: Private Sector; Where's the Beef? Here and There
description: When Arnold Schwarzenegger drove Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani into Times Square on Tuesday afternoon in a prototype of General Motors' three-ton Hummer H2 sport utility truck, he declared that the vehicle combined ''ruggedness with luxury.'' But creating that combination appears to have provoked a little culture clash between G.M. and A. M. General, the military contractor that sold the Hummer brand to G.M. and assembles the vehicle for it. The differences were visible at a dinner on Monday at AZ, a restaurant in the Flatiron district of Manhattan. The two A. M. General executives ordered the beef, rare and bloody, while all five executives from G.M.'s new Hummer division ordered the sea bass -- with watercress. But James A. Armour, A. M. General's chief executive, rose to the defense of G.M.'s managers, sort of. ''I'm spending a lot of my time in Florida, so that's where I'm getting my seafood,'' he said. ''I have a boat.'' Keith Bradsher

title: Ignored for Decades, They're Suddenly a Hot Band
description: SONGS that Rita Lee recorded back in the 1960's have suddenly emerged as hipster favorites on college radio stations in the United States.

title: Berlusconi, The Rerun
description: The richest man in Italy did two small things on his way to an international political conference on the French Riviera. Before boarding his Gulfstream jet, Silvio Berlusconi stopped in at a Milan courthouse where he had been called to testify in a trial of two of his employees charged in 1994 with committing perjury. (He didn't answer any questions, however, pleading an Italian version of the Fifth Amendment, as was his legal right since he is a defendant in a related bribery case.)

title: New Airport at Inchon Replaces One in Seoul
description: South Korea has opened Inchon International Airport, a mammoth project 32 miles west of downtown Seoul that has replaced Kimpo Airport for virtually all foreign flights. Kimpo has been converted to nearly all domestic flights, government officials said.

title: Bicycle Tutor Expands To Play Dates and Repairs
description: Aresh Mohit, Westchester's self-styled bike tutor, is expanding his business.

title: Ideas & Trends: Lost Illusions; Bring Back Bardot
description: MEN are from Mars and women are from Venus. Except in France. There, in American eyes, at least, the war between the sexes never began. In France, there is only mutual understanding and l'amour fou.

title: Racing Festivities At the Starting Gate
description: The Triple Crown of thoroughbred racing -- the Kentucky Derby on May 5, the Preakness Stakes on May 19 and the Belmont Stakes on June 9 -- is the centerpiece for a kaleidoscope of activities in Louisville, Ky., Baltimore, and Elmont, N.Y., the places where the races will be held.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about a Pentagon videotape showing an encounter in January between a Chinese fighter jet and an American spy plane misstated Donald H. Rumsfeld's title. He is secretary of defense, not state.

title: Sweet Salvation
description: At Easter the churches deliver religion and the big bunny delivers sweets. Then there are Testamints, which provide both. Testamints, based in Randolph, sells chewing gum, fruit-flavored candies and sugar-free mints with a biblical passage on the label and a cross on each piece. Alfred Poe, a former vice president of marketing for M&M/Mars in Hackettstown, was an original investor in Testamints five years ago and then became its chief executive. ''The candy presented an opportunity to spread the word of Christ that I could not resist,'' he said. The candy, 69 cents a package or $2.99 for a six-ounce bag, is sold mainly in religious bookstores, and is available in some catalogs and a few supermarkets. A portion of the company's income goes to support Christian shelters, Mr. Poe said, adding that ''the real product is the message.'' Karen DeMasters

title: 'Never Stop Moving'

title: Big
description: Julian Schnabel has guts. He tries things. If he's ''big opera,'' as Dennis Hopper says, that's O.K.; the entire history of art is filled with people who can be classified as big opera. Without personality, nothing is worth anything.

title: Jacqueline Young, Nicholas Perrins
description: Jacqueline Lee Young, the daughter of Rose Young of Fairport, N.Y., and Richard Young of Rochester, was married yesterday to Nicholas Dyson Perrins, a son of Barbara Spee Perrins of Richmond, Va., and Anthony Perrins of London. The Rev. Alma Daniel, an interfaith minister, officiated at Bloom Flowers, a floral shop in New York.

title: Harry Boykoff, 78, St. John's Star in the 1940's, Dies
description: Harry Boykoff, the first big-man superstar in New York City college basketball, died on Feb. 20 at St John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 78.

title: You Can Leave Your Hat On: Fedoras Are Snazzy Again
description: The fedora, that old film noir fashion statement so often described as jaunty or rakish, is staging a modest comeback in New York. While it may be premature to proclaim a trend, some men have discovered what Bogie and Sinatra knew all along. Fedoras are way cool.

title: Springtime for the Music Man in Me
description: LONG, long ago. The early summer of 1935. I was 9 years old, happy as a lark, and living with my widowed mother and three older brothers in an $18-a-month fifth-floor walkup in a tenement at 365 South Third Street in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

title: REPUBLICAN PARTY CHAIRMAN
description: The chairman of the state Republican party for the past six years, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, said last week that he would leave his post in June, allowing Acting Governor Donald T. DiFrancesco to select his close ally, state Senator Joseph M. Kyrillos Jr. a Republican of Monmouth County as his replacement. Abhi Raghunathan

title: Sites in Westchester Chosen for Richard Gere Film
description: A house on Rosedale Avenue in White Plains will become a movie set this month for ''Unfaithful,'' a romantic thriller co-starring Richard Gere and Diane Lane. The site was chosen because it shows Westchester's affluence, said Rob Striem, the film's location manager.

title: Silver Surfers
description: What is it about surfing? Only a tiny fraction of Americans have seen the sport with their own eyes, fewer have tried it, yet its image pops up everywhere -- on TV, in movies, in advertisements. Surfing first migrated from Hawaii to California in 1907, but by midcentury the carefree golden-haired surfer had flowered into a full-blown American archetype, alongside the pilgrim and the cowboy. Blame, perhaps, baby boomers, reared by survivors of World War II, determined to live a life less burdened by history and settled on surfing as the highest expression of their laid-back youth.

title: April 8-14; Nowhere to Go but Up?
description: The economic news looked bad, with unemployment claims up and retail sales down. But on Wall Street, optimism returned. A widely followed semiconductor industry analyst, Jonathan Joseph of Salomon Smith Barney, turned bullish on the theory that the news was so bad that it had to get better. An index of such stocks leaped 23 percent during the week while the Nasdaq composite rose 14 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed just 3 percent, but it topped 10,000 for the first time in almost a month. Floyd Norris

title: A Sanctuary in the Yucatn
description: AT the Hacienda Katanchel, the natural, historical and cultural legacies of the Yucatn peninsula are everywhere in evidence. Within the grounds of this luxury hotel, remains of an ancient Maya pyramid and a cenote, a sacred well, lie close to the elegant 19th-century salons of the estate's former ''great house.'' Windmills are still used to pump fresh well water to guest suites. And, as we would discover, Katanchel's cuisine makes ample use of indigenous herbs, vegetables, and fruit grown in its organic gardens and orchards.

title: In Municipal Bonds, A Search for Diversity
description: JUST when investors thought municipal bonds were a haven in a chaotic stock market, Pacific Gas and Electric filed for bankruptcy -- a sign of the escalating energy crisis in California.

title: Trading Countries
description: Simon Burke, a ninth grader from Norwell Mass., gets fitted for a Sari in Mumbai, India, when ''A Walk in Your Shoes'' makes its first international exchange on the Noggin series's season premiere, to be shown Friday at 6:30 a.m. on Nickelodeon.

description: Deborah Ruth Greenebaum, a daughter of Linda Greenebaum and Michael Greenebaum, both of Amherst, Mass., was married yesterday to Luis Vidali, a son of Juana Rebolledo of Mexico City and Carlos Vidali of San Diego. Frances Kirchner, a justice of the peace, officiated at the White House of Wilmington, an inn in Wilmington, Vt.

title: A Talk Show Pioneer, Before TV Talk Was Toxic
description: IT was after a discussion of organized crime on ''The David Susskind Show'' in 1973 that the program's longtime producer, Jean Kennedy, received a phone call in her office from an irate viewer.

title: Devils Reflect N.H.L.'s Stunted Development
description: Weather permitting, it should be a festive scene around Continental Arena today before Game 2 of the Eastern Conference quarterfinal series between the Devils and the Carolina Hurricanes. Throughout the parking lots, fans clad in team jerseys will enjoy a leisurely Easter brunch. Amid the munching and the sipping, children will play ball hockey with plastic sticks and the music of Bruce Springsteen will drift like barbecue smoke through the sweet spring air. These are the Stanley Cup playoffs, New Jersey style.

title: The Last Straw
description: Darryl Strawberry was beautiful. That was the first thing you noticed. A pure physical glory. The young slugger was long and lean and popping with sinewy muscle, not the kind manufactured in the weight room or purchased from the supplement aisle at the vitamin store, but the real thing. God-given, if you believe in that.

title: The Nation: The 'D' Word; Suddenly, Deficits Regain Their Luster
description: DEFICITS are respectable again. Until a few weeks ago, they were bad. Nearly everyone said so. But all of a sudden they have been resurrected as a lifeline that may be needed to avoid a recession.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, SIDNEY
description: GROSSMAN-Sidney. With the deepest sense of loss, his devoted family announces the passing of our indomitable patriarch. For every day of his 86 years he lived life to the fullest, with unconditional love for his family, commitment to philanthropic causes and passion for all that is just and decent in the world. His playful sense of humor, breadth of interests and boundless energy rendered every day of his life an adventure. He will be profoundly missed by Bunny (Beatrice), his beloved wife of 62 years; his children Nancy, Judy and Steven, Gary and Lynn; his grandchildren Robert and Amy, Andrew and Alyson, Michael and Daniel; his great-grandchildren Adam and Julie; and his sister and soulmate Shirley. The Legend will live in our memories forever. Services on Monday, April 16, 2001 at 10:30 AM, Hewlett East Rockaway Jewish Center, 295 Main Street, East Rockaway.

San Diego owns the first pick, and while several teams are expected to make a trade offer, look for the Chargers to take Michael Vick, the electric quarterback from Virginia Tech. ''The truth was that guilt or innocence (except as pronounced by a jury) didn't particularly interest me,'' says Sid Kaplan, a New York criminal lawyer who was on top of his game before he crashed on cocaine and arrogance. Now that he's straight and sober, Sid is itching to get back into action, and when a distraught mother asks him to handle her daughter's murder defense, he grabs his chance. The defendant, Priscilla Sweet, admits that she shot her husband, and that they were both dealing drugs. But Priscilla is white and shrewd, her victim was black and abusive, and Sid figures he can con the press and pull off his cynical Roxie Hart defense of a poor, helpless, battered woman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBNER, MELVIN
description: DUBNER-Melvin. Of Montclair, NJ, passed away suddenly April 12, 2001, at the age of 63. Beloved husband of Roberta, loving and proud father of Adam and Aaron. Delighted and doting grandfather of Sarah, the five month old daughter of Adam and Kim, and loving brother to Ronald, Martin, Harry and Ted. Mel's unexpected passing has stunned and saddened his family, friends and co-workers. A kind, loving, generous and charming man, Mel was a gentleman to the core. Mel was beloved at work as well as at home. As Vice President of Property Operations at New Plan Excel Realty Trust, (N.P. Excel), where he was employed for the past 13 years, Mel was respected by his co-workers and staff alike, by the 800 employees of N.P. Excel. Last year as the Employee of the Year, Mel was far and away one of the most valued employees of the company, whose employees believed he made everyone ''work smarter and better'', and acknowledged that although he wore many hats at N.P. Excel, all the hats fit perfectly and if a job needed to be done, he was the man who would get the job done. Mel's family was his treasure, his wife Roberta the crown jewel. The twinkle in his eye and the sparkle he always brought to a room will be sorely missed by one and all.

title: QUICK BITE/Linden; A Big Man, a Big Sandwich
description: Sometimes I'm drawn in by the cuisine. Other times it's a friend's recommendation. But more often than I'd care to admit, I pick restaurants because they have cool names. This is how I arrived at Big Stash's. It didn't hurt that the sign below read ''Bar, Restaurant, Sandwiches.'' Give me two slices of bread, put something between them, and I'm happy. But this day I had stumbled upon no ordinary sandwich joint. For one thing, Big Stash's is, well, big. In addition to a massive horseshoe bar, there are two large dining areas, banquet facilities and a cafeteria-style counter. (Waitress service is also available.) Atop the wood paneling is a vaguely Middle Eastern trim. Don't look for couscous on the menu, however. Linden has a large Polish community, and Big Stash's offerings reflect that. Bigos, or sauerkraut stew, was a special this Sunday. Other Polish favorites included beef goulash, sausage, and pirogi. I devoured a kielbasa sandwich ($4.25). My seventh-grade wood shop teacher, Mr. Mika, often sang the praises of kielbasa. He was not a small man, and clearly knew a thing or two about animal intestines stuffed with meat. I believe Mr. Mika would give Big Stash's juicy kielbasa an A plus. Aside from Polish specialties and deli sandwiches, Big Stash's has a full menu of American-style beef, chicken and seafood entrees. They're all reasonably priced, with the surf and turf (lobster and filet mignon) the most expensive item at $22.75. At Big Stash's on a Sunday at noon, all the stools around the bar are filled. Hungry men eat. And every one of them looks like his nickname might be Big Stash. JACK SILBERT

title: BEACH SMOKING BAN
description: The Borough Council of Belmar passed an ordinance last week to ban smoking on most of its milelong beach and boardwalk. The rules take effect in early May, but won't be enforced until Memorial Day weekend. Town officials say Belmar is first New Jersey Shore town to ban beach smoking. John Holl

The system is not expected to fare well unless airlines, airport authorities and federal transportation officials work together to buffer passengers from the immediate problems and to build the runways and traffic control systems that could provide a long-term solution.

No, Soriano's question was technical in nature, about whether he had the proper service time to qualify for the award.

title: The Nation; Going for Broke On the Budget

They couldn't care less, for instance, about the $731 million to fight drug trafficking in South America or the $112 million to prevent accidents on airport runways, which may never become law.

title: PrivateSector; Where's the Beef? Here and There
description: When Arnold Schwarzenegger drove Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani into Times Square on Tuesday afternoon in a prototype of General Motors' three-ton Hummer H2 sport utility truck, he declared that the vehicle combined ''ruggedness with luxury.'' But creating that combination appears to have provoked a little culture clash between G.M. and A. M. General, the military contractor that sold the Hummer brand to G.M. and assembles the vehicle for it. The differences were visible at a dinner on Monday at AZ, a restaurant in the Flatiron district of Manhattan. The two A. M. General executives ordered the beef, rare and bloody, while all five executives from G.M.'s new Hummer division ordered the sea bass -- with watercress. But James A. Armour, A. M. General's chief executive, rose to the defense of G.M.'s managers, sort of. ''I'm spending a lot of my time in Florida, so that's where I'm getting my seafood,'' he said. ''I have a boat.'' Keith Bradsher

title: The Better To Bat With
description: It took only 80 years, but there is finally a new wrinkle in eyelash curlers. Last month, Lashpro unveiled the first metal eyelash curler design to be patented since 1920. Lashpro and the Petite Lashpro (both $19 at Henri Bendel) improve on the standard curler by repositioning and rounding the curved plates that grasp the lashes and the blunt-tip posts at both ends. The Lashpro design helps guard eyelids and the skin around the eyes against inadvertent crimping, and it prevents that undesirable 90-degree lash kink. The gadget is cleverly angled away from the face, providing access to individual lashes. In an informal test, the Lashpro was easier to use than a traditional drugstore curler (although instructions to hold it in place for 20 to 30 seconds proved a bit of an eyestrain; shorter sessions worked as well, with fewer tears). The Petite Lashpro allows even more attention to detail for Asian women with softer eye slopes, as well as for beauty micromanagers who want to achieve their curl a few lashes at a time.

Buried alive for decades in detailed sketches that were finally shown to be a skeletal diagram for a living, breathing entity, maligned by the composer's colleagues after his untimely death, ignored during the last century by scores of conductors and even banned for a time by Mahler's widow when a credible performing version finally became available, the 10th has endured more than its share of troubles.

title: Ageless Latin Stars Who Embraced Their Roots
description: THESE days in America, we have a vampirish relationship with popular music. It is constantly put in front of us; we suck it dry and discard it. We identify with it on an interior level -- with aspects of sex, with glamour or scuffiness, with banging beats or layered productions that sound old in six months' time. It's hard to remember that there is such a thing as popular music that defines a culture and just stays around, acquiring deeper meaning as its disciples keep brushing against it.

title: Clues From Vesuvius
description: The eruption of Mount Vesuvius in A.D. 79 was a horrific event, burying Pompeii and the nearby beachside town of Herculaneum in 30 feet or more of volcanic ash and killing thousands of people. Because so much ash fell, it is common to think of the victims as having suffocated, and experts believe that happened to many of them. But others no doubt were killed by heat as a series of pyroclastic surges  fast-moving clouds of superheated gas and ash  swept over the ground.

title: Marjorie and Paul Temanson, Anna Lee, Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport, Feb. 20, 2001
description: Marjorie Temanson (left): "We had tried to have a baby of our own and were not able to. We were working with an adoption agency, and a caseworker told us about Anna. We met her three times before her daughter was born. It was very intense. You worry that she might not like you. After Mya was born, we talked at least once a week. And we felt it was important for Anna to be able to see her daughter periodically -- to see for herself how she's doing. That day, we got to see her in the airport, during a stopover on our way to Hawaii. I'm not nervous anymore when we see her. Maybe a little anxious. It's a pretty awesome responsibility to have someone give you their child and ask you to raise it. We certainly don't want to disappoint her. But she wouldn't have picked us if she hadn't felt that we were the right parents. There was just a level of trust." -->

title: Another Delay in Alabama Justice
description: The attempt to bring the last two living suspects in Birmingham's 16th Street Baptist Church bombing to trial received an unexpected setback last week when an Alabama judge ruled that one of the former Ku Klux Klansmen may be too demented to stand trial. Judge James Garrett's ruling came less than a week before Bobby Frank Cherry, a suspect in the case from the outset, was to stand trial today. He is charged with the murder of four black girls killed in a dynamite blast on Sunday, Sept. 15, 1963. The trial of a second suspect, Thomas Blanton Jr., identified in investigative files as the owner of the car that delivered the bomb, is to go ahead as scheduled today.

title: No Exit

Now Harris is selling the loft. Tanya Corrin, his former live-in girlfriend, has already departed and Harris, whose wealth in Jupiter stock options dwindled considerably two months before I met him, has also sold We Live in Public to Panopticon, a newly formed company owned by a former Pseudo employee. Harris, however, retains ownership of everything recorded in the loft, and he is still a 35% shareholder of Panopticon.

title: Upping the Tempo of Basketball
description: When the National Basketball Association held its annual All-Star Game in February, Commissioner David Stern gathered together some of the league's senior statesmen, players included, to discuss the state of the game. There was general agreement that professional basketball had become too slow and too predictable. There was also agreement that a major culprit was the so-called isolation play, in which the top players go one on one while everyone else stands aside. The ancient arts of passing and playmaking -- in a word, teamwork -- had suffered badly. More to the point, the fans were getting bored.

title: What's Not for Sale

He husked and cut the pineapples while his wife skewered their halves and placed them in a bucket filled with salted water. He was proud of his fruit and even prouder that I, an American, could appreciate it. Every time I bought a pineapple, he would stop husking, wait for me to take a bite, and ask, ''Is it delicious?''

title: Plane Crew Details Detention in China
description: On their first full day back home at the Whidbey Island Naval Air Station in Washington, several of the 24 Americans detained in China gave reporters details of an experience in which, at first, many were sure they would die and prepared to bail out. After they landed on Hainan island, they were treated to decks of cards, cigarettes, toothpaste, Chinese food so authentic it included fish heads, and living quarters with bugs and mosquitoes. Interrogations, often in the middle of the night, lasted up to five hours, and their recreation included teaching a guard the words to ''Hotel California.''

title: POWER COMPANY SHARES FALL AFTER IT CANCELS DIVIDEND
description: Shares in Sierra Pacific Resources fell 8.3 percent after the company, the owner of Nevada's two largest utilities, canceled its May quarterly dividend because it may need the money to buy electricity. Shares of Sierra Pacific, based in Reno, Nev., fell $1.21 to $13.29. They have dropped 17 percent this year. Sierra Pacific, which sold power plants last year to win regulatory approval of the merger that created the company, has lost ''hundreds of millions of dollars'' buying power at prices it cannot pass on to customers, its chief financial officer, Mark Ruelle, said on Friday. Nevada regulators permitted the company's utilities to raise rates 17 percent in February, but the losses will continue, Mr. Ruelle said. The company, which was created in the July 1999 merger of Sierra Pacific Resources and the Nevada Power Company, said it lost $18.2 million, or 23 cents a share, in the fourth quarter because of the surge in power prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONALDSON, DOROTHY ''WALLY''
description: DONALDSON-Dorothy ''Wally''. August 21, 1907-April 13, 2001 Born in Brooklyn, New York, Dorothy began a dancing and acting career at the age of 13. She moved to Hollywood in 1928 to work for MGM Studios, where she met songwriter Walter Donaldson. They married and had two children, Sheila and Ellen. Widowed in 1947, Dorothy had resided in Newport Beach, California since 1962, where she shared 35 wonderful years with Francis L. Tooley. ''Wally'' touched many lives with her generous love, kindness and humor, and will be lovingly remembered by her two daughters, Sheila and Ellen, her grandchildren Kelley, Kevin and Scott Kerslake, and Mary and Victoria Shea, as well as by Frank Tooley, his three daughters and grandchildren, along with many extended family members and friends. We celebrate, honor and carry on the spirit with which she lived her life. For information contact Pacific View Mortuary (949) 644-2700.

title: Metro Business Briefing; NEW LANDMARKS CHAIRWOMAN
description: Sherida E. Paulsen was named chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission yesterday by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Ms. Paulsen, a commissioner since 1995, will succeed Jennifer J. Raab on May 14. As a general proposition, Ms. Paulsen said yesterday, modern additions to landmarks should draw on the past without replicating architectural features exactly. ''We don't want to be who we were, but we do want to learn lessons,'' she said. Ms. Paulsen, 48, will resign as a principal in Pasanella & Klein Stolzman & Berg Architects of Manhattan, which she joined in 1999. She has also worked for Ehrenkrantz Eckstut & Kuhn Architects; for Skidmore, Owings & Merrill; and for the Forest City Ratner development concern.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLAYSON, DAVID MERRILL
description: CLAYSON-David Merrill. The Boards, Faculty, and Staff of Weill Medical College of Cornell University and New York-Presbyterian Hospital mourn the passing of David Clayson, Ph.D., professor emeritus of clinical psychology in psychiatry. For 25 years, from 1968 to 1993, Dr. Clayson was head of psychology and director of training in psychology at the Payne Whitney Clinic, and taught many who have become leaders in the field. In 1983, he became the first member of the Department of Psychiatry and the first and only clinical psychologist and nonphysician to receive the Medical College's highest teaching honor, the Elliott Hochstein Award. On February 5 of this year, he became the first recipient of the Dean's Award for Lifetime Achievement in Teaching. We extend our deepest condolences to his brother, nieces, and nephews. Antonio M. Gotto, Jr., M.D., Dean Weill Medical College of Cornell University Herbert Pardes, M.D., President and CEO NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Jack D. title: Optimism From PepsiCo
description: PepsiCo Inc. said today that its per-share earnings rose 15 percent in the first quarter and case sales in North America rose 4 percent. PepsiCo, which makes Frito Lay snacks in addition to Pepsi-Cola, earned $422 million, or 29 cents a share, a year earlier. PepsiCo will report earnings in detail next Monday, the company said. The company has agreed to buy Quaker Oats, maker of the Gatorade sports drink. Shares of PepsiCo rose 29 cents, to $42.20 a share.

For now, he has settled for the street corner as an office, making dozens of small loans to the vendors that pack Haiti's streets selling everything from pots and pans to shoes and food.

title: Marjorie and Paul Temanson, Anna Lee, Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport, Feb. 20, 2001
description: Marjorie Temanson (left): "We had tried to have a baby of our own and were not able to. We were working with an adoption agency, and a caseworker told us about Anna. We met her three times before her daughter was born. It was very intense. You worry that she might not like you. After Mya was born, we talked at least once a week. And we felt it was important for Anna to be able to see her daughter periodically -- to see for herself how she's doing. That day, we got to see her in the airport, during a stopover on our way to Hawaii. I'm not nervous anymore when we see her. Maybe a little anxious. It's a pretty awesome responsibility to have someone give you their child and ask you to raise it. We certainly don't want to disappoint her. But she wouldn't have picked us if she hadn't felt that we were the right parents. There was just a level of trust." -->

title: TURKEY: PLAN ENCOURAGES MARKETS
description: Turkey's currency, stocks and bonds rose on expectations that a government economic program announced over the weekend would win financial support from international lenders. The lira gained 2.6 percent; the benchmark stock index rose 4.9 percent; and the yield on the three-month bill maturing Aug. 8 fell 7 percentage points, to 131 percent. On Saturday, the economy minister, Kemal Dervis, announced the country's plans for ending an economic crisis that has dragged on for about two months. Turkish officials expect to complete talks with the International Monetary Fund and other lenders this week.

description: A lawyer for a defendant in the embassy bombings trial told a federal judge in Manhattan yesterday that his client's defense was being compromised because he could not find experts willing to testify about the United States' intervention in Somalia in 1993. He said the experts were scared off because of the terrorism allegations in the case.

description: In a year when census figures underscored the growing diversity of American society, three Pulitzer Prizes in journalism were awarded for articles that highlighted the perplexing, sometimes traumatic legacy of immigration and the country's changing ethnic mix.

description: With a new government in Congo that has expressed openness to United Nations peacekeeping efforts, there is growing pressure on Uganda and Rwanda to rein in their activities in support of Congo rebels, United Nations and Congolese officials and Western diplomats say.

description: A deadly Israeli airstrike on a Syrian radar installation deep inside Lebanon unsettled the Arab world today just as Israel was receiving the first Arab official to visit since Prime Minister Ariel Sharon took office last month.

title: Red Sox Run Yanks Out of Town
description: The herd thundered out of Fenway Park this afternoon, giddy shouts fighting through the cement walls and infringing on the silence within the visitors' clubhouse. The Patriot's Day game started at 11:05 a.m. and ended at 1:43 p.m., leaving plenty of time for the gloating Red Sox fans to walk two blocks to Beacon Street and see the leaders of the Boston Marathon begin their last mile.

title: The Leaderless F.D.A.
description: Although we've heard a good deal about the Bush administration's efficiency in making appointments, it is curious that there appears to be no effort to fill the critical position of commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration. The usual flurry of early rumors about possible candidates has subsided, and there have been no signs since then of any serious moves to settle on a nominee.

title: Support for War Crimes Court Is Fading, Sierra Leone Fears
description: Sierra Leone is concerned that richer nations are backing off promises to establish a criminal tribunal to prosecute rebels for brutality against civilians, African diplomats have said in interviews.

title: Foreign Affairs; Myth-Matched Nations
description: Of all the odd things that happened during the U.S.-China airplane standoff, surely the oddest was the report that the Chinese fighter pilot who was killed, Wang Wei, had held up an e-mail address in the window of his cockpit during an earlier confrontation with a U.S. surveillance plane. During the cold war there was a famous incident where U.S. pilots were trailing a Soviet long-range bomber, and as the U.S. planes approached for a closer look, the Soviet pilot held up a Playboy centerfold in his cockpit window. Centerfolds I understand. But a Chinese fighter pilot flashing his e-mail address to a U.S. spy plane at 25,000 feet? What do you suppose he was trying to say?

title: DRKOOP MAKES ACQUISITION AND PLANS REVERSE SPLIT
description: The consumer health Web site Drkoop.com said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire IVonyx, a provider of outpatient intravenous and injection services, for about $7.1 million in cash and stock. As part of the deal, IVonyx's chief executive, Peter Molloy, will become president of Drkoop, replacing Ed Cespedes, who will become vice chairman. The company also approved a 1-for-10 reverse stock split, subject to shareholder approval, which is intended to prevent its delisting from the Nasdaq exchange. Shares of Drkoop closed Monday at 14 cents, up 1 cent from Friday. Susan Stellin

title: Josephine Premice, 74, Actress Who Dazzled on Broadway
description: Josephine Premice, an actress nominated for Tony Awards for her performances in the musical ''Jamaica'' and ''A Hand Is on the Gate,'' an evening of black poetry, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 74.

title: Giuliani Aides Lobby Council to Maintain Veto
description: Top Giuliani aides, in an unusually intense effort to persuade the City Council not to override a recent mayoral veto, have made calls to more than a dozen Council members, at times advancing murky offers to address their ''needs,'' city officials said yesterday.

title: JAPAN: HARLEY-DAVIDSON GROWS
description: For the first time in 16 years, Harley-Davidson Inc. regained the top slot for sales of heavy motorbikes in Japan last year, tapping its image for classic Americana to overtake rival Japanese makers. Harley, the largest motorcycle maker in the United States, said registrations of its bikes in Japan rose 7.6 percent, to 9,467 units, in 2000, while the overall market for motorcycles with engines larger than 750cc fell 0.9 percent, to 44,161 units. Harley-Davidson's success in Japan, its biggest foreign market, was aided by an expanded sales network and long financing programs.

description: In this cartoon, published June 7, 2000, Ms. Telnaes comments on the campaign financing of the two major parties. The prize was based on originality, editorial effectiveness, quality of drawing and pictorial effect.

description: Deuce McAllister epitomizes all that is perplexing and yet tantalizing in Saturday's National Football League draft. It is like picking fruit -- sure looks ripe, but what is really at the core?

title: PANAMSAT EARNINGS DECLINE 91%
description: The PanAmSat Corporation's earnings fell 91 percent in the first quarter after a sharp decline in revenue from leasing space on its satellites. The operator of commercial satellites said it had net income of $5 million, or 3 cents a share, in the first quarter, compared with $56.5 million, or 38 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Although the company's results beat most analysts' expectations of a loss in the quarter, PanAmSat is expected to be pressed in coming months by lower-than-expected revenue from NET/36, a unit that provides satellite-based Internet broadcasting services. Simon Romero

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANZ, PAULINE STERNLICHT
description: GANZ-Pauline Sternlicht. Born 1906 in New York City to Adolph Sternlicht and Anna Scher Sternlicht. Pauline attended the Juilliard Institute of Musical Art, now known as The Juilliard School, where she was a student of Olga Samaroff. After graduation she became a concert pianist and, as Pauline Gilbert, performed as part of a piano-duo with classmate Hannah Klein. Pauline also arranged many works for two pianos, which the duo performed. She appeared as one of the four pianists in ''Stravinsky's Les Noces'' on television, the first woman to appear as a pianist on television. She also performed piano-cello sonatas with her younger brother Harold, who predeceased her. At age 60, Pauline enrolled in Hunter College, where she received both Bachelor's and Master's Degrees in English Literature, magna cum laude, and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. Since moving to Florida in 1972, she supported the Miami Jewish Community through her philanthrophic efforts. Pauline married Abraham Ganz in 1931 & together they had two children: the late Arnold Michael Ganz and Isabelle Ganz Lipschutz. Pauline is survived by her daughter, her daughter-in-law, Elinor Colker Ganz and son-in-law, Abbie Lipschutz, as well as 5 grandchildren: Charles Ganz, Susan Ganz Sugarman, Amy Ganz Sadeghi, Debra ''Griffin'' Gardner, and Gabrielle Lipschutz Moore, and ten greatgrandchildren. Her son predeceased her in 1987 and Abraham passed away in 1994. Pauline's lifelong passion for the arts and intellectual pursuits inspired her family, friends and community. The funeral will be held at 10:00 A.M on Tuesday, April 17, 2001 at Levitt-Weinstein Memorial Chapel in Aventura, Florida. Donations may be made to the Arnold Ganz Memorial Fund C/O the Greater Miami Jewish Federation or to the Juilliard School C/O the Juilliard School Development Office in New York City.

title: EXPEDIA SAYS THIRD-QUARTER LOSS NARROWED
description: Expedia, the Internet travel-booking service controlled by Microsoft, said its fiscal third-quarter loss narrowed on higher sales of travel packages. The company reported a loss of about $18 million, or 37 cents a share, for the period ended March 31, compared with a loss of $66.5 million, or $1.56 a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 88 percent, to about $110 million from $58.8 million a year earlier. Excluding the amortization of good will and stock-based compensation costs, Expedia said it would have had a profit of about $4 million, or 9 cents a share.
