title: Metro Business Briefing; MACK-CALI MERGER FIZZLES
description: Mack-Cali Realty Corporation and Reckson Associates Realty Corporation have ended talks to merge and create the largest owner of commercial properties in the New York metropolitan area, said Mitchell Hersh, the chief executive at Mack-Cali. Mr. Hersh said discussions ended amicably last week, but would not elaborate. Reckson officials were not available for comment. Mack-Cali, based in Cranford, N.J., owns 267 properties with 28.5 million square feet of space, including the Harborside Financial Center in Jersey City, where the discount brokerage firm Charles Schwab & Company is putting its East Coast regional headquarters. Reckson, based in Melville, N.Y., owns 188 properties with 21.3 million square feet.

title: Williams Can't Be Placed On D.L. During Absence
description: While the Yankees continue to play without Bernie Williams, their All-Star center fielder, the team has been informed by Major League Baseball that he cannot be placed on the disabled list because of his father's illness, and they still have no idea when he will rejoin the team.

title: Frank Annunzio, 86, Longtime Chicago Democratic Congressman
description: Former Representative Frank Annunzio, who championed such diverse causes as the survival of the neighborhood savings and loan and the minting of commemorative coins to raise money for civic projects, died on April 8 at his home in Lincolnwood, Ill., a Chicago suburb. He was 86.

title: PCB Worries Are Spreading From Hudson To Its Shores
description: For 25 years, environmental groups and state officials have concentrated on the problems posed by toxic PCB's in the Hudson River, but now they are starting to focus on dozens of contaminated spots in landfills and backyards in the upper Hudson Valley.

title: LUCENT TO SELL SYSTEMS TO U.S. CELLULAR
description: Lucent Technologies won a four-year contract from U.S. Cellular to supply the company with wireless technology. Under the agreement, which could produce as much as $100 million for Lucent, the company will provide U.S. Cellular with equipment, engineering and installation services in Virginia, West Virginia, North Carolina and South Carolina. The contract is a boost for code division multiple access technology, a wireless standard developed largely by Qualcomm that is more prevalent in the United States than in Europe and Asia. Simon Romero

title: JAPAN: ECONOMIC OUTLOOK WEAKENS
description: The Bank of Japan said that it now described Japan's economy as being in a ''state of adjustment,'' amid flagging exports and slowing production. The assessment represents a downgrade from the central bank's view last month when it said the economy had ''come to a pause.'' The government had also downgraded the economic assessment when it said last week that the economy was weakening. The bearish term was adopted for the first time since September 1995. Miki Tanikawa

title: Mushrooms With Garlic And Tariffs
description: While the reconnaissance aircraft episode was monopolizing the attention of most China watchers last week, ominous friction was building in China's commercial relations with two capitalist rivals much closer to home, Japan and South Korea. In each case, Chinese officials found themselves treading in some American footprints, fighting off protectionism born of domestic politics in its trading partners.

title: Stabbing Victim Gives Birth To Healthy Baby by Caesarean
description: A Brooklyn woman in her ninth month of pregnancy delivered a healthy baby yesterday after being stabbed three times by the mother of her boyfriend's two children, the police said.

title: JONES APPAREL TO BUY McNAUGHTON FOR STOCK AND CASH
description: The Jones Apparel Group said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the McNaughton Apparel Group for $275 million in cash and stock to increase sales of midprice garments. Jones Apparel will pay $10.50 in cash and about $10.50 in stock for each McNaughton share, the company said. The per-share price is 21 percent more than McNaughton's closing price of $17.40 on Thursday. Jones Apparel will also assume $297 million in debt. McNaughton will increase Jones Apparel's sales at midprice retailers like Sears, Roebuck & Company and the Kohl's Corporation to 10 percent of revenue from 5 percent, the company said. Jones Apparel is based in Bristol, Pa. McNaughton is based in New York.

title: Unadorned Voices Peal Out In Bitterness and Sorrow
description: It was Holy Saturday, and the 13th-century Fuentiduea Chapel at the Cloisters in Upper Manhattan was filled with the clean sound of unaccompanied voices ringing off the old stone. Twice in one afternoon the a capella ensemble Pomerium presented a seasonal concert of Renaissance Passion motets that was as lovingly curated and classily presented as any of the museum's other displays.

title: Learning What Fuel to Burn
description: Like nearly all scientists, I believe that global warming is the most serious environmental threat on the horizon for our grandchildren, and that carbon dioxide from fossil fuel burning is a major contributor to it. Yet I agree with President Bush that we must go slow on regulating carbon dioxide emissions from power plants. That is why we have to fall back on research on alternative energy sources and on energy conservation -- the two approaches that will help us achieve some reductions in carbon dioxide emissions in the near term. But Mr. Bush's proposed budget cuts for research and conservation move in precisely the wrong direction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMAN, JEFFRY ROSS (AKA JOEY RAMONE)

They, along with his family, friends and devoted fans, will remember both personally and musically the joy and happiness he brought to all that knew and saw him. He will always remain in their minds and hearts. Thanks Joey for the inspiration and innovations you provided for so many. A memorial celebration will be announced at a later date.

title: A Plot Seems to Vanish Behind Screens and Slides
description: Erich Wolfgang Korngold's ''Tote Stadt,'' which City Opera revived on Sunday, has something in common with the modern computer. There it is, up and running. Visions pass across the screen, this being a production of the opera in which slide projections and film are abundantly used, recalling the composer's later career in Hollywood. But how the thing works is unfathomable, and the original intentions behind it remain utterly mysterious.

title: An Incomplete Investigation
description: Unless Adm. Thomas Fargo decides otherwise, the Navy's investigation into the collision of an American submarine with a Japanese vessel near Honolulu in February is likely to end on a premature and unsatisfactory note. A report by Elaine Sciolino in Sunday's Times quoted senior Pentagon officials as saying that the public court of inquiry into the incident had recommended that the submarine's skipper, Cmdr. Scott Waddle, not be tried by a court-martial. Instead the commander would receive some lesser punishment, like a reprimand, that would effectively end his career but spare him the military equivalent of a criminal trial.

title: Star Wars, of a Sort, Over What to Call a Heavenly Body
description: By the simplest definition, a planet is a large object that orbits a star. But the universe, it seems, is hardly simple, and astronomers have lately been observing things that resemble planets but are drifting freely in space, beyond the gravitational embrace of any star.

title: A Royal Blossoming Brings Joy in Japan
description: Crown Prince Naruhito and Crown Princess Masako rode to the Imperial Palace in Tokyo yesterday. A statement from the Imperial Household Agency said the princess is possibly pregnant, sixteen months after she suffered a miscarriage. The cautious announcement led newspapers to put out special editions with full-page photos of the royal couple. There has been worried speculation in Japan since the 37-year-old crown princess miscarried that the immediate heirs to what is called the Chrysanthemum Throne would be unable to produce an eventual successor. Under the rules of succession, only male children are eligible to ascend to the throne.

title: Stick to Testing the Basics
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  The phrase "civil disobedience" does not usually bring to mind a protest of a state- wide school examination, especially in the affluent suburb of Scarsdale, N. Y. Yet approximately 100 families will be engaged in a form of civil disobedience when they keep their eighth- grade children at home next month during the testing period. I believe that they are right in doing so.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, BARBARA ANN
description: BECKER-Barbara Ann. January 1, 1937-April 13, 2001. Survived by her husband of fortythree years, Theodore Becker. Devoted mother to Cara Becker Lichtenstein, son-in-law Lorry Lichtenstein, and son, Jeffrey Scott Becker, mother, Dorothy Brotman and Studley Dog. Cherished ''Little Nana'', to August Julian Mendes, Brice Harrison Mendes, Landon Amory Lichtenstein, Grayson Royal Lichtenstein and Remy Colton Lichtenstein. She will be remembered for her sharp wit, cutting edge ideas, flawless logic, tremendous passion for life, unconditional interest in the personal achievement of others and the joy she received by mentoring the friends she cherished so dearly. She will forever be in our hearts and minds. Services were held in Miami, Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIEROT, LOUISE A.
description: PIEROT-Louise A. The Board of Trustees of the Animal Medical Center mourns the passing of Honory Trustee, Louise A. Pierot. Mrs. Pierot devotedly and cheerfully served AMC as a volunteer in the office of development for more than 17 years and was appointed Honorary Trustee in 1988. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family and friends for their great loss. Cynthia Phipps Chairman Guy Pidgeon, DVM, DACVIM President and CEO

title: Metro Business Briefing; FRIENDLY SELLS 31 RESTAURANTS
description: Friendly Ice Cream Corporation announced yesterday that it sold 31 Friendly's restaurants on Long Island to a franchisee, J & B Restaurant Partners Holding, for about $20 million. The sale includes an development agreement to open 29 restaurants during the next 12 years, Friendly said in a news release. The company did not immediately return phone calls seeking comment. Friendly, based in Wilbraham, Mass., runs 407 restaurants and franchises 154 restaurants in 17 states. The company also makes packaged frozen desserts. Shares of Friendly rose to $1.80, from $1.72, in late trading.

title: Hospital Security Bidder Is Dropped After Harassment Charges Surface
description: A push by New York City's public hospital system to save tens of millions of dollars by replacing its nearly 850-member police force with private security guards encountered a setback recently when the city discovered that the winning bidder failed to tell the Health and Hospitals Corporation about a series of sexual harassment complaints against it.

title: Breaking News Photography: Alan Diaz, The Associated Press
description: Mr. Diaz was honored for his picture of federal agents trying to seize 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez in the home of the boy's Miami relatives. He was the only photographer to capture the pre-dawn moment when agents entered the house in Little Havana. The picture was published on April 22, 2000.

title: Feature Photography: Matt Rainey, The Star-Ledger
description: Mr. Rainey's photographs in a series called "After the Fire" won the prize for feature photography. In this picture, published Sept. 19, 2000, a victim of a dormitory fire at Seton Hall University in New Jersey is being treated in a burn unit. Mr. Rainey's photos show the care and recovery of two burned students.

title: 16% Increase Is Negotiated For Librarians
description: At a time when many librarians are leaving for higher-paying jobs in the suburbs, the Giuliani administration and New York City's largest librarians' union said yesterday that they had negotiated a tentative settlement that would give members a raise of 16 percent this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMERMAN, FAY
description: HAMMERMAN-Fay. We extend heartfelt condolences to Steve Hammerman on the loss of his beloved mother, a true Eishes Chayil. As devoted friends and Founders of the Medical Center, Steve and his wife Eleanor, who is a member of the Women's Division Board, have made a vital difference to the well-being and survival of thousands of premature infants. Through their exemplary support of our Neonatal Research activites, they personify the highest standards of tzedakah and chesed, which was passed on to them by this very special woman. May Steve and the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm. for Shaare Zedek Jerusalem Med. Ctr.

description: LOS ANGELES -- Darius Miles did some hip-hop moves on the scorers' table. Lamar Odom, surrounded by kids at midcourt, also bounced to the music.

title: WARNING BY CISCO, AN INTERNET TITAN
description: Offering fresh evidence that economic growth is slowing notably, Cisco Systems said yesterday that its sales and profit were falling far short of expectations. Cisco, whose startling success in the 1990's mirrored the rise of the Internet, blamed a worldwide economic slowdown for its problems.

title: Despite 8% Decline in Earnings, Citigroup Still Surpasses Analysts' Predictions
description: Citigroup, the nation's largest financial services company, reported an 8 percent decline in first-quarter earnings yesterday as it failed to cut expenses fast enough to offset the sinking value of its investments and a rising level of loans going bad.

title: Calls for Verniero's Impeachment Are Unfounded, His Lawyer Says
description: Justice Peter G. Verniero today rebutted a State Senate committee's demands for his impeachment, saying the committee's charges about how he handled the racial-profiling issue rested on ''unfair inferences, misleading references and unfounded conclusions.''

title: Special Delivery for the Space Station: A Robotic Arm
description: The International Space Station is to receive a major arm up this week when astronauts aboard the shuttle Endeavour deliver a robot helper critical to expanding and maintaining the orbiting laboratory.

title: Journeying Underground To Unearth A Fresh Style
description: Last week at Wetlands Preserve, three different eras of underground rock fused into a band that played as one loud, unified mind. The group was J. Mascis and the Fog, and it featured well-known figures from prepunk, punk and post-punk music.

title: Better Business Bureau Faults Hale House Spending on Services
description: Hale House, the nationally known Harlem charity that provides shelter for babies born to drug-addicted and H.I.V.-infected mothers, does not meet the standards of the Better Business Bureau because it spends less than half its income on services and has repeatedly refused to cooperate with evaluators seeking information, the organization said yesterday.

title: Justice for Sierra Leone
description: It has been nearly a year since Foday Sankoh, the Sierra Leone warlord, was arrested in Freetown during renewed fighting in that war-battered West African nation. His Revolutionary United Front continues to terrorize Sierra Leone in a war that is now spreading into neighboring Guinea. Yet an international campaign to bring war crimes charges against Mr. Sankoh has been stymied by disputes over funding. Now the United Nations and its leading members have a chance to overcome these obstacles and make possible a belated measure of justice for Sierra Leone. They must not fail to do so.

title: Victory for Unions as Judge Upholds Law
description: A judge upheld a state law today that would have a state board arbitrate contract disputes involving New York City's police officers and firefighters, a ruling the unions hope will help get them larger pay raises.

title: Joey Ramone, Raw-Voiced Pioneer of Punk Rock, Dies at 49
description: Joey Ramone, the singer whose misfit style and guileless shout in the band the Ramones defined punk rock as a music for Everyman, died on Sunday at New York Weill Cornell Medical Center. He was 49.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: NEW LANDMARKS CHAIRWOMAN Sherida E. Paulsen was named chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission yesterday by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Ms. Paulsen, a commissioner since 1995, will succeed Jennifer J. Raab on May 14. As a general proposition, Ms. Paulsen said yesterday, modern additions to landmarks should draw on the past without replicating architectural features exactly. "We don't want to be who we were, but we do want to learn lessons," she said. Ms. Paulsen, 48, will resign as a principal in Pasanella & Klein Stolzman & Berg Architects of Manhattan, which she joined in 1999. She has also worked for Ehrenkrantz Eckstut & Kuhn Architects; for Skidmore, Owings & Merrill; and for the Forest City Ratner development concern. David W. Dunlap (NYT)

description: Glaxo-SmithKline P.L.C. has won the Food and Drug Administration's approval to market its antidepressant Paxil for treating general anxiety disorder, a new use for the drug.

title: Santa Fe Dusts Off a Venerable Theater and a New Reputation
description: As workers chip away decades of accumulated dirt and plaster from the interior of the once-grand Lensic Theater here, they are also putting the final touches on this city's emergence as a major arts center. By rights Santa Fe, which has only 70,000 residents and sits in the middle of a desert, should be a sleepy backwater. Instead it has become a cultural magnet that attracts world-class artists, musicians, theater groups and opera singers.

title: Front Row: Another Morality Tale About a Model's Tragic Life
description: To her profound misfortune, Gia Carangi lived the kind of narrative that leaves pop culture's maw always hungry for another chunk. Like so many in her mold, a woman too beautiful for this world, she left it early. Thanks to Stephen Fried's 1993 biography, "Thing of Beauty: The Tragedy of Supermodel Gia"; a 1998 HBO movie about her life; and at least seven fan Web sites, Ms. Carangi's life cum morality tale is now, ostensibly, familiar  a child of the 1970's catapulted into supermodeldom, she fell into drug use and obscurity, dying of AIDS in 1986 at 26.

title: NO RAISE FOR AMAZON CHIEF, AGAIN
description: Jeff Bezos, left, the chief executive of Amazon.com, did not receive a raise last year, according to a recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Bezos was paid $81,840 in 2000, the same salary as the previous two years. Other Amazon executives did quite a bit better, led by Warren C. Jenson, the chief financial officer, who received $2.1 million in total compensation, including a raise to $177,450 from $55,679. Jeffrey A. Wilke, vice president for operations, was paid $1.3 million and Mark J. Britto, vice president for cross-site merchandising, received $1.1 million. Despite the steep drop in price of Amazon stock, Mr. Bezos's 32 percent stake is still worth $1.7 billion. Andrew Zipern

title: Another F.C.C. Clearance For Verizon Long-Distance
description: Verizon Communications received approval yesterday from federal regulators to provide long-distance service in Massachusetts, bringing to five the number of states where large Bell local telephone companies can enter into the fast-changing long-distance communications business.

title: Where G.I.'s Were Consumed By the Holocaust's Terror; A Filmmaker Helps Thaw Memories of Wartime Guilt
description: Four plain wooden crosses stand in the cemetery above this quiet town in eastern Germany. One of them is inscribed ''Unknown Allied Soldier.'' He is unlikely to be an American, because the G.I.'s who died here were exhumed after World War II and taken home. But the mystery of this soldier's identity is only one of many hanging over Berga and its former Nazi camp.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Education Life section on April 8 about sex discrimination in science education misstated a conclusion of a study by the Independent Women's Forum. The study said that men among junior faculty members at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology wrote about the same number of articles as women did and were cited about as often in science journals. The women did not produce more articles and citations.

title: Daily News Is Interested if Post Must Sell, Zuckerman Says
description: Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the publisher of The Daily News, has said in a letter to a public interest group that he will bid to take over the paper's chief rival, The New York Post, in the event that federal regulators require the News Corporation to sell The Post.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; First Union Pursues Wachovia, Making Offer of $13.1 Billion
description: After a string of botched acquisitions, the First Union Corporation said yesterday that it would try the expansion strategy once again by acquiring Wachovia Corporation for $13.1 billion, making it the nation's fourth-largest bank by assets.

title: INDONESIA: GAS DRILLING SOUGHT
description: Indonesia said it hoped that Exxon Mobil would resume production at its natural gas fields in the strife-torn province of Aceh by the end of May. The company shut down the fields in March, after its employees were menaced by separatist guerrillas. The Indonesian director general of oil and gas, Rachmat Sudibyo, said the government and the state oil company, Pertamina, were working with Exxon to resume limited production. Exxon did not confirm plans to reopen the fields. Just last week, a fire broke out at one of the fields, damaging a warehouse. Mark Landler

title: What's Stonewashed, Ripped, Mended and $2,222?
description: Could anyone have known that the stoner from high school who spent senior year playing Hacky Sack on the town commons would turn out to be a fashion icon? That guy (and he knows who he is) spent a good part of the 1970's wearing a maroon rugby shirt and a pair of Levi's button-fly 501 jeans that had rarely, if ever, seen the inside of a Maytag. The trouser legs were so long the hems frayed to the point of being fringed. The buckle on his incised buffalo-hide belt wore a curious hole near the pocket crease. The seat of the pants were abraded white where his orange nylon Velcro-closure wallet wore it out. One or another from a wardrobe of novelty boxers tended to billow from a hole in the crotch.

title: Metro Business Briefing; NASDAQ DROPS LECHTERS
description: The Nasdaq stock market delisted Lechters Inc., a national chain of housewares stores based in Harrison, N.J., because the company was unable to convince a two-member panel of investment industry professionals that it would be able to raise its stock price above $1, market officials said yesterday. The company, which announced in February that it planned to close 35 of its 126 stores in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, said that its shares would now trade on the OTC Bulletin Board, or over the counter, and that it was ''focusing on the implementation of its recently announced strategic repositioning plan.'' The company's shares fell to 35 cents from 43 cents after the announcement. Its shares have traded for less than $2 for more than a year. Michael Brick

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUMKE, WILLIAM EDNER SR.
description: DUMKE-William Edner Sr. Devoted husband and father and long time resident of Scarsdale, NY died after a short illness on Thursda, April 12 at his Stonington, Conn. home to which he and his wife had retired. He was 71. Mr. Dumke is remembered by his wife of 45 years Patricia; his brother James Ralph Dumke; his five children, William Edner Jr., John Ralph, Andrea Lanning, Leslie Elizabeth and Sarah Ryder, his daughters-in-law Kelley Gipson and Kristina Harvey, his son-inlaw Brian McDonald and his seven grandchildren. For the last 25 years of his professional life Mr. Dumke was Vice President and CFO of Henningsen Foods Inc. in White Plains, NY. Mr. Dumke was a graduate of Colgate University and received his MBA from Columbia University after serving in the United States Air Force. A memorial service for Mr. Dumke will be held at his family church Hitchcock Presbyterian, in Scarsdale, NY on Saturday, April 21, at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, the family gratefully request sending donations to the Lust Garten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research, 877972-7373 in memory of William E. Dumke, Sr. Mr. Dumke will be interred at River Bend cemetery, Westerly, R.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GWIRTZMAN, BURTON
description: GWIRTZMAN - Burton. Died peacefully on April 14 from lung cancer at age 75. A true friend to literally thousands with whom he has maintained loving contact throughout his lifetime. A man of the highest integrity, loyalty and humanity. He served bravely as a medic in World War II, he worked with his beloved dad in the garment industry; opened his own brokerage firm as a successful and trusted investment counselor; ultimately became Vice President at Paine Webber. Chosen by the N.Y Rangers to raise the 1994 Stanley Cup banner at Madison Square Garden after six decades of dedication to the team. Selected by the N.Y. Giants for induction into the NFL Fans Hall of Fame as the all-time premier Giant's fan. He had a passion for fresh water fishing. Adored his wife of 15 years, Sarina, who he proclaimed made his last 15 years his best. Also survived by his brother, Arthur, and the innumerable grateful friends and relatives whose lives he touched with a unique gentleness and wisdom, He made a indelible impact that will always be treasured. Services to be held Wednesday, April 18, at 1:30 PM at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 E. 79 St. Contributions in his memory may be made to cancer research or to the Woodie Wheaton Land Trust, Forest City, Me. 04413

title: FLOWERS FOODS SEES LOSS IN FIRST QUARTER, THEN PROFITS
description: Flowers Foods, the maker of Mrs. Smith's and Nature's Own baked goods, said yesterday that it would lose more than $1 a share for its current quarter and have a profit in each of the remaining quarters of 2001. The loss includes transaction-related expenses and charges for the current period, which ends Saturday, the company said. Amos McMullian will remain chairman and chief executive for three years, Flowers Foods also said. The company, which is based in Thomasville, Ga., was spun off last month from Flowers Industries, which was purchased by the Kellogg Company.

title: Intuit Is Buying Software Maker

title: 30 Employees Laid Off At Cohn & Wolfe
description: In another sign of the slowing economy, Cohn & Wolfe in New York, a public relations unit of Young & Rubicam, laid off 30 employees yesterday, about 8.6 percent of its American staff of more than 350.

description: SCHLUSSEL - Barbara. Adored wife of Sy Schlussel, M.D. for 49 years. Mother of her beloved son Ralph and sister of Herbert Simon. Passed away April 15. She was genuinely the most devoted loving mother, always selflessly willing to sacrifice and forego personal rewards in caring for her Ralph. For many years she raised funds for the Mental Retardation Facility at the New York Medical College and for more than 30 years arranged the pre-graduation dinner dance for the New York Medical College. She will be sorely missed but never forgotten. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday and Wednesday 7-9PM with services Thursday 11:30AM. Interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCABE, ARTHUR
description: McCABE-Arthur. The New York Chapter of the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation International records with deep sorrow the death of Mr. Arthur McCabe, beloved father of our esteemed Board Member Kevin A. McCabe. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the bereaved family. Lawrence B. Sorrel, President New York Chapter

title: Through a Tiny Portal, Japan
description: WHEN most people think of Japanese food, they think of sushi. Prepared with cool artistic precision, sushi first feeds the mind, and then the appetite. But Japanese food is not sushi alone.

title: THE NETHERLANDS: NTT MAY RAISE STAKE
description: Japan's largest mobile phone company, NTT DoCoMo, may raise its $3.6 billion investment in KPN Mobile, the cellular unit of Royal KPN, to promote wireless Internet services in Europe. Although DoCoMo has not been asked by KPN, it would invest more if needed to help expand the Dutch cellular company's Internet services, Kiyoyuki Tsujimura, managing director of DoCoMo's global business department, said in an interview.

title: Seattle, a City Spurned, Heckles a Visiting Son
description: Some day, people in Seattle may look back on the night it rained cash from the sky, courtesy of the shortstop who spurned them. Sure, it was tax day, but it was also the second coming of Alex Rodriguez, known by the banners hanging from a sold-out Safeco Field as A-Wad, A-Fraud, Pay-Rod, Nim-Rod, K-Rod and, of course, the potential groom for any number of teenage girls whose hearts have not been hardened by the $252 million change in uniforms.

title: You Want Repeat Customers? Try E-Mail
description: IT'S cheap and it's fast. Customers respond to it and read it. They buy.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We're committed to helping Taiwan if they are attacked, but we don't need to be waving red flags in people's faces.''

title: Fire Dept. Delays Hiring Officer in Diallo Shooting
description: The Fire Department has decided to delay hiring one of the four officers involved in the shooting death of Amadou Diallo pending the outcome of police disciplinary charges against him, officials said last night.

title: Canada Is Set to Display Its Links to Latin Lands
description: Although Canada puts a premium on its warm ties with the United States, it plans to use the Summit of the Americas in Quebec, which begins on Friday, to highlight its growing involvement with other nations in the hemisphere.

title: Rivals Scrutinize Hevesi's Spending (or Lack of It)
description: City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi's comparatively modest spending early in his mayoral campaign drew scrutiny from his rivals yesterday, including the City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, who asked the city Campaign Finance Board to look into whether the comptroller might have cheated the system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, MARTIN
description: RICHMAN-Martin. On April 17, 2001. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Alan Richman, Jane Gewant and her husband Kenneth. Cherished grandfather of Jennifer. Very dear and devoted only son of the late Fannie and Henry Richman. First Lieutenant in U.S. Army in World War II. Awarded Medal with Battle Star for service in Europe and North Africa. Harvard Law School graduate, AB with Phi Beta Kappa, MBA and LLM. Asst. General Counsel of Prudential Insurance Company. Mason for 55 years. Serivces Thursday, 12:30PM, at Riverdale Temple, W. 246 St and Independence Ave. Riverdale, NY.

description: The Philip Morris Companies reported a 2.2 percent increase in first-quarter earnings yesterday, as higher cigarette prices more than offset the nation's slow but steady retreat from smoking.

description: DAVID BOULTER did not pay much attention when BP Amoco -- the oil giant formerly known as British Petroleum -- began exploring electronic commerce more than a decade ago.

title: The Secret's In the Sherry
description: ORDINARILY I believe there's a lot of latitude in the kind of wine you can use in cooking -- if a recipe calls for dry white wine, you can use almost anything but red. But sherry is different. If you use amontillado, which contains just a touch of sweetness, you can convert pork and onions into a dish with complex, rich, unusual, even mysterious flavor.

title: Powell Assails Israel for Gaza Incursion
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, employing the harshest language against Israel since the Bush administration took office, assailed Israel today for using ''excessive and disproportionate'' force in seizing a part of Palestinian-ruled territory in Gaza, and urged its forces to withdraw.

title: SCHOLASTIC WILL LAY OFF 100 EDITORIAL STAFF MEMBERS
description: The Scholastic Corporation will cut about 100 editorial jobs and take a charge in its current quarter after ending development of its literacy textbook series. A charge of $1.05 to $1.15 a share will be taken in the period that ends May 31. Scholastic Literacy Place, a textbook reading program started in 1995, will account for about 2 percent of Scholastic's sales this fiscal year, the company said. Scholastic, which is based in New York, said the literacy books are too expensive to develop and the company plans to focus its educational publishing business on reading improvement textbooks and materials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBY, HELEN
description: JACOBY-Helen. Of Manhattan. Ardent mother, grandmother; adoring sister, sister-in-law, aunt; trustworthy friend; eternal devotee of fun, laughs, good times. Real life movie star to everyone who experienced her luster. Died in her 2nd home in, fittingly, Hollywood Beach, April 16. Lucky are the stars to greet her now. Service Thursday 2 P.M., Parkside Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills.

title: No Torre? Players Don't Like Concept
description: Joe Torre's negotiations for a contract extension have stalled, and unless he and George Steinbrenner can agree to a new deal, Torre's tenure as Yankees manager will end after this season. Torre said on Sunday that he and Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, would resolve the matter this summer, ''one way or the other.''

title: Government Signs Harlem Lease for Clinton Office
description: After months of uncertainty and a high-profile search that took him from Midtown to Harlem, Bill Clinton finally has an office suite in Manhattan that he can call his own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERMUT, HYMAN
description: VERMUT-Hyman, 83. Beloved husband of Sydelle, passed away on April 17, 2001. He is survived and will be deeply missed by his children, Stephan and Barbara and Leslie and Tom, and his adoring grandchildren, Jennifer, Felix, Aaron, Ann, McGee, Lauren and Alex. The family will be sitting shiva at home. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the National Kidney Foundation of FL.

title: Liberties; Of Divas and Ditzes
description: Tracing the arc of the great heroines of fiction, from Scarlett to Gidget to Bridget, it is hard to know if women are making progress.

title: Relaford Is Slowly Adjusting to the Bench
description: Desi Relaford remembers taking the call, raising his eyebrows and not having much to say. Last October, Mets General Manager Steve Phillips let Relaford know the Mets had claimed him off waivers. The Mets?

description: Several acquisitions are being made in advertising and marketing services for undisclosed terms.

title: Forstmann Considers More Help for XO
description: Forstmann Little & Company, a private equity firm, is mulling making an investment of several hundred million additional dollars in XO Communications, according to an executive close to the discussions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HACKETT, DAVID P.
description: HACKETT-David P. April 17, 2001. Beloved husband of Ann, loving father of Allyson and her husband Mitchell Frischer. Cherished grandfather of Brooke. Loving brother of Vincent, Oliver and Terrence. A true gentleman who was respected for his honesty and integrity. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him, especially Daysie, Phyllis & Sadie. Service Thursday, April 19, 2001, 1:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. The family will receive on Thursday, Friday, Saturday evening and Sunday.

title: Metro Business Briefing; CITY'S ECONOMY STILL THRIVES
description: New York City's economy slowed only slightly in the first two months of this year, but the stock market's steep decline could mean trouble for the city in the future, according to a report released yesterday by H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, who is running for governor. The city added 16,700 jobs in January and February, down only slightly from last year, when 17,400 jobs were created in the same stretch, according to the report. Both figures were adjusted for seasonal factors. ''The city has so far felt only a slight echo of the nation's slowdown in 2001,'' the report says. But, it warns, ''the effects of both slowed national growth and the reductions of wealth stemming from the last year's slide in stock prices will slow economic growth in the region later in the year.'' Leslie Eaton

title: Food Stuff: Vegetable Spoken Fluently Here
description: Grenadillas, full of edible seeds, from South America. Spiny rambutans, cousins of the litchi, from Southeast Asia. Pepper-shape babacos from New Zealand. And let us not forget kaffir limes, essential in Thai cooking, and the bumpy little tubers called crosnes, or Chinese artichokes.

title: Sports of The Times; Sorenstam's Streak Stirs Mixed Ideas
description: WHEN Annika Sorenstam opened a fortune cookie in a Chinese restaurant that Tuesday after dinner in Tucson, the message read, ''Your goals will come true this week.'' The next evening, in another Chinese restaurant there, she opened another fortune cookie.

description: NEW Yorkers are thought of as a finicky, demanding bunch. Nothing is ever quite good enough. Their personal ads are long enough to need chapter headings. A bagel order can require a lawyer. All the more surprising, then, that certain restaurants, agreeable but hardly special, manage to catch fire.

title: e-UROPE; How Ducati Roared Onto the Internet

description: If this keeps up, professional football could be next.

title: WINSTAR MISSES PAYMENTS
description: Shares in Winstar Communications plunged yesterday after the telephone company said it had failed to pay about $75 million in interest due on its debt. The move by Winstar increased concern over the effect a potential default would have on companies that provided it with financing, including Lucent Technologies, which has reportedly lent Winstar more than $500 million to buy its products. A person close to Lucent said it had made provisions for the possibility that it would not be paid by Winstar. Simon Romero

McGreevey, that party's likely gubernatorial candidate, of leaking material about those allegations to The New York Times.

description: The Federalist Society was founded almost 20 years ago by a handful of conservative law students who felt that they were a beleaguered minority at their elite schools, isolated and even disdained in a dominant liberal intellectual environment.

description: The Eastman Kodak Company, grappling with a transition to digital technologies even as the slowing economy crimps sales in its conventional film and paper businesses, said yesterday that it would eliminate as many as 3,500 jobs over the next few months.

Most of the mushroom industry supports the program enthusiastically.

title: No. 5 Is Sore Spot For the Yankees As Keisler Falters
description: Randy Keisler keeps looking over his shoulder, glancing at the Yankees' dugout after he throws a bad pitch, peeking out at the bullpen when he gives up a run. He keeps looking over his shoulder, for confirmation or condemnation, and he loses track of the strike zone and hard-charging base runners.

title: Platform Built on a Divided City; Ferrer Courts Voters He Says Giuliani Left Behind
description: With a triumphant gait, Fernando Ferrer strode into the ornate auditorium at the Bronx Community College recently to deliver what was to be his final message as the Bronx borough president. His speech that chilly morning was somewhat valedictory, focusing on his list of accomplishments in the borough: the development of new housing, the upturn for the borough's small businesses, and the perception that the Bronx is no longer the city's laughingstock.

title: THE CHEF
description: I STILL feel lucky about this dish. I had never eaten anything quite like it until the night I made it. Already an hour into service, I muscled my way to a burner and improvised with some ingredients at hand: razor clams, hominy and smoked paprika. Now it's a dish that lives permanently in the small catalog of flavors, tastes and textures that I crave.

title: EBay Suspends Coin Seller Over Delivery Concerns
description: EBay, the Internet auction service, has suspended the account of a seller suspected of taking hundreds of thousands of dollars from people who bid successfully on gold and silver coins and bullion, sent their money and got nothing in return, the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRUBEK, MAX
description: TRUBEK-Max. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of NYU Medical Center mourn the passing of Max Trubek, M.D., Professor of Clinical Medicine at NYU School of Medicine and a renowned internist in private practice for 63 years. Dr. Trubek completed his training at Bellevue Hospital, where he subsequently taught and inspired generations of students and physicians. A consummate diagnostician and dedicated teacher, he loved and lived medicine. Sincerest condolences to his family. Robert M. Glickman, M.D., Dean NYU School of Medicine Theresa A. Bischoff, President NYU Hospitals Center Martin J. Blaser, M.D., Chairman Department of Medicine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, MILTON
description: LEVIN-Milton. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University mourns the passing of our devoted friend and honorary member of our Board of Overseers. A steadfast champion of our institution since its opening in 1955, he and his wife, Fanny, were among the first members of our Society of Founders and staunch supporters of our cancer research programs. For nearly a quarter of a century, he served as an esteemed member of our Board of Overseers. A University Guardian, he was a man of wisdom and wit, whose friendship and counsel will be sorely missed. To Mrs. Levin; to son, James; daughter, Gene Heller, and the entire family, we offer our heartfelt sympathy. Yeshiva University Dr. Norman Lamm, President Robert M. Beren, Chairman Board of Trustees Albert Einstein College of Medicine Robert A. Belfer, Chairperson Board of Overseers Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean

title: BRITAIN: OIL PRICES RISE
description: Crude oil prices rose after an unexplained explosion and fire at a Conoco refinery in Northeastern England raised worries about gasoline supplies for the United States, where inventories are 5 percent lower than last year and the peak summer travel season is approaching. The refinery, which produces 200,000 barrels a day, is one of the few European suppliers to the United States. The price of Brent crude for June settlement rose in London almost 3 percent, to $28.10 a barrel. Alan Cowell

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLASER, ANNA
description: BLASER-Anna, April 18, 1989. Cherished mother. We will never forget you. Love, Blaser Family

title: For Those Who Run From Eat-on-the-Run Pizza
description: NO matter how rubbery the cheese or sodden the crust, pizza almost always finds a way to satisfy. Too often, though, the reflex pleasure in consuming a slice on the street obscures the significant differences between junk food and the real thing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, SIDNEY
description: KLEIN-Sidney. On April 17, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Leah. Loving father of Virginia and Richard. Dear brother of Irving. Adoring grandfather of Colby. Service Thursday 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OROVAN, HERMAN E
description: OROVAN-Herman E. Formerly of New York, died in Arizona. He was an owner of an import/export business in New York. He retired in 1962. He moved to Arizona in 1971 from Great Neck. He is survived by his wife Elsie, 2 children, five grandchildren and nine greatgrandchildren. Funeral services were held at Green Acres Cemetery, Scottsdale, Arizona.

title: Here's Mud in Your Eye, Starbucks
description: THE sun had barely risen over the East Village the other day, and already, Martin Mistretta was fighting the good fight. Mr. Mistretta, 52, a photographer, is not by nature a warrior, but for a while now, he had felt the shadow of corporate latte creeping over his neighborhood. Now, as he stood in Cooper Square, his horizons were defined to the east by the Starbucks at Astor Place and Third Avenue, and to the west by the Starbucks at Astor and Lafayette.

title: Beijing Blocks U.S. Attempt to Debate China Rights Record
description: UNITED NATIONS, April 18  China, backed by Russia and major Asian, African and Arab countries, succeeded today in striking off the agenda of the United Nations Human Rights Commission an American resolution calling attention to Beijing's rights record.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOTT, C. HOWELL.

A memorial service will be held on Friday, April 20, at 11:00 AM, at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 18 James Lane, East Hampton.

title: Intel Reports Sharp Drop In Chip Sales
description: The Intel Corporation reported today that sales dropped sharply from the quarter a year earlier, but the company slightly beat its lowered earnings forecasts. Company executives said they were seeing signs that economic factors had begun to stabilize.

title: Diners Discover Life After Chardonnay
description: TO winemakers, the only thing better than getting you to buy in a shop is getting you to buy in a restaurant. Many small wineries concentrate their marketing on restaurants. And when it comes right down to it, where did you first get interested in wine?

title: Citing U.S. Slowdown, Philips Will Cut 7,000 Jobs
description: Scrambling to react to an economic slowdown that has spread swiftly to Europe from the United States, Royal Philips Electronics N.V. said today that it would eliminate up to 7,000 jobs and that it would probably lose money in the second quarter.

title: Johnson & Johnson Settles Lawsuits Over Contact Lenses
description: Johnson & Johnson has agreed to pay as much as $860 million to settle lawsuits accusing the company of misleading consumers into prematurely throwing away disposable Acuvue contact lenses.

title: Japanese Agree A Stolen Statue Will Be Sent Back to China
description: The Miho Museum, a major new antiquities museum near Kyoto, Japan, has acknowledged for the first time what many archaeologists have long alleged: that one of its masterpieces, a rare Buddhist statue from China, is one that was stolen from Shandong Province, China, in 1994.

title: Israel Seizes Swath of Land in Gaza as Reply to Shelling, Then Pulls Out
description: Israeli forces seized a swath of Palestinian-ruled territory today in the Gaza Strip, cut down orchards, positioned an infantry battalion there and announced plans to hold the land indefinitely as a border-area buffer zone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, SARAH TOMERLIN
description: LEE-Sarah Tomerlin. The New York School of Interior Design mourns the loss of devoted trustee and honorary alumna, Sarah Tomerlin Lee. Her distinguished career in hospitality design, fashion, and journalism is an inspiration to our students. Our condolences are extended to her sons Todd and Charles, her grandchildren, and to the entire family. Carl A. Schwarz, Jr., Chairman of the Board Inge Heckel, President

title: Clutch and Grab Rears Ugly Head in Playoffs
description: RALEIGH, N.C. -- With Pittsburgh holding a one-goal lead in a Stanley Cup playoff game Monday night against Washington, Mario Lemieux of the Penguins rushed down ice with the puck on his stick, cheers in his ears and hope in his heart. It could have been a memorable moment, the kind that sells tickets and attracts a television audience. Would the part-owner and star of the Penguins beat Olaf Kolzig? Or would the Capitals' goalie lift his team's spirits with a crucial save?

title: Trans-Atlantic Debate; Continents Clash on Content
description: Courts in France, Germany and Italy rocked the cyberspace world in recent months with rulings banning content from their borders that does not meet their national laws. The ensuing uproar over certain cases -- most notably the French decision to prohibit the display of Nazi insignia and pro-Nazi remarks on Yahoo's auction site -- highlighted differences between Europe and the United States (and even differences within Europe) on the best ways to regulate the Internet.

title: Really Plugged-In People Reveal Really Useful Web Sites
description: DESPITE the millions of dollars that dot-coms have been spending on marketing, some Web sites and other Internet technologies become popular by word of mouth -- or mouse, as the case may be. Early adopters are often catalysts for spreading the word, so perhaps the next Napster or eBay might come from these people's favorite Web sites.

description: To the Editor:

title: CANADA: RATE LOWERED
description: Canada's central bank has lowered interest rates by one-quarter of a percentage point, the third cut this year, in an attempt to help the country's slowing economy. The Bank of Canada said the slowdown was largely a consequence of the easing in the United States. With Tuesday's reduction, the cost of overnight loans by the central bank, which is comparable to the federal funds rate in the United States, is 4.75 percent. Timothy Pritchard

title: Metro Business Briefing; SLAMMING SUIT SETTLED
description: New Jersey officials announced the settlement yesterday of a lawsuit against Qwest Communications International charging it with illegally switching local or long-distance telephone service without subscribers' permission. The state said the company agreed to pay $500,000, but did not admit any wrongdoing. The suit over the switching practice, known as slamming, was brought by the State Division of Consumer Affairs and the State Board of Public Utilities, which had received more than 150 complaints about Qwest since 1997. The settlement also requires that every Qwest sales representative review and sign an anti-slamming advisory, the state said. A Qwest spokesman, Matt Barkett, said that the company did not tolerate slamming and had fired 25 telemarketing firms it said engaged in the practice. Steve Strunsky

title: Knicks Fear Carry-Over of Poor Play
description: As far as Allan Houston of the Knicks is concerned, the N.B.A. playoffs start tonight, against the Detroit Pistons. Houston wants to see the intensity, determination and singleness of purpose that powered the Knicks to the Eastern Conference finals the past two seasons.

title: NCR POSTS QUARTERLY PROFIT
description: NCR, a large maker of automated teller machines, reported a first-quarter profit of $117 million, in contrast to a loss of $5 million in the quarter a year earlier. On a per-share basis, NCR earned $1.18, in contrast to a loss of 5 cents in the first quarter of 2000. NCR said its first-quarter revenue rose 10 percent, to $1.38 billion, from $1.26 billion a year earlier. The company said its strong performance was paced by a 21 percent growth in revenue from its data-warehousing business, including what it called significant gains in its software and professional consulting services operations. Elizabeth Stanton

description: It will be a surreal burial.

description: Sure, you can scribble on your sandwich or bagel using a squeeze bottle of ketchup or mustard, but what if your artistic spirit craves a wider palette? description: Michael Ritchie, who directed films like ''Downhill Racer,'' ''The Candidate,'' ''Smile,'' ''The Bad News Bears,'' ''Semi-Tough'' and ''Fletch,'' died on Monday. He was 62 and lived in Manhattan.

description: A profit warning from Cisco Systems, an icon of the Internet-era economic expansion, did not deter investors from buying stocks yesterday.

description: NBC got exactly what it needed from the premiere of the new game show ''Weakest Link'' on Monday night: the kinds of ratings that hits are built on.

title: Mets' Pitching Carries Them One More Time
description: The Mets are not built to be an offensive power. They believe they will get the hits they need and win a lot of games because of their pitching. When there is no hitting, they will lose no matter how they pitch. But when there is just enough offense, their pitching will carry them.

description: BIRCH syrup, like maple syrup, is made from sap but is otherwise so different that you would not squander it on pancakes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LURKIS, JEFFRY LOWELL
description: LURKIS-Jeffry Lowell, 61, of Marina del Rey, CA, died of lymphoma on April 13. He was the loving companion of Edward Hiser for twenty years; the beloved son of author and retired NY City Chief Engineer, Alexander Lurkis and deceased artist Carin Tendler Lurkis; father of Elisa and Spencer Wetter, Louisa and Clifton; grandfather of Nathan and Max. He is also survived by many loving cousins. They will miss him dearly. Jeffry graduated from Columbia College, Law School, and Business School and became a CPA. He and his family moved to LA in 1972. In 1975 he helped found the Gay Fathers of Los Angeles Group. Funeral services were held at Mount Sinai. Donations may be made to the Levine Lymphoma Research Foundation at USC/Norris Cancer Center in Los Angeles.

title: In Surprise Move, Fed Cuts Interest Rates by Half Point
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 - Faced with growing signs that businesses are retrenching rapidly as the economy weakens, the Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point today, igniting a powerful rally on Wall Street.

title: Patterns of Police Violence
description: For the residents of Cincinnati, the death of 19-year-old Timothy Thomas on April 7 was a tragedy that says a lot about the community's deep racial divide and complicated history. But the case also ought to cause millions of Americans elsewhere and the Bush administration to study closely the use of deadly force against minorities. Ten years ago, grainy images of Rodney King being clubbed by Los Angeles police officers horrified the nation. More recently, police shootings and the possibility of racial profiling in street and traffic arrests have raised heightened concern about a systemic disparity in the treatment of whites and minorities by police in other states and cities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONALDSON, DOROTHY ''WALLY''
description: DONALDSON-Dorothy ''Wally''. August 21, 1907-April 13, 2001 Born in Brooklyn, New York, Dorothy began a dancing and acting career at the age of 13. She moved to Hollywood in 1928 to work for MGM Studios, where she met songwriter Walter Donaldson. They married and had two children, Sheila and Ellen. Widowed in 1947, Dorothy had resided in Newport Beach, California since 1962, where she shared 35 wonderful years with Francis L. Tooley. ''Wally'' touched many lives with her generous love, kindness and humor, and will be lovingly remembered by her two daughters, Sheila and Ellen, her grandchildren Kelley, Kevin and Scott Kerslake, and Mary and Victoria Shea, as well as by Frank Tooley, his three daughters and grandchildren, along with many extended family members and friends. We celebrate, honor and carry on the spirit with which she lived her life. For information contact Pacific View Mortuary (949) 644-2700.

title: Marjorie and Paul Temanson, Anna Lee, Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport, Feb. 20, 2001
description: Marjorie Temanson (left): "We had tried to have a baby of our own and were not able to. We were working with an adoption agency, and a caseworker told us about Anna. We met her three times before her daughter was born. It was very intense. You worry that she might not like you. After Mya was born, we talked at least once a week. And we felt it was important for Anna to be able to see her daughter periodically -- to see for herself how she's doing. That day, we got to see her in the airport, during a stopover on our way to Hawaii. I'm not nervous anymore when we see her. Maybe a little anxious. It's a pretty awesome responsibility to have someone give you their child and ask you to raise it. We certainly don't want to disappoint her. But she wouldn't have picked us if she hadn't felt that we were the right parents. There was just a level of trust." -->

title: EUROPEAN UNION: BANANA PACT CHALLENGED

title: Magic Kingdom Vacations
description: The key numbers here are three four and five. That is, Kingdom Vacations is taking its three-night packages at five Orlando-area hotels and making them four night, at no extra charge. The fourth-night-free plan, good for travel May 1 to June 1, is available at the DoubleTree Club, Marriott's Fairfield Inn, Courtyard and Springhill Suites hotels, and the Hyatt Regency Grand Cypress. Rates for the packages -- which include unlimited four-day access to the four Disney theme parks, one-day admission to a Disney water park or Downtown Disney Pleasure Island -- start at $365 a person, double occupancy, at the DoubleTree. At the other hotels, the package prices start at $379 a person (Fairfield), $385 (Springhill), $399 (Courtyard) and $609 (Hyatt). These prices do not include air fare. title: TIMKEN PLANS TO CUT ABOUT 1,500 JOBS IN NEXT TWO YEARS

The reduction represents 7.3 percent of Timken's work force of 20,500. Most of the jobs are at two plants the company will close and one it will sell, a spokeswoman, Denise Bowler, said yesterday. Timken will provide details of the closings and sale in the next few weeks. Timken, which is based in Canton, Ohio, said it would take a charge of about $18 million in the second quarter.

title: Russia's Endangered Media
description: Russia's progress toward democracy during the past decade has been uneven. But one crucial factor driving it toward a freer society has been the rise of truly independent newspapers, magazines and television stations. Now, one by one, these voices are being stilled. Last weekend, new management with economic ties to the government took over the country's only autonomous national television network, NTV. This week the Moscow daily newspaper Sevodnya was shut down and the staff of the political weekly Itogi, a joint venture with Newsweek, was dismissed.

title: Reckonings; Chip of Fools
description: At the level of bits and bytes, the most surprising thing about the advance of information technology has been the absence of surprises. Back in 1965 Gordon Moore, co-founder of Intel, predicted that the number of transistors on a chip would henceforth double every 18 to 24 months -- and Moore's Law has worked like digital clockwork ever since. But the translation of bits and bytes into dollars and cents is far harder to predict. And so it is no wonder, or cause for shame, when smart people get the economic impact of technology wrong.

At Home, which offers the Excite@Home high-speed Internet service and operates World Wide Web sites, said AT&T, which owns a controlling stake, might provide the money the company needed. At Home said it expected a loss of 14 to 15 cents a share, compared with the 13 cents analysts expected. Chris Gaither

title: PSINET LOSS HITS $3.2 BILLION

The huge loss adds to the problems at PSINet, a provider of Internet communications services, which has operations in 27 countries. Delek owns Israel's second-largest chain of gas stations, and the purchase will be its first expansion outside Israel. Most of the stores are located in Tennessee. Williams, which is based in Tulsa, Okla., is trying to focus on its energy businesses and commit more capital to them by shedding some units.

It cradles a dozen or so shell shaped cakes called madeleines. You pop one in your mouth. It's warm and soft and its clear fragrance of lemon and vanilla awakens your tired palate. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COX, BERT GEORGE ''B.G.''
description: COX-Bert George ''B.G.'' Cox of Rye, New York and Boca Grande, Florida died on Monday, April 16, 2001 in Rye. His death resulted from complications due to a stroke. He was 80 years old. Mr. Cox was with The Joseph & Feiss Company, Inc., America's oldest clothing manufacturer and a former division of the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation in New York and Cleveland for 45 years serving in numerous offices including President from 1970. He was Chairman from 1986-1990 after purchasing the company from PVH and later selling it to Hugo Boss. He was a two-time president of the Clothing Manufacturer's Association of America (1983-1985, 1988-1990) and president of the Men's Fashion Association from 1980-1982. In 1979, Mr. Cox represented the clothing industry as part of a U.S. trade mission in Cairo, Egypt. He began his industry career in 1946 as an assistant buyer for the May Co. in Denver, Colorado. Mr. Cox was a naval fighter pilot serving in World War II from 1942-1946 reaching the rank of Lieutenant Commander. He received the Distinguished Flying Cross medal in 1946. He served on the Bennington, Shangri-La, and Yorktown aircraft carriers. Prior to enlisting, he was an agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Mr. Cox was born on October 18, 1920 in Billings, Montana. He graduated from the University of Oregon in 1946 earning BS degree in Business. He was a member of the Phi Gamma Delta fraternity. He was a member of The Apawamis Club and American Yacht Club, both of Rye. He was also a member of the Boca Grande Club and Boca Bay Pass Club, both of Boca Grande, Fl. A resident of Rye for the past 40 years, he is survived by his wife of 52 years, Leone Larsen Cox; two daughters, Anne Zahringer of New York, N.Y., Karen Mandy of Rye; a son Robert H. of Stamford, CT and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held for B.G. Cox on Friday, April 20th at the Rye Presbyterian Church. Boston Post Road in Rye at 10:30 in the morning. In lieu of flowers, friends may send memorial donations to The Emergency Care Pavilion of New York United Hospital Medical Center (N.Y.U.H.M.C.), 406 Boston Post Road, Port Chester, NY 10573

title: MAKER OF CHIP-DESIGN SOFTWARE GAINS

Cadence shares rose $2.90, to $19.89. Cadence said yesterday that it expected software sales to increase 30 percent this year, bolstering optimism that the company and its competitors would skirt the economic slowdown, said John Barr, an analyst at Robertson Stephens. The shares also benefited from comments by Intel executives that demand for computer chips began to rise in March. Cadence lowered its sales estimate for the company as a whole to 18 percent from 20 percent because of a decline in business at its Tality Corporation unit, which provides design engineers on a contract basis.

title: Used Space Gear, None the Worse For a Little Moon Dust
description: Is the NASA spacesuit the modern equivalent of a suit of armor decorating the foyer? Christie's thinks so. Its first auction of space race paraphernalia, in 1999, brought $1.7 million. Now, Christie's East is re-entering the market on May 9 with an auction of 350 items from astronauts and private collectors: maps sprinkled with lunar dust, emblems, Yuri Gagarin's report on his first space flight and five spacesuits, including the Gemini Extravehicular Activity model, left, used for training in 1966. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUEST, RAYMOND R. (ANDY)
description: GUEST-Raymond R. (Andy). Died of Lymphoma, April 2, 2001 at his home, Rock Hill Farm, in Front Royal, Virginia. He was born September 29, 1939, the son of the late Ambassador Raymond R. Guest and Elizabeth (Lily) Polk Guest. Mr. Guest attended the Pomfret School, and was graduated from Yale University in 1964. He served in the U.S. Marine Corp Reserve and spent his adult life farming in Virginia. In 1971, Mr. Guest was elected to the Virginia House of Delegates, an office he held until he retired in 1999. He served on the Committees on Conservation and Natural Resources; Agriculture; Roads and Internal Navigation; Appropriations; and Rules, and served as Minority Leader from 1986-1992. He was also a member of the Virginia State Crime Commission and the Virginia Industrial Development Authority. Mr. Guest served on the Board of Directors of Bessemer Trust Companies and Bessemer Securities Corporation. Survivors include his wife, Mary Scott Derrick Guest of Front Royal; three children, Mary Elizabeth Looney, Raymond R. Guest III, and William G. Yarborough III; three sisters, Elizabeth Guest Stevens, Virginia Guest Valentine, and Laetitia Guest Oppenheim, a brother, Achille Murat Guest and six grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the St. Luke's Community Clinic, 842 North Shenandoah Avenue, Front Royal, VA. 22630, or Cunningham Chapel, Millwood, VA. 22646.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONN, RUTH
description: CONN-Ruth. Of East Quogue and New York City, died on April 18, 2001 after a long and valiant fight against cancer, at her home in East Quogue, surrounded by those whom she loved most. Beloved wife of Stephen R. Conn and mother of Orin Conn and of Omri Green and Ira and Lynn Liran, she was the daughter of Yeshayahu and Renee Anug of Jerusalem and sister of Yigal Anug of Kfar Bilu, Israel. In her brief but brilliant 49 years, she reached out and touched the lives of thousands, always seeking to do more for others than she sought to do for herself. She strived to leave the world a better place than she found it and succeeded. Her spirit, energy, fierce independence, generosity, compassion and concern, combined with an inner and outer beauty, will live forever. A memorial service will be held in Manhattan at a date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the East End Hospice, Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978.

title: AKAMAI POSTS HUGE LOSS

The loss was $2.22 billion, or $22.50 a share, compared with a loss of $35.4 million, or 47 cents, a year earlier. Sales surged to $40.2 million from $7.22 million. The company said it had $1.9 billion in costs in the recent quarter to write off good will from its acquisitions of Intervu Inc. and Network24 Communications.

title: Life Can Be a Little Better For Gamers on the Road
description: Anyone looking to fight aliens on the run knows that notebook computers are all work and no play when it comes to running 3-D games like Quake III or Unreal Tournament. But now, thanks to a new graphics chip by nVidia, a video graphics board maker, gamers can experience desktop PC gaming performance on the road. Introduced last month in Toshiba's Satellite 2805 S402, an nVidia's GeForce2 Go graphics chip is also at the heart of Dell's new Inspiron 8000 notebook. In the Toshiba, the chip has 16 megabytes of memory dedicated solely to the 3-D graphics that would drag an ordinary notebook to a crawl as you ran down corridors with guns blazing. To double the fun factor, the Inspiron 8000 has an nVidia chip with twice that video memory. Along with all that gaming goodness are features that make the Inspiron 8000 powerful enough to say goodbye to your desktop PC. Processor speeds range from a snappy 600-megahertz Celeron to a screaming 1-gigahertz Pentium III.

title: TELLABS CUTS JOBS

Tellabs said that because of lower expected revenue growth it will cut the pay of all corporate officers, eliminate salary increases and end development of a new switch. ''The quarter clearly did not live up to our expectations,'' Richard Notebaert, the Tellabs president and chief executive, said in a conference call. title: A Rare Chance to Hear, Then Read, 'Faune'
description: There is a special thrill in hearing music performed almost alongside the very pieces of paper on which the composer was working it out. This is the charm of the early evening concerts at the Morgan Library, of which the latest, on Tuesday, included two works that could be seen and heard, if not quite simultaneously: Debussy's ''Prlude  L'Aprs-Midi d'un Faune,'' of which the Morgan possesses a short score with annotations for scoring, and Ravel's ''Chansons Madcasses.''

title: At Long Last, A Place to Sit While You Wait
description: Denver has them. So do Los Angeles and Phoenix. But until this month, New York never had benches at bus shelters. On April 6, the city installed its first bus shelter bench, right, at Grand Concourse and 165th Street in the Bronx; 10 more will follow in that borough. Brooklyn will get 31, Manhattan 15, Queens 12 and Staten Island 6. Community boards decided whether to install the benches, which cost $335 each without the city's bulk discount. ''Some communities didn't want people living on them,'' said Iris Weinshall, New York City's commissioner of transportation. The benches are divided by welded steel bars, which preclude a comfortable nap. The bars also make it easier for the elderly to get up, said Jeffrey Sherman, who designed the bench. He is president of Lacor Streetscapes in Phoenix, makers of benches, shelters and kiosks. The perforated steel benches, he said, are resistant to vandalism and remain cool in the summer. The 75 benches will be in place by summer's end.

title: Recalling the Gentle Elegance Of John Lewis, Jazzman
description: To admirers, it seemed fitting that Tuesday evening's memorial concert in honor of John Lewis, the jazz pianist and founder of the Modern Jazz Quartet, clocked in at slightly over two hours -- concise and to the point. As speakers ascended to the pulpit of St. John the Divine to remember him, the picture they rendered was of a man gentle to the point of folksy in his manner and yet so precise in his work that he added up to an elegant riddle.

title: EUROPEAN UNION: DE BEERS INQUIRY

The commission cited two concerns: that De Beers might use the venture to increase its already dominant hold on the world diamond market and that it might favor those middlemen, known as sightholders, who would buy De Beers rough diamonds and then supply cut diamonds to the venture over those who supply cut diamonds to competing retailers. title: BRITAIN: RATE DISCUSSIONS
description: The minutes from the Bank of England's interest rate meeting earlier this month showed that members of the monetary policy committee unanimously agreed that an interest rate reduction was necessary to offset a broad economic slowdown, but differed over the size of the reduction. Six members of the committee voted to cut the benchmark rate a quarter percentage point, while three opted for a half-point cut. The decision has led analysts to suggest that the central bank may cut rates further in coming months, especially if interest rates continue to remain below a government target. Suzanne Kapner

title: Where Gropius Slept and Pei Housesat
description: Chrome banisters, glass blocks and horizontal windows. Industrial materials. It all seems familiar now, but in 1938, when Walter Gropius built his severe International Style house (below) in Lincoln, Mass., it was a revelation to his students at Harvard, who included Philip Johnson and I. M. Pei. In fact, Mr. Pei and his family housesat for Gropius one summer, and when Mr. Pei taught at Harvard, he led his students through Gropius's house. Gropius founded the Bauhaus design school in Germany in 1919. Fleeing the country, he became a professor at the Harvard Graduate School of Design in 1937 and lived in Lincoln, 30 miles from Boston, until his death in 1969. Gropius House will reopen on Saturday after four years of restoration. The replanted orchard and meadow follow Gropius's original design. Weekends until June, then Wednesday through Sunday. Admission, $10. (781) 259-8098. CAMERON SMITH

A Lucent spokeswoman said the lawsuit was ''without an ounce of merit.'' Lucent had provided Winstar with about $700 million of credit to buy its products as part of Lucent's largest vendor-financing deal, valued at $2 billion. Simon Romero

title: CELESTICA PROFIT BEATS ESTIMATES
description: The Toronto-based Celestica Inc., the world's third-largest contract manufacturer of electronic components, reported a 95 percent increase in first-quarter profit yesterday, slightly beating analysts' expectations. But because of a drop in orders from its customers -- about 40 companies, including I.B.M., Motorola and Hewlett-Packard -- Celestica said it would eliminate about 3,000 jobs, representing 10 percent of its global work force, in the second quarter. First-quarter profit was $87.3 million, or 39 cents a share, on revenue of $2.69 billion, up 67 percent from a year earlier. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had forecast profit of 38 cents a share. The company said it expected second-quarter profit of 40 to 42 cents a share, but backed off its full-year forecast of at least $2.05 a share, citing ''continuing caution'' among its customers. Celestica shares rose $9.67, or 29 percent, to $43. Timothy Pritchard

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COX, BERT GEORGE ''B.G.''
description: COX-Bert George ''B.G.'' Cox of Rye, New York and Boca Grande, Florida died on Monday, April 16, 2001 in Rye. His death resulted from complications due to a stroke. He was 80 years old. Mr. Cox was with The Joseph & Feiss Company, Inc., America's oldest clothing manufacturer and a former division of the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation in New York and Cleveland for 45 years serving in numerous offices including President from 1970. He was Chairman from 1986-1990 after purchasing the company from PVH and later selling it to Hugo Boss. He was a two-time president of the Clothing Manufacturer's Association of America (1983-1985, 1988-1990) and president of the Men's Fashion Association from 1980-1982. In 1979, Mr. Cox represented the clothing industry as part of a U.S. trade mission in Cairo, Egypt. He began his industry career in 1946 as an assistant buyer for the May Co. in Denver, Colorado. Mr. Cox was a naval fighter pilot serving in World War II from 1942-1946 reaching the rank of Lieutenant Commander. He received the Distinguished Flying Cross medal in 1946. He served on the Bennington, Shangri-La, and Yorktown aircraft carriers. Prior to enlisting, he was an agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Mr. Cox was born on October 18, 1920 in Billings, Montana. He graduated from the University of Oregon in 1946 earning BS degree in Business. He was a member of the Phi Gamma Delta fraternity. He was a member of The Apawamis Club and American Yacht Club, both of Rye. He was also a member of the Boca Grande Club and Boca Bay Pass Club, both of Boca Grande, Fl. A resident of Rye for the past 40 years, he is survived by his wife of 52 years, Leone Larsen Cox; two daughters, Anne Zahringer of New York, N.Y., Karen Mandy of Rye; a son Robert H. of Stamford, CT and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held for B.G. Cox on Friday, April 20th at the Rye Presbyterian Church. Boston Post Road in Rye at 10:30 in the morning. In lieu of flowers, friends may send memorial donations to The Emergency Care Pavilion of New York United Hospital Medical Center (N.Y.U.H.M.C.), 406 Boston Post Road, Port Chester, NY 10573

title: Metro Business Briefing; NEW NUMBERS IN NEW JERSEY
description: Increased telecommunications in northern New Jersey have resulted in the creation of three more area codes. Starting July 1, new numbers assigned to geographic calling areas now served by the 201, 973 and 732 codes will start with 551, 356 and 848 respectively, the North American Numbering Plan Administration, the agency that creates new area codes, announced this week. In a so-called overlay plan approved by the State Board of Public Utilities last month, existing telephones, fax machines and computer dial-up networks will keep their current area codes. But users of the new numbers will have to dial their area code plus 1 for all calls, even local, meaning 10-digit dialing at all times. A grace period allowing callers to disregard the new area codes will be in effect from July 1 to Dec. 1. Recorded messages will then begin telling callers to hang up and dial using the proper area code.

title: The Work of a Hemisphere
description: Working with our friends in the Americas is one of the first and highest priorities of President Bush's administration. If our neighbors are democratic and law-abiding, open to trade, and willing to cooperate with us on improving the environment, fighting drugs and stopping disease, we can make a vital difference in the life of every American. With this in mind, President Bush has already started to bolster our relationships in this hemisphere. He has met with the leaders of Canada, Mexico, Colombia, El Salvador, Brazil and Chile and meets today with Fernando de la Ra, president of Argentina. Tomorrow, when he travels to Canada to attend the Third Summit of the Americas -- a gathering of 34 democratically elected heads of state -- he will promote this vision of a better life for all who live in the region.

title: Survive and Advance
description: A master of angles and with the ability to cross over against any poor soul he wants to, Allen Iverson is still the most compelling and dynamic player who will suit up this postseason. But the 6-foot Philadelphia guard would go home early without protection from the long arm of the law: 7-2 Dikembe Mutombo. Whether it is Alonzo Mourning in Miami, Tim Duncan and David Robinson in San Antonio or Shaquille O'Neal in Los Angeles, if you want to advance to the conference finals, you need a bona fide big man. Chris Webber's Kings and Ray Allen's Bucks have a decent shot and the Dallas Mavericks will provide international flavor and entertainment as long as they last. But in the finals, Shaq and Kobe, the two best players in the league at their respective positions, claw and scratch their way past Pat Riley's latest collection of bruisers. title: SECURITY GROUP TO SELL SERVICES
description: The CERT Coordination Center at Carnegie Mellon University said it would begin selling its computer security warnings to private clients. Since 1988, CERT, the taxpayer-financed computer security organization formerly known as the Computer Emergency Response Team, has issued warnings on viruses and security attacks to government agencies. Now CERT has formed the Internet Security Alliance to offer businesses immediate access to those warnings as well. Membership in the alliance costs $2,500 to $75,000, depending on size and participation level. CERT's current $3.5 million in financing comes from the government, most of it from the Defense Department. The new arrangement will help CERT cope with the heavy demand for its services, said Richard Pethia, its director. ''The relationship will allow us to grow the staff a little so that we'll be able to produce more information for everybody,'' he said.

title: In the Accents of Thomas Hardy, a Tale of the Gold-Hungry Old West

In ''The Claim,'' a languorously muted, occasionally magnificent film inspired by Thomas Hardy's novel ''The Mayor of Casterbridge,'' the English director Michael Winterbottom makes that frontier the backdrop for a story about the tragic fall of a self-styled king.
