title: KIMBALL SAYS IT HAS LAID OFF 9 PERCENT OF ITS WORKERS
description: Kimball International, which makes office furniture and electronic components for products like antilock brakes and insulin-measuring devices, laid off 1,025 workers, or 9 percent of its staff, as sales decreased in some segments. The job cuts occurred between Jan. 1 and April 18 throughout the company, said the chief financial officer, Robert F. Schneider. More cuts are possible if sales continue to decline, Mr. Schneider said. Kimball said overall sales for the third quarter ended March 31 rose 1 percent, to $312.7 million from $309.5 million. Excluding acquisitions, sales declined in the furniture and cabinet, and contract electronics-assembly segments, the company said.

title: A Genius Pulled Apart By Both Love and Chess
description: ''The Luzhin Defense'' takes place in what looks, at first glance, like familiar movie territory. The chugging locomotive, the cloche hats and elegant summer suits, the picturesque limestone villa all denote Europe between the world wars. But the literary source of Marleen Gorris's elegant, tenderhearted film is not Waugh or Maugham but Nabokov; the lush scenery and period costumes are not vehicles of historical reckoning or social observation but rather the scaffolding for a delicate fable about memory, devotion and the vulnerability of genius in a cruelly ordinary world.

title: WEB SITE OPERATORS FINED
description: Three online companies that operate child-oriented Web sites will pay a total of $100,000 in civil penalties to the Federal Trade Commission to settle charges they violated a year-old law protecting children's online privacy, the F.T.C. said yesterday. Monarch Services Inc. and Girls Life Inc., operators of www.girlslife.com; Bigmailbox.com Inc., operator of www.bigmailbox.com; and Looksmart Ltd., operator of www.insidetheweb.com, illegally collected personally identifying information from children under 13 without parental consent in violation of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act. These are the first civil penalty cases the commission has brought under the law. Also yesterday, the Center for Media Education in Washington issued a report that found that the law had changed the way that many -- but not all -- Web sites do business. ''This new law has already begun to correct some of the most egregious marketing practices on the Web that threatened children's privacy,'' said Kathryn Montgomery, the group's president. But she added, ''More effective education and stronger enforcement will be necessary to ensure that this law is fully effective.'' John Schwartz (NYT)

title: Wanting to Be Joey Ramone
description: With a body shaped like a Chinese eggplant, eyes shrouded in sunglasses, mop-like hair and a leather jacket that intimidated no one, lacking both a chin and, apparently, the ability to form hard consonants, Joey Ramone might have seemed an unlikely person to front a rock 'n' roll band, let alone to galvanize a stylistic revolution. It was as if Ringo had been allowed to front the Beatles, and the Beatles had been permitted to succeed without a single song actually breaking through on the charts. In the mid-70's, when the Ramones first appeared, the band might have seemed a bit of a practical joke, and in many ways that's what it was: exactly the practical joke needed to slash rock music back to its essential mixture of rebellion, frenzy and goofy joy, all in songs lasting less than three minutes, sometimes less than two.

title: INDIA: BROKERAGE FIRM BARRED
description: A Credit Suisse Group unit was barred from trading stocks in India, the first such ban on a foreign brokerage firm, after reports linked it to an insider-trading scandal. The ban on Credit Suisse (India) Securities Ltd. and two local brokerage firms will remain in force ''until further notice,'' said L. K. Singhvi, senior executive director of the Securities and Exchange Board of India. The action, which affects Credit Suisse's 39-person India unit, came after a report by the regulator linked the company to Ketan Parekh, a broker now in judicial custody on suspicion of having borrowed 8.4 billion rupees ($179 million) against illicit bank drafts, The Economic Times reported.

title: A Return to the Junction Of Art and Commerce
description: Jean-Lon Grme was no Ingres, but he made some very seductive paintings. With glinting jewellike colors, transparently glassy surfaces and magic, near-photographic realism, his works depict exotic, often titillating visions of distant places, mythic times, powerful men and beautiful women. Even if we think we should know better than to be taken in by such polished sexist and ethnocentric confections, they are hard to resist.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits yesterday about the next generation of Microsoft Windows referred incorrectly to statistics from an industry analyst on the use of various existing versions. The figures were percentages of all Windows-based personal computers in use last year, not those shipped last year.

title: Metro Business Briefing; ECONOMY FARING WELL
description: New York's economy is cooling off a little, but growth in the state and the city remains far stronger than the national average, according to data released yesterday by the New York State Department of Labor. The number of private-sector jobs in the state hit a record 7,264,000 in March, an increase of 1.9 percent over the past 12 months. While that is slower than the 2.9 percent growth rate hit last September, it is far above the 1.1 percent national average for March. Unemployment for the entire state fell to 4 percent from 4.3 percent, and for the first time in a decade is well below the national rate of 4.3 percent. The rate in New York City was 5.1 percent, the same as in January. Private-sector jobs grew by 2.4 percent in the city but still slipped to the lowest level in more than three years. Leslie Eaton

title: New Video Releases
description: Billy Elliot

title: Identity Molded by Czech History and Harmony
description: Turn the pages of a Vienna telephone book and you will sense how close Czech art came to disappearing into the jaws of German culture. For oddly enough, the Havliceks, Prohaskas, Hrbaks or Halases that you find are names typical to native Viennese: loyal citizens whose tastes run to Schiller and Haydn. Unlike their dim ancestors, they speak not a word of Cesky and to this day find the music of Dvorak charming but nave and unfinished.

title: A Scam That'll Knock 'Em Dead
description: HOW do you single out highlights in a bonfire? Everybody who sees ''The Producers'' -- and that should be as close to everybody as the St. James Theater allows -- is going to be hard-pressed to choose one favorite bit from the sublimely ridiculous spectacle that opened last night.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 10.

title: Collins Would Love to Be Jordan's Coach Again
description: Michael Jordan hired a new coach today, adding kindling to the speculation that sometime before the start of next season, Jordan, the president of basketball operations for the Washington Wizards, will bring in a new player: a 38-year-old bald guy with a fistful of gaudy championship rings, one Michael Jeffrey Jordan.

title: KOREAN OFFICIAL SAYS G.M. IS NEGOTIATING DAEWOO TERMS
description: General Motors is negotiating for tax breaks and support from the government against labor problems as key provisions for a takeover of the bankrupt Daewoo Motor Company, according to Jung Keun Young, governor of the government-owned Korea Development Bank. Mr. Jung, testifying before a committee of the National Assembly, said an offer from General Motors was imminent. G.M. was expected to suggest a price of nearly $1 billion, covering Daewoo's three major manufacturing sites. Daewoo, meanwhile, said that its net loss last year totaled $10.4 billion, three times what it lost in 1999. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: 'Hit Them Hard!' -- 'The Brazilian Fighter Squadron in World War II'
description: Directed by Erik de Castro

title: EUROPEAN UNION: INFLATION STEADY
description: Annual inflation in the 12-member euro zone was 2.6 percent in March, the European Union's statistical office, Eurostat, said. It was the same level as in February, but up from 2.4 percent in January. The core rate, excluding energy, food, alcohol and tobacco, rose to 1.8 percent from 1.7 percent in February. The highest inflation levels were in Portugal at 5.1 percent; the Netherlands, 4.9 percent; and Ireland, 4.1 percent. The lowest levels were France at 1.4 percent and Austria at 1.9 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHBERG, ALAN
description: HOCHBERG-Alan. The partners and staff of Lipsky, Goodkin & Company, PC, deeply mourn the passing of our client and admired friend of many years. This compassionate man abundantly showered his love, understanding and consideration to his family, employees and friends. Alan was a man who enjoyed the excitement of life. To his wife Lucille, his children Robert, David, Shari, Marsha and Howard, and his grandchildren, Allie and Nicki, our heartfelt condolences.

title: Four Who Are One, Togetherness to a Fare-Thee-Well
description: The Brentano String Quartet, which played for the Chamber Music Society at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night, is something special. These are musicians who take the great priority of chamber performance -- that of playing not so much out to the audience as in to one another, and to the music -- to an exquisite extreme. Their musicmaking is private, delicate and fresh, but by its very intimacy and importance it seizes attention, just as in speech a floated suggestion or a quiet confession may strike far more deeply than a resolute pronouncement.

title: So When Does It Start Getting Late?
description: The last awful loss had been over for more than an hour as Mike Piazza neatly folded his blue undershirts and placed them inside a duffel bag. He was tired of reviewing Steve Trachsel's hideous outing against the Expos and weary of trying to explain why the Mets have generated as much offense as a tee-ball team lately because he had done that for almost a half-hour. So Piazza talked about everything else on a vacant Wednesday afternoon.

title: Serving the Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Fresh, Free and Nimble In an Ambitious Debut
description: It was a pleasure to get to know Ballet Memphis, which made its New York debut on Wednesday night at the Kaye Playhouse. Its dancers looked young and fresh and their performance had an unforced exuberance. The organization, directed by Dorothy Gunther Pugh, is an outgrowth of a student group founded in 1975 that turned professional a decade later. Its artistically enterprising program featured unfamiliar works.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINOWITZ, SADIE
description: MINOWITZ-Sadie. Passed peacefully at age 87 on April 18, 2001. Devoted daughter of the late Abraham and Rebecca. Loving sister of the late Meyer, Edward and Michael. Survived by caring nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Interment at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Victims' Race Affects Decisions On Killers' Sentence, Study Finds
description: A study of death penalty cases in North Carolina in the 1990's has found that the odds of getting a death sentence increased three and a half times if the victim was white rather than black.

title: Urged by Distraught Victims, Judge Sends Fake Heir to Prison
description: Stripped of his finery and deceptions, a con man who passed himself off as the heir to a billion-dollar family trust admitted today that he owned nothing more valuable than the sports jacket he was wearing.

title: Hard-Hitting Truths To Pass On to Vick
description: This week the small but growing club of black National Football League quarterbacks will add another member, Michael Vick, the explosive player from Virginia Tech. He will be called a potential star, applauded for being a great athlete and hailed as the savior of the San Diego Chargers, the team that holds the first pick in the N.F.L. draft and that is expected, after much internal debate, to select him tomorrow.

description: MINTZER-Sylvia. My beloved Mother, you are always in my heart, always missed. Freya

title: Manifest Destiny: Moving West With Maps and Entertainment
description: Real estate and entertainment. It's hard to think of the United States without them. They are among the most prominent obsessions of the moment, and it doesn't require nicer-sounding synonyms -- like property and culture or homeland and civilization -- to realize that they are deeply embedded in the nation's psyche and history.

title: Chinese Raid Defiant Village, Killing 2, Amid Rural Unrest
description: Before dawn last Sunday, more than 600 police and paramilitary troops stormed this village in southern China and opened fire on a gathering crowd of unarmed farmers, killing 2 and wounding at least 18, witnesses and local officials say.

description: Consolidated Edison Inc. said yesterday that first-quarter profits fell 4.8 percent after an electricity rate cut. Net income fell to $179.1 million, or 84 cents a share, from $188.1 million a year ago, the company said. Revenue rose 25 percent, to $2.88 billion. The company reiterated its 2001 per-share profit forecast of $3.20 to $3.30.

title: Smaller Bookstores End Court Struggle Against Two Chains
description: The trade group for the nation's independent bookstores, battling competition from national chains, suffered a major defeat in court yesterday. In a surprising turnaround, the trade group settled a closely watched antitrust suit against two national chains for a payment of even less than the group's legal fees.

description: Lowits, a family-owned upscale men's clothing store in downtown Hackensack, N.J., will close tomorrow after 75 years in business. David Linden, whose family has owned the store since the 1950's, said he was closing the store because of ''a changing retail climate.''

title: Foreign Affairs; To Tell the Truth
description: Listening to Secretary of State Colin Powell talk about the Middle East lately has become a lot like listening to an umpire calling balls and strikes. One moment he says the Palestinians are being ''provocative'' for launching mortars on Israel. Then he condemns Hezbollah for raids on the Israeli border. Then he criticizes Israel for using ''excessive and disproportionate'' force in response to Palestinian violence. It's a lot like watching an umpire -- with only one difference. He's calling balls and strikes in a game with no rules.

title: The Summit of the Americas
description: President Bush will make his first important appearance at an international gathering this weekend, at the Summit of the Americas in Quebec, an assemblage of 34 hemispheric heads of state. No other president entered office having emphasized the importance of ties with Latin America to the extent that Mr. Bush did on the campaign trail. His election has therefore raised expectations throughout a continent that often felt neglected by the Clinton administration. Mr. Bush's principal aim at this meeting is to reaffirm the worthy goal of achieving a Free Trade Area of the Americas by the year 2005.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, MILTON
description: LEVIN-Milton. The firm of Max Gruber Associates mourns the passing of our esteemed senior member, Milton Levin, who along with his partner, Maurice D. Gruber, developed much of the land on Long Island. For the past 55 years they were developers, builders and owners of properties such as Westbury Music Fair. Together they assembled land for builders including Levitt and Sons, builders of Levittown and others. Mr. Levin's keen wit marked by frequent puns, sound judgment and striking ability to close a deal will be missed. Mr. Levin's son, James P. Levin, has also been an important part of the firm for the past 27 years and will carry the firm forward along with Philip Gruber. Mr. Levin was an active contributor to charities such as UJA-Federation and Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University where he was a founder and honorary member of the Board of Overseers. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Fanny, and children, James Levin and Gene Heller, and grandchildren, Michael Heller, Kenneth Heller, Joanna Levin Karp, Stephanie Levin and Alexander Levin. Maurice Gruber, Principal Philip Gruber and Nathaniel Finkelstein

description: Craft is a work-ethic restaurant. As the name artfully, or craftily, suggests, the cooking concentrates on fundamentals, with ingredients subjected to the bare minimum of manipulation. title: Course Correction on Redistricting
description: As redistricting gets under way, the Supreme Court this week used a long-running squabble about the contours of a heavily black North Carolina Congressional district to provide some guidance about efforts to enhance the voting power of racial minorities. The ruling is far from the strong affirmation of the 1965 Voting Rights Act that the country needs, but at least it interrupted the flow of recent rulings that invalidated efforts to improve minority voting power. In a critical 5-to-4 decision written by Justice Stephen Breyer, the court upheld the constitutionality of North Carolina's consolidation of black voters to create a near-majority black district. The ruling conveyed to state legislatures the message that race can continue to be a legitimate consideration in redistricting as long as it is not the ''dominant and controlling'' one.

title: In Scarsdale, Debate on Tests Masks Much Bigger Issues
description: On the surface, the issue is testing. That is, just how much time schools here should spend preparing for state tests and even whether students should take them.

title: EMC REPORTS SALES AND PROFIT GAINS
description: EMC, which makes data storage equipment for big corporate computer systems, said yesterday that its sales were up 29 percent in the first quarter from a year earlier, to $2.3 billion. Its profits increased 20 percent, to $399 million. The report matched last week's announcement of the company's preliminary results, which were lower than analysts had expected. EMC earned 18 cents a share, compared with the 20 cents analysts had been expecting. Speaking with analysts, the company's chairman, Michael C. Ruettgers, presented an upbeat forecast, suggesting that the sharp decline in corporate computer purchases may be bottoming out. Thomas Kraemer, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, disagreed. ''The survey work we have done suggests that the spending environment will continue to deteriorate,'' Mr. Kraemer said. Saul Hansell (NYT)

description: STEIN-Bessie. title: RULING LETS IVAX CONTINUE SELLING GENERIC CANCER DRUG
description: The Ivax Corporation said yesterday that a federal judge had allowed the company to keep selling a generic version of the cancer drug Taxol, rebuffing a rival company for the second time since October. The ruling by Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly of United States District Court in Washington is a setback for American BioScience, which asked the judge to order federal regulators to revoke the generic drug's approval. The two companies, along with the maker of Taxol, Bristol-Myers Squibb, are waging a multifaceted legal fight over a treatment that had sales of more than $1.5 billion last year.

title: For an Old Flag, A New Rationale
description: Can you imagine, in the year 2001, a state actually voting to have a Confederate symbol as part of its flag? Once again, Mississippi performs its national service as scapegoat. People across America, no matter how bad racial problems are in their localities, can once again breathe a sigh of relief and say, ''Look at how horrible those people in Mississippi are!''

description: The Police Department yesterday overhauled the management of the New York City Police Museum in Lower Manhattan, reassigning its executive director and cutting the number of officers working there in half after an investigation into suspected improprieties at the institution.

description: ''The Producers,'' the Mel Brooks musical that opened on Thursday, broke a Broadway box office record yesterday, selling more than $3 million worth of tickets in a single day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTRAUB, MORRIS
description: WEINTRAUB-Morris. Of Weston, CT., and Palm Beach, FL, passed away April 18, 2001. He is survived by his loving wife Audrey, his adored son Robert and dear granddaughters Erin and Kira, his brother Jack and many nephews and nieces. Morris was retired president of National Cleaning Contractors, Inc., a past president of Rolling Hills Country Club, Wilton, CT, and a member of Banyan Country Club of West Palm Beach, FL. He was active in many philanthropic organizations and has been honored by the United Jewish Appeal for his years of service on behalf of Israel. He was truly loved and respected by his many friends and his loss will be felt by all. Graveside services will be held Sunday at 11:00 AM in Independent Hebrew Society Cemetery, Richards Avenue, Norwalk, CT. For details contact Collins Funeral Home, Norwalk, CT. 1-203-866-0747.

Aarones's place as Tiffeny Milbrett's partner on attack will be taken by Tammy Pearman, primarily an attacking midfielder.

description: On the eve of the National Basketball Association playoffs, the Knicks have been forced to deal with an unexpected distraction -- comments made by Charlie Ward, and to a lesser extent by Allan Houston, that have drawn the ire of the Anti-Defamation League.

description: Officials struggled yesterday to increase the capacity of an online database that tracks immigrants who were brought into the United States through Ellis Island after the Web site was deluged with visitors.

description: Challenging the conventional wisdom that New Yorkers will face higher electricity prices this summer, the chairman of Consolidated Edison predicted yesterday that prices for power would hold steady.

description: His admirers say they are impressed that President Bush is secure enough to surround himself with capable advisers. His detractors say he is so unprepared that he has no choice but to lean heavily on others.

Beloved husband of Cecile. Loving father of Richard, Paula and Jane. Cherished grandfather of Mark, Caryn and Nancy. Services will be held at 12 Noon, April 22 at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills. Contributions may be made in his name at the Forest Hills Jewish Center.

title: SINGAPORE: LOSS AT CHIP MAKER
description: Chartered Semiconductor Manufacturing of Singapore, the world's third-largest chip subcontractor, said it lost $30.8 million in the first three months of 2001 amid shrinking orders that would probably push it farther into the red this quarter. Chartered Semiconductor makes chips under contract for companies like Ericsson, Conexant and Broadcom, all of which are suffering from a slowdown in demand for communications equipment. First-quarter sales fell 13 percent, to $206.7 million. The company's loss contrasted with a profit of nearly $40 million in the first quarter of 2000, but was better than analysts had predicted.

title: Nokia's Earnings Meet Expectations, While Ericsson Disappoints
description: Demonstrating that it can outstrip rivals even as a broad slowdown batters the mobile phone industry, Nokia of Finland reported first-quarter earnings today that put it on a very short list: technology companies that have not disappointed investors.

title: CANADA: INFLATION FALLS
description: Canada's annual inflation rate fell for a fourth consecutive month, dropping to 2.5 percent in March from 2.9 percent in February. Excluding energy and food costs, core inflation rose at a1.7 percent annual rate last month, compared with 2 percent in February, and was lower than economists had expected. Food, rather than energy, has been mainly responsible for pushing the consumer price index higher -- a typical trend during the winter months. With little inflationary pressure, further cuts in interest rates to stimulate a cooling economy are expected from the Bank of Canada. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: On Native Land, a Fear of Free Trade
description: All this week, the Mohawks of Akwesasne used provisions of the United States' oldest major international trade agreement -- the Jay Treaty of 1794 -- in reacting to America's newest trade effort, the Free Trade Area of the Americas agreement currently being negotiated, and fiercely protested, in Quebec City. As Canadian officials detained protesters flying in from North and South America, busloads trekked along New York State Route 37 to the St. Regis Mohawk Indian Reservation, or what Mohawks call The Land Where the Partridge Drums.

title: Astros 10, Cardinals 1
description: HOUSTON (AP) -- Moises Alou went 2-for-2 with his wishes in his first start of the season Friday night.

description: Campaign records show that a report released Thursday on spending in last year's legislative elections overstated spending on behalf of Republican State Senate candidates by about $2.3 million. Republicans said they were angered by the incorrect figures in the report.

description: When William J. Bratton walked into police headquarters here this week, Henry Rivas, the director of the Caracas Metropolitan Police, was waiting at the door for him. In a nearby conference room, division heads and precinct chiefs of the 8,000-member force had assembled for a strategy session with the former New York City police commissioner.

description: The composer Peter Lieberson has won wide respect for the intellectual rigor of his music. But there are other qualities in his works as well: wistful lyricism, pensive spirituality and rhythmic spunkiness of a kind that you might expect from an American baby boomer.

description: A doctor who stabbed a pregnant nurse in the Bronx with a syringe that contained an abortion-inducing drug was sentenced yesterday to two years in state prison for the attack, the authorities said.

description: Next month, the United States will resume executing federal prisoners, ending a four-decade hiatus, putting to death Timothy J. McVeigh, the man convicted of mass murder in bombing the Oklahoma City Federal Building six years ago.

description: LEVY-Isadore. Of Aventura, FL & Long Beach, NY. Passed away April 17. Beloved husband of Rosalind. Adored father of Richard (George Ann) and Bruce (Linda), and adoring grandfather of Emily, Kevin and Ben. Also survived by sister Blanche Tempkin and an extended family including many nieces, nephews and cousins. A loving, kind, charitable, generous and gentle man. A Funeral Service at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Rockville Centre, NY on Sunday, April 22 at 10AM. title: A Legionnaire, She Was Never Timid In Amour or War
description: As a well-bred Englishwoman educated in the nuances of understatement, Susan Travers still seems unimpressed that she is the only woman ever to join the French Foreign Legion. She had spent World War II as a volunteer driver with Free French legionnaires who were fighting in North Africa and Europe. But in the summer of 1945, she faced demobilization and did not relish the prospect.

title: BRITAIN: PRUDENTIAL'S SALES INCREASE
description: Buoyed by income from acquisitions in Asia, Prudential P.L.C., which has bid to buy the American General Corporation, said first-quarter sales rose 29 percent, to $920 million. The figure is calculated on an industry standard reflecting regular premium sales and 10 percent of sales with a single premium payment. Asia, where the company has made deals in 11 countries, accounted for 40 percent of the sales. The company, the second-biggest life insurer in Britain, also said its $20 billion bid for American General was still on the table, despite a higher offer from the American International Group. Prudential's shares, which have underperformed the insurance sector, rose by 3.6 percent, to 800 pence.

title: Price Caps for California Power
description: California's energy crisis is beginning to yield some useful responses from politicians who have heretofore preferred posturing to policy-making. Gov. Gray Davis, after months of waffling, has authorized his regulators to begin charging consumers fair prices for the energy they use. Mr. Davis and the Legislature have also put in place an aggressive program of energy conservation and taken steps to streamline California's cumbersome siting process to speed the construction of new power plants. All these strategies are aimed at eventually curing the imbalance between supply and demand that lies at the root of the crisis.

title: Incentives Offer On Ford Explorer
description: The completely redesigned 2002 Ford Explorer has been on sale only a month, and Ford Motor is already offering discounted lease rates and rebates for customers who own an earlier Explorer model.

title: For Protesters at Yale, A Who's Who Audience
description: In recognition of Yale University's 300th anniversary, many of its most famous alumni have returned to campus this weekend to participate in a series of private seminars and lectures on the school's impact on world culture and politics.

title: Abbott Labs Setting Aside $344 Million to Settle a Lawsuit
description: Abbott Laboratories said yesterday that it was setting aside about $344 million to settle accusations raised by the Justice Department in an investigation into the marketing of a popular prostate cancer drug.

title: Democratic Leader Leaps to Hevesi's Defense

Hevesi as he runs for mayor. Mr. Rangel invited Mr. Hevesi to his office in Harlem, where, in front of television cameras, he repeatedly praised him for criticizing Police Department practices.

title: Rutgers's McMahon To Realize Dream
description: Mike McMahon will be far from the limousines and the limelight that celebrate the National Football League draft debutants today. McMahon, who will be at his home near Pittsburgh, is an intriguing oddity of this draft: a player with a wrong-side-of-the-tracks college pedigree whose stock has skyrocketed, vaulting him from an also-ran to perhaps a second-round draft pick.

title: BRAZIL: MINING ACQUISITION
description: Consolidating its position as the world's largest iron ore miner, Cia Vale do Rio Doce of Brazil, acquired half of the local miner Caemi Mineracao e Metalurgia S.A. from the Japanese trading company Mitsui & Company for $280 million. The deal, which left Vale do Rio Doce and Mitsui each with 50 percent of the miner, thwarted an effort by the Australian miner BHP Ltd. to buy a controlling stake in Caemi, the world's fourth-largest iron mining company. Regulators must still approve the deal, which could generate opposition in Europe, where Brazil supplies more than half of the iron ore. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the signing of a lease for former President Bill Clinton's offices in Harlem gave an incorrect total from the General Services Administration for the annual federal payment to the landlord. It will be $346,128, not $261,450. Details appear today in an article on Page B4.

title: Interest Groups Set for Battle On a Supreme Court Vacancy
description: They are mobilizing troops, developing battle plans and moving their supporters to a state of high alert. Interest groups on the left and the right are busily preparing for the possibility of a Supreme Court vacancy, perhaps as early as summer, and what many predict will be a brutal political war.

title: Swiss Master Discovers a Creative Defense
description: Most of the great players of the last half century have come from the three countries that have dominated the world championship scene: the United States, Italy and France. A few other countries have been able to challenge effectively because they had one brilliant player who provided leadership.

title: Scientists Find Way to Gauge Earth's Glow
description: The eerie glow of earthshine -- sunlight bouncing off Earth and striking the Moon -- makes the dark part of the Moon's disk just barely visible to the naked eye. Now a team of astronomers and physicists has done what the eye cannot. They have detected slight variations in the glow, in effect, variations in how much sunlight Earth reflects hour by hour, season to season and year to year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGEE, MARIE E.
description: MAGEE-Marie E., 75. Of St. Petersburg, FL died April 18, 2001 at her residence. She was born in Baltimore, Maryland and moved to St. Petersburg in 1989. She was an attorney and judge in New York City, practicing law from 1942 to 1989 working with EEOC. She was a 1949 graduate of Fordham University Law School, a member of the Republican Club & a member of St. John's Catholic Church. She is survived by two sisters, Joan M,. Sina of St. Pete Beach and M. Patricia Magee of St. Petersburg, FL. Brett Funeral Home & Cremation Services.

He was eager to return to playing baseball after spending 11 days with his ill father and, unlike his teammates, he had not returned to New York at 5 a.m. after a draining 17-inning game in Toronto. Williams might have had more sleep than any other Yankee.

title: Tale of Lust and Violence, So Tastefully Told
description: With sex, violence and melodrama, the rape of Lucretia seems a natural subject for an opera. The protagonists of this Roman legend are Lucretia, the only virtuous woman in Rome; the sexually omnivorous Etruscan prince Tarquinius, who rapes her; and her noble husband, Collatinus, whose forgiveness cannot keep his dishonored wife from killing herself.

title: GERMANY: UTILITY DISPUTE SETTLED
description: The German utility E.ON A.G. said it had settled a dispute with the Mirant Corporation of Atlanta that will allow it to sell its 49 percent stake in Bewag A.G. once lawmakers back the plan. It also said it expected clearance to sell its stake in two eastern German utilities within weeks as it sells assets in its home country and pursues a strategy of its chief executive, Ulrich Hartmann, to become a major international utility company.

title: BUSH WILL PRESS FREE-TRADE ISSUE AT QUEBEC TALKS
description: President Bush arrived at his first summit meeting today declaring that he would make the expansion of economic and political ties with Latin America his first foreign policy priority.

title: Federal Judge Halts Opening Of Slag Plant
description: A federal judge has blocked the opening of a cement additive plant in a poor black neighborhood in Camden, N.J., a ruling that legal experts said was the first time an environmental agency that issues permits had been found in violation of civil rights law.

title: A Pantheon of Artists Rescued From Hitler
description: Oskar Schindler became Liam Neeson in an Oscar-winning Steven Spielberg movie in 1993. Raoul Wallenberg was played by Richard Chamberlain in an Emmy-nominated 1985 television film. Now Varian Fry, their American counterpart, is embodied by William Hurt in a Showtime film that is intelligent if not gripping.

description: April 21, 2001

title: HIGH AND LOW: A MEDLEY
description: Music for film has traditionally been a poor cousin of the classics. But as yet another classical composer wins an Oscar -- this year, Tan Dun for ''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon'' -- it is becoming clear that for better or worse, the distinctions between soundtracks and symphonies are crumbling. By David Schiff, in Arts & Leisure.

title: Gospel Message, Rap Style; To a Brooklyn Preacher, Good Works Yield a Fortune
description: The screams and wails mingled with shouts of Jesus' name, echoing from inside the brick walls of a former toy factory in the East New York section of Brooklyn. Sweat rolled down the faces of some 800 young black men and women, many keening back and forth, clutching the back of chairs, gripping Bibles, and shouting ''Amen! Amen! Amen!'' like sinking swimmers in a rip tide.

title: Anthropology's Alternative Radical
description: Among students at Columbia University, Michael Taussig has a glamorous reputation. An anthropologist who specializes in South America, he has hung out with shamans and tripped on yage, a potent hallucinogen, dozens of times. He keeps an enormous rainbow-colored hammock in his campus office. And his lectures are famous for their dramatic flourishes; he once gave a talk with his head in a paper bag (a homage to a Dadaist artist). Not surprisingly, his classes are always filled to capacity. ''He's like a rock star,'' said one graduate student in anthropology. ''He's the professor that all the students think is cool.''

title: Sandbags in Place, a Town Waits for the River to Have Its Way
description: As floodwaters rise among this tiny stretch of houses along the Mississippi River, time seems to stand still.

title: FRANCE: SAGEM'S SALES FALL
description: The French maker of telecommunications, military and automobile products, Sagem S.A., said first-quarter revenue fell 22 percent because it sold fewer mobile phones. Sales at the Paris-based company fell to 759.5 million euros ($681 million) from 979.9 million euros a year earlier. Revenue for the communications unit fell 45 percent, to 322.2 million euros, while sales at Sagem's military and automobile divisions gained. The company's shares fell 8 percent.

title: WINSTAR BANKRUPTCY MAY HURT A WIRELESS EXPANSION
description: The Williams Communications Group said the Chapter 11 bankruptcy by Winstar Communications Inc. might affect Williams's plans to expand its own wireless capacity. Williams, a fiber optic network provider, said that because of Winstar's bankruptcy filing, a network of 270 antenna sites to be built by Winstar Wireless might not be completed, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Williams, based in Tulsa, Okla., had paid Winstar $300 million for the use of 200 completed antenna sites, as of March 31, with another $100 million owed on completion of the other 70, the filing said.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES

title: U.S. Visa for Ex-Taiwan Leader Risks Irritating China More

title: Nordic Tracks
description: Fifteen, twenty minutes north of Reykjavik, along the coastal Ring Road that circumscribes the whole of Iceland, the last of several small, suburban developments gives way to an elemental vastness just this side of the ineffable. Late one afternoon in mid-February, a grayish sea joined a low, leaden sky at no point I could confidently discern. To the inland side, snow-peaked mountain ridges, hewn and crevassed by glaciation, alternated in the mist with mournful expanses of rimy moorland. There were no trees, no birds, no color, few signs of habitation, really. Wind blew. Flurries squalled. Volcanic boulders rested disconsolately in the pallid light. It all felt far, far away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, SYLVAN
description: MEYER-Sylvan, 79. Died peacefully in Dahlonega, Ga., on April 8 watching Tiger win the Masters and his Grand Slam. He was the crusading civil rights editor of the Gainesville, Georgia, Daily Times ('47-'69), and later editor of the Miami News, 1969-73. In the 1970s, he wrote the prospectus for Florida International University's School of Journalism, chaired Miami's Bicentennial celebration, bought and published South Florida Magazine. He was a Nieman Fellow of Harvard University 195051, chaired the Georgia Advisory Committee to the U.S. Civil Rights Commission during the turbulent l950s exposing himself and his family to death threats; was a Pulitzer Prize juror, a board member of The American Society of Newspaper Editors and of the National Conference of Editorial Writers, chaired the City Regional Magazine Association and won the Sigma Delta Chi editorial writing award. He wrote ''Prostate Cancer...Making Survival Decisions'' (University of Chicago Press), subsequently conquering the disease. He died of renal and heart failure with a .002 PSA. He was a Navy Veteran (Executive Officer, U.S.S. Foote) serving in the Pacific's Desron 23 under Adm. Arleigh Burke. A private pilot for 45 years, UNC alumni, avid golfer, Rotarian and environmentalist, he chaired the Georgia Mountains Planning Commission and the Lake Lanier Islands Authority. He received honorary doctorates from FIU and Oglethorpe University (Atlanta), and mentored many journalists. Survivors include wife Anne Heineman Meyer; daughter Erica (Alan) Rauzin of Miami Beach, sons David Norman Meyer II of NYC and Ketchum, ID; and Jason (Tracy) Meyer of Pennington, NJ, five grandchildren, brother Leonard (Janet) Meyer, Atlanta, sisterin-law Joan Banov of Glen Cove, NY, one niece and three nephews. Memorial donations may be made to the Sylvan Meyer Newsroom, c/o Dean Arthur Heise, School of Journalism, FIU North Campus, A.C. II, Rm. 335, Miami, FL, 33181.

Maxwell ''distinguishes himself with a host of dexterous and nimbly honed lines and images,'' Andy Brumer wrote here in 1999.

title: Collecting Coins and Memories on Delaware River Toll Bridge
description: On Aug. 16, 1951, Omero C. Catan of Teaneck became the first person to pay a 75-cent toll for crossing the Delaware River Memorial Bridge, a two-mile, twin steel span that links Pennsville, in Salem County, with New Castle, Del. As part of the bridge's 50th anniversary celebration, officials at the Delaware River Bay Authority are asking for written anecdotes and old photographs about the bridge. The six winning memoirists will be invited to a lunch in Wilmington on Aug. 16, where they will share their memories with the bridge's longest-serving employee, Robert DiCamillo Jr., the toll superintendent, who began work as a toll collector in 1967. Mr. DiCamillo recently shared his own memories.

title: What He Hunted, What He Gathered
description: Succumbing to what he calls ''mal Afrique,'' or the need to return to Africa, in 1997 James Stephenson suspended his career as a terrace gardener in New York to spend nine months in Tanzania among the Hadzabe, ''perhaps the last hunter-gatherers living a traditional life in Africa.'' In the bush he learned, among other things, how to extract honey from a nest in the baobab tree and how to pass a lion's den without being attacked. He hunted wildebeest, traversed the parched bush in search of a sacred mountain and viewed secret rock paintings. He tried to save a Hadza girl from dying of a dog's bite. As in the best of travel literature, the account of the physical journey in THE LANGUAGE OF THE LAND: Living Among the Hadzabe in Africa (St. Martin's, $24.95) becomes a voyage of the self. Among Stephenson's personal realizations, the most central was his ''new union with nature.'' ''The energy of the stars, the earth, the trees, the animals, the water,'' he writes, ''all seemed to channel through me. . . . To have experienced this harmony was the greatest lesson of my life.'' Stephenson also treats readers to a memorable portrait of the Hadzabe, a shy people who relish the moment, do not understand greed and manifest profound reverence for nature and their ancestors. Their way of life is being threatened by encroaching farmers and hunters, and by the alcoholic drink pombe, available in nearby villages. Stephenson fears even his book may draw harmful attention to the Hadzabe. With alluring descriptions of nature and an inspiring depiction of this ancient tribe, he will more likely provoke readers into a new respect for remote corners of the earth, where people still understand ''the language of the land.'' Gardner McFall

title: April 15-21; Israel Ignites Storm
description: Israel started the week with an airstrike on a Syrian radar position in Lebanon. Then, after a Palestinian mortar attack, it bombarded Palestinian security installations in the Gaza Strip from land, sea and air, and briefly reoccupied a section of Palestinian-controlled land, causing friction between Israel and the United States, and prompting European censure and wrath in the Arab world.

title: Busting Out
description: Yes, there is a Fifth Avenue Easter parade. It never was a formal march with big bands. From its beginnings in the 1880's, it was a promenade of churchgoers. Last Sunday's was a beauty, mixing fashion past and present. Our parade starts top far left with an Edwardian day suit and period flowered muff and continues chronologically through the decades across the top and bottom rows, ending with its present-day carnival atmosphere of imaginative headdresses and costumes, bottom far right. Along the way were many authentic looks and others evoking familiar figures (a drag Queen Mother, top second from far right; Madeline, bottom fourth from left). In the middle row, right, top hats were worn by church ushers, and young women followed their own fashion rules. This once-rigid procession is now a dazzling spring festival, celebrating religion, the holiday and the reawakening of nature.

title: The Next Kate
description: 'When I was a child,'' says Kate Beckinsale, who stars in both ''The Golden Bowl,'' which opens in New York on April 27, and the spectacular ''Pearl Harbor,'' which will arrive in theaters Memorial Day weekend, ''I learned very early that hot is hot, cold is cold and very healthy people can drop dead in a second.'' Beckinsale, who is sipping fizzy water at the Mercer Hotel in SoHo, has luminous pale skin, which accentuates her dark eyes and long, wavy hair. She is speaking about two things, or really, they merge as one: the sudden death of her father, Richard Beckinsale, at age 31, and the very likely possibility of her own fame. ''My mother is an actress, and my father was a huge TV star in England,'' Beckinsale explains. ''He couldn't go anywhere. As a young girl, it was quite a thrill -- I got to meet the Monkees.'' In 1979, when Beckinsale, who is now 27, was 5, her father died in his sleep of a massive heart attack. ''Suddenly, everything was over, but then again it wasn't. My father has been dead for 22 years, and he's still on TV all the time. I'm so used to seeing him. Whenever there's a really significant moment in my life, he's on the TV. When my daughter, Lily, was born two years ago, I said, 'Let's turn on the TV,' and there he was. At first, it was hard to watch him, but now I see it differently. Now it almost feels like he's watching me.'' Beckinsale pauses. ''My father's death -- well, his fame and his death -- have given me a strong sense of the power of film. The work, if it has resonance, will outlive me.''

The most recent of the genre is the just released ''Luzhin Defense,'' a period romance set during a chess tournament in Italy, directed by Marleen Gorris and starring John Turturro and Emily Watson.

Bush and 33 other heads of state are gathered this weekend to reaffirm a 2005 deadline for creating a free-trade zone stretching from Canada to Argentina. And once again their target is a global bogeyman that the Humane Society of the United States, speaking for animals, has labeled ''the single most destructive international organization ever formed.''

title: Hobbits in Hollywood

Imagine: A teenage actor playing Frodo Baggins, a hobbit 50 years old! New Zealand as a location for Middle Earth, whose geography was explicitly modeled on the hills and forests of Tolkien's beloved England! Tolkien, besides being a patriot, was a conservative Roman Catholic who never quite approved of his fans -- many of them American hippies, at least in his day -- let alone the industry of ancillary products that mushroomed around his work. He once despairingly described his own following as a ''deplorable cultus.''

Connell Watkins, 54, and her assistant Julie Ponder, 40, placed Candace Newmaker inside a sheet and urged her to struggle out as a way to simulate birth and create a bond with her adoptive mother. An autopsy found the girl died of asphyxiation after 70 minutes. Michael Janofsky

title: Introduction
description: Sara Corbett's article on the Sudanese refugees drew stacks of mail. Readers said the chilly welcome awaiting the young men left much to be desired. Fargo -- brrr! And the sketchy preparation for the necessities of daily living (food, clothing) made their resettlement doubly daunting.

When New Jersey's power brokers break bread, the real hunger is for a prime slice of the Boardwalk, a better legislative committee assignment or an inside track on a land deal. Sometimes, money has even been known to change hands -- above the table or underneath (this is New Jersey, after all). The food happens to be on the table.

And there are plenty of pretty faces, if you are not too fussy about their acting or diction and do not object to ''a clone-type of beauty,'' as the director James Ivory has put it.

description: The MetroStars committed a soccer sin this afternoon and paid the penalty. Leading by a goal with 15 minutes left but playing a man short, the MetroStars looked to attack instead of protecting their lead. The result was that they yielded three goals, including two three minutes apart, and lost, 3-1, to the Tampa Bay Mutiny before 17,253 at Giants Stadium.

title: Picks and Pans in the N.F.L. Draft
description: In the days after the draft every team loves its picks, but the reality is some teams selections are outstanding and some are not. Here is the good, the bad and the ugly of this past weekends National Football League draft.

title: Rahman Takes Lewis's Belts In Big Upset
description: Hasim Rahman, who was given scant chance of scoring an upset here, did just that today, unseating Lennox Lewis as the World Boxing Council and International Boxing Federation heavyweight champion in a fight that will now go down for much more than simply bringing big-time boxing back to Africa.

title: Exotic Newcomers At Baltimore Aquarium
description: Sea horses and a few of their exotic relatives in the Syngnathidae family are the inhabitants of a new exhibition area that opened on March 31 at the National Aquarium in Baltimore. Through 2003, visitors can peer into display tanks containing re-creations of Tasmanian kelp beds, mangrove swamps, Caribbean reefs and other habitats to view hundreds of the tiny, graceful fish that are covered with bony plates instead of scales, all part of the exhibit ''Seahorses: Beyond Imagination.'' They include potbellied sea horses from Tasmania, tiger-tail sea horses from Asia, weedy sea dragons -- frilly-looking creatures that resemble a drifting swatch of lace -- and alligator pipefish, which live in the Pacific Ocean.

title: Chinese Youths' Darkening View of U.S.
description: Zhou Jing's view of the United States as dangerous and domineering has hardened since American warplanes bombed China's embassy in Belgrade two years ago and an American spy plane more recently collided with a Chinese fighter jet off this country's southern coast.

description: Last fall, as the presidential campaign gave way to the long count in Florida, Dick Cheney picked up a disturbing nugget of economic intelligence.

description: PISCES is well named. Service at this new Atlantic Beach restaurant, like its namesake astrological sign, resembles two fish swimming in opposite directions: smooth and attentive or so inept that it's laughable.

title: A Sense of Place: Literature on Location
description: WELCOME to Cooperstown, land of Natty Bumppo, noble hero of James Fenimore Cooper's ''Leatherstocking Tales.'' Many of Natty's adventures take place during the 1700's, in what was then America's wild frontier: upstate New York. With his Mohican sidekick, Chingachgook, Natty (also known as Deerslayer, Leatherstocking or Hawkeye) engages in daring attacks on enemy tribes during the French and Indian Wars and rescues helpless women - all the while escaping the entanglements of civilization and marriage and establishing the prototype for the lone Amerian hero and his classic sidekick, from Tonto and the Lone Ranger to Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid.

title: Lisa Teevan, Robert Carey
description: Lisa Anne Teevan, the daughter of Elizabeth and Martin Teevan of Holmdel, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Stephen Carey, a son of Margot and David Carey of Sudbury, Mass. The Rev. Francis E. Chambers performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Catholic Church in West Orange, N.J.

title: Italian Stories, Without Bullets
description: THE real problem is not ''The Sopranos,'' the television mob opera, or all those movies and books showing vulgar Italian-Americans wolfing down pasta and working for the Mafia. The problem is that popular culture makes little room for defining Italian-Americans in other ways. And the best solution for Italian-Americans troubled by stereotypes is to passionately support Italian-American writers creating different kinds of characters and exploring issues outside the crime matrix.

title: A Warholian Finds a New Center of Gravity
description: BRIGID BERLIN was the ultimate insider at Andy Warhol's Factory, but to meet her now, at 61, is to encounter someone who more closely resembles an outsider artist. Her spacious apartment in the East 20's is packed with art, but there's not a Mao silkscreen in sight; a casual visitor would never guess that Ms. Berlin once belonged to one of New York's most jaded circles.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: SO this obnoxious man gets elected president. His staff considers him a fool, and his wife can't stand him. When he has a stroke and falls into a coma, his aides, who don't like the idea of giving up power, call on a happy-go-lucky temp-agency owner (Kevin Kline) who happens to be a presidential look-alike. Posting as the leader of the free world in Ivan Reitman's DAVE (1993), Mr. Kline's title character, a peach of a human being, balances the budget, does nice things for homeless children and generally brings pride back to America. Even the first lady (Sigourney Weaver) warms up to him -- Saturday at 8 p.m. on Channel 9.

title: For the Pop Culturati, Patterns That Say Tokyo Cool
description: THE disco floor in the tent was small and the crowding made worse by the number of Southern Californians uncharacteristically swathed in layers. But the night was chill, the lines outside the tent and the adjacent gallery long, and however much fashion may have urged the chiffon leggings, leather largely prevailed. The occasion was the opening of ''Superflat,'' the inaugural exhibition at the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art's newest gallery, situated in the courtyard of the blocklong Pacific Design Center.

description: Dubbed the Queen of Rockabilly, Wanda Jackson was the first female country and rockabilly star. As if the royal title wasn't enough, she soon became known as the female Elvis Presley. She made a brief detour as a singer of Christian music, but she still rocks the house. Known for big hair and a bigger voice, she is an American musical pioneer. ''From Fujiyama Mama'' to ''Riot in Cell Block No. 9,'' she keeps the joint jumping. She'll appear Friday, with the Morells, 9:30 p.m., at Maxwell's, 1039 Washington Street, Hoboken. Robbie Woliver

title: Just the Basics on a Truck Safari
description: WE have come to Etosha National Park in northern Namibia in September, during its punishing dry season, and as our truck halts at one of the few watering holes to survive the rainless days and the heat, I hear the excited sighs of my two dozen companions. The stark contrasts and vividness of the scenery awe us: behind us, receding from the modest pond, stretches an arid landscape of stunted, naked trees and hard earth; but not 15 yards in front of our noses, at the precious watering hole, many animals have gathered for a drink. The image is neither calm nor idyllic, as the animals match brawn against speed and wits. Skittish jackals and dainty springbok dart in for opportunistic slurps, while the bigger animals -- majestic, straight-horned gemsbok, zebras and wildebeests -- bully their way in at will.

title: Investing; In Some Funds, Hedging Is No Haven
description: MUTUAL funds that act like hedge funds were a tough sell in the bull market. In theory, these funds, which proliferated after a regulatory change in 1997, provide protection during market declines. Predictably, that pitch did not resonate with investors when the market was roaring. As a result, there are now fewer than 20 hedged mutual funds.

title: Hospital Workers' Union Waging New Fight in Bronxville

title: A Long Way Round
description: How many in-flight movies can be shown on one trip? One way to find out is on a round-the-world flight aboard a South African Airways jet on Nov. 17 to 19, which will challenge a round-the-world record of 54 hours 7 minutes 12 seconds set in 1977 by a Pan American 747. It's $7,495 and up for a seat. The 747-444 will leave from New York, with three 90-minute stops, and cross both poles. Visit the Web site at www.over-both-poles.com.

title: Air Canada Plays Tough With Competitors
description: WITH the onset of spring, Americans look north again to Canada, a nation that is expected to surpass Britain this year as the most popular destination for air travelers from the United States. This summer, returning visitors will discover that over the last year Canadian skies have quietly undergone an air-travel revolution -- not entirely for the better.

title: Streetscapes/3 East 52nd Street; An 1871 Building With a Plaque Honoring a Visitor
description: LAST fall a commemorative organization, La Section Americaine du Souvenir Francais, put up a plaque outside the restaurant La Grenouille, at 3 East 52nd Street, memorializing the aviator and writer Antoine de Saint-Exupery, who often visited the building while in exile from German-occupied France during World War II. In the din of traffic and construction on the street, it's hard to notice not just the plaque but even the entire house, which dates back almost to the Civil War.

title: Lost in a Blizzard of Reproductions
description: One of the great themes in this digital age is the dream of perfect reproducibility, the ability to create generation after generation of digital copies with no loss of information. Binary code has also become the Esperanto of equivalence, translating music, words and images into a common, readily manipulated language. It has dissolved the fundamental differences between text and illustration. The time when photographs by Jacob Riis, the journalist and social reformer, had to be turned into wood engravings in order to be printed in The New York Tribune seems almost as distant as the time, only a few years ago, when copiers and printers were entirely different machines, when combining text and illustration meant an exacting outing with scissors and paste and a bottle of Wite-Out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, MURIEL ORR.
description: BROWN-Muriel ORR. 92 of Staten Island and NYC. Passed peacefully on April 19, 2001 at Kateri Residence in Manhattan after a long illness. Beloved widow of the late Isaac Brown and mother of the late Gerard Brown. She is survived by sons Dr. Norman Brown of Staten Island, Dr. Howard Brown of Williamsburg, VA., stepson Dr. Roy Brown of Huntington, NY. Grandchildren Allan, Anthony, Allison, Carol, Michael, Ali, Christopher, Clifford and Catherine. 13 great grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. title: Berlin Sights
description: To the Editor: I found Daisann McLane's article on Berlin, ''Peeling the Layers of History in Berlin'' (Feb. 4), superficial. If the article's emphasis is supposed to be on frugality, she should have recommended traveling just 15 minutes on the splendid public transit system away from the center of town (Mitte) to one of the neighboring boroughs. There you would find much cheaper rooms and an equally large choice of restaurants, beer gardens and cabarets. And no visit to Berlin would be complete without visiting the Pergamon Museum with its magnificent Greek altar and Babylon treasures.

He thought others might have the same urge, so he built four ''cabanas'' with plunge pools and a small bungalow, gave them each a butler and opened the Cayo Espanto resort in Belize in December 1998. The guests, paying an average of $1,100 a night, started asking if he knew where they could get an island of their own, so he started selling them.

Though it is the least industrialized state in the South, its voters rejected arguments that the flag would drive away tourism and investment, expressing resentment that outsiders might try to dictate their symbolism. This has meant digitally blending shots from actual races with Harlin's own footage of actors and stunt drivers filmed on the same tracks and then later adding computer-generated special effects. Beats having to build a full-scale wood-and-plaster version of ancient Babylon at the intersection of Hollywood and Sunset, as D.W. Griffith had to do in 1916 for ''Intolerance.''

title: Long Shot

But that the daughter should simply drive her mother to the bus station and leave her there, washing her hands of her, is unspeakable. Caring for the members of one's family is not just a fair-weather activity.

The Communist Party itself has its roots in the student-led May 4 Movement of 1919, which condemned the Chinese government's weakness in negotiating the Treaty of Versailles after World War I.

title: Bon Appetit!, Jersey-Style; Where They Develop More Than an Appetite
description: CREAM cheese or creme brulee, it doesn't much matter. When New Jersey's power brokers break bread, the real hunger is for a prime slice of the Boardwalk, a better legislative committee assignment or an inside track on a land deal. Sometimes, money has even been known to change hands -- above the table or underneath (this is New Jersey, after all). The food happens to be on the table.

title: A Step Forward In a Campaign For the Fat Girls
description: THREE years ago Camryn Manheim held her Emmy award high over her head and declared, ''This is for all the fat girls!'' It was, Ms. Manheim says, a high water mark for her, a symbol of recognition not only for her role as the lawyer Ellenor Frutt on ABC's ''Practice'' but also for the personal struggle she has waged most of her life: dealing with being fat in a society obsessed with being thin.

title: THE WIRELESS AGE; Theories of Connectivity
description: As I drive my rental car across Silicon Valley under a cloudless and starry sky, it is fitting that the electronic navigation device on the dashboard should be talking to me. ''Approaching left turn,'' says Helga (as I call her). ''Left turn in point five miles.'' Headlights rush past us, exit signs loom and are gone, and now it occurs to me that this freeway doesn't even have left turns. Helga is trying to show me something on a tiny, color-coded, icon-studded moving-map display at the edge of my peripheral vision. Up in the real world, we hurtle under an overpass. That wasn't my left turn, I hope. But yes, apparently Helga lacks perfect knowledge of California cloverleaf topography. ''Calculating route,'' she chirps, as if we can simply begin again with no memory of the past. I am mindful of the German motorist who drove his BMW into the Havel River one night because he put too much trust in his dashboard navigator.

title: April 15-21; No Court-Martial for Skipper
description: The accidental sinking of a Japanese fishing trawler by an American submarine off Hawaii in February created anger and resentment in Japan, but it will not bring a court-martial of the submarine's skipper, Cmdr. Scott D. Waddle. Pentagon officials said Adm. Thomas Fargo, commander of the U.S. Pacific Fleet, would accept the unanimous recommendation of a Navy court of inquiry not to proceed with a court-martial but will conduct an administrative hearing this week. Commander Waddle is expected to receive a formal letter of reprimand, effectively ending the career of one of the submarine corps' most beloved officers. Elaine Sciolino

title: April 15-21; A Question of Motive
description: With a new wave of redistricting looming, the Supreme Court stepped back from the political fray and upheld North Carolina's 12th Congressional District, which a lower court had invalidated as the product of an unconstitutional racial gerrymander for its concentration of black voters. In holding that the motive for drawing the district was mainly partisan politics rather than race, the ruling gave welcome breathing room to legislatures and lower courts. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor joined the court's four more liberal justices in its fourth review of the district -- presumably its last for a while. Linda Greenhouse

title: Painting, Photography In the Wilds of Ontario
description: In a new program called ''Arts in the Wild,'' Ontario's art academies, resorts, parks and galleries are offering courses in the creative arts amid the region's rugged wilderness. Visitors can set up easels in the old-growth red pine forests of Temagami, a five-hour drive north of Toronto; learn soapstone carving in the Kawartha Lakes region, about two hours from Toronto; or study wildflower photography in an Algonquin Park valley accessible only by canoe. Tamed lynx, coyote and wolves from a wildlife sanctuary model for sculptors and painters at the Algonquin Academy on the west side of Algonquin Park. At the Golden Lake First Nation, just east of the park, overnight guests sleep in tepees and learn beadwork, deerskin crafts and drumming. Poets and songwriters lead workshops using the quiet rivers, lakes and islands as inspiration.

title: The Remains of the Bird
description: It looked like a flamingo, had short, powerful wings and lived in New Jersey some 65 million years ago. Meet the New Jersey Wing Bird, an ancient but newly discovered species of sea bird found by the curator of the New Jersey State Museum of Natural History, David C. Parris. Dr. Parris found its remains in the Inversand Mine in Mantua Township in 1972, but it took years to determine that the three wing bones belonged to an undiscovered species. It was the first time in 100 years that fossil bird remains had been found in the state and the only find ever with more than one bone. The bird won't get its official Latin moniker until an article about it appears in a paleontology journal, so until then we'll call it the Ewnay Ersey Jaybird. Margo Nash

title: Declaration of Quebec City

We have adopted a Plan of Action to strengthen representative democracy, promote good governance and protect human rights and fundamental freedoms.* We seek to create greater prosperity and expand economic opportunities while fostering social justice and the realization of human potential.

title: The Long, Long, Long Road to Fargo
description: Sara Corbett's poignant portrayal of the Sudanese children (April 1) was gripping to read and even more compelling to think about long after I finished it. The cover photo initially struck me more as a Ralph Lauren Polo advertisement than as an image of a displaced teenager. But after reading the article, I realized just how deep this paradox cuts. In our effort to give these children ''better'' lives (i.e., lives filled with all the creature comforts we have come to enjoy and expect), are we not merely replacing one set of physical and psychological hurdles with another? Have we simply transplanted them into another predatory environment in which only the strongest survive? I would be interested in revisiting these boys in a year or two to see what this gift of a new American life has really given them.

title: A Museum in Florida For a Spanish Original
description: HOW Dali would have loved the busload of high school students drifting somewhat uncertainly through the Salvador Dali Museum in St. Petersburg, Fla., identifying the insects and body parts (''That's an eyelash! A grasshopper!'') scattered across his canvases and emitting little cries (''Oh, wow, that's gross!'') of titillation and disgust! By the time he died, in 1989, the defiantly outre artist had begun to realize that the public was growing progressively more difficult to shock, and one can only suppose that he would have been thrilled to watch his paintings work their old black magic even on young viewers presumably weaned on, and inured to, the horrors of teenage slasher films.

title: April 15-21; Talks With China End
description: The Bush administration learned that it's easier to land a spy plane in China -- even a crippled one -- than to get it back. The first meeting between American and Chinese officials since the release of the EP-3's crew was an exercise in blame-exchange. After a bad start -- the Americans nearly walked out -- the State Department declared that the final session was ''very productive.'' But the Chinese made no promises to return the plane, whose surveillance equipment has presumably been carefully picked over. If it is sent back, it will probably be in small boxes, sans the spy gear. David E. Sanger

title: Competing for Your Hand
description: Having exhausted the range of subspecialized unguents, from lip exfoliants to seaweed masks for firming thighs, cosmetics companies are going back to the basics -- hand cream. The new crop of nostrums and salves is, predictably, far fancier than that sink-side jug of Jergens -- redolent of herbs and spices, formulated by doctors and generally sold in cunning three- or four-ounce packages. Exotic Hand Lotion by Neal's Yard -- sunflower oil, sandalwood and ylang-ylang -- is said to ''impart a calm sense of well-being'' ($24 at Jeffrey). Kanebo's Sensai Intensive Hand Treatment, which includes pink cotton gloves to be worn following each application ($85 at Bergdorf Goodman), is not to be outdone by Bliss's new ''high intensity'' hand cream (why are hand creams so intense?). The Bliss treatment is $14 at Bliss stores. Brandt Balanced Hand Cream, created by Fred Brandt, dermatologist to the stars, promises to ''resist penetration of soaps and detergents'' ($40 at Bergdorf Goodman). Donna Karan's Cashmere Mist Hand Conditioning Creme provides scent and sunscreen ($28 at Bloomingdale's). And from Linda Rose, a two-part system ($45 at Saks Fifth Avenue). Television viewers may remember Ms. Rose's hands from Palmolive's manicure Madge commercials -- hers were the fingers that were ''soaking in it.''

title: What Did The C.I.A. Do to His Father?
description: Michael Ignatieff (April1) describes Harold Abramson, a medical consultant used by the C.I.A., as an allergist, thereby casting doubt on the C.I.A.'s assertion that it sought psychiatric advice for Frank Olson. Although Dr. Abramson specialized in the treatment of patients with allergies, he was indeed a psychiatrist. In his extensive research on LSD (in which he used informed volunteers), he studied chemical inhibitors in the hope that they might be useful in the treatment of psychoses, and he tested LSD as an adjunct to psychotherapy and explored its possible military use through aerosols. His subjects were often treated afterward to cocktails because he uniquely believed that alcohol was an antidote for LSD. Thus, the bourbon that he prescribed for Olson may have been intended for more than sleep.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-22-01: List: Contraband; The Flesh of Others
description: Recently, British government officials admitted that illegal meat imports were the probable culprits responsible for its current outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease. Stateside, Department of Agriculture inspectors seized more than 300,000 illegal animal products in the last fiscal year, which they immediately incinerated or ground up to eliminate the risk of disease. Travelers try to smuggle not only the flesh of cloven-hoofed animals from nations where foot-and-mouth disease is endemic but also meats from vermin and bush animals that could harbor deadly viruses like Ebola. People use all kinds of surreptitious tactics -- pork sausages hidden in diapers or disguised as cigars in cigar boxes -- to evade authorities. ''It's really difficult confiscating meat,'' says Shirlene Ceballos, the port director of Dulles International Airport near Washington. ''Some people start crying, saying it's for a sick relative who's craving a national delicacy.'' Others, she jokes, ''have heart attacks.'' Here are some of the illegal imports seized in the last two years. -- Reena Jana

title: Taking Movie Music Seriously, Like It or Not
description: FOR two years in a row, the Academy Award for best film score has gone to a classical composer: first John Corigliano for ''The Red Violin,'' then Tan Dun for ''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.'' While cynics claim that this is the film industry's way of advertising its high-art pretensions, Hollywood may really be ahead of New York in acknowledging that the opposition between film music and concert music is a phantom of the last century. Today the two styles constantly interact. John Williams's scores for George Lucas's ''Star Wars'' movies and for Steven Spielberg's ''Jaws'' and ''Close Encounters of the Third Kind,'' which resurrected the symphonic style for film in the 70's, have also exerted a huge influence on the work of young concert composers. Philip Glass's music for ''Koyaanisqatsi'' made Minimalism an essential component of any film composer's stylistic vocabulary.

Using such fibers can save much of the energy needed to make a car and result in parts that are 40 percent lighter -- and biodegradable. By 2010, the New Jersey consulting firm Kline & Company expects natural fibers to replace a fifth of the fiberglass in today's automobile interiors.

title: Reconciliation in the Balkans?
description: My first visit to Belgrade was soon after the NATO bombing. I crossed the border on foot, as there were no flights to the city. Thousands were marching in the streets, the black market flourished and, with Slobodan Milosevic firmly in charge, the opposition was understandably depressed. I met with academics, students, human-rights groups and representatives of the media. I had no public meetings and made no statements on the record, because I hoped to return. Unfortunately, this was not possible; a few months later, my application for a visa was denied by the foreign ministry. And a few months after that, Mr. Milosevic was ousted and Vojislav Kostunica was president.

The sailors were cared for and given dry clothes. The next day, the group attended a private memorial in the airy reading room. A photograph of the occasion is now taped beside the lurching elevator in the lobby.

title: It's the Best Of Times, Nonetheless
description: IN New York, as elsewhere, there are plenty of Jeremiahs in the world of classical music and plenty of reasons for them to be lamenting. Most concerts pursue a routine that has been established for many decades and that long ago lost much of its purpose. Whether for that reason or others, there are not enough younger people in concert halls to ensure a regeneration of the audience. Opera companies face the same problems. And most disturbingly, there is a failure of creative talent: the ''young'' composers now are in their 40's and 50's, the mature masters in their 80's.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-22-01; I, Pollinator
description: For a while there, it looked as if this might be the year it never happened, but the gardening season has arrived at last. Last week the peas went in, finally, and today I'll plant potatoes. Nights are still way too cold to put out the tender vegetables -- tomatoes and the like -- but on my windowsills their seedlings are already pressing against the pane, leaning into the strengthening sun and the traffic of bees building outside. Am I the only gardener who, especially at this time of year, identifies with these bees? I doubt it. Sooner or later, most gardeners begin to look at things from the perspective of their plants -- and from a plant's point of view, there's really not a whole lot of difference between a human being and a bumblebee.

title: Country Singers Who Still Display A Country Heart
description: MAINSTREAM country music has taken a deserved critical drubbing for at least the last decade, at a time when, not coincidentally, it became a dominant commercial force. Success, as it so often happens, has made major-label country music only more conservative, closed not only to innovation but also to its own uproarious history. Increasingly, the sounds emanating from Nashville are indistinguishable, one from another. What often passes for country now, particularly on radio stations playing that tightly controlled format, is a bland blend of tried-and-true formulas, with every edge smoothed by waves of hit-making experience. Country these days is defined more by what it lacks than by what it is: it's 70's rock without the sexual knowingness; singer-songwriter narratives without the desperate confessions; friendly, slickly packaged Southernness with none of the region's literary flair or ungovernable eccentricities.
