title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINER, ROSE
description: KLEINER-Rose. Died at home with her family on April 14, 2001, in Los Altos Hills, CA. Loving and beloved wife of Eugene Kleiner for 54 years, mother of Robert Kleiner and Lisa Kleiner Chanoff, grandmother of Jake Kleiner and Yael, Talia and Eli Chanoff, and sister of Bruno Wassertheil. Rose was born in 1925 in Katowice, Poland. In the fall of 1939 her family set out across the Atlantic for the New York World's Fair. While they were en route, Germany invaded Poland, and Rose and her family were suddenly emigres. They settled in Manhattan. Rose graduated from Brooklyn College in 1946, and served as a social worker at Quaker House. In 1947 Rose married Eugene Kleiner, an engineering student at Polytechnic University and also an emigre from Europe. In 1952 their first child, Robert, was born. In 1956 the family moved to California where Eugene was one of a group assembled by Willliam Schockley to produce the transistor. In 1959 their second child, Lisa, was born. Rose put her lifelong passion for social work on hold to devote her considerable energy and talent to raising her family. She created a house of abundance, filled with delicious food, music, laughter and fun. She sang in madrigal and jazz singing groups, and moved two pianos into her living room to play duets with her daughter Lisa. At age 49, after raising her two children, Rose returned to school and earned a master's degree in gerontology at Berkeley's School of Social Welfare. She became the first program director of the Senior Coordinating Council's Senior Day Health program. In 1982, Rose founded Older Adults Care Management (OACM), a pioneer in designing support plans, training companions, and providing support services for the elderly. Rose merged OACM with The Goldman Institute in 2000. As a community leader, Rose was a thoughtful and unstoppable force for good. She served on the boards of El Camino Hospital Foundation, the Career Action Center, the International Tremor Foundation, The Parkinson's Institute, Respite & Research for Alzheimer's Disease, the U.C. Berkeley Center for Aging Research, the International Longevity Center and the Goldman Institute, and was a member of the Citizen's Advisory Committee at Duke University Council on Aging & Human Development and of the Geriatric Advisory Council of Mt. Sinai Medical Center, NY. She was honored with a Woman of Vision award from the Career Action Center, an Athena award from the Palo Alto Chamber of Commerce, and the Adele Elkind award from the National Association of Professional Geriatric Care Managers. In 1988 she received a Lifetime of Achievement Award from the Senior Coordinating Council of Palo Alto. Rose was a positive thinking woman of action. She was enormously generous with gifts, spirit and love. She loved to take care of people and to make them happy. She always found the good in people and situations, and never spoke badly about another human being. She was wise, innovative, had a great sense of humor, a great sense of style and was completely original. She loved life and was adored by her family, friends and colleagues. She was and will continue to be an inspiration to everyone who knew her. ''I have always tried not to complain,'' Rose once said, ''but to see what I can do about something, to embrace life no matter what it brings.'' We celebrate her memory. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the International Longevity Center, 60 E. 86th St, NYC 10028, or the charity of your choice.

title: Showering the South Fork With Kindness
description: IN his workaday life, Jay Lockett Sears designs the kinds of houses most people only dream of -- 15,000-square-foot postmodern villas with soaring entryways, palladium windows, decorative columns, gambrel roofs, twin turrets, billiards rooms, a dozen bathrooms and stereophonic wine cellars. His architectural creations -- more than 1,500 over the past 40 years that started with the big, boxy, flat-topped Bauhaus look, then shifted to dramatically angular pitched shed rooflines in the 1970's and 80's before settling into the current country-look, shingle rage -- dot the waterfront from the Moriches to Montauk.

title: A Royal Station in Scotland Is Restored
description: The railway station in Scotland that was used for 100 years by members of the royal family on their way to their Scottish home, Balmoral Castle, has been restored and turned into a tourist attraction. Built in 1866, the Old Royal Station in Ballater was the terminus of the Deeside Line from Aberdeen, where it connected to the national rail network. Queen Victoria, the first British monarch to use the train regularly, enjoyed vacations at Balmoral, which Prince Albert bought for her in 1852. The station had been unused since 1966.

title: QUICK BITE/Highland Park; Bagels in the Name, More on the Menu
description: Ensconced in the bustling downtown of Highland Park is the Bagel Dish Cafe, a cross between a restaurant, a coffee shop, a luncheonette and maybe even a diner. Its eclectic menu is testament to that. Consider, for example, the specials offered on one recent day: Grilled vegetables and portobello mushrooms over baby greens with goat cheese; balsamic grilled shrimps over bay greens; and hickory-grilled cheeseburger on a hard roll. On the daily menu, among other inventive dishes, are wraps: hot or cold, from tuna and grilled vegetables with goat cheese, to veggie burger, Buffalo chicken, honey mustard chicken and cracked-pepper turkey. The bagel part of the name is represented, but bagels are not a primary item and are not sold by the dozen as might be assumed. In fact, the bagel moniker is a holdover from when the place under a former owner was an extension of another bagel maker a few blocks down Raritan Avenue. Stephanie and Valilio Papagiannis bought what she prefers to call her ''gourmet cafe'' four years ago. The Papagiannises previously owned eating places in Sparta and Elizabeth, with Valilio, who began as a dishwasher, the chief cook, which he still is. Because of some of the items on the menu -- including fish and more strictly vegetarian items -- she also refers to it as ''a healthful eating place.'' This might account for the abundance of medical personnel who are regular customers. ''Doctors are No. 1,'' she said. Politicians come in too: ''The mayor was just in with her husband,'' Stephanie said. And to add a note of sanity: ''Every therapist in town comes in.'' Norman Oshrin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HEARN, CHARLES
description: O'HEARN-Charles. 99, died in Naples, FL on Friday, April 19, 2001 at Windsor Court. He was a partner of Scudder, Stevens and Clark in New York City until 1951, when at the age of 50, he became Assistant to the President of Yale University in charge of fund raising, from which he retired in 1970. He graduated from Yale in 1924. He lived in Scarsdale, NY for many years, in New Haven, CT while at Yale, and upon retirement moved to his summer home in Kennebunk Beach, ME, moving to Old Lyme, CT in 1980. Beginning in 1970, he spent winters in Naples, FL, becoming a full time resident in 1991. His wife of 66 years, Anna Virginia Curtis, died in September, 1994. Survivors include two daughters, Virginia Broadbent of Mt. Carmel, CT, Peggy Denby of Boca Grande, FL and a son, C. Michael O'Hearn, Jr. of Naples, FL; ten grandchildren and nine great grandchildren. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEIDERMAN, KENNETH BENSON
description: SCHEIDERMAN-Kenneth Benson, 54. Died Tuesday, April 17, 2001 at Baptist Medical CenterBeaches. He was a resident of St. Augustine, Florida, at the time of his death. Born in Summit, New Jersey on July 2, 1946, to Robert and Betty Scheiderman, Ken grew up in Green Village, New Jersey, graduating from Chatham High School in 1964. Ken then joined the U.S. Army and served tours of duty in Korea and Viet Nam as a topographic surveyor. He received his B.S. in geography from Arizona State University and served as a veteran's counselor in the Phoenix area. In 1978, Ken founded California College for Health Sciences in San Diego, CA. The results of his efforts are compelling: by the time of his retirement in 1996, California College had over 30,000 graduates around the world from 11 undergraduate and graduate programs, primarily through distance learning. During his career, Ken served on the Board of Trustees for the Distance Education and Training Council, as well as Vice Chair of the Accrediting Commission of the Distance Education and Training Council. He also served as a commissioner for the Accrediting Commission the ACCSCT and as Chair of the Advisory Committee of the American Council on Education's College Credit Recommendation Program. He received the honarary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters from the University of St. Augustine for Health Sciences, the Distinguished Service Award from the Distance Education and Training Council and was inducted into the DETC Hall of Fame this month, all for his contributions to the highest ideals of distance education. Ken was also a yachting enthusiast both in San Diego and St. Augustine. He was a past commodore of Coronado Cays Yacht Club in 1987 as well as a member of the Southwestern Yacht Club in San Diego, the St. Augustine Yacht Club and the International Order of the Blue Gavel. He was a member of the Green Village Methodist Church in Green Village, New Jersey and Grace United Methodist Church in St. Augustine. His family includes his wife, Robin Hanson Scheiderman; a son, Erick (Kristi) Scheiderman; granddaughters, Breannah and Kelsea Scheiderman; step-granddaughter, Sheli Richmond, as well as many friends and family around the country. A Service of Remembrance will be held from the graveside at the Ponte Vedra Valley Cemetery on Saturday, April 21st, at 11:00 A.M. with the Reverend Doug Clewis, officiating. A reception will follow at the Marriott Island Green Villas. In lieu of flowers, the family request donations be made to the Green Village Methodist Church, Green Village, New Jersey, 07935 or Grace United Methodist Church, 8 Carrera Street, St. Augustine, Florida 32084. Services under direction and care of Quinn-Shalz, a family Funeral Home, 3rd Street at Ponte Vedra Boulevard, Jacksonville Beach, Florida 32250, 904/249 - 1100, www.quinn-shalz.com

title: April 15-21; Russian Media Takeover

The state-dominated gas monopoly Gazprom, a hostile shareholder and creditor, wrested away the core of the Gusinsky conglomerate in a series of boardroom coups -- most important, a takeover of the NTV television network after an 11-day protest by journalists. Also gone are Sevodnya, a Moscow daily folded by another shareholder allied with Gazprom, and the respected newsmagazine Itogi, whose staff was replaced. A lone, but key victory for Mr. Gusinsky: in Spain, where he now lives, a high court rejected a Russian attempt to extradite him on a fraud warrant. Michael Wines

Scattered among old clothes, rusty electric fans and fading concert announcements are records -- roughly 100,000 -- stacked to the ceiling, filling two bedrooms and spilling out onto the kitchen counter. title: The Way We Live Now: 4-22-01: Design; Freezing Time
description: Today about 90 people are ''suspended'' nationwide. Not strung up with wires or making do without driver's licenses, but frozen in the hope that molecular nanotechnology will soon allow bodies suspended cryonically post mortem to be reanimated. Four organizations offer such services. But another is in the works, and its plans are a bit more ambitious. If things go as planned, Timeship will be a six-acre, $180 million ''Noah's Ark'' for 10,000 people and plants and animals, as well as stem cells of near-extinct species and human organs for transplant. ''This is historic, biblical in nature,'' says the project's architect, Stephen Valentine. Valentine ultimately hopes to create a sort of ''cryoworld'' with a hotel, conference center, hospital and hospice for those ''traveling'' to the future. So what exactly goes into making such an ark, given that hickory bark doesn't cut it in the silicon age?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITCHFIELD, MARJORIE S.
description: LITCHFIELD-Marjorie S. Mrs. Marjorie deGreeff Litchfield, known to her family and friends as Bambi, died on April 17, 2001, at her home in Katonah, after a long illness. Mrs. Litchfield was born in New York on October 31, 1918. She moved with her family to Mt. Kisco in the late 1920's. She attended New Castle and Scarborough Schools and graduated from The Madeira School in 1936. She attended Bennington College for one year and married Edwin Jacobi in 1939. Her first marriage ended in divorce. In 1966, she married Edward Sands Litchfield. They lived in Katonah and Naples, FL. Mr. Litchfeld was Chairman of the Board of Directors of several corporations including The Brooklyn Improvement Company. He died in 1984. Mrs. Litchfield was active in many organizations. She was a Past President of the Northern Westchester Junior League, she volunteered on behalf of the local rations board in World War II and John V. Lindsay's mayoral campaign in 1965, she was a member of the St. Mark's Players in the 1950's, and she was active on behalf of Heritage House in Ho-HoKus, NJ, and the Westchester Land Trust. Mrs. Litchfield liked to recall that she had auditioned for the part of Scarlett O'Hara in David O. Selznick's film prodution of ''Gone With the Wind.'' Mrs. Litchfield leaves three sons, Robert Jacobi of Healdsburg, CA, Jan Jacobi of St. Louis, MO, and Dr. Peter Jacobi of Durham, NC, two stepdaughters, Ann L. Schofield and Beatrice L. Larned, a stepson, Pieter Van Cortlandt Litchfield, eight grandchildren and nine stepgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, NY on April 27, 2001, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Mrs. Litchfield's name may be made to St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, P.O. Box 293, Bedford, NY 10506; or the Master Teaching Fund at Rippowam Cisqua School, P.O. Box 488, Bedford, NY 10506.

title: The Search for an AIDS Vaccine

description: TOKYO, April 23  Junichiro Koizumi, a reformist lawmaker of Japan's governing party, was virtually assured election as the next Japanese prime minister today after he scored a landslide victory in local primary elections of the Liberal Democratic Party. His victory ended a weeklong scramble for the leadership.

title: Thanks to One Punch, Rahman Wears the Title Belts and Holds the Cards
description: With his battered left eye closing after a few rounds and his shot at stealing the heavyweight title beginning to slip away, Hasim Rahman was not about to give up on his carefully planned fight strategy. At least the part about winning.

title: Carter Once Again Yields Under Pressure
description: Vince Carter's foul shot clanked off the front of the rim with 24 seconds left in the first half yesterday, prompting his Toronto teammate Antonio Davis to walk over and give him a sympathetic pat on the head.

title: Sports of The Times; Lilly's Bid for No. 5 Spot Gives Yanks Hope
description: THEODORE ROOSEVELT LILLY, a fresh-from-the-farm acquisition, sat in front of his locker at noon yesterday at perhaps the least desired spot in the Yankee clubhouse, beside the entrance door. It is the big blue door, conveniently located, coincidentally, for pitchers who have been in his spot and have entered and exited with preposterous regularity.

title: Talks Reported On a Deal for Unit of Degussa
description: OM Group Inc. and the Ferro Corporation, two specialty chemical companies, are close to an agreement to acquire DMC2, the metals and catalyst unit of Degussa A.G. of Germany for about 1.2 billion euros, or $1.08 billion, executives close to the negotiations said yesterday. The boards of the three companies are expected to vote on the deal today, the executives said.

title: Ramirez Ends Homecoming With 2 Home Runs
description: Manny Ramirez and his family have long since moved from Washington Heights to Florida, so Ramirez, the Boston Red Sox slugger, stays at the team hotel when he travels to New York and visits his childhood friends. He is still a big hit, though, and everything he does at Yankee Stadium elicits a combination of boos and cheers from fans torn between team allegiance and nationalistic loyalty.

title: 3M to Cut 7 Percent of Work Force
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, reacting to the slowing economy with a pre-emptive strike, said today that it would cut 7 percent of its work force, or some 5,000 jobs.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Colgate-Palmolive's first-quarter earnings misstated the decline in market share for Procter & Gamble's Crest toothpaste in the period. The share dropped to 26.3 percent from 27 percent a year earlier, not to 24.3 percent.

title: People
description: Dave Robinson, executive vice president and media director at the T&O Group, Irvine, Calif., was named to the new post of general manager.

title: Votes Show Montenegro Leaning Toward Independence
description: Montenegro took a modest step toward independence on Sunday, with early results in the general elections showing a majority of voters supporting parties that favor breaking from Yugoslavia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TITONE, SALVATORE
description: TITONE-Salvatore, 71. Beloved husband of Angela. Survived by two sons, Vincent and Michael and his wife Eileen; two daughters, Rosalie Posteinek and Theresa Jaffe and her husband Sheldon; one sister, Rosalie Lamb and her husband, Richard; his five grandchildren: Ariel and Alexis Jaffe, Paul and Brianna Posteinek and Gabrielle Titone, all who were the joy of his life. He was a CPA in Manhattan for 27 years, a graduate of Pace College, and a resident of Brooklyn for 68 years. A Funeral Mass will be offered 9:15 AM, Wednesday, at St. Luke's Church, Toms River, NJ. The burial will follow at NJ Veteran Cemetery, Arneytown, NJ. Visitation will be Monday and Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9, at D'Elia Funeral Home, Rt. 70 and Vermont Ave, Lakewood, NJ.

description: TOKYO, April 24  Junichiro Koizumi, an iconoclastic reformer written off as an "oddball" by his own Liberal Democratic Party just a month ago, was elected by his party with a strong majority today to become Japan's 11th prime minister in 11 years.

title: Streets of Fashion Dreams, One in Brooklyn . . .
description: Whenever Manhattanites of the Kelly bag persuasion alight from the subway in Park Slope, Brooklyn, they are quick to observe that few of the neighborhood's residents look as soigne as the $1.2 million brownstones that line the streets. For as long as the affluent have set up house in the area, the stylistic muse has been the frump. Nothing has represented the collective aesthetic more than the Park Sloper's accessory of choice: the net grocery bag, which is meant to last through a Chelsea Clinton presidency and lets the world know that hydroponically grown lettuce is inside.

title: SUNY Albany Gets $150 Million For Development of Microchips

title: Arnott Expected Back For Toronto Rematch
description: As their coaches looked over videotape and read scouting reports yesterday to prepare for the Toronto Maple Leafs, the Devils got good news about the injured left knee of a key player. Jason Arnott, their first-line center, passed a magnetic resonance imaging examination and is expected to practice with the team today and play Thursday night in Continental Arena in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference semifinals.

title: BURGER KING SELECTS AN EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT
description: The Burger King unit of Diageo P.L.C. unit named a former Minnesota Twins baseball executive, Christopher Clouser, its executive vice president and chief marketing officer, a position created as part of recent management changes at the company. Mr. Clouser, 49 years old, will handle advertising and sponsorships and will help create products and set pricing. Mr. Clouser was the chief executive of the Twins for seven months, resigning in December.

title: KROLL-O'GARA TO SELL ARMORED VEHICLE BUSINESS
description: The Kroll-O'Gara Company, a provider of security and private-investigation services, agreed to sell its armored vehicle business to Armor Holdings for as much as $56.5 million in cash, stock and debt. Armor Holdings, which makes Mace self-defense spray, bullet-proof vests and military helmets, will pay $39.5 million in cash and $15 million in stock for the unit, which modifies limousines and adds armor to the military's Humvees. The purchase also includes as much as $2 million for certain performance levels and assumption of debt. Kroll-O'Gara is selling the unit to focus on its corporate investigations business, which provides asset tracing, substance-abuse testing and other surveillance services. As part of the transaction, the company, which is based in New York, will drop ''O'Gara'' from its name. Kroll-O'Gara was formed in a merger in 1997.

After a lifetime as a feisty and tireless volunteer for many causes, Lee died April 21 at age 86 following a courageous struggle with heart disease. He is survived by Ruth, his wife of 61 years, children Marci of San Francisco, CA., son Carl, daughter-inlaw Fran, and daughter Jane of Atlanta, GA. and 3 loving grandchildren Lisa, Paula and Alex. title: Science's Elusive Realm: Life's Little Mysteries
description: Physicists observe the natural world and extract from it laws and principles that reliably explain everyday phenomena. At the smallest scale, they use quantum mechanics to predict the behavior of subatomic particles and small molecules. At larger scales, they devise theories to explain magnetism, the conduction of heat and electricity and other phenomena that occur the same way in a wide variety of materials.

title: I.B.M. OFFERS LINUX-CAPABLE SERVERS
description: I.B.M. introduced two new Unix-based midrange server computers that run applications written in Linux, the free software language that has been widely adopted by government and academic computer programmers. The servers use microprocessor-insulating technology and other features I.B.M. had previously deployed in mainframe computers to cut costs and improve reliability while bolstering processing speed. Analysts said the new servers, which will cost $17,000 to $100,000, clearly undercut comparable products from Sun Microsystems, the Unix market leader, in many e-business and data center applications. But they noted that it cannot be expanded as easily as Sun's. Barnaby J. Feder

title: City Offers New Plan on Homeless In a Bid to Avoid a Contempt Order
description: The Giuliani administration, seeking to avoid a contempt-of-court order for its treatment of homeless families, presented yet another plan yesterday detailing how it will rapidly add beds at homeless shelters and move hundreds of other families to permanent apartments.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: BOAR'S HEAD MOVING Boar's Head Provisions, a century-old maker of delicatessen meat and cheese products, will move its corporate headquarters from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to Sarasota, Fla., this summer. The company made its announcement yesterday after being enticed by one of its major customers, Publix Super Markets . Boar's Head, whose more than 350 deli products are found at Publix supermarkets and at independent stores, will move five top management members to Sarasota. Thirty-nine management and clerical positions will be open for local hiring, said RuthAnn LaMore, the company's director of marketing. The company has maintained sales, marketing and training offices in downtown Sarasota for about five years. The company, which operates five processing plants around the country and employs 2,500 people, will maintain its sales office and distribution center in New York. (NYT)

title: GERMANY: CONFIDENCE GAUGE FALLS
description: A closely watched barometer of German business confidence dropped again in March, providing new evidence that the American economic slowdown has affected Europe. The IFO index of business confidence, based on a monthly survey by the IFO research institute in Munich, dropped for the ninth consecutive month and reached its lowest level in 12 months. But the decline was much smaller than last month, and it merely seemed to corroborate expectations that economic growth in Germany, Europe's biggest economy, will drop from about 3 percent last year to nearly 2 percent this year. Despite signs of trouble, the European Central Bank reiterated its view that European growth will remain relatively healthy and that there is no need to emulate the United States in lowering interest rates. Edmund L. Andrews

description: Donald Kirkendall, an exercise physiologist at the University of North Carolina, will never forget the time he put a heart-rate monitor on a member of the United States rowing team and asked the man to row as hard as he could for six minutes.

title: ARGENTINA: BOND MARKET TURMOIL
description: When the Argentine government called off a $750 million debt auction scheduled for today, credit market investors took it as a sign that the country, mired in a long recession and strapped for cash, may be in danger of defaulting on its $128 billion in debt, and they bid bond prices down sharply. Prices for the widely traded floating-rate government bond fell 5.6 percent, pushing its yield up to 22.1 percent, higher than that of bonds issued by Russia, which defaulted in 1998. Cooler heads prevailed in the stock market, where the benchmark Merval index fell a more moderate 2.05 percent. The debt auction was scrapped because rate-setting talks with banks failed to reach agreement, the government said.

title: The Big City; Striking Oil? My Backyard Is Just Fine
description: NEW YORK CITY has some of the world's most spectacular waterfront property, but its prime use often seems to be as a battleground. The latest fight is over power plants in Long Island City, Harlem and Brooklyn, and it features the usual histrionics on both sides.

title: . . . And One in Harlem, That Cradle of Style
description: A shop sign in Harlem reads, ''Where Style Begins.'' And who can dispute the claim? So many styles have begun in Harlem in the last 20 years that to list them would use all the space allotted here. Among the additions to the fashion landscape that, if they weren't exactly born on 125th Street, were surely incubated there, one would probably include Afros, box braids, do-rags, jogging shells, warm-up suits, outsize leisure clothing, doorknocker-size earrings, platinum rope chains, rhinestone body jewelry, diamond studs, colored contact lenses, white mink in all seasons, gangland bandannas, Adidas shower shoes, Chuck Taylor sneakers, cabana sets, electronic devices as accessories, virtually the entire and seemingly unending trend for camouflage cloth and the Afro all over again.

title: BRITAIN: HOTEL ACQUISITION
description: As hotel operators compete for trade among Europe's business travelers, the Hilton Group, which owns the Hilton chain outside the United States, said it would buy Scandic Hotels of Sweden for $890 million, adding 133 hotels in Scandinavia and 21 in other parts of Europe. The price represents a 31 percent premium over Scandic's closing price last Friday. The Swedish company's stock rose 30.5 kronor, to 140.5 kronor; Hilton's stock fell slightly in London. Hilton's chief executive, David Michels, said he was seeking acquisitions in Europe. As hotel groups consolidate in Europe, Marriott International and the Holiday Inns of Bass P.L.C. are also moving to extend chains on the Continent. Alan Cowell

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIER, HORACE
description: BIER-Horace. On April 20. The Union for Traditional Judaism and the Institute of Traditional Judaism record with profound sorrow the loss of Horace Bier, the founding president of the UTJ and the first and only chairman of the ITJ. Without Mr. Bier's vision, loyalty and generosity the achievements of these organizations and many others would not have been possible. The entire UTJ and ITJ communities extend deepest sympathies to his wife, Pauline, to his children, Joyce, Bruce, Bryan, and Joseph, to his grandchildren and great-grandchildren. May they be comforted among the mourners for Zion and Jerusalem, and may his memory be a blessing for all who were privileged to know him.

title: Foreign Affairs; Protesting for Whom?

While the protesters in Quebec were busy denouncing globalization in the name of Africans and the world's poor, Africans themselves will tell you that their problem with globalization is not that they are getting too much of it, but too little.

title: Campaign Reform in the House
description: Three weeks have elapsed since the Senate passed the McCain-Feingold campaign finance bill, but it is not too soon for supporters of reform to press for action in the House. The cause there is to be taken up once again by Christopher Shays of Connecticut and Martin Meehan of Massachusetts, whose version of the bill passed in 1998 and 1999 by wide margins. Success this year, however, hinges on the steady determination of Richard Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, and on the willingness of the House speaker, Dennis Hastert, to reject the stalling tactics supported by Tom DeLay and other Republicans and schedule a quick vote.

title: AD GROWTH SLOWS SHARPLY
description: The slowdown in advertising spending in online media was underscored yesterday when the Interactive Advertising Bureau in New York released its ad revenue report for 2000. The report, compiled by PricewaterhouseCoopers, showed that ad revenue in the fourth quarter rose 8.5 percent from the third quarter, to $2.16 billion from $1.99 billion. That was a far lower rate than in previous years, when spending rose 30 percent to 40 percent from the third quarter to the fourth quarter. The increase in the fourth quarter from the fourth quarter of 1999, when ad revenue totaled $1.78 billion, was 21.3 percent, also well below usual. The bureau attributed the slowdown to the faltering national economy as well as the higher revenue base as online ads grew. For all 2000, Internet ad revenue totaled $8.2 billion, up 78 percent from $4.6 billion in 1999. Stuart Elliott

title: When Lead Paint Vanishes and Returns

title: Suit on Sex Harassment at Work Fails to Meet High Court's Test
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that because the federal law against sex discrimination in the workplace does not extend to isolated incidents of teasing or sexual innuendo, it also does not shelter employees who complain about such incidents from retaliation by their employers.

The rate is good through Aug. 31 and includes use of the hotel's Olympic-size pool and fitness room. Information: (800) 529-4683 or www.fourpointslax.com .

title: Court Allows Arrest for Minor Violations
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  In a decision that could affect drivers and police agencies across the country, the Supreme Court ruled today that the police can handcuff and arrest people even for minor offenses, like failure to use seat belts, which are normally punished by fines.

title: Senate Panel Votes to Repeal Power Law
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  A Senate committee today voted to repeal a Depression-era law that restricts ownership and operations of utilities, a perennial goal of large electricity providers that has gathered momentum because of California's power crisis.

title: Suffolk Day-Labor Center Appears Doomed as Veto Draws Support
description: Several Suffolk County lawmakers said today that they would let stand County Executive Robert J. Gaffney's veto of a bill to create a community support center for day laborers, an idea proposed after two Mexican workers were badly beaten and the racial tensions in the area were laid bare.

description: It's endearing to think of Igor Stravinsky in 1942 trying to compose a score for a film called ''The Commandos Strike at Dawn,'' about a Nazi attack on Norway. That project didn't work out for Stravinsky. Nor did his ambitions as a film composer.

title: Kenneth Mickey, Kansas City, Mo., November 2000
description: 'm in my office, about 150 feet underground. We are inside caves -- well, they call them caves, but they're really limestone mines. This is a subtropolis, a metropolis but underground. I am with Records Center of Kansas City. We store archival records: closed case files, patient charts, X-rays from hospitals, film and other records for other businesses. In the refrigerated film storage, we have 'Ben-Hur.' And in one corner, all the episodes of 'M*A*S*H' and 'Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea.' Most of the offices down here don't have windows. I've got a window. That day, I could see two trucks and a pillar and part of a wall. It's kind of nice, even though it's not exactly a C.E.O. view. And I'm the sales rep, so I get appointments and get out of here. The receptionist, she's here all day.

title: The Selling of Free Trade
description: The Summit of the Americas concluded Sunday with a call to create a free-trade area linking the hemisphere's democracies and their 800 million people by Jan. 1, 2005. Now comes the hard part -- turning that laudable abstraction into a concrete deal. Though a draft of an agreement will be published shortly, negotiating its details should prove challenging.

title: Mother and Sisters of Knicks Star Held Hostage for Hours
description: The mother and two sisters of Marcus Camby, the center for the New York Knicks, were held hostage at knifepoint for hours yesterday in their home near Hartford by a man who knew the family, the police said. The man, who repeatedly demanded to speak to Mr. Camby, surrendered after eight hours, the authorities said.

title: CONSECO TO ACQUIRE EXL, OUTSOURCING COMPANY
description: Conseco said yesterday that it would pay $52.6 million to buy EXL Service, an outsourcing company that Conseco's chairman, Gary Wendt, helped found. The action came after the insurer assigned 2,000 jobs to EXL in India. Mr. Wendt, the former chief executive of the General Electric Capital Corporation, invested $1.1 million in EXL two years ago after moving 4,000 GE Capital customer support and back-office jobs to India. Conseco's decision to outsource the jobs to EXL and to buy the company was approved by the board under an agreement with Mr. Wendt that does not allow him to be paid or recover his investment in EXL until Conseco recovers its investment in cost savings, the company said.

title: Peru's Reckless Shooting
description: It should not have taken the tragic deaths of two innocent members of an American missionary family to force Washington to re-examine its cooperation with Peru's risky drug interdiction program. Although the facts of last Friday's incident are still being sorted out, the deaths raise serious questions about how Peru's air force has been carrying out a program involving help from the Central Intelligence Agency to fight drug trafficking. The White House is right to suspend the program's operations until it can be sure more reliable controls are in place.

title: American Express First-Quarter Profit Fell 18%
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that its first-quarter profit fell 18 percent as it lost money on high-yield securities and customers spent less freely.

It sometimes takes years and many failed attempts before a problem drinker can finally achieve lasting sobriety.

title: OUTPOST.COM ALTERS SHIPPING POLICY
description: The struggling Internet retailer Outpost.com has changed its shipping policy for the second time in two months, settling on a two-tiered pricing plan in hopes of quelling mounting losses. The company, based in Kent, Conn., had offered free shipping since its inception in 1995. It began charging for shipments earlier this year but retreated after customers complained the price was too high. ''We loved being able to offer you free shipping on your orders for a couple of years, but I think we all knew that, like the Beatles, it couldn't last forever,'' the Outpost chief executive, Darryl Peck, wrote in a letter to customers over the weekend. The news comes just a few days after Outpost announced it would lay off 30 percent of its workers and named Mr. Peck, its founder, as chief executive and president. Laurie J. Flynn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIANCHI, ANNE
description: BIANCHI-Anne, 53. Founder of Toscana Saporita Cooking School & author of many books on Italian culture and cuisine, died April 22nd. Survived by her mother, Maria Bianchi of Massarosa, Italy, and her sister, Gloria Piccolella of New Jersey.

title: Regents Study Shows Gains For Students In Special Ed
description: The number of special-education students who took and passed state tests in New York has jumped sharply over the past five years, suggesting the preliminary success of a plan to stem the use of special education as a dumping ground for difficult students, the Board of Regents said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARVEY, CLARA
description: HARVEY-Clara. Died April 20, 2001. Loved by daughters Lisa and Cynthia, sisters Ethel and Juanita, grandson Conal and nieces and nephews. Mrs. Harvey gave so much of herself to her daughters. Born in Mexico, she resided in California (where she married Gordon Harvey-the marriage ended in 1973) until daughter Cynthia joined American Ballet Theatre in 1974, when she moved to New York. In New York, she worked for Manufacturers' Hanover Trust in the Leasing Department. In 1994, she returned to California, this time living closer to daughter Lisa. In Los Angeles, she began a shortlived career as an actress doing several commercials for Hispanic television in particular, including ads for Miller Lite Beer, Cigna Health Insurance and Southwest airlines to name but a few. Clara moved back to New York in early 2000 and after a period of ill health, succumbed to pneumonia. There will not be a viewing. Mass to be held Wednesday April 25 at 10AM at St. Elizabeths' Church-187th Street off St. Nicholas Avenue, Washington Heights. Her love of the music and dance, her tenacity and intelligence and especially her beautiful brown eyes, will be a memory everlasting.

title: Argyll, 63, Chief of Clan Of Campbell, Is Dead
description: Ian Campbell, 12th Duke of Argyll and Chief of the Clan Campbell, who rebuilt Inveraray Castle, his family's ancestral Scottish home, after a disastrous fire and entertained views on Scottish history that drew sharp criticism, died on Sunday in London during heart surgery. He was 63.

title: Takeover of Istanbul Hotel Ends in a Quiet Surrender
description: The takeover of a luxury hotel in Istanbul ended quietly yesterday when the pro-Chechen gunmen released their hostages and surrendered to the police. The gunmen said they had not intended to harm anyone and wanted only to protest Russian military action in Chechnya.

title: A Leapfrog Pattern in Pay Pacts for Airline Pilots
description: Last summer, United Airlines set a new standard for pilot pay when it agreed to raise wages 22.5 percent to 28 percent. The airline has since said it was forced to offer such generous increases after Delta Air Lines increased pay rates on the Boeing 777 the previous year 18 percent above the industry peak.

title: Parent of SwissAir in Deal To Shed Some Hotel Assets
description: The financially beleaguered SAirGroup, parent of Swissair, said today that it had reached agreement to sell its Swisstel chain of 23 luxury hotels to Raffles Holdings of Singapore for $170 million and some related assets to other buyers for a another $65 million. Raffles, majority-owned by CapitaLand, a Singapore land developer, will also assume $72 million of debt.

title: Corrections

title: CHINA: PROFIT AT OIL CONCERN
description: PetroChina, China's biggest oil company, said profit more than doubled last year because of cost cuts and a 61 percent rise in its crude oil price. Net income rose to 55.2 billion yuan ($6.7 billion), or 0.32 yuan a share, from 27 billion yuan, or 0.17 yuan a share, in 1999, better than the 52.8 billion yuan forecast by analysts.

title: Editor of The Post Steps Down, Leaving Her Staff Surprised

title: In a Cost-Cutting Move, 3M Says It Will Eliminate 5,000 Jobs
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, reacting to the slowing economy with a pre-emptive strike, said yesterday that it would cut 7 percent of its work force, or about 5,000 jobs.

title: Generic Medicine for AIDS Raises New Set of Concerns
description: Recent offers by companies in India and elsewhere to make low-cost generic drugs for AIDS, and the decision on Thursday by brand-name drug makers to stop fighting South Africa's efforts to import cheaper products, have raised hopes that the medicines will finally reach at least some of the 25 million people infected with the virus in sub-Saharan Africa. But AIDS experts are divided over whether drug manufacture in developing countries is really the best way to ease the crisis.

title: BRAZIL: OIL COMPANY IS FINED
description: Brazil's state-owned oil company, Petrleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras, was fined a total of $8.9 million by federal environmental regulators after recent accidents on two offshore rigs spilled nearly 400,000 gallons of oil into the sea 120 miles off the coast of Rio de Janeiro. Petrobras was also cited for inappropriately using detergents while cleaning up the smaller of the two spills, caused by an uncontrolled gush of oil earlier this month. A final report on the cause of the explosion that killed 11 workers and sank the company's largest oil platform in March is still pending. Jennifer L. Rich

title: Recife Resounds With the Futurist Mix of a Rock Hero
description: Every properly documented art movement glorifies its sacred birthplace. For the mangue beat movement it was the Soparia, a little bar near the beach in this northeastern port city. In the mid-1980's, Chico Science, a poor mestizo kid who liked break-dancing, graffiti and rapping, used to go there to meet his friends, who would become his band, Nao Zumbi.

title: ALLTRISTA GETS BID BY INVESTMENT PARTNERSHIP
description: Marlin Partners II L.P., an investment partnership based in New York, has bid $17 a share to buy the Alltrista Corporation, a manufacturer that makes metals and plastics, according to a regulatory filing. Marlin Partners already holds 9.8 percent of the outstanding shares in Alltrista, which is based in Indianapolis and makes jars and coin blanks. Alltrista's stock rose $2.55, or 20 percent, to $15.36 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Metro Business Briefing; PRICELINE CEO COMPENSATION
description: Daniel Schulman, the chief executive officer of Priceline.com, was given a $9 million pay package in 2000 to assume leadership of the online seller of airline tickets and hotel rooms as it struggles to turn around a history of losses. The Norwalk, Conn., company, known for its pitch urging customers to name their own price, has cut staff and put expansion plans on hold to try to achieve its first profit. Mr. Schulman, who was promoted to chief executive officer last May, signed a new contract in December with a $3.8 million restricted stock award, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company also forgave Mr. Schulman $4.8 million of debt, half of the loans he has received from the company since joining in 1999, plus interest. He earned a $329,808 salary for the year. ''We believed that it was critical for Priceline.com to maintain senior management continuity in order to facilitate the company's turnaround plan and differentiate Priceline.com from other companies in the e-commerce arena that were experiencing a flight of senior management talent,'' the company said in its proxy filing.

Dorothy was the widow of William Campbell Steere, Sr, distinguished international botanist, mentor to generations of researchers, and Garden President from 1958 to 1972. Known with great affection as the ''First Lady of the Garden'', Dorothy touched the lives of Garden staff from the 1950s to as recently as last week. We will cherish the memories of her delightful sense of humor, spirited curiosity, unfailing acumen, and enduring warmth. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her son William C. Steere, Jr., Vice-Chairman of the Garden, and his wife Lynda, her daughter Alice Steere Coulombe and her husband Joseph and her grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Wilson Nolen, Chairman Thomas J. Hubbard, Chairman Emeritus Gregory Long, President Brian M. Boom, Ph.D, Vice-President for Botanical Science and Pfizer Curator of Botany Patricia K. Holmgren, Ph.D, Director Emeritus, NYBG Herbarium

Executives close to the deal said OM Group was negotiating to sell the assets to the Ferro Corporation, another chemicals company in Cleveland. Credit Suisse First Boston advised OM Group in conjunction with the acquisition, the company said. Squire, Sanders & Dempsey provided legal counsel.

title: Squandering Their Hopes In a Welter Of Anguish

The subject, for lack of a better term, is existential ennui, but don't be deterred. title: Metro Business Briefing; ROHATYN'S NEW VENTURE
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker who helped save New York City from bankruptcy in the 1970's and recently completed four years as the United States ambassador to France, is starting a new venture. Rohatyn Associates will provide financial advice to corporations and manage the Rohatyn family's financial affairs and philanthropic activities, among other endeavors, Mr. Rohatyn said yesterday. He is also to become a senior adviser to the Lazard group and is chairman of the board of Aton Pharma, a company recently formed to develop and test a promising cancer therapy. Mr. Rohatyn began at Lazard in 1949 and stayed for nearly half a century, rising to senior partner and managing director. ''This will allow me to organize my business, personal and nonprofit activities most effectively,'' Mr. Rohatyn, 73, said of his new firm. ''My objective is to maintain a very small firm with a very limited group of clients.''

title: VISX ASKS ICAHN FOR DETAILS ON BUYOUT OFFER
description: Visx Inc., a leading maker of lasers used to correct vision, asked the financier Carl C. Icahn to present details of his $1.84 billion buyout proposal to its board. Mr. Icahn, who has a 9.9 percent stake in Visx and is trying to oust the board and sell the company, offered $32 a share on Friday, a 54 percent premium to the closing price of Visx shares the day before the proposal. Visx said it was skeptical of Mr. Icahn's offer and considered it a ploy to gain votes for his slate of directors before the company's May 4 annual meeting. Visx wants Mr. Icahn to provide definitive terms of his proposal. Mr. Icahn has said he intends to sell Visx to a larger company and has had discussions with two ophthalmic companies he has declined to identify.

So after songs like ''Misunderstood,'' in which it dawns too late on a heart-stricken man that he has been dumped, he gave the crowd the unreleased ''My Daddy Is a Mummy,'' a clever, simple rockabilly-style song he wrote to teach schoolchildren about ancient Egypt.

title: Metro Business Briefing; BOAR'S HEAD MOVING
description: Boar's Head Provisions, a century-old maker of delicatessen meat and cheese products, will move its corporate headquarters from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to Sarasota, Fla., this summer. The company made its announcement yesterday after being enticed by one of its major customers, Publix Super Markets. Boar's Head, whose more than 350 deli products are found at Publix supermarkets and at independent stores, will move five top management members to Sarasota. Thirty-nine management and clerical positions will be open for local hiring, said RuthAnn LaMore, the company's director of marketing. The company has maintained sales, marketing and training offices in downtown Sarasota for about five years. The company, which operates five processing plants around the country and employs 2,500 people, will maintain its sales office and distribution center in New York.

title: Metro Business Briefing; SOLAR POWER PROJECT

George E. Pataki of New York said Sunday. In a statement, Mr. Pataki said the project was the largest ever for commercial application of solar power by a single user. The Long Island Power Authority will pay $4.5 million of the $9.3 million cost for the system. The Fala DM Group will have an option to sell unneeded electricity to the authority. Bert J. title: ITALY: PHONE DIRECTORY PURCHASE

title: QUORUM HEALTH GROUP SETTLES MEDICARE FRAUD CASE
description: The Quorum Health Group, which owns and manages hospitals, said yesterday that it completed an $82.5 million settlement with the Justice Department in a Medicare fraud case. Quorum of Brentwood, Tenn., reached a tentative $77.5 million settlement in October in a case that accused the the company of inflating cost reports to maximize payments from Medicare. It also agreed in October to pay $18 million to settle a lawsuit that said the company improperly shifted costs at an Alabama hospital to its home-health agency. Triad Hospitals is expected to close a $2.4 billion transaction to buy Quorum this week.

title: W. W. GRAINGER CLOSING WEB VENTURE, CUTTING 178 JOBS
description: W. W. Grainger, a seller of maintenance and repair products, will cut 178 jobs as it shuts down a money-losing Internet venture. The cuts, representing about 1 percent of Grainger's 16,000 employees, will take place at the Material Logic unit, which is based in the Chicago suburb of Lincolnshire. It operates three Web sites, FindMRO.com, TotalMRO.com and MROverstocks.com. Grainger, which sells products like compressors, lighting equipment and motors, said the sites had failed to attract enough customers. Grainger.com, the company's main venue for selling products on line, will not be affected, said a spokeswoman, Jan Tratnik. Grainger, which is based in Lake Forest, Ill., will take second-quarter charges of $24 million, or 25 cents a share, to close Material Logic and $14 million, or 15 cents, to write off investments in other failed technology ventures.

title: Scientists Often Mum About Ties To Industry
description: Scientists who report research findings are expected to divulge any financial ties that might influence their work. But often they do not, according to the first comprehensive analysis of disclosure policies in science and medical journals.

title: MANPOWER PLANS TO BUY AN ACCOUNTING SERVICES FIRM
description: Manpower Inc., the temporary-staffing company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Jefferson Wells International for $174 million in cash and assumed debt. Jefferson Wells, which is based in Milwaukee and provides audit, accounting, technology and tax services, has 24 offices in the United States and Canada. It employs 1,500 people. Manpower, also based in Milwaukee, has 3,700 offices in 59 countries. It had revenue of $10.8 billion last year. Manpower said it expected the acquisition to generate revenue of more than $175 million in the next year. The amount of debt in the transaction was not disclosed.

title: Teacher Programs at CUNY, Once at Risk, Are Now Passing
description: Most of the teacher education programs at the City University of New York that were threatened with closure just a few years ago have emerged from the danger zone, improving the rates at which their students pass the teacher certification examinations, according to figures released yesterday by the State Education Department.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALK, DAVID J.

His humor and wisdom will be missed by all who knew him. Predeceased by his first wife, Selma, of 28 years, and the last survivor of five siblings: Irving, Michael, Ann & Ray. David is survived by his loving second wife, Loretta, his children: Connie (Mico) Sopic & Leon (Lisa Phillips) Falk & grandchildren Aliosha, Sasha, Natalie, Milan, Olivia and Savannah. David is also survived by stepchildren: Elisa (Steven) Weinstein, Edward (Cynthia) Wagner, Denise (Mitchell) Jaffe and grandchildren Arielle, Max, Paul, Michaela, Sage, and Kendra. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice and Home Care by the Sea, 1531 West Palmetto Parkway, Boca Raton, FL. 33486 for their compassion and care during a difficult time.

title: Time for Europe to Lead
description: Where is Europe when the world needs it? As international finance ministers and central bank governors gather in Washington this week for the spring meetings of the Group of Seven and International Monetary Fund, the prospects for world growth look gloomier each day. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, is doing his best to shore up the American economy, with four interest rate cuts already this year and promises of more to come. But his European counterparts have kept euro interest rates on hold. Few expect the European Central Bank to cut rates when it meets Thursday.

title: Corrections

title: THE BOSS; The Discovery of Flying Solo
description: My mother's father was fascinated with the world and wanted to share. When I was 12, he sent the family to Oslo to see an eclipse of the sun. A year later, the day my aunt got married, we went to the San Carlos airport south of San Francisco so he could take a free flying lesson. My grandmother looked at my grandfather and said, ''James Murray Kemp, how could you possibly do this on this day.'' He said, ''What better day to do this?'' He learned to fly at age 60.

description: Senator Robert G. Torricelli passionately defended himself today before a closed-door session of Democratic senators, fellow lawmakers said, telling them that it was ''painful and difficult'' to come under investigation but insisting that he had not received ''illegal gifts'' from a supporter.

title: Signaling Change, Bush Picks 3 Executives for Pentagon Jobs
description: President Bush signaled his intention to impose a more corporate management style on the Pentagon bureaucracy today by nominating three business executives -- two of them from the weapons industry -- to be the secretaries of the Army, Navy and Air Force.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the aftermath of protests and vandalism in Cincinnati quoted two phrases incorrectly in a comment from Scott Greenwood, a lawyer at the Ohio chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union, which is a plaintiff in a suit contending that the police engaged in racial profiling. Discussing efforts to include representatives from as many community groups as possible in mediating the suit, Mr. Greenwood said that African-American leaders would be included and that the objective was to achieve comprehensive results through a settlement. He did not use the expressions ''Afro-American'' and ''comprehensible results.''

title: 13 NATIONS JOIN FRAUD INITIATIVE

The multilingual site provides consumer protection tips and an online complaint form that will feed information to consumer protection officials in participating countries. John Schwartz

title: French and Italian Preschools: Models for U.S.?
description: Observing Isabelle Guigou guide 24 young pupils through a preschool class at a Parisian primary school is a little like watching Napoleon direct his troops at the battle of Austerlitz -- discipline and order rolled out on a vast plain of puzzles, flash cards and poster paint.

description: Supreme Court justices heard oral arguments today on whether legal immigrants convicted of certain crimes could be deported even if their convictions predated a 1996 law that mandated their expulsion.

The work of the Smithsonian Institution's Anacostia Museum and Center for African-American History and Culture, the Web site, www.si.edu/anacostia/food, is rich with archival photos and fascinating details.

description: Among the oddballs and exhibitionists who clustered around Andy Warhol in the 1960's and 70's perhaps the scariest was Brigid Berlin, a chubby, motormouthed rebel from an upper-crust New York City family who relished the way her ''underground'' celebrity embarrassed her proper conservative parents. Her father, Richard Berlin, a friend of Richard M. Nixon and an admirer of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, ran the Hearst Corporation, which he had helped save from bankruptcy in the 40's. Her mother, Honey, was an elegant, ladies-who-lunch-style socialite of the old school.

title: Women Who Go Down to the Sea for Salmon
description: Is fish that takes a week to get from sea to market really fresh? Lori Whitmill and Sherry Tuttle (above, from left), who own Rose Fisheries in Sitka, Alaska, look at freshness another way. They go out on their fishing boat, the Rose, to catch Alaskan king and coho salmon with hook and line, not in nets, and then gut and flash-freeze them on board. But selling the fish to consumers obsessed with freshness (which, to most, means never frozen) is another matter, as Ms. Tuttle found a few weeks ago, when she gave out samples at Fairway on Broadway. Skeptical customers were pleasantly surprised after tasting the fish.

description: Cooper Industries, the maker of Halo lighting fixtures and Crescent wrenches, will cut 2,000 jobs, or about 6 percent of its work force of 34,300, by the end of the year as it moves production to Mexico and Asia to reduce expenses. Cost savings from the job cuts have not been forecast yet, said John Breed, a spokesman for Cooper, which is based in Houston. Work hours are being reduced as well. Cooper also said first-quarter earnings fell 33 percent, led by a decline in sales in the tool and hardware business. Profit was also hurt in telecommunications and electrical products.

He rose to the top of the governing Liberal Democratic Party today by exploiting his bad-boy image within a political organization whose rank-and-file members, like the public at large, are longing for a plain-spoken leader with charisma and a vision of a new, politically and economically vibrant Japan.

At Maxmil Caf and Crperie, an inviting new spot at 642 Amsterdam Avenue (91st Street), Sam Moamen, far left and center, a Tunisian, makes fresh crepes, some with French fillings like ratatouille, and some not, like a spinach, Swiss cheese and sun-dried tomato crepe, left. Mr. Moamen's menu of 10 savory crepes to eat in or to go, $7.95 each, includes some with Middle Eastern ingredients. Sweet crepes filled with Nutella, ice cream or berries are $4 to $5.95. Breakfast crepes are $3.95 to $4.95. The savory crepes are made with white flour, but on request, Mr. Moamen will use a buckwheat flour blend, as the French do. There are also sandwiches and salads.

title: One Awful Night in Thanh Phong

title: AUSTRALIA: INFLATION HEATS UP
description: Consumer prices in Australia rose 1.1 percent in the first quarter, nearly twice as fast as expected. Food was largely responsible; vegetables alone rose 20 percent because of short supply caused by floods in Northeast Australia. title: RUSSIA: STEEL LIMITS CHALLENGED
description: Russia's biggest steel producers appealed on Monday to the Russian government to cancel a trade agreement with the United States that limits their access to the American market, according to the Russian daily Vedomosti. Russia, the world's largest steel producer in Soviet times, has lost most of its American market since the United States began imposing restrictions on imports, saying Russia was producing and selling at below-market prices. Russian producers said they had prepared a study they hoped would prove that their metal was priced fairly and should not be subject to limitations, the paper reported.

title: Making a Case for Healing, Even of Holocaust Wounds
description: ''The Gathering'' by Arje Shaw isn't a terribly good play, but it is an affecting sermon. The issue is forgiveness, the lesson is that the endless harboring of anger and resentment -- even over the egregious cruelties of the Holocaust -- is a soul-warping endeavor, and the message is that, for their own good as well as the world's, it is time for Jewish survivors to let go of their vengefulness and allow the healing to begin.

title: Getting It Right on Taiwan
description: American arms sales to Taiwan have been a delicate issue since President Nixon signed the Shanghai communiqu in 1972. China opposes the sale of military equipment to the island, but Taiwan's defenders are quick to criticize any American president perceived as exposing the island to Chinese aggression. President Bush, for whom relations with China have provided a tense introduction to superpower diplomacy, has chosen a course of diplomatic caution by assembling an arms sales package that sends appropriate signals in both directions. Taiwan will not get the advanced American radar and missile defense systems it sought, at least for now. However, Washington will strengthen the island's navy and increase its ability to cope with a future Chinese blockade. Instead of letting tensions surrounding the accidental downing of an American spy plane off the Chinese coast dominate the deliberations, Mr. Bush followed the consensus advice of senior State Department, Pentagon and White House officials.

The United States Committee on Foreign Investment, which considers national security issues when foreign companies buy into the American market, sent its recommendations to Mr. Bush; he is expected to make a decision within 15 days, the companies said. ASM Lithography, which develops systems used to map semiconductor circuitry, said in October it would buy Silicon Valley for $1.6 billion. The deal cleared an antitrust review last year. I am with Records Center of Kansas City. We store archival records: closed case files, patient charts, X-rays from hospitals, film and other records for other businesses. title: Food Stuff: Women Who Go Down to the Sea for Salmon
description: Is fish that takes a week to get from sea to market really fresh? Lori Whitmill and Sherry Tuttle, who own Rose Fisheries in Sitka, Alaska, look at freshness another way. They go out on their fishing boat, the Rose, to catch Alaskan king and coho salmon with hook and line, not in nets, and then gut and flash-freeze them on board. But selling the fish to consumers obsessed with freshness (which, to most, means never frozen) is another matter, as Ms. Tuttle found a few weeks ago, when she gave out samples at Fairway on Broadway. Skeptical customers were pleasantly surprised after tasting the fish.

''We looked at all the options, including selling Tinsley Laboratories'' to allay national security concerns, said ASM's chief financial officer, Peter Wennink, in a telephone interview. The deal for Silicon Valley, based in San Jose, Calif. was arranged in October and is awaiting results of an investigation into whether it would compromise United States intelligence secrets. ASM's purchase would make it a leading maker of machines that print circuits onto semiconductors. President Bush has until midnight, May 8, to decide whether to approve the acquisition after a government committee has reviewed the purchase for 45 days, ASM said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DECOSSE, JEROME J., M.D., PHD.
description: DECOSSE-Jerome J., M.D., PhD. The Boards, Faculty, and Staff of Weill Medical College of Cornell University and New York-Presbyterian Hospital mourn the passing of our distinguished colleague Dr. Jerome J. DeCosse. Dr. DeCosse was the first holder of the Medical College's Lewis Thomas University Professorship and had been Professor & Vice Chairman of the Department of Surgery since 1978. The author of more than 250 articles and books, he was a leader in establishing guidelines for the detection, treatment, & prevention of colorectal cancer. He expanded our understanding of patients with hereditary colon cancer by recognizing their special needs. An outstanding educator of medical students, surgical residents, and surgeons, he served on innumerable professional and national committees, and, despite illness, he worked tirelessly until his death for the Department of Surgery, the Hospital, and the College. His intelligence, his keen wit, and his personal warmth will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Contributions to an endowed professorship in Dr. DeCosse's name may be sent to the Development Department, Weill Cornell Medical College, 525 E. 68th St., Box 123, New York 10021. Antonio M. Gotto, Jr., M.D. Dean, Weill Cornell Medical College Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO, NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital John M. Daly, M.D. Chairman, Department of Surgery

Japan's gross domestic product rose a revised 0.7 percent in real terms in October, November and December from the previous quarter, compared with a preliminary estimate of 0.8 percent growth, as net exports dipped and as companies made modest spending plans amid increasing gloom in Japan, the world's second-largest economy.

Banks applying to open branches in the district of South Harlem, which stretches from 110th to 120th Street and from Morningside Avenue to Fifth Avenue, are entitled to a partial property tax exemption and other incentives. title: Warhol Didn't Sleep Here, But You Can, in His Cottage

The villa at left seems gently Palladian, though with corrugated metal roofs, plywood walls, polished concrete floors and pathways of fine granite sand. The hotel, in Sonoma County in the Northern California wine country, is owned by Pat and Peter Lenz, East Coast transplants who owned the Moveable Feast restaurant and the Lenz Vineyards and Winery on Long Island. ''Being an outdoor person,'' said Mr. Lenz, who was born in Germany, ''I wanted to try the West Coast weather.'' His wife, a sculptor born in New York, designed the secluded hotel inside and out. The Lenzes plan to offer a new wine in two years. Rates for the six villas and four cottages are $225 to $325 a night. At 421 Foss Street, Healdsburg, Calif.; (800) 431-9341 or www.duchamphotel.com.

title: Kenneth Mickey, Kansas City, Mo., November 2000
description: 'm in my office, about 150 feet underground. We are inside caves -- well, they call them caves, but they're really limestone mines. This is a subtropolis, a metropolis but underground. I am with Records Center of Kansas City. We store archival records: closed case files, patient charts, X-rays from hospitals, film and other records for other businesses. In the refrigerated film storage, we have 'Ben-Hur.' And in one corner, all the episodes of 'M*A*S*H' and 'Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea.' Most of the offices down here don't have windows. I've got a window. That day, I could see two trucks and a pillar and part of a wall. It's kind of nice, even though it's not exactly a C.E.O. view. And I'm the sales rep, so I get appointments and get out of here. The receptionist, she's here all day.

title: $49 MILLION TO BE INVESTED IN CHINESE VENTURE
description: Ford Motor agreed to invest $49 million in a Chinese joint venture that will assemble passenger cars in that country, which is expected to eventually become one of the world's largest car markets. But the modest investment reflects the difficulty the company has faced in finding a suitable project and reflects the market's slower-than-expected growth. General Motors has invested more than $1 billion in two auto plants in China so far. Ford's partner, the Chongqing Changan Automobile Company, is China's No. 3 carmaker and is based in the central Chinese city of Chongqing. The venture is expected to begin production in 2003. title: EUROPE CLEARS LIBERTY MEDIA-UNITEDGLOBALCOM DEAL

The companies will combine most of their international cable businesses in a transaction valued at $4.02 billion when it was announced last June. The terms were changed in February after bondholders rejected the transaction. The merger gives Liberty Media, which already has $54.2 billion invested in cable, phone and Internet companies, access to UnitedGlobalCom subscribers in Europe, Latin America and Australia. UnitedGlobalCom's European unit, United Pan-Europe Communications, is the No. 2 cable provider there. Liberty has stakes in Argentina and Mexico.

title: Bomb Kills 6 in Chechnya
description: Six Chechen policemen died today and five people were wounded when a bomb destroyed a wing of a police headquarters in Gudermes, the Moscow-appointed administration's temporary capital in Chechnya. Viktor Dakhnov, the republic's new prosecutor general, blamed rebels for the explosion, saying they were trying to disrupt the government as it is moving to new quarters in Grozny, the regular capital. Later today, a car bomb with 260 pounds of explosives was discovered and defused in Grozny near the new government building.

title: Upset in Japan
description: The politician selected this week as the next leader of Japan talks and acts differently, and looks different, from the failed prime ministers of the last decade or so. Junichiro Koizumi -- a maverick with modishly long hair, a taste for rock music and a blunt manner -- won an unusual popular vote to become president of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, which is tantamount to becoming prime minister. He has made welcome pledges to restructure the party and reform the Japanese economy, but his outsider status is likely to make it difficult to accomplish these goals. And if he fails to convince the Japanese people of his abilities, he may be out of the job by summertime.

title: Hard Drive With CD Burner That Acts Like a Tape Deck

''I probably shouldn't describe it this way, but it's an ultra-high-tech cassette deck,'' said Phil Shey, product training supervisor for the Yamaha Electronics Corporation of America.

title: A Fancy New Spot in Vegas, But Nary a One-Arm Bandit
description: It's not all neon and plaster Doges' palaces in Las Vegas. The Lloyd D. George U.S. Courthouse and Federal Building, designed by Mehrdad Yazdani of Cannon Dworsky in Los Angeles, could make a dent in the city's reputation for frivolous architecture. This $95 million building is one result of the Design Excellence Program, started 10 years ago by the General Services Administration in an effort to hire notable architects to help improve civic architecture. Under the program, Richard Meier designed two courthouses, in Phoenix and in Islip, N.Y. Mr. Yazdani's other public designs include the Vermont/ Santa Monica Metro Rail Station, with a stainless steel canopy like a giant eye. In Las Vegas he has created a courthouse that weds public and private, stately and light, the monumental leavened with human scale. The public plaza (inset), shaded by a steel and aluminum canopy, is a point of entry to the three-story rotunda and the jury assembly room. ''We think the courthouse needs to show the democratic nature of the justice system,'' Mr. Yazdani said. Above, a view through the rotunda, which serves as a ceremonial public lobby. The city of Las Vegas considers the courthouse, at Bridger Avenue and Las Vegas Boulevard, part of the continuing revitalization of the downtown area. Nearby, a county courthouse is being built, a county detention center is getting an addition designed by Mr. Yazdani and a new office building is in the works.

title: The War Within Bob Kerrey
description: In one sense, wars last as long as the lives of the soldiers who survive them. That is why the aging veterans of D-Day still weep to recall the costly landing on the Normandy beaches, and that is why a new generation of men in their 40's and 50's are haunted by operations such as that conducted by former Senator Bob Kerrey and six other Navy Seals in the village of Thanh Phong on the night of Feb. 25, 1969. A story to be published in The New York Times Magazine on Sunday and now available at The New York Times on the Web relates the tangled story of how Mr. Kerrey, then a lieutenant, and his men killed as many as 20 unarmed Vietnamese men, women and children in what was supposed to be an operation to capture a Vietcong official. The former senator says the event arose from the confusion of night combat but nonetheless filled him with shame, guilt and remorse throughout a political career based in part on the fact that he won the Medal of Honor under heroic circumstances in a later engagement. Another member of the squad says the victims included 14 or 15 women and children rounded up as a group and shot on Mr. Kerrey's direct order. It is a story that -- with its conflicting evidence, undeniable carnage and tragic aftermath -- sums up the American experience in Vietnam and the madness of a war that then, as now, seemed to lack any rationale except the wrecking of as many lives as possible on both sides.

title: Metro Business Briefing; LOSS AT WIT SOUNDVIEW
description: Wit SoundView Group, a New York investment bank, said yesterday that it would have a net loss of $22.6 million for the first quarter of this year. The loss was attributed to an overall drying up of public offerings, mergers and acquisitions. It was also seen as a sign of the poor financial condition of many institutional investors who poured money into technology ventures in recent years. The company reported a profit of $7.5 million in the first quarter of 2000, an increase of 10 cents per share, compared with a loss of 20 cents per share in the first quarter of 2001. Wit SoundView managed only one initial public offering of a company's stock in the first quarter of this year, down from 31 initial public offerings in the first quarter of 2000, company officials said. Shares in Wit SoundView, which also operates as an online brokerage and investment research firm, dropped 22 cents, or 9 percent, to $2.14 in Nasdaq trading yesterday.

title: Crushed Glass, Banana Trees: Just a Simple Little Garden
description: He first made his mark two years ago with a tiny garden of crushed glass and plants in the Echo Park neighborhood of Los Angeles. Now Andy Cao, below, who was born in Vietnam, has won the Rome Prize for landscape architecture. He recently designed the garden for the Chateau Marmont hotel in West Hollywood with his partner, Stephen Jerrom. It took Mr. Cao five weeks to build the 250-square-foot mural behind him, using purple, orange, midnight blue, cobalt blue, green and amber crushed glass from recycled beer and wine bottles. The two men also sprinkled glass and plants throughout the cottage courtyard garden, above, including banana trees transplanted from the Echo Park garden. ''Andy's exotic romanticism matches the mood of the Chateau Marmont precisely,'' said Andr Balazs, the hotel's owner.

title: McGraw-Hill Wins Suit Against Vanguard

Before this season, Mr. Goode had been forced to take two years off from the concert stage while he received treatment for a muscular ailment. But from the first rippling flourishes of the piano accompaniment he was at his exquisite best. Ms. Upshaw started to sing with the rosy sound and communicative joy her admirers cherish.

Sun, which manufactures computer servers and systems, said in an e- mail message to employees yesterday that all but "mission-critical" workers, like those involved in customer service, must take the week off, either as paid vacation or as an unpaid leave. The company's fiscal year begins that week and the Independence Day holiday falls in the middle of the week. Chris Gaither (NYT)

The investment was structured as a purchase of bonds convertible into shares, which represented about 1 percent of Samsung's equity. Since Intel announced its investment, Samsung shares have more than doubled, to 220,000 won ($168) today from less than 100,000 in early 1999.

title: Mr. Giuliani's Risky Budget
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's proposed $39.5 billion budget for the next fiscal year came with a note of caution yesterday. The huge surpluses of recent years cannot be counted on in the future, Mr. Giuliani said, and expenditures for next year will have to be kept under tight control. Unfortunately, the mayor's spending plan does not heed his own advice. Mr. Giuliani would cut taxes and increase spending so heavily that the next New York City mayor, to be elected in November, will immediately face annual deficits approaching $3 billion in following years. Mr. Giuliani and the City Council need to avoid leaving such a damaging legacy.

Mr. Levitt, a Wall Street veteran known for instituting tough federal guidelines that barred companies from disclosing financial information to stock analysts before investors, served as chairman of the S.E.C. from 1993 to 2001, chairman of the city's economic development corporation from 1989 to 1993, and was chairman of the American Stock Exchange. title: Metro Business Briefing; STATE STEPS INTO VERIZON DISPUTE

The union has said the reports contain inaccuracies and ''direct falsification,'' basing its charge, in part, on complaints that workers phone in on a union hotline. The company has called the charge false and the complaints unsubstantiated. A commission spokesman, David C. Flanagan, said the parties were also to work out procedures to prevent retribution against hotline users. A union research director, Kenneth Peres, said that in ordering the parties to resolve the dispute instead of doing its own investigation, the commission would ''default on its responsibility.'' A Verizon spokesman, Mark Marchand, said the commission's staff had found the company's procedures ''adequate to prevent any significant misreporting.'' Joseph P. Fried

title: SPAIN: DELAY IN TELEPHONE ADVANCE

MetLife, which is based in New York, acquired control of Conning in 1999 when it bailed out the company's parent, the GenAmerica Corporation, after a run on its assets.
