title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMPTON, PHILIP M.
description: HAMPTON-Philip M., who lived in New York City until 1996, former vice chairman of Bankers Trust Company, died on April 20, 2001 in Naples, Florida where he maintained a home. The cause of death was cancer. He was 68 years old. Mr. Hampton was born in Whittier, California and grew up in the Columbus, Ohio area. He graduated from Bexley High School in Bexley, Ohio and in 1954 earned a BA degree from Miami University in Oxford, Ohio. In 1965, he was awarded a degree in graduate banking studies from Stonier School of Banking at Rutgers University. In 1954 Mr. Hampton joined Bankers Trust Company in New York City. Over the next 35 years, he rose through the ranks from assistant treasurer to senior vice president and head of the US Banking Department in 1978. He held senior positions in marketing, operations, and strategic planning before becoming head of worldwide banking and investment activities. He was vice chairman and a director of Bankers Trust Company and Bankers Trust New York Corporation at his retirement in 1989. Upon Mr. Hampton's retirement the chairman's message stated: ''The loss is great for the company. What we have been able to accomplish simply would not have been possible without the standards that Phil set for commitment to our goals and collegial style.'' After retiring from Bankers Trust, Mr. Hampton became chairman of Metzler Corporation, the US affiliate of the German private bank, H. Metzler Seel, Sohn & Co. He joined R.H. Arnold & Co. in 1997. He has served as director of a number of corporations including Bibb Co., Hemasure, and Tyco International Ltd. His professional affiliations included directorships of the Empire State Chamber of Commerce and the New York State Bankers Association. He was a village trustee of Croton-on-Hudson, NY. Mr. Hampton retained a strong interest in his alma mater, Miami University of Ohio. For the last 25 years, Mr. Hampton has been a trustee of Carnegie Hall and a director of the New York Pops where he was chairman in 1997. Mr. Hampton is survived by his wife of 29 years Elaina Frutiger Hampton, and two sons, Mark L. Hampton of Durham, NC and John Andrew Hampton, USN, of Virginia Beach, VA. Their mother Jean Trout Hampton died in 1971. There are three grandchildren. Two sisters also survive him, Lucy H. Sohm of Scarsdale, NY and Linda H. McWhinney of Santa Fe, New Mexico. Though Mr. Hampton lived most of his adult life in New York City and Westchester County, he maintained ties with relatives in Ohio and in the Richmond, Indiana area, site of the Hampton family farm, as well as with boyhood and high school friends. A long time friend said, ''Phil Hampton has been known during his entire life for loyalty, superb judgment, good humor, and integrity.'' In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the New York Pops at 881 Seventh Avenue, New York, NY 10019. A memorial service will be held at a later date in the N.Y. area.

title: Policy Adjustments on Taiwan
description: In a pair of television interviews Wednesday, President Bush reformulated the diplomatic language that has long defined American policy on defending Taiwan. By openly declaring that America would defend Taiwan in the event of an unprovoked attack from mainland China, he broke new ground. But subsequent clarifications by Mr. Bush, the State Department and White House aides emphasized that the charged language was less significant than it sounded, and China would be wrong to read too much into it. It has long been assumed that the United States would help Taiwan defend itself against mainland aggression, and Mr. Bush, in later statements, made clear that the United States was sticking to the other half of its policy of strategic hedging. That is to say, the island could not count on American help if it provoked Beijing by declaring independence.

The shares will come from the 64 percent stake held in Reliance Petroleum by Reliance Industries, India's biggest petrochemicals maker. Reliance will then be left a 51 percent stake. Reliance would become the first Indian company to convert its local shares into overseas listed securities.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: WESTCHESTER HOME PRICES Despite the economic downturn, the price of homes in Westchester County has increased significantly this year, according to the Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service. The service announced yesterday that purchase prices for homes in the county had risen 11 percent for the first quarter in 2001, compared with the same period in 2000. The median price of a single-family home in early 2001 was $412,500, up from $372,000 a year earlier. The 2001 price is the highest ever recorded in a first quarter, according to the listing service. Donna M. Tierney, president of the Westchester County Board of Realtors, said that the stock prices had not affected the market. Ms. Tierney, a real estate broker specializing in Armonk and Chappaqua, said that buyers had been particularly interested in high-end homes ranging from $820,000 to $1 million.

title: CON EDISON TO SPEND $2.4 BILLION ON SYSTEM UPGRADES

Donohue Jr., senior vice president for electric operations. Con Ed's chief executive, Eugene R. McGrath, said last week that the company was spending $483 million this year to improve power transmission and distribution.

Ms. Seldes's appearance in this patched-together but still entertaining movie, around which dire rumors have swirled, is all too brief. But her character, the enraged, sex-starved wife of a wealthy right-wing gun nut (played by Charlton Heston with a Leslie Nielsen-style edge of self-parody) gives ''Town and Country'' a welcome jolt of outrageous comic adrenaline.

title: E.E.O.C. FILES DISCRIMINATION SUIT AGAINST NORTHWEST
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has sued the Northwest Airlines Corporation, saying it discriminated against people with seizure disorders. In the suit, filed in Federal District Court in Minneapolis, the commission said that the airline would not hire people with insulin-dependent diabetes or epilepsy requiring anti-seizure medication, for jobs as airplane cleaners and baggage handlers. The company violated the Americans With Disabilities Act by refusing to assess the ability of each applicant to perform the job and make accommodations to help employees, the commission stated. The company, based in Eagan, Minn., declined to comment on specifics of the case, but said that it ''evaluates applicants based on specific job requirements'' and its ''dedication to maintaining the highest safety standards for our customers and employees.''

title: Redemption of Sudanese Slaves
description: Sudan's 18-year civil war between an Arab-dominated government in the north and the long-subjugated black African south has claimed two million lives and forced more than four million southern Sudanese from their homes. It has also perversely transformed many international efforts to provide humanitarian assistance into fuel for further fighting. The latest example is a global campaign to curtail one of the most pernicious symptoms of this intractable war -- slavery. The efforts of well-meaning foreigners to buy the freedom of captive southern Sudanese -- a practice known as slave redemption -- may be expanding the very market it seeks to eliminate.

Mrs. Steere served on the executive board of the Garden. A celebration of the life of Dorothy Osborne Steere and Eucharist will be held on Sunday, April 29th at 10 A.M. at Christ Church, Bronxville, her parish church for over forty years. Survivors include her son, William C. Steere, Jr. of Rye, New York and her daughter, Mrs. Joseph Coulombe (Alice) of Pasadena, California, ten grandchildren and eleven great grandchildren. Private committal service will be held in Ann Arbor, Michigan. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Christ Church, 17 Sagamore Road, Bronxville, New York 10708, or the New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Kazimiroff Boulevard, Bronx, N.Y. 10458. title: Blocking Judicial Ideologues
description: With President Bush expected to unveil his first batch of judicial nominees in early May, the jostling is intensifying over the Senate's confirmation process. Senate Republicans who spent the better part of the past eight years stalling confirmation proceedings to block approval of President Clinton's centrist judicial choices are now maneuvering to fill as many of the existing 94 judicial vacancies as possible while their party still controls the evenly divided chamber. title: CANADA: POTATO AGREEMENT
description: Agriculture officials from the United States and Canada have reached an agreement that will allow farmers on Prince Edward Island to resume exporting their No. 1 crop -- potatoes -- if they meet certain conditions. The agreement appears to end a dispute by the nations, the world's largest trading partners, that was important enough to be raised at last week's Summit of the Americas in Quebec. United States officials banned the potatoes in October after a disease was found on a Prince Edward Island field. The disease is not harmful to humans, but it causes malformations in the potatoes. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: ONLINE GROCER OFFERS SURVIVAL PLAN
description: Webvan Group, the beleaguered online grocer, said yesterday that it would eliminate 885 jobs, cutting its work force by about 25 percent; close its operation in Atlanta; and try to increase its share price through a 25-to-1 reverse stock split. The company reported that its first-quarter loss more than doubled, to $217 million, or 46 cents a share, from $101.3 million, or 23 cents, a year earlier. Sales more than doubled, to $77.2 million from $37.5 million. Webvan, based in Foster City, Calif., also named Robert Swan, formerly the company's chief operating officer, as its new chief executive. He replaced George Shaheen, who resigned last week after an 18-month tenure. Webvan stock slid 10 cents, or 41.7 percent, to close at 14 cents a share. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

description: Hoping to pre-empt a possible bidding war for control of the Barrett Resources Corporation, the Royal Dutch/Shell Group raised its hostile offer yesterday to about $2 billion from $1.8 billion.

title: SOUTH KOREA: SAMSUNG'S PROFIT SLIPS
description: South Korea's largest conglomerate, the Samsung Group, said it had a pretax profit of $2.06 billion for the first quarter, 3.6 percent less than in the first three months of 2000. The Samsung Group, however, reported total sales of $23.7 billion, an increase of 3.6 percent. Lee Hak Soo, chief of the Samsung restructuring committee, attributed the rise in part to the depreciation of the won against the dollar, which he said had helped to compensate for the decline in semiconductor prices. Early this week, Samsung Electronics, the conglomerate's flagship company, also reported a lower first-quarter profit, though its results were not as weak as some analysts had expected.

title: MP3.COM REPORTS A LOSS
description: The online music provider MP3.com reported a first-quarter loss of $21.8 million, or 3 cents a diluted share, compared with a net loss of $8.4 million, or 13 cents, a year earlier. The results beat analyst estimates of 8 cents. Sales totaled $21.8 million, up from $17.5 million a year earlier but off slightly from $22 million in the fourth quarter of 2000. Further slackening in sales is expected in the second quarter, said Paul L. H. Ouyang, MP3.com's chief financial officer. ''We frankly do not see any rebound in the marketplace,'' he said. The San Diego-based company now has 150,600 approved artists on its site, a 4.3 percent increase over the previous month. The company also said that over 280 new artists had posted their music to MP3.com every day in the first quarter.

title: SPAIN: BANK'S PROFIT IS UP
description: Banco Santander Central Hispano, Spain's largest bank, posted first-quarter profit of 668 million euros ($599 million), up 38 percent from the period a year earlier, as a boom in Latin America made up for lower domestic earnings and an increase in bad-debt coverage ordered by the Bank of Spain. Net interest income rose to 2.41 billion euros ($2.16 billion) from 1.71 billion euros ($1.53 billion); operating costs increased 43 percent; and operating profit rose 31 percent, to 1.39 billion euros ($1.25 billion). Shares in Banco Santander Central Hispano rose nearly 5 percent, to 10.89 euros ($9.76), after news of the results and the suggestion that the company might sell its 7 percent stake in the Italian bank Sanpaolo IMI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FESEFELDT, JULIE
description: FESEFELDT-Julie. All of us at Slomin's mourn the passing, on April 26th, of our cherished Julie Fesefeldt, who from the age of 17 has been a part of our ''family''. Julie brought sunshine into the lives of all who knew her. In the last three years she increased our breast cancer awareness and epitomized courage in the face of adversity. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Bob and Tommy; Lucy, Donna, Jack and Michael.

title: 6 Red Cross Workers Slain Delivering Medicine in Congo
description: Six workers of the International Committee of the Red Cross were shot and hacked to death Thursday in northeast Congo, but a spokesman for the organization said today that it ``had no idea'' who carried out the attack, the worst on the group's aid staff in years.

title: Crashes! Women! But, Hey, What's Under the Hood?
description: If you're one of those effete East Coast intellectual types who think that auto racing is a pointless waste of time and fossil fuel, ''Driven'' is unlikely to change your mind. But even fans of open-wheel racing, the high-speed, high-stress pastime that is the subject of Renny Harlin's hectic new film, may walk away from it more logy than exhilarated. Though Mr. Harlin blends stunt driving and computer-generated daredevilry with film he shot at actual races, his technique is too jumpy and self-conscious to convey either the meticulous skill the sport demands or the visceral thrill it can produce.

title: Technology Slowdown in U.S. Weighs on Taiwan Chip Maker
description: HONG KONG, April 27  In a sign of how hard the slowdown in American technology spending has pinched Asian suppliers, Taiwan's largest chip maker, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, said today that its net income plunged 16.6 percent in the first quarter.

title: Al Hibbler, a Singer With Ellington's Band, Dies at 85
description: Al Hibbler, the blind baritone singer who came to prominence with Duke Ellington's orchestra in the 1940's and then scored a hit with his version of the Alex North song ''Unchained Melody,'' died on Tuesday at Holy Cross Hospital in Chicago. He was 85 and lived in Chicago.

description: About this time every year, the thoughts of publishers with horse books on their lists begin to turn to the Triple Crown, and from there to best-seller lists. Sometimes it works, as this year, with "Seabiscuit," and sometimes it doesn't, but the fact is that Americans love horses, and there are more horses living more or less useful lives right now than at any time since the rise of the automobile. Useful lives and good lives. Horses have moved out of the vehicle category and into the companion-animal category, and the resources consecrated to their welfare have proliferated accordingly.

description: MOSCOW, April 27 -- A court in the southwest Russian city of Voronezh convicted a visiting American Fulbright scholar on drug charges today and sentenced him to 37 months in a penal colony near Moscow.

title: A Need for Ambiguity
description: In an interview Wednesday on ABC's ''Good Morning America,'' President Bush said the United States would do ''whatever it took'' to help Taiwan defend itself, up to and including the use of military force. The White House later insisted that Mr. Bush had said nothing new. But his crystal-clear statement was unquestionably a departure from the longstanding policy of strategic ambiguity -- in which the United States expresses a strong interest in Taiwan's security while avoiding an outright promise to defend it in war.

title: Witnesses Testify Defendant Displayed Hatred of Blacks
description: A former girlfriend testified today that Thomas E. Blanton Jr., who is being tried on murder charges in the 1963 bombing of Birmingham's 16th Street Baptist Church, took her on dates to Ku Klux Klan rallies, to a Klan Christmas party and to a grocery store parking lot where she watched him pour acid on the seats of black motorists' cars. She also said she once watched him steer his car toward a black pedestrian, sending the man diving for the curb.

title: Foreign Affairs; It Takes A Village
description: When you read the statistics about AIDS infection in Africa, they are so staggering as to seem unbelievable. More than 25 million Africans are now living with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. Last year alone, 2.4 million Africans died from the disease, and it is expected to claim the lives of about half of all 15-year-olds. More than 35 percent of all adults in Botswana are H.I.V.-infected. Throughout Southern Africa, you can now find villages populated only by young people and grandparents, with the whole middle population killed off by AIDS, creating a huge orphan problem.

Schlossberg is seated near a drawing table in his loftlike office at 641 Avenue of the Americas, trying and failing to extrapolate a logical progression from his rather charmed -- he'd probably opt for a favorite word and call it cool -- life's journey, which now includes the design of the interactive database on Ellis Island that links Americans to 22 million ancestors.

title: OLD MUTUAL IS PAYING $635 MILLION FOR INSURER
description: Old Mutual P.L.C., South Africa's biggest money manager, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Fidelity and Guaranty Life Insurance Company for $635 million in cash and stock. Old Mutual, based in London, will pay the St. Paul Companies, Fidelity and Guaranty's parent, about $300 million in stock and $335 million in cash. Old Mutual, which moved its headquarters to London from Johannesburg in 1999, has been making acquisitions to reduce its reliance on South Africa, where it generates more than 75 percent of its profit. Last year, it bought United Asset Management, a fund manager based in Boston. Fidelity and Guaranty is based in Baltimore.

title: JAPAN: PROFIT FALLS AT FUJITSU
description: The electronics maker Fujitsu said its group profit for the fiscal year ended last month fell 80 percent, to 8.5 billion yen ($69.5 million), while sales grew 4.4 percent, to 5.48 trillion yen ($44.82 billion). Earnings were hurt by more than 100 billion yen ($817.9 million) in charges arising from a groupwide revamping, including changes in manufacturing operations. Group operating profit rose 62.7 percent, to 244 billion yen ($2.40 billion), because of strong sales of semiconductor products during the first half of the year. The company forecast that revenue for this year would rise to 5.8 trillion yen ($47.44 billion) and net profit would increase to 50 billion yen ($409 million). Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Three Directors In New Roles
description: For directors, the last couple of weeks before a film is released can be the most anxious. At that point it's out of their hands. The film has been made and edited. The marketing campaign is in full swing. All that remains is the arrival of the dreaded tracking numbers, which provide a running statistical commentary on how eager the ticket-buying public is to see the film.

title: McVeigh Says He Considered Killing Reno
description: Timothy J. McVeigh said yesterday that he bombed the Federal Building in Oklahoma City after considering a plan to assassinate Attorney General Janet Reno.

title: SWITZERLAND: CHEMICAL MAKER'S PROFIT IS UP
description: Ciba Specialty Chemicals said that its first-quarter net income rose 7 percent, to $68.9 million, helped by spending controls and lower debt costs, as sales remained flat at $1.9 billion. Ciba Specialty Chemicals predicted profit growth of slightly more than 10 percent for the rest of the year. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DECOSSE, JEROME J., MD.

Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC on Tuesday, May 1, 3-5 & 7-9PM. Memorial Mass at St. Catherine of Siena, 411 E. 68 St., NYC on Wednesday, May 2nd at 10AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Dr. Jerome DeCosse Endowed Professorship, Development Department, Weil Cornell Medical College, 525 E. 68 St., Box 123, NY, NY 10021 or the East Hampton Healthcare Foundation, POB 4184, East Hampton, New York 11937.

For 64 years, devoted wife of the late Emil Mogul. Beloved mother of Malcolm and his wife Harriette of Chappaqua, New York & Suzanne Spector of Cardiff, CA. Adored grandmother of Wendy, Donna, Sharrin, Jennifer, Fred & Douglas, great-grandmother of Sydney & Zachary. title: A Batting Guru, With Pitching
description: For half an hour yesterday, he was vintage Lou Piniella. The man who knows as much about hitting as any man alive or dead was in a corner of the visiting clubhouse at Yankee Stadium, watching videotape and working with Dan Wilson, the Seattle Mariners' catcher. The manager had spotted a flaw in Wilson's swing and wanted to eliminate it before another game passed.

title: Microbe in Salon Footbath Is Suspected in Boil Outbreak
description: A trip to the nail salon had far from beautiful results for at least 110 customers at a California establishment, government health officials reported here today. The customers, all but one of them women, developed boils and skin ulcers, apparently from a microbe growing in a footbath used for pedicures.

title: C.I.A. Opens Files on Hitler
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  A Central Intelligence Agency file on Adolf Hitler was made public today, including a report that described the Nazi leader as a "border case between genius and insanity" and predicted that Hitler could become the "craziest criminal the world ever knew."

title: CORNING SAYS IT PLANS TO CUT 1,000 ADDITIONAL JOBS
description: Corning, the fiber optics maker, said yesterday that it would eliminate 1,000 jobs on top of 3,300 already planned in recent weeks as it scrambles to rebound from a slump in telecommunications markets. Over all, the cuts account for about 10 percent of Corning's payroll of 40,000. The new cuts were announced yesterday as Corning reported a first-quarter net profit of $132 million, or 14 cents a share, up 71 percent from $77 million, or 9 cents a share, in last year's first quarter. Sales rose 42 percent, to $1.92 billion from $1.35 billion. Corning, however, cut its earnings estimate for 2001 to 90 cents to $1 a share, down from a revised forecast in March of $1.20 to $1.30.

title: IN THE STUDIO WITH/Tony Oursler; A Sculptor Of the Air With Video
description: MY work is more traditional than other media artists' work because I'm still making objects, just not conventional sculptures,'' says Tony Oursler, proving that everything in life, especially art, is a matter of perspective. He is surrounded at the moment by a mess of television antennas, plexiglass panels, wires, video cameras, projectors and other equipment crammed into his studio near City Hall. It's a Thursday afternoon, late March, a month before his new show, which opens tomorrow at Metro Pictures in Chelsea.

title: A New Politics of Pain: Japan's Tough Economic Repairmen
description: For Japan's reform-minded new government, the central economic challenge is that almost anything it does to try to fix the long-term problems of an out-of-control budget deficit and a wobbly banking system will almost certainly exacerbate the country's immediate woes and risk pushing the economy into a new recession.

title: China and Taiwan Urge Talks, but Their Call Rings Hollow
description: BEIJING, April 27  Eight years after they began a historic and ultimately abortive dialogue on future relations, mainland China and Taiwan both made calls today for renewed talks.

title: Metro Business Briefing; COCA-COLA IN TIMES SQUARE
description: The Coca-Cola Company, which has advertised in Times Square for more than 80 years, extended its lease there for an additional 10 years, it was announced yesterday. The company signed a lease extension with Sherwood Outdoor, which owns and leases billboard space for several prime properties in Times Square, keeping its neon logo at 2 Times Square through 2011. The sign could soon be one of the only large neon ones left in Times Square, said Brian T. Turner, president of Sherwood Outdoor. Suntory Whisky, which has a sign just above Coca-Cola's, does not plan to renew its lease, and Samsung, which has a sign above Suntory's, is to remove the neon when it renovates its sign. Coca-Cola and Sherwood would not disclose the rent, but the company that will lease the Suntory space will pay roughly $2.5 million a year, said one local landlord. Corey Kilgannon

title: Critics Too Quick to Bury Carter
description: Hardly anyone uses the term Vinsanity anymore. Vince Carter is still breathtaking, even amazing some nights. Yet the moniker that came to define his stratospheric rise last season is no longer part of the National Basketball Association's lexicon.

description: This week, with Congressional hearings under way, the debate begins in earnest over President Bush's proposal to allow religious organizations to spend federal money on programs that help the disadvantaged. But that support is undercut by two objections.

title: SWITZERLAND: SALES BEAT TARGET AT NESTL
description: Nestl said its first-quarter sales volume grew 4.5 percent, to $11.4 billion, above its long-term target of 4 percent. Nestl officials said the company expected record sales and profit this year in all areas of its global market, barring major negative economic or currency effects. So far in 2001, its greatest growth has been in Asia.

title: Germany Looks Like Europe's Weak Economic Link
description: Germany is Europe's biggest economy by far, but it looks increasingly like its weakest link.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the arts pages on Thursday about Film Fest New Haven, an alternative series that opened yesterday, misstated the general ticket price for today and tomorrow. It is $7; $5 is the price for students and those over 55. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the number of screening sites. It is five, not three.

title: Russia's Media Variety Survives Network's Travail
description: Svetlana Ivanovna, a 57-year-old pensioner with a mind made up like a marine's bed, has a word for the liberal journalists who worked at Russia's independent television network NTV until its takeover this month: ''barbarians.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKLIN, ANN KERR
description: FRANKLIN-Ann Kerr. Of Locust Valley, New York died peacefully on April 25th after a long illness. Beloved mother of Jeanne F. Ferrer, Remmi F. Lyon and Philip A.S. Franklin, Jr. Aunt of E. Coe Kerr III. Grandmother of Bowe and Andrew Ferrer; Addison, Sidney and Philip Lyon; Keeley and Cain Franklin. Great aunt of Chauncey and Samantha Kerr. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Humane Society of New York, 306 E. 59th, New York 10022, or the Nassau County Museum of Art, One Museum Drive, Roslyn Harbor, N.Y.11576.

title: Sports of The Times; One Hurdle Too Many For Knicks
description: JEFF VAN GUNDY met with the news media, as usual, yesterday afternoon. He waited for his Knicks players to finish shooting free throws and doing interviews before he came down from his office wearing warm-ups, no shoes, a T-shirt. He sat on a table and with his ever-present diet soda, and faced the microphones and notepads.

title: Giants Harbor No Doubts About Peterson
description: William Peterson was the other cornerback the Giants drafted last weekend, the other guy nicknamed Will chosen two rounds after the team took Will Allen of Syracuse in the first round. Allen may have been the Giants' first choice, but Peterson's selection was no less notable, if for a different reason.

title: New Flood, Old Truths
description: One hopes that each new natural disaster, be it an earthquake or a giant mudslide or destructive flood, will leave people better prepared for the next one -- or at least teach them not to repeat the same mistakes. Yet the latest Mississippi flood suggests, again, that when the waters recede, so does human memory.

title: Earnings Decline by 16% At Taiwan Semiconductor
description: In a sign of how hard the slowdown in American technology spending has pinched Asian suppliers, Taiwan's largest chip maker, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, said today that its net income declined 16.6 percent in the first quarter.

title: Agency Warns Of Fuel Pump On Boeing 737
description: The Federal Aviation Administration told airlines today to stop using a fuel pump on the Boeing 737 under certain circumstances after investigators found that the pump might have contributed to the explosion of a plane at a gate in Bangkok last month.

title: Depression's Lessons

Predeceased by husband Herman, sister Emma and three brothers. Educator, civic activist, devoted member of the Hollis Presbyterian Church. Visitation at the R. Stutzmann & Son, Inc, Funeral Home, 224-39 Jamaica Ave, Queens Village, NY, Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Cutting Edge in a Backwater; Phone Company On Isle of Man Aims to Unite The Internet And Wireless
description: This blip of an island in the Irish Sea has muscled its way to a latter-day prosperity through such attractions as ever-lower taxes, offshore banking and motorcycle races around the twisting roads that gird its hilly interior.

title: Kerrey's Role at New School Re-examined
description: The central patio of New School University was quiet yesterday, as if nothing momentous had occurred to shake the university. A handful of students sat in the warm sunshine, sipping coffee and catching up on homework and year-end projects.

title: Candidate Green Misses Several Meetings of Council
description: When the City Council met for one of its more intensely anticipated legislative sessions earlier this week, the staff had worked overtime to ensure that as many members as possible would be there, and even dispatched sergeants-at-arms to round up a few stragglers from their homes. But what turned out to be the year's best-attended meeting was, in the end, notable for a conspicuous absence: that of Mark Green, who, in addition to having staunchly supported one of the laws the Council was trying to pass with an override, as the public advocate, is mandated by the city charter to preside.

title: An American Maestro Gets an A
description: There had to have been a lot of pressure on the conductor David Robertson for his debut with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall. In recent years Mr. Robertson, a lanky, boyish 42-year-old Californian, has become one of the most respected conductors in the business. With his wide-ranging repertory and deep connection to contemporary music, he is the sort of dynamic conductor who was talked of as a potentially exciting choice to succeed Kurt Masur in 2002. So there was much at stake.

title: Daily Life as a Frozen Game of Tag
description: Fresh, creative, original: it's Maguy Marin. The best known of the 10 choreographers in the continuing France Moves festival, she has returned with a stunningly clever and affecting work about getting through the day, never mind life.

title: S.E.C. Seeks Data on Trading of Initial Offerings
description: Securities regulators are gathering information from Wall Street firms in a new inquiry into whether prices of offerings of new stock were manipulated at the height of the 1990's stock boom.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a resurgence of interest in nuclear power included a company erroneously among members of a task force on new nuclear deployment set up by the industry's trade association, the Nuclear Energy Institute. Constellation Energy of Maryland is not a member.

title: Israeli Objections Leave New Mideast Peace Proposals in Doubt
description: Israel's foreign minister, Shimon Peres, will head to Amman and Cairo this weekend carrying objections to a Jordanian-Egyptian peace initiative for the Middle East that are substantive enough to sink the idea before it gets off the ground.

title: Famous Daughters Talk Up Their Bout
description: There has been at least one noticeable difference between Laila Ali and her father, Muhammad. He never shut his mouth when cameras and microphones were in his face. Sometimes, she clams up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMONSON, DR. HANA
description: SIMONSON-Dr. Hana. Witty, brilliant, caring, courageous, honest, devoted, loving wife, sister, mother and grandmother. She endeared herself to whomever she met, wherever, whenever. A straight talker, she told it as it was-no pretense, no nonsense. Her rare & remarkable courage & strength in the face of challenges most of us could never handle will stand as an inspiration for all humankind. Hana, Ma, Bobbie will be missed terribly. May we honor her by carrying memories she had forward always. Hana is survived by her sister, Rachel, her children, Shia, Rayze and Alex, and by her grandchildren, Rebecca, Raphael, Noa, Solomon, Zosh, Yair and Yonah.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday about a forum on President Bush's program for religiously sponsored charities misidentified a clergyman who attended. He is the Rev. Marcus Harvey of Pittsburgh, not Bishop Harold Calvin Ray of Miami.

title: Protests Intensify in Puerto Rico As Navy Resumes Bombing Drills
description: The Navy resumed military maneuvers on this lush, hilly island today, sparking angry demonstrations and civil disobedience here as hundreds of Puerto Ricans demanded an end to bombing exercises that they say are harming the island's ecology and its residents' health.

title: Rowing Event a Test for U.S.
description: The first rowing World Cup staged in North America got under way today in blustery conditions on Lake Mercer. It is the first international competition since last year's Olympics, and it gives coaches a chance to test their lineups for the 2004 Games.

description: JONES-Asilnett Viola Lewis. On April 26th, 2001. Beloved sister of Basil (England), George (Canada), Cecil (New York), Ruby (Jamaica, W.I.) & Sonia (Canada). title: For Seat-Belt Violator, a Jam, a Jail and Unmoved Justices
description: GAIL ATWATER'S son had a rubber vampire bat attached to her pickup truck's window by a suction cup. When the truck was moving, the bat's wings fluttered. But somewhere between soccer practice and home one day in March 1997, the toy disappeared. And since her son, Mackinley, liked it so much, she decided to look for it.

title: American Airlines Is the Winner in a U.S. Antitrust Case
description: A federal judge dismissed a major antitrust case yesterday in which the Justice Department accused American Airlines of driving three competitors out of one of the country's largest airports by undercutting their fares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABELOFF, MICHAEL
description: ABELOFF-Michael. Left this world peacefully on April 26, 2001 at his home in the company of loved ones including his wife, Suzanne & two daughters, Shanna and Michelle. At age 62, loved by many, he completed his life's work with great strength and courage. For many years, Michael worked as a city planner and housing developer. Living at 382 Central Park West for 30 years, he was an active community member and leader. In his last four years, he served with The PRASAD Project, carrying out their charitable work in India's Tan-sa Valley and in Sullivan Co., N.Y. Contributions may be offered to the work he loved. The PRASAD Project, 465 Brickman Road, Hurleyville, New York 12747, 845-434-0376.

title: War and Memory
description: Thirty-two years ago a team of American soldiers killed at least 13 innocent people in the Vietnamese village of Thanh Phong. How did they come to do such a thing? The leader of that team, Bob Kerrey, says that it was a terrible accident, that they shot the civilians while returning enemy fire. Another soldier, Gerhard Klann, says that the unarmed women and children were rounded up and executed on Mr. Kerrey's orders. That is how each man claims to remember it.

title: Students Have Their Night, So Mettle Is on the Program
description: The Peabody Conservatory in Baltimore is one of the country's best music schools, and like many institutions devoted to preparing musicians for professional careers, it periodically thrusts them into the public spotlight. On Wednesday evening the Peabody Symphony Orchestra, led by its music director, Hajime Teri Murai, presented a demanding program that focused on two of the school's graduates who have done well: Michael Nathaniel Hersch, a composer who, at 29, has attracted considerable attention in the last few years, and the guitarist Manuel Barrueco, who studied at Peabody in the 1970's and is now a member of the school's faculty.

title: Kenneth Mickey, Kansas City, Mo., November 2000
description: 'm in my office, about 150 feet underground. We are inside caves -- well, they call them caves, but they're really limestone mines. This is a subtropolis, a metropolis but underground. I am with Records Center of Kansas City. We store archival records: closed case files, patient charts, X-rays from hospitals, film and other records for other businesses. In the refrigerated film storage, we have 'Ben-Hur.' And in one corner, all the episodes of 'M*A*S*H' and 'Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea.' Most of the offices down here don't have windows. I've got a window. That day, I could see two trucks and a pillar and part of a wall. It's kind of nice, even though it's not exactly a C.E.O. view. And I'm the sales rep, so I get appointments and get out of here. The receptionist, she's here all day.

title: Runaway Bay, Jamaica
description: How many times can you give a gift certificate for Mother's Day? Now, the Franklyn D. Resort in Runaway Bay, Jamaica, has another gift idea. Through June 14, mothers will be charged only for the first and last nights of their stay -- a total of $560 -- no matter how long they stay, while their spouses or traveling companions pay $280 a night. These prices include all meals, an open bar, wine with lunch and dinner and use of sports facilities. Children under 16 can stay and eat for free when sharing a room with two adults. This offer is available through Rich Worldwide Travel. Information: (800) 431-1130 or www.richtravel.com .

title: Hernndez Returns With Gusto, Ending Yanks' Skid
description: Mel Stottlemyre, usually a placid observer, leaned forward on the front edge of the Yankees' bench in the early innings last night, his left hand bouncing off his jiggling left leg as sunflower seeds streamed from his mouth; this is what anxiety does to a pitching coach. But his worry was appropriate: Orlando Hernndez returned to the mound last night after nine days of uncertainty regarding the condition of his elbow and confidence.

title: Adding Art to the Rigor Of Statistical Science

description: GAULL-Sherry Heffernan, 67. Of Washington, DC, Wednesday, April 25, of cancer at Johns Hopkins Medical Center, Baltimore, MD. She was the beloved mother of Shelagh Ellman-Pearl, Tom Ellman, Barat Ellman, Kitsey Canaan and Nan Ellman and cherished grandmother of nine granddaughters. Mrs. Gaull was the widow of Dr. Gerald E. In addition to her children and grandchildren, she is survived by two sisters, Emily Leonard and Shelagh O'Neill, and two stepsons, Erik and Stephen Gaull. title: BELGIUM: LERNOUT & HAUSPIE WOES
description: Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products is having trouble finding buyers for its units as it tries to avoid insolvency, said Philippe Bodson, the company's new chief executive. The company, which makes speech-recognition and translation software, filed in November for bankruptcy-court protection in the United States and Belgium after problems from accounting irregularities at its Korean unit. Mr. Bodson told shareholders at a special meeting in Ieper that no buyers were lined up for Mendez, the American translation unit. He said Mendez would be sold later than expected and for less. Without asset sales, Lernout's bridge financing will run out by the summer, Mr. Bodson said. Lernout has hired Credit Suisse First Boston to help it find buyers for its divisions. Paul Meller (NYT)

description: At the request of Executive Robert J. Gaffney, Suffolk County legislators voted today to increase the county sales tax rate by a quarter of a percentage point to help plug a budget gap that is projected to grow anywhere from $78 million to $142 million for the 2002 fiscal year.

description: According to C.I.A. files made public today, Hitler's own physician considered the Nazi leader to be a ''border case between genius and insanity'' and predicted in 1937 that he could become the ''craziest criminal the world ever knew.''

description: Arkansas, a perennial N.C.A.A. champion returning to the Drake Relays after a 20-year absence, scored a runaway victory in the men's four-mile relay yesterday, winning with a time of 16 minutes 23.35 seconds in Des Moines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIZK, KHALIL
description: RIZK-Khalil. It is with deepest sorrow that the Board of Directors and Officers of Venetian Heritage, Inc. mourn the premature death of their beloved President, Khalil Rizk. Khalil's enthusiasm for restoring beautiful monuments and works of art, his tireless ability to bring us new friends, his imagination & flair in creating wonderful events here and abroad, and his generosity in supporting us financially and morally, have made the deepest possible mark on us personally, on our organization, and indeed on the City of Venice. We offer our deepest sympathy to his family and all his friends who loved him. Countess Cristiana Brandolini, International Chairman Lawrence D. title: Club Owners Becoming Focus Of Effort to Combat Drug Use
description: Frustrated by the rising popularity of Ecstasy and other illegal drugs among young nightclub revelers, law enforcement agencies and local governments around the country are increasingly going after the clubs themselves, saying that the electronic music they play has a close connection to abuse of these drugs.

title: A Throatful Of Vampires, Defanged
description: Some vampires apparently have better table manners than others. Compared with the elegant time travelers of ''Interview With the Vampire,'' who siphon eternal life from pretty necks with the snooty discrimination of oenophiles, the bloodsuckers who terrorize the Southwestern badlands in ''The Forsaken'' are slurping beasts who bury their faces in their victims' mutilated bodies. The difference between these two styles of noshing might be described as the difference between a black-tie banquet and a roadside beer blast of bikers on acid.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Thursday about arrests for environmental crimes at junkyards near Shea Stadium misidentified the section of Queens. It is Corona, not Willets Point.

title: As Door to Amnesty Closes, Immigrants Rush to Qualify
description: The door is about to close on the opportunity of a lifetime for many illegal immigrants: the chance to become a legal permanent resident without first leaving their families and jobs in the United States.

title: ECONOMY'S GROWTH PROVES STEADFAST ALTHOUGH MODEST
description: The economy showed surprising resilience in the first three months of this year, growing at a 2 percent annual rate and extending the longest American expansion on record to a full 10 years, the government reported yesterday.

title: Progress for Tolerance in Bosnia
description: Peacekeepers in Bosnia struck a powerful blow for the cause of ethnic coexistence when they raided the Herzegovacka Bank earlier this month. As odd as it may seem, the bank seizure was one of the most important actions taken by the international high representative running Bosnia in the five years since the peace agreement was signed. It will cripple financing for the hard-line nationalist Croats, and it signaled a new willingness in the international community to enforce the accords aggressively.

title: Inquiry on Peru Looks at a C.I.A. Contract
description: With inquiries beginning into Peru's downing last week of a flight carrying American missionaries, Congressional officials say they are examining the role played by C.I.A. contract employees who worked for the Aviation Development Corporation of Montgomery, Ala.

title: Untimely Exercises on Vieques
description: The Navy's decision to begin a multiday bombing exercise on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques yesterday was legally authorized but politically insensitive. Puerto Rican opposition to such exercises is strong, and yesterday's maneuvers were greeted with demonstrations and civil disobedience. A referendum among Vieques's 9,400 residents in November will determine whether the Navy will have to phase out use of the island as a bombing range. Studies on whether noise from the bombings is causing heart problems among Vieques residents are currently being evaluated by the Department of Health and Human Services. The Navy should have postponed further exercises until that evaluation was complete.

title: GERMANY: MERGER POSSIBLE AT BAYER
description: Manfred Schneider, left, the chief executive of Bayer A.G., said he would be prepared to merge the company, Germany's largest drug maker, with a rival. The company is ready to undertake a ''major transaction,'' Mr. Schneider said in a speech at Bayer's annual shareholders' meeting. A merger is one of a variety of options for the future, including big acquisitions, Bayer officials said. In a victory for Mr. Schneider, shareholders voted against a proposal by the Tweedy, Browne Company to form separate entities for Bayer's drug, chemical and farm chemical operations.

title: Bus Crash in Canada Kills 4 Students From Massachusetts
description: A bus carrying middle-school band members from this Boston suburb to a music festival in Nova Scotia skidded off a highway ramp in New Brunswick, Canada, early this morning, killing four students and injuring several others.

title: South African Leader Fights a Fraying Image
description: For a moment today, President Thabo Mbeki was everyone's hero. Barefoot girls punched their tiny fists in the air as he unveiled the first water tap in this dusty village, and people cheered when clean, clear water gushed from the faucet.

title: BOB KERREY'S WAR
description: The article that has forced the former senator and Medal of Honor winner -- and the nation -- to relive the night he killed women and children for his country. An investigation by Gregory L. Vistica, in The Times Magazine.

title: Cuttings: A Lifting of Small Voices Heralding the Spring
description: ABOUT two weeks ago, when the spicebush was covered with yellow flowers, I got a little e-mail from Dr. Jim Duke, my botanist friend in Fulton, Md. It was in verse.

title: Bush Honors a Kingmaker and Mentor
description: President Bush returned to the Texas state Capitol today to honor the Democrat who years ago urged him, with a mix of advice and expletives, to run for president.

title: Vivid Color In a World Of Black And White
description: ''Yellow,'' a book of short stories, ''Blue,'' a novel, and ''Mauve,'' a book about the invention of a color, have all just been published. A few years ago, Alexander Theroux wrote ''Secondary Colors'' and, before that, ''Primary Colors.'' There is William Gass's ''On Being Blue'' and the Polish director Krzysztof Kieslowski's trilogy of films, ''Blue'' (1993), ''White'' and ''Red'' (both 1994). This month the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History put up an exhibition of paint-by-number paintings.

title: A City Long Passionate About Its River Finds a Fondness for Its Flood Wall
description: Here in the hometown of Mark Twain, life on this stretch of the flooding Mississippi is mostly high and still mostly dry these days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, LAURENCE W.
description: LEVINE-Laurence W. The directors and staff of the Davis Mutual Funds mourn the sudden and untimely passing of their dear friend and esteemed director for 32 years. He had a distinguished career as a lawyer and diplomat. He was also a wise, and generous of time, counselor to us, our many thousands of shareholders, and our employees, and we shall miss him dearly. Our deepest condolences to his family.

title: BRITAIN: VOTE OF CONFIDENCE
description: In a rare vote of confidence, Sir Christopher Bland, the newly appointed chairman of British Telecommunications P.L.C., will invest about $1.4 million of his own money in the debt-ridden company, British Telecom said. Sir Christopher will replace Sir Iain Vallance on May 1. A big part of Sir Christopher's $700,000-a-year job is to revive the company's share price. With the stock at less than half of last year's peak, Sir Christopher may be assuming that the only way is up. But since his appointment was announced Thursday, the stock has fallen about 10 percent. British Telecom did not say when Sir Christopher planned to buy. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Hal Prieste, America's Oldest Olympian, Dies at 104
description: Hal Prieste, America's oldest Olympian and the oldest surviving Olympic medal winner in the world, died on April 19 at a nursing home in Camden, N.J. He was 104.

title: Behind Computerized Beats, The Slurp of Liposuction
description: Reality barely stood a chance against synthetic pandemonium when Kid 606 and Matmos shared a bill at Tonic on Monday night. Both Kid 606 and Matmos want to make sure electronica isn't limited to dance music, and while they know how to generate familiar computerized beats, they are also willing to jettison a steady pulse for other sonic possibilities.

title: UNILEVER TO CUT 8,000 JOBS AND SHUT 30 PLANTS
description: Unilever, the British-Dutch consumer products giant, said yesterday that it would eliminate 8,000 jobs and close 30 factories as it digests the acquisition of its United States rival, Bestfoods. Unilever, which makes Dove soap and Lipton tea, said first-quarter net income fell by 61 percent, to 254 million euros ($230 million), as borrowing costs related to acquisitions ate into profits. In February, Unilever said it would cut 25,000 jobs over five years, part of a restructuring program to weed out three-quarters of its brands and leave it with the top-selling 400 lines. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Marks Relishing Role As Underdog to Lewis
description: No boxer wants to be thought of as just a speed bump in another fighter's career. But that is the signal Larry Marks has been getting recently from Andrew Lewis, whom he will fight tonight in the Hammerstein Ballroom in Manhattan for the World Boxing Association welterweight belt.

A lot of people have applied the laws of physics to sports, Mr. Brancazio among them. He's the guy who demonstrated that Michael Jordan's vaunted hang time was only eight-tenths of a second, and that a rising fastball doesn't really rise. (It just doesn't fall as quickly as the batter expects.)

title: COLUMBIA SPORTSWEAR EXPECTS HIGHER ANNUAL PROFIT
description: The Columbia Sportswear Company, a maker of fishing apparel and hiking boots, has said its profit this year may be almost double what analysts are forecasting, setting off a sharp rally in its stock price. Columbia said late Thursday that earnings would rise 26 percent to 29 percent from last year's $2.22 a share. That would result in profit of about $2.80 to $2.86 a share, topping the $1.59 expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. The company made the projection after first-quarter profit more than doubled, also exceeding analysts' estimates. Columbia has been expanding its selection of products at department stores to take advantage of the growing popularity of roller blading, skiing, mountain biking and other sports, analysts said. Its stock rose $10.44, or 19 percent, to $64.80 a share, on Nasdaq.

title: Foes Remain of Two Minds on 'One China'

title: SOUTH AFRICA: PROTECTION SOUGHT
description: South African diplomats have asked Zimbabwean authorities to step up protection for businesses, many of them South African-owned, that have become the latest target forby ruling -party militants angered by the effects of the country's economic crisis. Demanding that laid-off workers be reinstated, mobs of militants have confronted owners and managers of big businesses, often assaulting them and damaging equipment. With the economic crisis dragging on, companies have been shedding jobs by the hundreds and in some cases closing down altogether. Henri Cauvin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, JAMES J.
description: CASEY-James J. On Wednesday, April 25th, 2001, of Peapack, NJ. Age 86. Predeceased by his first wife, Ann Gambrill Casey. Survived by his wife, Claudia Prout Casey, his children, Anne H.C. van den Bergh, Edith Blair Casey, Richard Gambrill Casey, and five grandchildren. Mr. Casey was a graduate of Columbia University, Class of 1937, and the Columbia University School of Law, Class of 1940. He retired as Lt. Commander after serving in the Navy during WWII, including active duty in the Pacific Theater. He was a founding partner of the law firm, Casey, Lane & Mittendorf in NYC. He served on the Boards of Visitors for Columbia College and for the Columbia School of Law. Mr. Casey was a member of the United Nations Administrative Tribunal from 1960 to 1963 and a delegate to the UN Human Rights Commission. He also served as a director of several corporations and clubs in New York, New Jersey and Rhode Island. A service will be held at St. Brigid's Church, Peapack, NJ, 11 AM, Thursday, May 3rd. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Peapack-Gladstone First Aid Squad, Gladstone, NJ 07934 or the Fund for Medical Leadership at Columbia University, ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, Office of the Chairman, Department of Medicine, 630 West 168th Street, Box 30, New York, NY 10032.

title: JAPAN: SONY RESULTS STRONG
description: The Sony Corporation posted stronger-than-expected profit for its fiscal fourth quarter, but its full-year results were hit hard by a change in accounting. Much of the buoyancy in Sony's results for the quarter came from nonelectronics businesses -- movies, music and insurance -- and from asset sales, but its game business continued to drag down earnings. Sony's net income for the quarter ended March 31 was 15.7 billion yen ($127 million), compared with a loss of 36.7 billion yen ($298 million) in the quarter a year earlier, which was caused by the cost of introducing the PlayStation 2 game console. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OWEN, VERA DAMMANN
description: OWEN-Vera Dammann. Born January 14, 1904, Yorkshire, England. Died April 5, 2001, Somers, NY. Predeceased by her first husband, Pierre Dammann, her second husband, Joseph W. Owen, and her son, Jean-Pierre Dammann. Survived by her daughter, Jacqueline Dammann Everett, of Mt. Kisco, NY, six grandchildren, seven great-grandchildren, and two sisters. Graduate of Cambridge University and the Sorbonne. Formerly of Riverdale-onHudson, NY, she developed a bilingual program for the NYC Board of Higher Education. Previously, she headed the family's importing company, translated psychoanalytic texts, and worked on the Normal Child Development Study at Columbia University. Memorial service 11 AM, Saturday, May 12, at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 191 South Greeley Ave., Chappaqua, NY. title: A Cause With Horsepower
description: Ralph Lauren wants to make the Pink Pony speak for breast cancer the way the red ribbon does for AIDS. The second shipment of the fiercely promoted Pink Pony T-shirt, which has been seen on celebrities like Rene Zellweger and Penlope Cruz and graced ''Will and Grace,'' arrived last Thursday at the Polo.com Web site and in Ralph Lauren Polo stores. The first shipment of 5,000 sold out within weeks last winter; since then, waiting lists for the black and pink logo-emblazoned shirt ($52, $15 of which goes to the Ralph Lauren Center for Cancer Prevention and Care) have been filled in New York, Paris, London and Japan. The charity T-shirt has had such retail success that now Polo is making a $52 black-and-white version for summer, with all proceeds benefiting Ralph Lauren's other big cause: retail fashion.

title: South Asia
description: To the Editor: Barbara Crossette's article ''A Week in Centuries Past'' (April 1) evoked wonderful memories for me and my family. We lived in Sri Lanka in the late 70's and spent two weeks at the Galle Face Hotel while looking for a house to rent. Yes, the waiters were in bare feet, and the Indian Ocean breezes made the lime and soda taste even better. Sri Lanka is indeed magical, with wonderfully warm people, ancient culture and gorgeous scenery.

title: Home Alone
description: The comedian Phyllis Diller likes to kick back, slip into a favorite caftan and dine on some of her homemade garbage soup. ''I always have a huge pot brewing on the stove. Whatever is left on the plate is chopped and thrown in. So are leftovers -- spaghetti, vegetables, meats. If you think it sounds unsanitary, remember: anything that's boiled is sterile.''

title: Survival
description: To the Editor: The story of the Eisendrath family, ''After a Plane Crash, Celebrating Life,'' (March 18) made me remember a 1960 small-plane crash I survived on the island of Mindanao in the Philippines. Three of us were going to fly in supplies to an isolated tribal village in the jungle of Cotabato province. We were about 30 minutes into our flight when the engine suddenly lost power. The crash happened so rapidly that I scarcely had time to realize the danger I was in. Charles R. Eisendrath is right -- it is a conversation stopper. I've yet to meet someone who says, ''That reminds me of the crash I was in.'' And, like him, I never stopped flying as a result.

title: Lemony Snicket Says, 'Don't Read My Books!'
description: Who is this mysterious and unlikely sounding Lemony Snicket, creator of the best-selling books called ''A Series of Unfortunate Events,'' and what has kept him from showing up at his own scheduled author appearance? What does he look like and where, exactly, is he from? (His author photo, which changes from book to book, is always a blurry shot taken from the back, in which he is walking away from the camera, or staring out a window or down at a book.) And why are the wildly tongue-in-cheek, neo-gothic stories he spins about the miserable lives of the terrorized but resourceful Baudelaire orphans -- 14-year-old Violet, who is a whiz at inventing things; her bookwormish brother, Klaus; and baby Sunny -- always dedicated to the late but still longed-for Beatrice? (From ''The Ersatz Elevator'': ''For Beatrice -- When we met, my life began. Soon afterward, yours ended.'')

title: Irish Music
description: To the Editor: In the Q & A column on March 4, Marie Brown asks how to find traditional music in authentic, nontouristy settings in Ireland. Eight years ago I drove around Ireland for two weeks and managed to find traditional music in almost every town where I stopped. I just asked local people, which is always a good way to make friends. I drove along the west coast and through central Ireland. It was a rainy May and I did find a weekend music festival in Ennistymon, County Clare; because it was well publicized, I also ran into the most tourists there. I much preferred the lesser-known pubs in Donegal. I also found several music pubs in Galway City, Cork, Doolin, and even in a tiny town like Keel on bleak, beautiful Achill Island.

title: Quick Breaks
description: To the Editor: I loved reading about Elizabeth McBride's brief vacations-of-the-mind in ''Slowing Down: Vacation as a State of Mind'' (March 4). Even though my husband and I can get away pretty frequently, I still find that I need a break, or ''mind scrub,'' every few weeks. I drive west out of St. Louis to the Lewis & Clark Trail, where it winds westward along the Missouri River. The narrow road drops down a rocky bluff, and for those few moments I can imagine I'm in Germany. My favorite swamp twitches with fish. Am I in Missouri, or down in Louisiana?

title: Acting as She Sings, She Makes Each Song a Drama
description: FORTY years ago this month, the great singing actress Judy Garland gave her landmark two-act solo performance at Carnegie Hall. This event was preserved and is now expanded in the Capitol recording ''Judy at Carnegie Hall.'' When it appeared, the record won the Grammy for Album of the Year, and she won for Best Female Vocal Performance. It spent 95 weeks on the charts, 13 at No. 1. (The new CD, unbound by the time restraints of the LP, puts before the listener every second of tape recorded that night.) And though by the end of her short, cometic life, Garland had made 32 films, 60 television appearances and almost 400 radio shows, ''Judy at Carnegie Hall'' is the most conclusive document we have of her extraordinary talent. You don't have to listen long before you can see that she was a great interpreter of popular American music, maybe the greatest. But hearing the concert again, what strikes you is that this is the work of a dazzling actress.

description: FULL disclosure: This Hudson River village, 10 minutes north of Bergen County, is where I grew up in the 1950's and 60's. In my day, though Nyack had its charms, fine dining was not among them. It was a stolid workingman's town, home to shoe factories and meat markets and secondhand stores. Aside from taverns and luncheonettes, I remember only one restaurant -- a Chinese place whose egg rolls could have served as ballast down at Julius Petersen's Boat Yard.

title: Whitman May Be Gone But She's Not Forgotten
description: When it comes to civil rights suits in this largely minority and heavily industrialized city, politics makes strange co-defendents.

title: Baby Not Crawling? Reason Seems to Be Less Tummy Time
description: When Gary Slaughter turned 6 months old, his mother, Charlene, began waiting for him to crawl. After all, that is when the books said that babies can be expected to reach this developmental milestone. But nothing happened. He did not even roll over.

title: Shift Lifts Knoblauch's Disposition and Yanks
description: Chuck Knoblauch has seen the glare from inside the fishbowl the last three seasons. He knows what it is like to have his motivation, movements and mood analyzed by people who have never met him, and by some who have. He escaped all that last month when he shifted from second base to left field.

title: DataBank; Economic Growth Revives Momentum
description: After two of the best weeks for stocks in months, investors took some profits last Monday, but plunged back in by week's end when a report on economic growth in the first quarter showed surprising strength. Investors were also buoyed by good news on consumer spending as home sales in March grew at their fastest pace ever.

title: A Yearning for Pinball Machines
description: AT 37, Kevin McHugh spends his days attempting to recapture his youth. He does not do it through face lifts or elixirs; instead he collects the vintage pinball machines that captivated him as a child.

title: Charles Schreiner III, 74, Dies; Colorful Texas Rancher Fought to Save Longhorn
description: Charles Schreiner III, who as he led a fight to preserve the legendary Texas longhorn breed became a Lone Star State symbol himself, died of congestive heart failure on April 22 at a San Antonio hospital.

title: 'A Full Human Being'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Funding Shift and Towns Try to Make Do
description: AN unpleasantly tight budgeting season is under way for cities and towns across the state, the first in several years, and the local difficulties are aggravating political differences between the Democratic-controlled State Legislature and the governor over the state budget.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: OSCAR WILDE wrote plots -- fairly high-minded ones, in fact -- but they seem so unnecessary. The real pleasure of his work, like the most recent film version of AN IDEAL HUSBAND (1999), directed by Oliver Parker, is, of course, in the aphorisms. ''Even you are not rich enough to buy back your past,'' Mrs. Chevely (Julianne Moore) tells Sir Robert Chiltern (Jeremy Northam). ''No man is.'' The hero, Lord Goring (Rupert Everett, born to do Wilde), sums up the human experience with ''It takes great courage to see the world in all its tainted glory and still to love it.'' So who cares that Minnie Driver, as Mabel, seems to have drifted in from ''Good Will Hunting''? Or that the play is really about blackmail and a crooked Argentine canal scheme? -- Sunday at 1 p.m. on Encore.

title: Needed a Rest, but Got a Break
description: BRIAN STOKES MITCHELL, who won a Tony Award last year for his role in ''Kiss Me, Kate,'' was getting ready to leave the show last January and take a break from Broadway. Then the phone rang.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, LILY
description: LEE-Lily. On April 27, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Ralph. Devoted mother of Arlene and David Lee and the late Marilyn. Cherished grandmother of Michael, Jaclyn and Briana. Loving motherin-law of Ruth Lee. Services Sunday at 11:00 AM at ''WeinsteinGarlick-Kirschenbaum Chapels'', 1153 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Age 10 and Dressed to the Nines in the Ballroom
description: SIX dance instructors, representing the expert teachings of former champions from foreign countries, were spread out on the 2,200-square-foot Royal Ballroom Dance Studio floor here recently, providing lessons to a dozen dance hopefuls from the age of 20 to 70.

title: The Nation; The Check Is In the Mail. Almost.
description: THE economy has been looking shaky lately, and like it or not, Congress is on the case.

title: Personal Business; Why Wait for That Money? Download It Instead
description: IT was not too long ago when consumers could easily appease their creditors by simply advising, ''The check is in the mail.'' But the Internet is making it harder to come up with excuses.

title: The Sport of Kings for the Well-Heeled of Philadelphia
description: IT was May 22, 1942, and things weren't looking good, either in the Pacific theater, or for construction of the new racetrack on the Marlton Pike.

title: How to Defend Someone You Know Is Guilty
description: Feige has painted himself into a very difficult corner. He depersonalizes the victims and ''likes'' his clients. What happens when he doesn't like his client or empathizes with a victim?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHMAN, JACK
description: HOCHMAN-Jack. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother and friend. Died Thursday, April 26, 2001 at the age of 79. A former manager of the ILGWU, Chairman of the Workmen's Circle Division of UJA/Federation, board member and one time chairman of the Workmen's Circle Home for the Aged, decorated WW II veteran. He is survived by Rachel, his wife of 57 years, children Anne and Seth, grandchildren Aaron and Hannah and a sister Mimi. Funeral services at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Sunday 11 AM.

title: The World: Defining a Free Press; The Unique Evolution of Russian TV
description: THE swift and brutal dismantling of Media-Most, Russia's largest privately held media empire, and its flagship television station NTV, has raised questions about the future of independent media in post-Communist Russia. But the question can be put another way: Has Russia ever had an independent television station during the last decade of democracy, and if not, why?

title: Paris by Bike
description: To the Editor: It is heartening to learn that in the land of the Tour de France, bicycling is finally catching on as a lifestyle. Last June, upon arriving in Paris, I walked over to the plaza in front of the Htel de Ville (City Hall) and found to my amazement La Fte du Vlo -- a weekend festival to promote the use of bikes in the city. There were games for children and refreshments each day of the festival. The highlight came on that Sunday when, with about 5,000 fellow bicyclists in yellow caps, we took over the streets of Paris, and made a 20-kilometer circuit of the city, past many major monuments and landmarks. This year's event is scheduled for June 2 and 3 (Web site: www.feteduvelo.com).

title: In an Oil Spill's Aftermath, the Hard Part: Laying Blame and Paying for the Damage
description: Clots of heating oil have congealed and cling like tar to the rocks on the shores of Little Neck Bay and Udall's Cove. As the weather warms, it is expected that the oil will melt and spread in a greasy sheen across the surface of both bodies of water.

title: How to Defend Someone You Know Is Guilty
description: David Feige lets himself off easy as he rationalizes (by way of his affection for his clients) any concerns he may have regarding truth, justice and society. He gives us Kevin (described as ''wonderful''), charged with ''trying to rob an undercover police officer.''

title: How to Deliver Bad News
description: It was heartening to read Dr. Michael A. Weiner's remarks (What They Were Thinking). He offers hope and encouragement to the parents of desperately ill children.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''George W. Bush has a little more of his mother in him. Where his father would bite his tongue, every once in a while George W. Bush flaps his tongue.''

title: Another Brooks Book
description: To the Editor:

title: How To
description: Tried to e-mail like a C.E.O. :-) Tried to make a Frank Gehry building. Failed. Harvested a live organ. Wasted it. Didn't rob a bank. Thanks anyway.

title: Collins Quickly Squandered What Franks Gave the G.O.P.
description: Even in a state where political honeymoons are often perilously short, Bob Franks's campaign for New Jersey governor began with an unfortunate stroke of luck. In fact, Mr. Franks hadn't even made it down the aisle when he was handed his first seething political problem.

title: The City's Fastest-Growing Neighborhood: Small, but Sailors Galore
description: More than most people, Mark Bobal has a job that follows him home. Lying in bed at night in his town house in Staten Island, the Coast Guard commander can hear the foghorns blowing. His two children memorize the designs of tankers and cruise ships by watching them from the lawn, which sits on a ridge overlooking the water.

title: In Tune With the New Feminism
description: BECOMING the Ultimate Woman is a goal most sensible women reject somewhere between their first diet and their last bikini. Yet feminism's gains have not allowed women to relax. They have only fed the pressure to stand out, and the path to success grows increasingly intricate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, JOSEPH ''CAPPY.''
description: KAPLAN-Joseph ''Cappy.'' Beloved father of Bart and Shelley, Brian and the late Mitch. Adored grandfather of Jared and Marni. Devoted husband of the late Lillian. Services were held.

title: Winnie Hahn, Jack Flyer
description: Dr. Winnie Yoonhee Hahn, a medical resident, and Dr. Jack Lawrence Flyer, a cardiologist, were married last evening by Cantor J. Shep Jeffreys at the Willard Hotel in Washington.

title: April 22-28; Sub Commander Is Punished
description: When Cmdr. Scott D. Waddle was allowed to resign from the Navy, with a full pension and a reprimand, there were ripples of outrage, especially in Japan. After the nuclear submarine he skippered sank a Japanese fishing trawler in February, killing nine, it soon became clear that crew errors and the presence of civilian guests probably helped cause the collision, leading to calls for harsher consequences. But Commander Waddle rejected the idea that he'd gotten off easy, predicting that he would have been acquitted in a court-martial. Hubert B. Herring

title: Private Sector; A Benign Compaq Shark In Silicon Valley's Pond
description: Michael D. Capellas, the chairman and chief executive of Compaq Computer, is the first to acknowledge that he was not particularly having fun last week, when the company reported a plunge in earnings and new cost-cutting steps that included many job reductions. But Mr. Capellas did say that one of Compaq's self-promotional expenses had been a huge success: buying the naming rights to a hockey arena in the heart of Silicon Valley, where Compaq has long been considered the enemy interloper from Texas.

title: Thanks, Mel Brooks
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping Up With The Joneses' Kids
description: Today's overburdened parents find themselves commiserating often on the issues raised by children's parties: the gargantuan effort involved in organizing these Lilliputian fetes, and the enormous pressure to outdo (or at least come close to) the Joneses. But historical evidence suggests that children 12 and under deserve every Carvel ice cream confection they can get.

title: The Street Is Familiar, but Can't Remember the Nickname
description: J & R Music World/Computer World, the electronics retailer with seven stores on Park Row, was unable to persuade city officials to designate part of the street J & R Row. But the effort cast a spotlight on a little-understood practice: the awarding of so-called street aliases.

title: INVESTING WITH/Val Jensen; Jensen Portfolio
description: CAN a book change a life? Absolutely, says Val Jensen, lead manager of the $40 million Jensen Portfolio.

title: Private Sector; She's Good at Playing With Numbers
description: Ask Rosario Marin about her penmanship and she demurs with a chuckle. After all, Ms. Marin, President Bush's nominee to be the next United States Treasurer, must make it through the confirmation process before her signature goes on the currency. But ask her age, and you'll find that having fun with numbers is not a problem.

title: The Great Outdoors
Waiting at Heathrow? Take a Shower
description: Pay toilets are not new, but a pay-as-you-go lounge with showers is a first at Heathrow Airport in London.

title: Counting on Pfizer?
description: IN the late 1980's, the economy of southeastern Connecticut was so heavily dependent on defense that it was one of the few regions of the country to have mixed feelings about the end of the Cold War. The construction of submarines plummeted and employment at Electric Boat in Groton, which built the boats and was once the state's largest employer, plunged by almost two-thirds, from 26,000 to about 9,000, while smaller defense contractors scattered throughout New London County suffered as well.

description: SEARFOSS-Mary. On Thursday, April 26. Mother to Gerard, Frank, Robert and John. Reposing Sun and Mon 7-9PM Macagna Funeral Home, 495 Anderson Ave, Cliffside Park, N.J.

title: Boston on the Run: Drer to Jim Dine
description: I SPEND a great deal of time with words: reading them, writing them, watching their monotonous march across a computer screen. So when I was asked to spend a weekend in Boston looking at art, I felt my right brain stirring with excitement.

title: Introduction
description: Many readers were entertained by our ''How to'' issue; they enjoyed the mixture of fact and fun -- and the surprising mix of contributors. But not everyone was amused. Some emphasized that teenage popularity has a dark side.

title: April 22-28; House Passes Bill On Violence to Fetus
description: The House voted to establish criminal penalties for harming a fetus while committing a federal offense against a woman. The 252-to-172 vote came after a heated debate over abortion rights. The bill's proponents said it was designed to punish criminals for attacks on pregnant women. Its opponents said it was an effort to undermine abortion rights by granting legal status to the fetus.

title: Amanda Rosenberg, Kevin Hall
description: Dr. Amanda Justine Rosenberg, a daughter of Barbara Rosenberg and Dr. Stephen Rosenberg of Manhattan, is to be married this evening to Kevin Allen Hall, the son of Dr. Susanne Hall Lammot of Ventura, Calif., and Dr. Gordon Hall of Palm Desert, Calif. Rabbi Judith Lewis is to officiate at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Formula One Sets Off a Debate as It Embraces High-Tech Again
description: BARCELONA, Spain, April 28  To computerize or not to computerize, that is the question that forms the backdrop to the fifth Grand Prix of the season here on Sunday. Whereas seven years ago, high-tech driving aids were banned in an effort to accentuate the skill of the drivers, in this year's Spanish Grand Prix the drivers will be racing under a different set of rules that reinstate some of the electronic wizardry.

title: Schools That Work
description: URBAN Catholic schools surpass their public counterparts at fulfilling the public-school mandate: providing good schooling to rich and poor alike. They break the link between race, income and academic achievement, proving that poor, minority students can be educated. Why is this so?

title: Let Nature Prevail On Fire Island
description: Re ''Corps Drops Sand-Replenishment Plan for Fire I.'' [April 15]: It makes sense to abandon the proposed Army Corps of Engineers beach-rebuilding project. It makes sense from an ecological point of view, from an economical point of view, from a common sense point of view. The notion that the ocean can be kept away from a sand bar is totally illogical. If the Montauk Lighthouse will eventually have to be moved, so be it. As for Fire Island, let nature takes its course.

title: A Restaurant Near the River in Irvington
description: ALTHOUGH the nearby riverfront is not yet reclaimed for recreation, Solera itself sets a standard that certainly suggests pleasant waterside promenades in the hot days to come. Now almost three years old, as the second restaurant to occupy this elegantly renovated warehouse, Solera has maintained its inherited imaginative and polished space.

Both were smiling down on the girls far below their perch in the press box at Lions Stadium. The College of New Jersey women's lacrosse team had just beaten the visitors from Frostburg State University, 18-4.

title: American Masterpiece, Made of Prairie Dust
description: IN the fall of 1913, Willa Cather immersed herself in her third novel, taking the advice of her mentor, the novelist Sarah Orne Jewett. Write what you know, Jewett had told Cather several years earlier, and so Cather did, drawing on her upbringing among immigrant families on the prairies in Red Cloud. Neb.; her deep affection for the American Southwest and her budding friendship with the opera diva Olive Fremstad.

description: FOR most of the 1990's, shareholders had little reason to carp about the stewardship of their assets by company executives. Stock prices were rising; shareholders were content.

description: The asparagus shoots are coming up in Bill McVeigh's garden. ''The strawberries should be ready in the middle of June,'' he said, offering to share them with a visitor.

description: Here is an archive of game stories from the Devils' 2001 postseason.

description: In his first title defense, Andrew Lewis worked harder than he expected, but he got the outcome he desired.
