description: ARE the 31 Friendly's restaurants that dot Long Island's most trafficked roads a fading memento of small-town America, a Depression-era holdout unlikely to last long into the new century?

title: A Walk (at Least) in the Park
description: Parks are for strolling, or maybe flying a kite or flinging a Frisbee, right? If they are state parks, they are also for mountain bike racing (Ringwood State Park, Sept. 9), shark tournaments (Leonardo State Marina, June 30), Revolutionary War battle re-enactments (Monmouth Battlefield State Park, June 23 and 24) and fly-fishing seminars (Kittatinny Valley State Park, June 16). These are among hundreds of events listed in the spring and summer calendar from the State Park Service, which oversees state parks, forests, recreation areas, marinas and historic sites, which are distributing the free 60-page booklet. And save time for kayak outings (Swartswood State Park, July 29), a blueberry festival (Lebanon State Forest, June 30), meteor watching (Vorhees State Park, Aug. 11) and -- spare the six-pack -- an 1830's temperance rally and charitable society fair (Allaire State Park, July 29).

title: Putting Shoppers In Control
description: ADD grocery stores to the list of businesses that are concluding that the best provider of customer service may be the customers themselves.

description: Mimi Oka and Doug Fitch were in Oka's Manhattan loft taking me through the menu for a dinner they were planning.

description: Something About Al

title: Document Reveals 1987 Bomb Test by Iraq
description: Iraq tested a bomb in 1987 that cast a radioactive cloud in the open air and was designed to cause vomiting, cancer, birth defects and slow death, according to a secret Iraqi report on the weapon's construction and testing.

title: What Happened in Thanh Phong
description: Senator Bob Kerrey's hands trembled slightly as he began to read six pages of documents that had just been handed to him. It was late 1998; the papers were nearly 30 years old. On the face of it, they were routine ''after action'' combat reports of the sort filed by the thousands during the Vietnam War. But Kerrey knew the pages held a personal secret -- of an event so traumatic that he says it once prompted fleeting thoughts of suicide.

title: How to Get Into College After Being Rejected
description: I finished college 14 years ago but still have a recurring nightmare that my alma mater, Dartmouth, has rescinded my diploma. The rationale is always the same: the college had never meant to admit me in the first place. I wasn't smart enough.

title: Separates Re-employed
description: After years of twin sets, the blazer is back -- this time revamped with 1980's twists and tweaks. Featuring strong shoulders or gathered sleeves, and in stretch pastels, wool pinstripes and iridescents, the blazer is newly sexy worn with everything from miniskirts to leather pants.

title: A Monkee by Any Other Name . . .
description: Shoe Suede Blues came together as a touring band, in 1994, after performing for a benefit fund-raiser. Made up of mostly veteran contemporary blues players, the star of this band is Peter Tork. Yes, the ex-Monkee. His musical roots might have been in folk, but they are strong. So while he adds rock-star allure, the others can carry the blues torch. This party band plays a mix of blues standards, R&B, oldies, originals and yes, some Monkees songs. They'll appear tonight at the Stone Pony in Asbury Park. Robbie Woliver

description: MORNING

title: April 22-28; Delta Pilots In Tentative Deal
description: Delta Air Lines and its pilots reached a tentative contract settlement one week before a strike deadline. The deal, which must still be approved by the union's leadership and Delta's nearly 10,000 pilots, saved the White House from having to intervene. The price of peace was expensive. The pilots will receive pay increases ranging from 24 percent to 34 percent over four years, costing Delta more than $2 billion. Two other airlines, American and United, still face potential strikes later this year. Laurence Zuckerman

title: A Hut Of Her Own
description: Cosmopolites whose idea of summer entertaining is at least three cocktail parties on a Saturday night, chased by an expense-account dinner at a trendy restaurant in the Hamptons with great cell-phone reception, could learn a lot from Mary Vinson's relaxed approach to the lost art of getting lost.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COMRAS, OSCAR
description: COMRAS-Oscar. Ozzie, so many years, so many tears, lovingly remembered always. Blanche and Children

title: On the Trail Of Television's Lost Treasures
description: LAST fall the maintenance staff at City Center in Manhattan pried open a painted-over closet and uncovered a treasure trove. Squirreled inside were boxes full of scripts and other documents stored there by Max Liebman, producer of ''Your Show of Shows.'' The discovery was an extraordinary pop-culture windfall. But in a way it was nothing unusual.

title: Corrections
description: Two articles on Page 7 of Arts & Leisure today about August Wilson's new play, ''King Hedley II,'' and a listing on Page 40 carry outdated references to the opening date at the Virginia Theater. After the section had gone to press, the producers announced that because the star, Brian Stokes Mitchell, was ill, the play would open on Tuesday, not today.

title: Leonard Setting Sights on Ryder Cup Berth
description: Justin Leonard has earned a healthy living as a golfer, but he is also concerned about the health of others.

title: Up to the Elbows In Formality
description: Gloves, for day and evening, all but vanished during the 1960's peacock revolution. The rare exception was Brooke Astor's set, who never gave them up. Last Monday night, at the opening of the Jacqueline Kennedy exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum, long white or black gloves were the surprise fashion statement of a very formally dressed list of 4,000 guests. Leading this revival of formality (above) was a glowing Caroline Kennedy.

title: OUT THERE/London; English Jeweler, a Bit Faded, Turns to the House of Jagger
description: I DON'T want to design jewelry just for the ladies who lunch,'' Jade Jagger declared with puckish emphasis, lunching at Claridge's earlier this month, as one of the grandes dames in question, seated nearby, flashed a look of disapproval and returned to her pheasant. ''That's not what my job is about.''

title: How to Solve The New York Times Crossword Puzzle
description: The helpful instructions that Will Shortz (Endpaper) gives for solving Times crossword puzzles do not address one particular constituency: those who find the puzzles fairly simple, even on Thursdays and Sundays. As one who was ranked among the top 150 crossword solvers nationwide in a contest held by Games Magazine (of which Will Shortz was then editor in chief), I can offer a couple of ways. One method is to fill in the first ''across'' word, and then use only the letters from that word to continue. An even more challenging method is to fill in the first ''across'' word, fill in the ''down'' word from the last letter of that word and complete the grid by adding the word that includes the last letter of each new word.

title: Letters
description: Many readers were entertained by our "How to" issue; they enjoyed the mixture of fact and fun -- and the surprising mix of contributors. But not everyone was amused. Some emphasized that teenage popularity has a dark side.

title: Same as He Ever Was
description: David Byrne carries everything he needs in a big red knapsack. He is self-contained. Like a strangely merry refugee, he wears the pack wherever he goes, his world on his back. ''It weighs me down a bit,'' he says, ''but I'm kinda married to it. I feel naked without it now. I like bein' portable.'' To prove its utility, he rifles through the miniature household: ''Got my passport here, just in case. Once in a while you get to the airport and you don't have the passport. Makes life easier. Here, got a toothbrush. And my Swiss Army knife. Flashlight. Hey, look -- a sewing kit.''

title: A High-Tech Lifeline In Europe's Rust Belt
description: THE factory floor of Z.R.E. Grodek seems an unlikely center of Poland's nascent Internet economy. Its 160 workers spend most of their time forging, banging and welding pieces of metal into boilers, racks, pumps and other parts for the heavy industry that the Internet revolution was supposed to make us forget.

title: Portland, Ore.
description: In the friendly rivalry between Portland and Seattle, Portland has traditionally played second fiddle in terms of urban vigor and allure.

title: Three U.S. Crews Win in World Cup Event
description: United States national team crews won three races today in the first round of the Zurich Rowing World Cup, the first time the event has been staged in North America.

title: Exploring Baltimore's Inner Harbor
description: LIKE most parents, I divide my traveling life into two eras: B.C. and A.C.: Before Children and After Children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLISHUK, SIDNEY
description: POLISHUK-Sidney. On April 16. Former Assistant Finance Administrator of the City of New York. Retired after 43 years of dedicated service. Devoted to his family and Synagogue. He was a kind and generous man who will be sorely missed.

title: Amtrak to Begin Weekend Acela Service
description: Amtrak will add its new Acela Express trains to the Washington-Boston route on weekends beginning today. The weekend trains make the run in 6 hours 50 minutes, compared with about eight and a half hours on conventional trains.

title: At Yale, Lessons in Writing and in Life
description: WHEN Robert Penn Warren, the poet, novelist and critic, arrived at Yale in 1927 to pursue his doctoral studies, he lasted in New Haven for just a few months. In 1928, having moved on to Oxford, he wrote to a friend, ''What I really wanted was to get in an environment where men were actually doing creative writing, but Yale is not the place for that, I learned too late.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUER, ELIZABETH CROKER
description: AUER-Elizabeth Croker. A longtime resident of Armonk, NY, on April 27, age 81. Born in Manhattan, Mrs. Auer later moved with her family to White Plains, before moving to Cedarhurst, LI. She graduated from Our Lady of Mercy Academy, Syosset, NY, and was married for 55 years to the late George J. Auer Jr., a partner in the law firm of Brewer and Auer, White Plains, NY. She held various leadership roles in the Westchester County Women's Republican League and was a volunteer at White Plains Hospital. She is survived by her brothers Howard and Wallace Croker of Belfast, ME, her daughter Kathleen James of Mt. Kisco, NY, her sons George J. Auer III, of Medford Lakes, NJ, and James T. Auer of South Weymouth, ME, and ten grandchildren. Visiting hours will be on Monday, April 30, from 5 PM until 7 PM, at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave, White Plains. Funeral mass Tuesday, 10 AM, at St. John the Evangelist Church, White Plains. Interment Middle Patent Cemetery, Bedford, NY. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be sent to White Plains Hospital.

title: Alewives Get Boost From Spawning Ladder
description: In its second season, a fish ladder strategically situated at a small dam on the Peconic River in Riverhead is succeeding in opening up new spawning grounds for alewives, said a retired Riverhead biology teacher who led efforts to place the ladder.

title: The Joy of a Comeback That Leaves the Past Behind
description: CHARLOTTE RAMPLING'S screen image in the late 1960's and early 1970's was so strong that for many moviegoers she remains fixed as the seductive and disturbing young woman who haunts, say, ''The Damned'' or ''Night Porter.'' In practice, of course, her life kept going: two marriages, two children and 40 more movies, many made in France, her home for the last 30 years. Yet the star she had been still shadowed her. Even her enduring beauty evoked that other younger woman, that earlier more celebrated career.

title: 2 Actors Grow Into Big Roles In 'Oz'
description: A NICE little story is unfolding on the stage of the old Palace Theater here, where the Growing Stage Theater for Young Audiences is presenting ''The Wizard of Oz.''

title: Dan Lacy, 87, an Expert on Copyright Law
description: Dan Lacy, a former executive of the McGraw-Hill Companies and a nationally recognized expert on copyright law, died on April 17 at a retirement home in Durham, N.C. He was 87.

title: San Francisco Has A Lot on Its Plate
description: THE San Francisco Farmers Market, a grid of wooden and concrete trestles with corrugated metal roofs, was coming to the end of its Saturday morning rush. Carrots the size of mortar shells were down to 25 cents a pound and the huge globe artichokes that only seem to be available in California were down to $1 each. Deals were to be had. ''Make an offer.'' ''How much do you give me?''

description: THE Davison Art Center at Wesleyan University is a major repository of historical prints and printmaking techniques, and with ''Digital Printmaking at Singer Editions,'' it is showing that it is interested in the latest developments in the field.

title: Why No Star Shines As Bright
description: SHE would have been 75 in June. ''What would have happened to Marilyn Monroe?'' asked Jeanine Basinger, chairman of the film studies department at Wesleyan University and the author of several books on women in Hollywood. ''Let's pray she would have won an Oscar, and played 'Hedda Gabler' on Broadway and been given a Life Achievement award. But I wouldn't bet on it.''

title: On the Left Bank, an Updating Worthy of Wilde
description: Not so long ago, Left Bank hotels were better known for dingy wallpapers and fraying carpets than for marble bathrooms and high-thread-count linens. Jean-Guy Dubucheron changed all that. In the late 60's, he restored the weary Htel d'Alsace on the Rue des Beaux-Arts -- where Oscar Wilde died -- naming his shiny bit of nostalgia L'Htel.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on April 8 with an article about where Westchester students go to college misstated the location of Walter Panas High School. It is in Cortlandt Manor, not Peekskill.

title: McCall and Silver Enjoying a New Rapport
description: For years, the main feature of Comptroller H. Carl McCall's relationship with Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver was a frosty mistrust. These days, it is the long, friendly chats they regularly share, in person or by phone, during which the speaker offers Mr. McCall advice on his run for governor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLOW, HERBERT
description: KAPLOW-Herbert. April 26, 2001. Of Coconut Creek, FL, and Long Beach, NY. Beloved husband of the late Geraldine Kaplow. Dear father of Robert (Lois) Kaplow and Carol (James) Gumpert. Adored grandfather of Julie and Jeffrey Kaplow, Evan Gumpert and Jessica Gumpert. Loving brother of Irving (Gloria) Kaplow and Sylvia (Sam) Simon. Dear friend of Lois Dorman and her family. Fond brother-in-law of Edward and Ruth Seligman, Lottie Seligman and Sam Gartel. Also survived by many loving nieces, nephews and friends. Services Monday, 10 AM, at ''Gutterman's Inc,'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Streetscapes/Greek Consulate, 69 East 79th Street; 1909 Carrre & Hastings House, and a '62 Extension
description: EARLIER this year, Dimitris Platis, the consul general of Greece in New York, oversaw the cleaning of the facade at 69 East 79th Street, the Greek consulate, as part of his effort to restore the 1909 town house. But what was cleaned was really two buildings: the original house, designed by Carrre & Hastings, and an unusually sensitive 1962 extension.

title: 5 Seals With Kerrey Back Him on War Raid
description: Bob Kerrey has been joined by five members of his Navy Seals team in denying that they knowingly killed civilians during the Vietnam War in a wanton raid. The statement disputes assertions of a seventh member of the team that it herded civilians into a group and killed them.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: 1. We called this story ''Why Don't You ... Give a Small Dance?'' for a variety of reasons. It worked well with the sexy clothes and, in a time of economic uncertainty, the theme also suggested opportunities for frivolity without extreme financial penalties. ''I liked shooting our small dance,'' says the photographer and hostess Ellen von Unwerth, whose full-length documentary, ''Cannes Confidential,'' will be broadcast by France's Canal Plus in May. ''Sometimes you have the right ingredients, great people, a great place, but the party doesn't take off. This one did from the first Polaroid. The glamorous clothes helped. People feel sexy when they dress up.''

title: Lives; The Champ
description: Armando Santos, 12, who began training at 8 and first fought at 10, has decided to dedicate his life to the sport. He even gave up sweets. His discipline paid off. In December, he was crowned the champion of Mexico City's Golden Gloves tournament in his class when his final opponent's cavities disqualified him in accordance with a Mexican rule.

title: MEXICAN LABORERS IN U.S. DURING WAR SUE FOR BACK PAY
description: Thousands of Mexicans brought to the United States as laborers during World War II say they have never received money that was deducted from their paychecks for them, and now many are seeking hundreds of millions of dollars in reparations.

title: BENEFITS
description: A Film Premiere

title: There's No Panic at the Top in Atlanta Despite the Braves' Struggles
description: What the Atlanta Braves need to pump fire into their lineup is the kind of hitter John Schuerholz was when he hit .420 in his senior season at Towson University in Maryland. Schuerholz is not available to play second base for the Braves because he's 60 years old and baseball has never had a playing general manager. But Schuerholz the general manager may be seeking a .420 hitter before this season is over.

title: Memento Mori
description: It's the ultimate curtain call. The Hollywood Forever Cemetery, 6000 Santa Monica Boulevard in Los Angeles, the burial ground for such film luminaries as Rudolph Valentino, Cecil B. De Mille, Peter Lorre and John Huston, has created a theater in the main building and kiosks throughout the grounds with touch-screen visual biographies of those interred there.

title: How to Rob A Bank
description: As a bank teller, I was shocked at Shane DuBow's feature about how to rob a bank. At first I thought it was a joke, but as I continued reading, I realized you were serious. I have been fortunate so far in not having been involved in a robbery. Some tellers I know have not been so lucky. One had a knife held to her throat during a robbery. In the few years I have been with the bank, I have had courses on how to quickly identify a robber's clothing and the type of weapon used. The fact that this is routine training is scary enough, but to have your magazine give people ideas about how to make robberies easier is outrageous.

title: Out of a Nightmare, New Dreams Are Born
description: WHEN Sara Haghbin was 3 years old, living in a small Iranian village, her mother had an argument with a neighbor who flung battery acid at both of them. The mother is still institutionalized, having suffered not only physical injury but also a mental breakdown. Sara's facial features were burned away by the caustic substance, and she was blinded.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Select Showings

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   VANN, SIDNEY H.
description: VANN-Sidney H. Remembering forever your birthday my love 4/29/30-4/2/99

title: Commercial Property/Newark; Buyers of Gateway Tower Have Plenty of Patience
description: MOST developers buy an office building because they see the opportunity to make changes. If tenants are paying rents that are below the current market rate, those leases can be renegotiated as they near expiration or new tenants are found to pay the higher rate.

title: Two Major Changes for the Around Alone Race
description: In 1982, a young, unknown Frenchman named Philippe Jeantot set sail from Newport, R.I., to begin the first BOC Challenge, also known as Around Alone. It was the first singlehanded round-the-world race to start and finish from the United States, and Jeantot proved to be in a class by himself. His winning time of 159 days was 11 days ahead of the runner-up.

title: Dance Listings
description: ALVIN AILEY AMERICAN DANCE THEATER  Tilles Center, Route 25A, Brookville (516-299-3100) Fri., 8; Sat., 2 and 8.

title: In the Midst of Rustic Surroundings
description: IT is the dcor at the Adirondack Grill that makes the biggest impression. Appropriately situated on Forest Avenue in Glen Cove, the newcomer makes a statement even before diners enter. The outdoor porch of the lodge-like structure features stacks of firewood, Flexible Flyer sleds casually propped against a wall and crossed snowshoes over the door.

title: Three Plans Equal One 'Ecumenical Drive'
description: THE applications seem to be a coincidence, as does the fact that they will be judged amid much discussion of the Census Bureau's recent report detailing the Island's increasing ethnic diversity. But it would be hard to imagine a better example of that diversity than three building permit applications now on file in Lake Success, where the Korean Presbyterian Church, the Jain Society of America and the North Shore Hebrew Academy may soon be neighbors.

title: Rene Goldberg, Shane Edelman
description: Rabbi Rene Beth Goldberg and Shane Zachery Edelman were married last night by Rabbi Charles A. Kroloff at the Ritz-Carlton in Boston.

title: Knicks 2001: The Playoffs
description: Here is an archive of game stories from the Knicks' 2001 postseason.

title: Designed For Living
description: When the fashion photographer John Rawlings and his wife, Babs, a fashion illustrator and magazine editor, were not producing stories, they were in them -- hoisting martini glasses at the latest nightspots, hosting small, formal dinner parties in their art-filled, Robsjohn-Gibbings-furnished apartment on Sutton Place or, most notably, giving perfectly casual (and casually perfect) little cookouts at their converted boathouse in Oyster Bay, N.Y. Babs was famous for her Champagne-soaked barbecued seafood and tarte tatin, as well as her tart remarks, which amused guests like Vogue's editor Edna Woolman Chase; her daughter, the actress Ilka Chase; and the legendary photographer Horst P. Horst. But Babs was no homebody. Her seemingly effortless entertaining notwithstanding, she once famously admonished a young co-worker that ''home is for changing one's clothes.'' And what clothes they were. Another Babs -- Babs Simpson, a former Vogue editor -- recalls, ''She was always dressed for the Riviera, whether it was midsummer or midwinter.'' Indeed, both Rawlingses were pioneers of the laid-back chic that epitomized postwar American fashion.

title: Wyoming Keeps Low-Tax Title
description: Dick Cheney may have reaped more than political rewards for moving back to Wyoming. In 2000, for the fourth year in a row, Wyoming was the state with the gentlest tax bite, according to a survey by Bloomberg Personal Finance magazine.

title: School Was Important, After All
description: There is bad news for anyone who ever took home a report card that noted ''Does not play well'' or ''Does not complete homework.'' The poor marks you thought you had left behind in grammar school may indicate that you will have trouble expanding your company through an acquisition.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-29-01; How To Look Gainfully Employed
description: There are countless pink slips in the brave new economy. Here's how to convince people that you're still industrious even if you were on the receiving end of one of them.

title: And on the 96th Day . . .
description: It was 7:30 a.m. last Wednesday when President Bush arrived in the Oval Office, beaming and joking with his secretary, Ashley Estes. He tackled the personal correspondence she brought him, handwriting thank-you notes just as his father did.

title: How to Defend Someone You Know Is Guilty
description: The tired argument that only by defending the guilty will the system work for the innocent is specious and self-serving. It's analogous to physicians arguing that quality medical care for everyone can only be ensured if we demand surgery on the terminally ill.

title: How To
description: Inasmuch as your special issue appeared on the day of Mr. Woods's triumph at the Masters, there must have been hundreds of professional golfers who wished you'd included a ''How to Beat Tiger Woods.''

title: At Long Last Love
description: With due respect to Patrick Dennis, his Auntie Mame had nothing on Elsie de Wolfe. The world's most celebrated interior decorator stood on her head at the slightest provocation, served cocktails in the bathroom and had a blithe disregard for personal space. ''She was always jabbing you,'' says the designer Albert Hadley, who got the sharp end of her elbow more than once. When Cartier delivered an aquamarine and diamond tiara, Elsie dyed her snow-white locks pale blue in color-coordinated homage. But nothing this design diva did in all her years on earth topped what Elsie did on March 10, 1926. She got married.

title: As a Hotel Goes Up, So Does The Unease of the Neighbors
description: Every morning on the way to work, Ahsan Farooqi walks out of the St. George Tower and Grill apartment building at 111 Hicks Street and peeks at the construction in the empty lot next door. The sight, he said, makes him uneasy: workers digging under the east wall of his 30-story landmark building and drilling reinforcing rods into it.

title: Workers, and Bosses, in a Visa Maze
description: AT the Delhi Darbar restaurant, where the Indian expatriate community here comes to eat, the talk is not about the food, but about the uncertainty of life in America these days. Gathered around the table are four computer programmers, born in India and educated at top schools there, who now work in high-technology jobs in the New York area. Along with their wives and children, they came here nearly six years ago, on the promise of a job paying 10 times more than they could earn back home and the expectation of pursuing the American dream.

title: April 22-28; Augusto Pinochet, He's Not
description: Extradition battles are usually carried out between nations, not states. But in a highly unusual legal tussle over a murder case that dates to 1963, California and Oregon are fighting over what to do with an ailing 70-year-old man.

title: MUSIC; An Imagination Bordered in Allegory
description: ''ICONS IN SOUND'' is how the English composer John Tavener often refers to his compositions and sometimes titles them, alluding to the visual representations of Christ and the saints that have been the dominant art form of the Eastern Orthodox Church for the last thousand years. With his requiems, canticles, hymns and liturgical cantatas, Sir John, at 57, has created a body of religious art in a secular age.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIZK, KHALIL
description: RIZK-Khalil. It is with deepest sorrow that the Board of Directors and Officers of Venetian Heritage, Inc. mourn the premature death of their beloved President, Khalil Rizk. Khalil's enthusiasm for restoring beautiful monuments and works of art, his tireless ability to bring us new friends, his imagination & flair in creating wonderful events here and abroad, and his generosity in supporting us financially and morally, have made the deepest possible mark on us personally, on our organization, and indeed on the City of Venice. We offer our deepest sympathy to his family and all his friends who loved him. Countess Cristiana Brandolini, International Chairman Lawrence D. Lovett, Chairman Marchesa Barbara Berlingeri, Marchesa Lesa Marcello, Mrs. Donald K. Miller, Mrs. Lawrence Copley Thaw, Vice Presidents Alexis Gregory, Treasurer

title: For Lack of Support, U.N. Agency Shrinks Aid to Refugees
description: The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, responsible for the welfare of 22 million people, is making drastic cuts in staff and services because of diminishing support, especially from Europe.

title: Ideas & Trends: Muddy Waters; In Defense of Defenseless River Towns
description: AS the Mississippi River was reaching its crest during the record flood of 1965, each day my grandfather would back his gray Rambler into the alley behind his house in Dubuque, Iowa, drive about seven blocks south and park near the water's edge at 17th and Jackson Streets. There he and a handful of other men would step into waiting skiffs and motor out to the town's meatpacking house. Though ''the Pack'' was deeply flooded, the men were security guards there and they made as many of the usual rounds as they could on the water.

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.)

title: It's Raritan River Time Again
description: The Raritan River Festival's award for adventurous programming, from Ascap-Chamber Music America, was earned. The four-week series is performed in separate West Jersey locations -- none of which were meant to be concert halls -- and the music comes from all over the world, and from multiple centuries. This Saturday, ''Music of Silk and Bamboo'' opens the series at the Prallsville Mills in Stockton. Performed on traditional Chinese instruments, it complements the cellist Yo-Yo Ma's current Silk Road Project, an international series finishing at Carnegie Hall next spring, and featuring music from along the Europe-China trade route. Such music influenced the composer Tan Dun, who won an Oscar for his score to ''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon,'' in which Mr. Ma was the soloist. On May 19, the Corigliano Quartet performs at Bloomsbury's Old Greenwich Presbyterian Church. John Corigliano, son of the New York Philharmonic's longtime concertmaster, has just been awarded the Pulitzer Prize in music. The quartet's program mixes old masters with recent compositions. (908) 213-1100. Leslie Kandell

title: Science Fiction
description: Science fiction is a genre without clear boundaries. It is not fiction about science but fiction that bids for the reader's attention by clothing its fabrications with the authority of science. Stories that explore the social impact of scientific advances are obviously science fiction. But so are stories that adopt the measured, dispassionate tone of scientific communication -- what Isaac Asimov called a ''transparent'' style -- to lend plausibility to the most outlandish flights of imagination. Octavia E. Butler, the only science fiction writer to win a MacArthur Foundation ''genius'' grant, has been extending the genre's reach in unexpected directions during a career that spans three decades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, LARRY
description: LEVINE-Larry. Melinda Bush deeply mourns the untimely passing of Larry Levine and sends her deepest sympathy to the Levine family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODWIN, HAROLD
description: GOODWIN-Harold. Died of cancer on April 11th at his home in Lyme, CT. at age 81. He served with the RCAF as a navigator in W.W. II. He was a mural, portrait & genre painter, & author-illustrator, teacher, and the first President of the Lyme Academy of Fine Arts. He is survived by his wife, Barbara Eckhardt - Goodwin, daughter, Georgiana Goodwin, and granddaughter, Sophia Harvey. There will be no public service.

title: A Revival Of 'Hair,' A Graying Pit Band
description: AT a recent band rehearsal for the forthcoming revival of ''Hair'' at City Center, the final production in this season's Encores! concert musicals series, Galt MacDermot, the show's composer, a scarecrow with a kind face and a fringe of white hair, and Rob Fisher, the musical director of the series, couldn't stop grinning at each other across twin keyboards. Around them, a small crew of middle-aged players appeared to approach the music with a mixture of old-pro seriousness and playfulness.

title: Analyze This Guy
description: A LIFE OF JUNG

title: Breath of Fresh Art
description: Altoids limited-edition tins are featuring works by the painters Virgil Marti and Dario Robleto and the New York party photographer Jessica Craig-Martin on the lids. The images on the tins, which are sold at Tower Records, were chosen from a group of 70 works that the company donated to the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo last fall. ''Every party photographer has breath mints in her bag,'' Ms. Craig-Martin said. ''They're the most important tool, next to your camera.'' Flash: People are more likely to say cheese if you envelope them in a curiously strong cloud of wintergreen. JENNIFER TUNG

title: Square Roundly Criticized
description: At first glance, the message seems like a perverse boast, since the town center is a drab corridor of strip malls, chain stores and gas stations along State Highway 35, an ugly stepsister to its famously hip neighbor, Red Bank.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: 1. ''Elsie de Wolfe hated her looks, so her face is quite guarded,'' says Holland Taylor, our Elsie manqu 1/8. To get into the role, the actress -- who appears as a lusty judge on the ABC drama ''The Practice'' -- studied portraits of de Wolfe, like this 1929 photograph by H.T. Koshiba (a), $3,500, from R. Louis Bofferding Decorative and Fine Art, and the 1939 portrait by Franois Kollar (b) recreated in this story. ''And it's obvious that Elsie really didn't like her hands, either,'' Taylor adds. ''When she wasn't wearing little white gloves, she curled them into the oddest shapes, which only made them look like claws.''

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: In the Business Of Helping Women Feel Good
description: Lisa Porter, manager of Entre Nous in Mount Kisco, takes the name of her boutique very seriously. The store's name, French for ''between us,'' provides personalized services to women who have undergone breast surgery or who are undergoing chemotherapy.

title: Opera Stars Scale Down for Pop
description: TO the list of the inescapable that includes death and taxes add the appeal of crossover to opera singers. Since Enrico Caruso at least, the siren song of popular music has seduced divas and divos alike. Sometimes the results have proved surprisingly successful, as when the bass Cesare Siepi crooned Cole Porter or the soprano Hilde Gueden sweetly sang Nol Coward and Ivor Novello. At other times -- when, for example, Jos Carreras tries ''Over the Rainbow'' -- the results can only be called embarrassing.

title: Reassessing an Era When Excess Was the Norm
description: THE art world tends to clock itself in decades. But the 1980's were something else, a decade of bloated reputations, excessive prices, collective rapaciousness and some serious painting.

title: BOOX
April 22-28; Advance in Stem Cell Study
description: Biologists at the National Institutes of Health have learned how to make the embryonic cells of a mouse generate structures very similar to the islets of the pancreas gland. The islet-like clusters are composed of several different types of cells, arranged in the correct architecture, and produce insulin when exposed to glucose.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: April 22-28; Supreme Court Backs Full Arrests on Minor Charges
description: In a 5-to-4 decision that splintered usual alliances among the justices, the Supreme Court ruled that a police officer who observes someone committing a crime, even a minor offense for which the maximum penalty is a fine, can make a full arrest without violating the Fourth Amendment's prohibition against unreasonable seizure.

title: Use of Herbicide Is Proposed In Weed-Choked Lake George
description: A state environmental agency charged with protecting Lake George is proposing the first use of an herbicide in an Adirondack lake, to fend off an insidious weed that has choked native plants and mired swimmers and boats.

title: It's Cherry Blossom Time And That Means a Festival
description: There will be plenty of Japanese music, dance, art and food at the second annual White Plains Cherry Blossom Festival, but the real stars of this show are the trees.

title: Molly McSkimming, Thomas Bianco
description: Mary Teresa McSkimming, a daughter of Beverly J. McSkimming of St. Louis and the late John W. McSkimming, was married yesterday to Thomas Louis Bianco, the son of Carmela and Albert L. Bianco of Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Jeffrey J. Madley performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary in Southampton, N.Y.

title: Business; Recovery Lessons From an Industrial Phoenix
description: NENERABLE industrial companies like Owens Corning, W. R. Grace and Armstrong World Industries, a division of Armstrong Holdings, have all sought bankruptcy protection in recent months because of lawsuits from workers sickened by asbestos. But these companies have one common consolation: 18 years ago, another company blazed the asbestos-bankruptcy trail and survived.

title: The 'Next Guy' Dies
description: To the Editor:

title: Sew Cool
description: When Elisa Jimenez began designing six years ago, she lacked the money to hire a team of professional seamstresses, so she taught her girlfriends to sew. On Friday nights, the women would gather at different locations to help the designer execute her ideas. One person would provide the food, another the booze, a third the apartment. In exchange, Jimenez would provide each assistant with a custom-designed outfit of her choice. This is not the typical means by which a designer produces a clothing line, but Jimenez, who bathed a plus-size model in a pool of honey and sent her dripping down the runway last season, is not your typical designer.

title: The View From/Orange; From a Simple Home To a Town Treasure
description: WHEN Nathan Bryan and his wife, Elizabeth, stood in front of their new home, a modest two-story house built around 1740 on a small hill in what is now Orange, all they could see for miles around was the raw wooded wilderness occupied by wild fox, coyote, beaver and the Native American Paugussets who still lived there.

title: Personal Business; Planning a Defense Before the Layoff
description: ABOUT a year ago, a top executive at a major fashion retailer was fired. He had been accused of turning a blind eye while an employee -- whom he had hired -- embezzled nearly $500,000 from the business.

title: Rescued Retreat
description: JUST as we were pulling out of the driveway, our daughter burst through the door.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Pocantico Hills; Simple Living Near the Rockefellers
description: IN 1893, when John D. Rockefeller Sr. first saw the land that would become the family's Kykuit estate, he said it was a place ''where the fine views invite the soul and where we can live simply and quietly.''

title: Preparing to Grieve For a Catholic School
description: For Corey Patrick, a 31-year-old city bus driver who lives in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, sending his son to All Saints School in Harlem is very convenient. The school, on East 130th Street in Manhattan, is just minutes from the bus depot at 146th Street and Lenox Avenue, where his shift ends at 2 p.m.

title: Verdi and More Verdi
description: This year, many musical events could be named ''Giuseppi Verdi Memorial Concert.'' It is the centenary of the composer's death. On Friday at the John Harms Center for the Arts in Englewood, the Ars Musica Chorale, of Ridgewood, is to present a memorial concert of choruses, sacred pieces and solo arias under the direction of Italo Marchini, with the tenor Steven Harrison. Next Sunday afternoon at Harms, Verdi is to be memorialized with ''Rigoletto'' by the National Lyric Opera. Leslie Kandell

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAGID, BRUCE
description: JAGID-Bruce. On April 28, 2001. He was 61 years old. He is survived by his beloved wife Lillian. Devoted father to Jonathan, Jeffrey and Joshua. Dearest brother of Irene. Loving grandfather of Leo, Eliza and Nikki. He will be deeply missed by all who knew him. For further information please call Hellman Memorial Chapels, 845-356-8600.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDOLPH, THEODORE
description: RUDOLPH-Theodore. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Theodore Rudolph, associated with The Times from 1921 to 1964.

title: Appraising The Value Of a House
description: THE ability to get a mortgage is based largely on income, creditworthiness and the amount of the down payment. But there's another element, over which the buyer has little control: the appraised value of the house.

title: Italian Race Winds Down And Nerves Begin to Fray
description: Two weeks before Italians vote for a new prime minister, the best indicator of how the race is going is not polls (unreliable at best) or television campaign commercials (banned), but the mood of the candidates.

title: Reroute the F and G Trains? Derail the Plan, Riders Say
description: ''Be sure you're on the right track.'' So say Metropolitan Transit Authority posters plastered on trains around the city. But many angry G and F train riders in Brooklyn and Queens think the agency has not followed its own advice.

title: Navy Bombing Is Betrayal, Puerto Rico's Governor Says
description: As Sila M. Caldern hopscotched across this island during her successful campaign for governor last year, she promised that, if elected, she would end the Navy's bombing runs on the island of Vieques that have so inflamed the nationalistic passion of Puerto Ricans. It is a promise that helped make her the first woman to become governor of this commonwealth, but one she has not been able to keep.

title: Eve Stamato, Kenneth Mandel
description: Eve Mary Stamato and Kenneth Douglas Mandel are to be married today by Mayor John J. Delaney of Morristown, N.J., at Bretton Woods, a caterer in Morris Plains, N.J.

title: The Spot at Stony Brook Tries to Remain Upbeat
description: THE future of the Spot, a music club at the State University at Stony Brook that The Long Island Voice and Newsday have both called ''the best on Long Island,'' appears to be in jeopardy. Some university officials say the Spot, subsidized by the Graduate Student Organization, is not serving the needs of graduate students, but rather attracting outsiders and underage patrons.

title: Private Sector; Like Father Like Son, Minus Airline
description: Edward S. Trippe, whose father, Juan, founded Pan American World Airways and helped open Bermuda as a destination for air travelers in the late 1930's, is following in his father's footsteps, at least on the ground.

title: Richard Scammon, 85, Analyst Of Political Trends and Statistics
description: Richard M. Scammon, an influential political scientist and elections analyst who had the ear of politicians and journalists in the turbulent 1960's and 70's, died Friday in a retirement community in Gaithersburg, Md. He was 85.

title: Permit Was Issued For Roosevelt Field
description: In his opinion essay ''When a Mall Goes Out of Control'' [April 8], E. Christopher Murray claims that a ''massive foundation had begun'' on the site of a proposed expansion at Roosevelt Field. Later, he also claims that work commenced on the site without a permit from the Town of Hempstead.

description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Yes, There Is a Free Lunch
description: Outbreaks of foot-and-mouth disease have helped drive down McDonald's stock price by more than 30 percent in less than a year, and its dividend is just eight-tenths of 1 percent. title: NEW AREA CODES
description: Beginning in July, three new area codes will be assigned to new telephone connections in northern and central New Jersey, giving the state a total of nine area codes. Rather than being placed in territory carved from old areas, the codes will be assigned to new connections inside the areas served by existing codes. New telephone connections in the 201 area will be assigned an area code of 551, new connections in 973 will be 862, and new connections in 732 will be 848. Existing numbers in these areas will not be changed. A phase-in period will begin July 1, when callers will be able to dial the old seven-digit number for their current area code. But beginning Dec. 1, callers will be required to dial 10 digits for all calls, even to their own area codes. The cost of local calls will not be affected, according to the North American Numbering Plan Administration, which assigns new area codes. Karen DeMasters

title: Strom In the Balance
description: In his front-row seat in the Senate chamber, Strom Thurmond sits with mouth slackly agape. His thin, rust-colored hair is stretched back from the top of his head, so straight that some strands do not follow the curve of his skull but float out behind it. His hands have grown enormous, spidery, and the fingers don't bend as easily as they once did at knuckles that have come to look like walnuts. Those hands were cut up in the crash landing of an Army glider flown over the bloody Normandy beaches; Thurmond was already 44 years old then. Now he occasionally raises them to touch his eyebrows, his cheeks and his lips with his index fingers, straight as chopsticks, or to pat that wayward hair. As his name approaches in the roll call -- around about the R's -- the aide seated beside him leans over and whispers urgently in his ear. Then, as the senator's name is called, the aide taps him on the elbow, and Thurmond rises to his feet to cry out, ''No!''

title: QUICK BITE/Hoboken; Applying the Pita Principle
description: ''Ruggedly handsome''? Yes, I am. ''Simply irresistible''? Guilty as charged. But ''positively healthy''? Sorry, you've got the wrong guy. So when the Pita Grill opened and advertised itself as ''positively healthy,'' I wasn't sure it was the place for me. Walking in, I was caught off guard by the fairly elegant dcor. With the name Pita Grill, I was expecting a scene akin to Belushi's ''cheeseburger, cheeseburger, cheeseburger'' skit. Instead, this restaurant offers exposed brick walls, a pressed-tin ceiling, tiled floor, muted lighting and flowers on the tables. I also didn't anticipate waiter service. And imagine my surprise when, after I had ordered a 20-ounce bottle of Coke, the server poured it for me at the table. Was I supposed to sniff the cap? With the stiff competition along Washington Street, it's important for a place like Pita Grill to distinguish itself. Hoboken patrons can be fickle: Johnny Rockets has thrived, for example, while Small Burgers folded faster than an American flag at Arlington National Cemetery. Pita Grill also claimed to have the ''best grilled chicken anywhere.'' So I selected grilled chicken on a pita, topped with roasted garlic sauce ($6). I added fresh mozzarella ($1.50). Best anywhere, I'm not sure, but the chicken was juicy, and with the garlic sauce, quite flavorful. On the side, I skipped hummus, baba ganouj, tabbouleh and couscous to find my old unhealthy friend french fries ($3). They were hand-cut, golden brown and not at all greasy. The menu promises live jazz Wednesday evenings and Sundays noon to 3, but on a recent Sunday no musicians were on hand. I didn't mind; there was piped-in music, and it had been a while since I last heard Andy Gibb's ''I Just Want to Be Your Everything.'' JACK SILBERT

Mr. Casey was a graduate of Columbia University, Class of 1937, and the Columbia University School of Law, Class of 1940. He retired as Lt. Commander after serving in the Navy during WWII, including active duty in the Pacific Theater. He was a founding partner of the law firm, Casey, Lane & Mittendorf in NYC. title: Mr. Bush's Beginning
description: We are not among those who complain that the tradition of measuring the first hundred days of a presidency has turned into an empty ritual. It is a convenient way to demarcate a period in which a new chief executive and the American people learn things that cannot emerge in the campaign vortex. The glimpses we get often can be valuable and even prophetic. Before the end of his first 100 days as president, Franklin D. Roosevelt rescued the banking system and won approval of 15 major laws. John F. Kennedy suffered the Bay of Pigs fiasco and Ronald Reagan proposed a sweeping economic program and survived an assassination attempt. Bill Clinton struggled to enact his economic policies and health care reforms amid the chaos created by his swirling personal style and distracting issues like gays in the military.

The work, which has been going for five years, is open to anyone who enrolls in the Field Methods in Archaeology course at the college, and the public is also invited to come to the battlefield and observe the work. Mr. Pagoulatos recently talked about the excavation.

Even though David Duchovny will be doing something scary on an oil rig in ''The X-Files'' on Fox, and James Gandolfini is sure to be up to no good in ''The Sopranos'' on HBO. And the show is clearly a major event, being done live from a sound stage in Los Angeles with a multipart theatrical set, 8 cameras and a 7-piece off-screen orchestra.

title: Cinqueterre
description: To the Editor: Regarding your article about the Cinqueterre, ''On the Edge of a Time Gone By,'' (March 18), my family and I visited this wonderful place in February. In our three days there, we were mesmerized by the vision of wondrous terraced mountains that worked their way down to the sea. We feasted on fresh, deliciously prepared seafood and local produce and wine. The residents were very friendly and we had many walking adventures in the five villages -- although many trails had been washed out by heavy winter rains. I hope that Cinqueterre retains its beauty and unspoiled charm.

title: Shining a Light on a Path Promising Happiness
description: THE Qian Yuan Temple stands here atop Green Dragon Peak, surrounded by terraced fields and lush bamboo. Long ago, it was a prosperous Taoist monastery with more than 800 rooms, situated on the holy ground where the ''immortal'' Li Ming developed his elixir of immortality around 200 B.C. Centuries of decline and warfare culminating in the Japanese pillage of nearby Nanjing in 1937, however, left Qian Yuan a burned-out shell, marked only by an engraved stone stele and the well from which Li Ming had drawn water.

title: What's New in Classical Music? Not Much

In the 19th century, let's face it: with all due respect to Tolstoy, Ibsen and Czanne, orchestral music and opera seized the public imagination.

title: INSPIRATION; Guess Who Came To Dinner
description: In the 1980's, when he was already famous as a restaurant critic and cookbook writer, Craig Claiborne made a partial retreat from Manhattan to the country and had a house in East Hampton, N.Y. The house was on Clamshell Avenue, built literally out over the water of a wide creek, and had a professional kitchen with a number of ovens and a great marble work surface where Craig and his collaborator, Pierre Franey, spent hours perfecting recipes, the latter at the controls, so to speak, and Craig in half glasses standing at the typewriter, taking down the details.

title: The Durable Jackie
description: Broadway's latest hit may be ''The Producers,'' but Seventh Avenue remains fixated on the erstwhile glories of Camelot. On Tuesday, two coffee-table books celebrating the style of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis will be released. ''Jackie: The Clothes of Camelot'' by Jay Mulvaney (St. Martin's) catalogs her wardrobe with chapters solemnly titled ''The Inauguration Ensembles,'' ''Gowns for State Events'' and ''Private Living and Casual Wear.'' ''Jackie Style'' by Pamela Clarke Keogh (HarperCollins) goes a step further by providing readers actual tips on how to recreate ''Jackie glamour'': wear sleeveless A-line dresses, lots of Valentino and white jeans. Also starting on Tuesday, the Costume Institute will present a show of more than 80 outfits worn by Mrs. Kennedy during her White House years. The accompanying catalog, ''Jacqueline Kennedy: The White House Years'' by Hamish Bowles, offers details about the thinking behind the former first lady's wardrobe choices as well as insights on the making of the clothes. And from June 15th through the 25th, Sloan's Auctioneers will offer Kennedy memorabilia from the collection of Mary Gallagher, Mrs. Kennedy's former personal secretary. Items offered at www.sloansauction.com. include a leopard pillbox hat (estimated at $300 to $500) and a charge card for Pappagallo ($400 to $600).

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; The Best Revenge in Manhattan
description: The playwright Han Ong's assured first novel, FIXER CHAO (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25), introduces us to William Narciso Paulinha, a Filipino street hustler who is eager to get out of the life -- that is, until he meets Shem C, a marginal writer with a chip on his shoulder and a proposition William can't resist. Shem hires him to assume the role of ''Master Chao,'' a fictitious feng shui practitioner, as a vengeful way to fleece and humiliate the inner circle of Bill Hood, an esteemed novelist of Philip Roth stature, whose successes illuminate Shem's many failures, both in his career and his romantic life. As Master Chao, William proves to be a quick study, swiftly rising in status from seedy bar denizen to an A-list guest among the upper echelons of Manhattan society. As he supposedly arranges their decadent homes to invite good fortune, William discreetly heeds Shem's instructions to ensure that important details were ''off by just a few crucial degrees,'' paving the way for his clients' destruction. Roguish though he is, William is a keen observer, and his ever-

title: A 'Drunken Boxer' on the Bowery
description: This building was once alive with activity; you can feel it. And the beautiful structures are still in place  the 20-foot ceilings, marble stairs, ground-floor theater, basement swimming pool and fenced playground on the roof. But its clear that this Bowery-area building  9 Second Avenue  has seen better days. Debris lines the perimeter of nearly every room and some overflow with long-abandoned furniture, books, board games and clothing. Plaster crumbles from the steel-enforced walls and ceilings. Its hard to imagine that this was once a thriving community center for nearly 30 local arts groups. The city-owned building has been slated for destruction since 1971, and finally, demolition is imminent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTER, RUTH WEINREB BERENDA, PH.D.
description: CARTER-Ruth Weinreb Berenda, Ph.D. On April 28, 2001. Distinguished psychoanalyst and the first woman psychology teacher at City College of New York. She also did psychological diagnostics with delinquent children in the New York Family Court System, and for many years was an Attending Staff Member in psychiatry at St. Luke's Hospital. Obtained her Ph.D. at the Graduate Faculty of the New School for Social Research in New York City. Trained at the William Alanson White Institute. Avid world traveler and art collector, she was a patron of the opera, concert and theater world. She is survived by her husband of 42 years, Charles Carter, a retired travel agent, and by numerous nieces, grandnieces, nephews and grandnephews. title: A Brotherly Feud Over Energy

Just how vexing that problem is became clearer when news leaked out recently that the president's brother, Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, strongly opposes the administration's plan to open up an area off the Florida coast in the Gulf of Mexico to oil and gas exploration. The polls have been telling President Bush that the public favors conservation over development, even when energy supplies are short. His brother is now conveying essentially the same message.

title: Barry Smith, Greenwich, Conn., April 4, 2001
description: his couple bought the property, but they weren't thrilled with the house, so they wanted to tear it down to build a new, bigger house. They said the bedrooms were a little small and there wasn't a lot of closet space. Only in Greenwich does someone buy a house for a million just to smash it. I don't know what these people are thinking. You should have seen the hardwood floors inside! I would have loved to live in that house. The house I own would fit inside it. I've been doing this for about 10 years, a couple times a month in the summertime. It's good because it's work for everybody including me. And after all, it's the homeowner's choice. But sometimes I wonder. If my boss tells me we are taking a house down, I go by and look first. It's got all the landscaping, it's beautiful and it's just going down. You feel a little bit bad about it. But in another way, it's fun, a lot of fun. Ask any kid why."

A lifetime member of the Retired Officers Association and the Reserve Officers Association of the United States, he dedicated himself to serving his Jewish community and was actively involved in supporting the activities of B'nai B'rith, the AntiDefamation League and Beth El Synagogue of East Windsor. What does he look like and where, exactly, is he from? (His author photo, which changes from book to book, is always a blurry shot taken from the back, in which he is walking away from the camera, or staring out a window or down at a book.) And why are the wildly tongue-in-cheek, neo-gothic stories he spins about the miserable lives of the terrorized but resourceful Baudelaire orphans -- 14-year-old Violet, who is a whiz at inventing things; her bookwormish brother, Klaus; and baby Sunny -- always dedicated to the late but still longed-for Beatrice? Mr. Casey was a graduate of Columbia University, Class of 1937, and the Columbia University School of Law, Class of 1940. He retired as Lt. Commander after serving in the Navy during WWII, including active duty in the Pacific Theater. He was a founding partner of the law firm, Casey, Lane & Mittendorf in NYC. He also served as a director of several corporations and clubs in New York, New Jersey and Rhode Island. A service will be held at St. Brigid's Church, Peapack, NJ, 11 AM, Thursday, May 3rd. title: Sound the Zurnas and Daoulis! It's a Party!
description: When there's a wedding in Macedonia, the neighbors definitely know it. The next town probably knows, too. Played on two piercing double-reed zurnas and two daoulis (two-headed drums), central Macedonian wedding music by the Gevgelis Ensemble needed no amplification to rock Town Hall on Friday night. It opened the second annual Festival of Greek Music and Dance, a three-night series presented by the World Music Institute and Arts, Dance and Music Productions.

title: Let the Stories Go
description: When Margaret Mitchell published ''Gone With the Wind'' in 1936, the law gave her a copyright for up to 56 years. Under that agreement, the book should have fallen into the public domain in 1993. Why, then, was Mitchell's copyright, now owned by her estate, still powerful enough to prevent the planned publication this month of Alice Randall's ''The Wind Done Gone,'' a retelling of the story of 19th-century Southern plantation life from an African-American viewpoint?

title: European and Mediterranean Cruises
description: Seabourn Cruise Line is eager to get passengers aboard its fleet of five smaller, yacht-like vessels that cruise European and Mediterranean waters, and to do so, it is offering free round-trip air fare from major North American cities on 59 cruises through Nov. 3. The cruises are 6 to 14 days long, and the ships range from the Seabourn Goddess I and II, which each have 58 double cabins, to the Seabourn Pride, Spirit and Legend, with 104 double cabins on board each. The air-fare offer is based on availability. Information: (800) 929-9391 or www.seabourn.com .

title: Mortality on the Mind, A Legacy on the Agenda; Father G. Is Out to Preserve Rebuilt Bronx
description: From his office window in the Hunts Point/Longwood neighborhood of the South Bronx, the Rev. Louis R. Gigante can see St. Athanasius Roman Catholic Church, where he started as a parish priest nearly four decades ago. Radiating from it are dozens of well-kept apartment buildings, residences for the elderly and private homes, all brought into being or back to life by a nonprofit organization -- a secular parish of sorts -- that he founded in 1968. In the midst of it all is Father Gigante Plaza, a brick expanse edged with lions' heads, which he secured $830,000 in government funds to build.

title: One Awful Night in Thanh Phong
description: Senator Bob Kerrey's hands trembled slightly as he began to read six pages of documents that had just been handed to him. It was late 1998; the papers were nearly 30 years old. On the face of it, they were routine "after action" combat reports of the sort filed by the thousands during the Vietnam War. But Kerrey knew the pages held a personal secret -- of an event so traumatic that he says it once prompted fleeting thoughts of suicide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLASS, MORTON
description: KLASS-Morton. On April 28, 2001, at home. Age 73. Beloved husband of Sheila Solomon for 48 years. Beloved father of Perri, David and Judy. Beloved grandfather of Orlando, Josephine, Anatol, and Gabriel. Professor of Anthropology at Barnard and Columbia for 30 years. In the 1980s he was Director of the Southern Asian Institute at Columbia. His field research was among the East Indians in Trinidad and in West Bengal. Author of ''East Indians in Trinidad,'' (Ansley Award, Columbia University), ''From Field to Factory,'' ''Caste,'' ''Singing with Sai Baba,'' ''Ordered Universes,'' and other books, as well as numerous articles. In recent years his research focused on the anthropology of religion and consciouness. Morton Klass enriched the lives of all he met, and lived his life to the fullest. He was a gifted community theater actor, who was memorable as George in ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf,'' Sir Andrew Aguecheek in ''Twelfth Night,'' and Bogart in ''Play it Again, Sam.'' He was an inspired teacher, a magnificent husband and father, and one of nature's true gentlemen. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the Leonia Players Guild, 130 Grand Ave., Leonia, NJ 07605.

title: Baffert's Path Led Him to Louisville
description: Before this year's big horse, there were lots of little ones -- scrappy quarter horses who belonged to his father rocketing down the straightaways of Arizona bush tracks. Each night, Bob Baffert crouched beneath them and massaged their legs with rubbing alcohol. He was 12 and wondered how in the world he would ever find his way to the big races with horses that belonged to well-heeled owners.
